Social Service Territory and the University

Author: Bini, Laura11 U Florence, Italy

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61419681?accountid=14925

Abstract: Although - or because - social work education in Italy has for some 15 years now been exclusively in the domain of the university the relationship between the academic world and that of practice has been highly tenuous. Research is indeed being conducted by universities, but rarely on issues that are of immediate practice relevance. This means that forms of practice develop and become established habitually which are not checked against rigorous standards of research and that the creation of knowledge at academic level pays scant attention to the practice implications of social changes. This situation has been made even worse by the dwindling resources both in social services and at the level of the universities which means that bureaucratic procedures or imports of specialisations from other disciplines frequently dominate the development of practice instead of a theory-based approach to methodology. This development does not do justice to the actual requirements of Italian society faced with ever increasing post-modern complexity which is reflected also in the nature of social problems because it implies a continuation of a faith in modernity with its idea of technical, clear-cut solutions while social relations have decidedly moved beyond that belief. This discrepancy puts even greater strain on the personnel of welfare agencies and does ultimately not satisfy the ever increasing demands for quality and accountability of services on the part of users and the general public. Social workers badly lack fundamental theoretical reference points which could guide them in their difficult work to arrive at autonomous, situation-specific methodological answers not based on procedures but on analytical knowledge. Adapted from the source document.

Neighbourhoods Mobilise the Troops -- Community Organising, Violence and Governmentality

Author: Stovesand, Sabine11 Hamburg University of Applied Sciences, Germany

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61419702?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article reflects on the difficult relation between community work against domestic violence and local crime prevention under the conditions of the neoliberal state that cuts down on social benefits and promotes self-help, active citizenship and self-responsibility instead while at the same time restoring the punishing state with its strict regime of law-and-order. The author describes a project Tarantula - she started herself while being a social worker in Hamburg, Germany. Tarantula was aimed at strengthening social networks and the neighbours' willingness to get involved in favour of affected women. Although conceptualized as an emancipatory approach referring to community organizing in the tradition of social movements it is questionable whether and how this can really work in the current situation. At present, the field of crime control is being reconfigured as a result of political and administrative decisions, which, for their part, are based on a new structure of social relations and cultural attitudes. The demolition of the 'welfare state' means the re-coding of the security policy that facilitates the development of interventionist techniques that govern and control individuals through their own ability to act. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Students' Use of Knowledge in Direct Practice -- Reasons, Strategies and Effects

Author: Blom, Bjorn1; Nygren, Lennart; Nyman, Cia; Scheid, Carina1 Umea U, Sweden

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61397519?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article describes a study of Swedish social work students' use of knowledge during their field practice. Data was collected by using short written narratives, where the students reflect on situations from practice, situations they experienced as critical or problematic. The narratives were analysed with a method inspired by the interpretation theory of Paul Ricoeur. The article starts with a discussion adhering to the present trend of evidence-based social work practice. This is followed by a study of 144 narratives from social work students containing critical or problematic events. A quantitative description of the material as well as qualitative model of two type-strategies, that social work students use, is presented. The results show, among other things, that students use several forms of knowledge, where facts/evidence is one of several. The study also shows that there is a strong adaptation to varying critical situations. A conclusion is that it is difficult to a priori define the types and proportions of knowledge to use in social work practice. Adapted from the source document.

Theory and Practice: A Matter of Words. Language, Knowledge and Professional Community in Social Work

Author: Fargion, Silvia11 U Trento, Italy

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61423259?accountid=14925

Abstract: The relation between theory and practice in social work has always been controversial. Recently, many have underlined how language is crucial in order to capture how knowledge is used in practice. This article introduces a language perspective to the issue, rooted in the 'strong programme' in the sociology of knowledge and in Wittgenstein's late work. According to this perspective, the meaning of categories and concepts corresponds to the use that concrete actors make of them as a result of on-going negotiation processes in specific contexts. Meanings may vary dramatically across social groups moved by different interests and holding different cultures. Accordingly, we may reformulate the issue of theory and practice in terms of the connections between different language games and power relationship between segments of the professional community. In this view, the point is anyway to look at how theoretical language relates to practitioners' broader frames, and how it is transformed while providing words for making sense of experience. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Theory+and+Practice%3A+A+Matter+of+Words.+Language%2C+Knowledge+and+Professional+Community+in+Social+Work&amp;author=Fargion%2C+Silvia&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=5&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2007-01-01&amp;spage=&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Contingencies for Intercultural Dialogue in Virtual Space: An Empirical Research on the Role of Internet in Fostering Intercultural Competences from the Perspective of Migrant Youth

Author: Wang, Yafang

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61407000?accountid=14925

Abstract: Against the background of the emerging multicultural migration society, acquisition of intercultural competences is getting vitally important for youngsters to actively and effectively engage with intercultural dialogue in a co-existent life context. Contingencies for such intercultural dialogue and to foster intercultural competences of youngsters are opened in virtual space when youth with different ethnic, social and cultural background go online. However, differences in Internet use and competences acquisition as 'digital inequality' also exist among youth with different socio-cultural background. This article reports on a quantitative survey of 300 Turkish migrant youth in Germany as empirical sample about how Internet use generally fosters their intercultural competences, what differences exist among them and which indicators can explain the differences. Preliminary findings show that the contingencies of Internet in fostering intercultural competences are still not much employed and realised by Turkish migrant youth. Four online groups connected with bonding, bridging, both (bonding and bridging) and none socio-cultural networks are found out based on the cluster analysis with SPSS. These different networks, from the perspective of social cultural capital, can explain the differences concerning development of intercultural competences among them. It is indicated in this research that many Turkish migrant youth still lack recognition and capabilities to construct their intercultural social networks or relations through using Internet and further to employ the relations as intercultural social capital or social support in their life context. This therefore poses a critical implication for youth work to help migrant youth construct and reconstruct their socio-cultural networks through using Internet so as to extend social support for competences acquisition. Adapted from the source document.

Quality Management and Formalization in Social Service Organizations -- A Survey on Home-Based Family Intervention Services

Author: Beckmann, Christof1; Otto, Hans-Uwe; Schaarschuch, Andreas; Schrodter, Mark1 U Wuppertal, Germany

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61410905?accountid=14925

Abstract: Although the effects of quality management on social work are still widely unexplored, critics suspect that it will lead to a negative standardization of working conditions, whereas supporters of quality management hope for a greater transparency and effectiveness of service delivery. This article reports on a survey of 30 managers, 261 professionals, and 435 families in 30 family intervention service organizations. It uses cluster analysis to explore the relationship between quality management and different forms of work formalization. Results showed that working conditions generally are enabling for professional practice, but differences exist between what is called here a managerialist machine bureaucracy, an atomistic professional organization, and a collegiate professional organization. Adapted from the source document.

Exploring the Unexplored: Dalit Wordview in Development Discourse

Author: Waghmore, Suryakant11 Centre for Social Justice and Governance, School of Social Work, Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61423886?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article sets a stage for an interface between the process of political struggle vis-a-vis empowerment of Dalits and the deconstruction of development drive amongst the post-modernists in the development debate. It specifically aims at discussing the socioeconomic and political deprivation/development of Dalits historically. As a response to the post-development celebration of local culture, this article exposes the dominant local culture in India as a site of oppression leading to development exclusion of Dalits. It explores the specific political context of Dalit exclusion and locates modernity', both in the colonial and post-colonial period as a necessary socio-political condition facilitating change. Adapted from the source document.

India's New Caste War: The Archaeology of a Perpetual Conflict

Author: Mohan, Brij11 School of Social Work, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, USA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61422583?accountid=14925

Abstract: Caste as a system of stratified inequality has globally survived in different forms since times immemorial. Its functionality on the subcontinent, however, is sustained by a mythologised social reality that runs contrary to the ideals of a secular democracy. This article seeks to theorise caste as a conceptual anomaly and a source of perennial strife-ascribed status, discontent and conflict-that pervade a civilisational crisis at the crossroads of progress. State, Market and Development of Dalits

Author: Teltumbde, Anand11 Petronet India Ltd., Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61418970?accountid=14925

Abstract: Neo-liberal reforms have disoriented the developmental discourse around the State versus the market Dalits, as resource-poor people, have always relied on the resources of the State for their development. It was the State during colonial times that catalysed the emergence of the Dalit movement and associated development that created an impression among them about the neutrality of the State vis-a-vis their struggle for social justice. The neo-liberal paradigm tends to blame the persistent lack of development of Dalits to the State and promises to open up flood gates of opportunity for them. It was reinforced by the argument that globalisation, much like colonisation, would weaken the castes. Much of the resultant confusion, as the article argues, is due to the dichotomous conception of both the State as well as the market. While welfarism is not an essential feature of the State, as reflected by the statist position of Dalits, markets are incapable of channelling resources to them. Markets that necessitate the State in its primal coercive form can never benefit Dalits. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=State%2C+Market+and+Development+of+Dalits&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2007-01-01&amp;volume=68&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=34&amp;author=Teltumbde%2C+Anand

Development of the Dalits: Some Observations

Author: Jogdand, P G11 Department of Sociology, University of Mumbai, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61407749?accountid=14925

Abstract: Development has acquired different meanings with the change in emphasis from economic growth to the development of the capacities of people. It is evident that socioeconomic development is explained in terms of an overall change, including social progress, economic growth, and change in perception and attitude of the people. In the case of Dalits, development is to be understood in terms of bringing them out of their degraded social status, acute poverty and exploitation. Undeniably, the reservation policy and other policies and programmes initiated by the Indian Government have helped the Dalits in getting access to different jobs in the public sector undertakings, educational institutions, and the political arena. However, much remains to be done. In a changing situation, emphasis should be given for entrepreneurship to take up self-employment in all sectors of the economy through training, education and provision of financial and other facilities. Adapted from the source document.

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61425705?accountid=14925

Combating Alzheimer's Disease: Immediate Concerns and Implications for Social Workers

Author: Sinha, Debotosh1; Dey, Namita1 Department of Social Work, Viswa Bharati University, Sriniketan

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61378827?accountid=14925

Abstract: Dementia is a common pathology in late life and a term used to describe a number of physical disorders of the brain arising from different causes. Dementia is usually progressive, irreversible and ultimately fatal. Alzheimer's disease is the most common type of dementia, accounting for approximately 50 per cent of all cases. Of the 18 million people currently in the world with Alzheimer's, about 66 per cent live in developing countries. As the population grows and people live longer, these numbers will increase manifold by the year 2050. Lack of awareness about Alzheimer's disease and lack of knowledge on how to care for such patients leads to inappropriate care-giving. This article makes an attempt to see what exactly is Alzheimer's disease, its causes, the extent of the problem, diagnosis and prognosis, and treatment. The different stages of the disease, role of the care-givers, and the personal and emotional stress they face will also be dealt with. Discussions on the role of professional social workers are highlighted in the article. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Combating+Alzheimer%27s+Disease%3A+Immediate+Concerns+and+Implications+for+Social+Workers&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2006-10-01&amp;volume=67&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=410&amp;author=Sinha%2C+Debotosh%3BDey%2C+Namita

Poverty and Human Rights: The Role of Social Security and Especially Child Benefit

Author: Townsend, Peter11 Social Policy Dept, London School Economics & Political Science

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61406776?accountid=14925

Abstract: Poverty has been reduced by too little, or not at all, in recent years. A fifth, perhaps a quarter, of the world's population are living in extreme poverty. The measurement of the phenomenon, & especially of annual trends in the rates & severity of poverty, is not acceptably precise, consistent, & generally agreed. Nor is policy being analyzed & justified in precise correlation with such trend reports as have been published. The first Millenium Development Goal- to halve world poverty by 2015 -- has become an unlikely prospect. The reasons lie in the present form of the globalization of the market, together with continuing preference shown to neo-liberal economic & social policies. If poverty is to be systematically reduced, the orthodoxies of definition, measurement, explanation & resolution, which as key elements of the problem necessarily reinforce each other, have to be re-examined & re-formulated quickly. In re-examining approaches to measurement & policy the new human rights instruments, endorsed by a majority & in some cases by an overwhelming majority of governments, must playa vital role. Their potentialities are considerable for the measurement of poverty, deprivation, exclusion & development. But, crucially, they can help to engineer an international, as well as scientific, consensus in the war on poverty. One priority illustration would be a UN Child Investment Fund to finance the universal right of children to social security. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: [Unknown]

Abstract: This article is aimed to outline the features of Macao's social welfare system & identify its welfare model. The analysis shows that the welfare system is characterized by its low social welfare expenditure, mixed economy of welfare, underdevelopment of social rights, restricted impact on social stratification & the dominant role of the political-economic factors in social policy-making. It is argued that Macao's social welfare system has shared most of key features of other East Asian welfare regimes & therefore it can be regarded as a productivist welfare model. Social Withdrawal of Young People in Hong Kong: A Social Exclusion Perspective

Author: Wong, Victor1; Ying, Winnie1 Dept Social Work, Hong Kong Baptist U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61402442?accountid=14925

Abstract: In the light of the social exclusion perspective, this paper discusses the indicators & different forms of social withdrawal experienced by young people in Hong Kong. The study examined the case records of 88 service users aged 13-24, & conducted 4 focus group interviews with a team of social workers involved in outreaching & reengaging the socially excluded users. Youth's personal agency exercised in their reaction to life events & crisis in the form of social withdrawal is arguably a complex social process, which is shaped, amongst other factors, by the hegemonic definition of youth trajectories & transitions to adulthood, & equally important by social exclusion at the institutional, cultural & relational levels. It is argued that both the structural & subjective dimensions of social withdrawal & reengagement work deserve critical examination in order not to further reproduce social inequalities & disadvantages. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

International Recruitment of Social Care Workers and Social Workers: Illustrations from the UK

Author: Evans, Sherrill1; Huxley, Peter; Munroe, Maria1 Social Carework Research Centre, Swansea U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61395063?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper presents the results of a survey of international recruitment of social workers & social care workers into the United Kingdom. The literature on international recruitment, especially in relation to social care workers, is extremely sparse. Reviews conducted by the authors for the UK Department of Health did not find any definitive answer to the question of the numbers at present in the UK workforce, their movement between jobs, & their length of stay in the UK. The present study is based on qualitative interviews with three senior managers, four human resources managers, one employment agency manager, one senior social services inspector & three inspectors & three staff from the voluntary & private sectors. The interviews confirmed some of the major benefits associated with international recruitment: a reduction in vacancy rates; filling gaps in key shortage areas; improved sickness records; & once training has been provided the standards of care have improved. In addition, recruitment from overseas has the effect of creating a more diverse staff mix through the appointment of people with more varied experience & experiences. There may also be cost benefits associated with the reduction in costs of employing agency staff. The challenges involved are: having an ethical recruitment policy; the transferability of qualifications & skill sets, & cultural expectations & differences. Employers need to recognize that higher levels of induction are needed in order to meet the unique local knowledge requirements of an overseas candidate. Generally however, there are very few problems, & employers recruiting from overseas find that any problems that exist diminish with each round of recruitment, that is, as employers learn from their previous mistakes. Nevertheless, international recruitment is only a short term strategy, &, alone, does not solve the fundamental domestic problems that lead to the shortages in the first place. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=International+Recruitment+of+Social+Care+Workers+and+Social+Workers%3A+Illustrations+from+the+UK&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2006-07-01&amp;volume=40&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=93&amp;author=Evans%2C+Sherrill%3BHuxley%2C+Peter%3BMunroe%2C+Maria

Record Keeping in Interdisciplinary Practices

Author: Kulbeth, Susan1; Cheung, Monit1 Graduate Coll Social Work, U Houston

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61418066?accountid=14925

Abstract: Health care services today require an extensive amount of interdisciplinary effort & collaboration. Mutual knowledge among the variety of disciplines that interact within health care is essential in the process of promoting a teamwork concept. This study addresses issues that can arise when professionals from diverse disciplines work together in a health care setting. A systematic analysis of literature regarding documentation efforts necessary for client record management in the care team is focused upon, with special attention given to the role of social workers. Four major gaps in record keeping practices were found & highlight the need for an integrated approach to the design & maintenance of standardized & comprehensive patient records, but such incorporation has not yet been practically defined. The hindrances to record keeping practices define the need for establishing an evaluative component in record keeping. References. Adapted from the source document.

Factors Affecting Family Resiliency: Implications for Social Service Responses to Families in Hong Kong

Author: Y.C., Chan11 Department of Applied Social Sciences, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61419879?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study used the Family Hardiness Index to study the resiliency of families in Hong Kong. Results show that less resilient families are those in the low income group; those with family relationship problems; and those struck by a lot of family problems. Multivariate analysis found that only family income and family relationship problem are significant factors affecting family resiliency. Implications to social service responses are discussed in the light of these findings. Adapted from the source document.

Beyond Private and Public: New Perspectives on Personal and Personalist Social Work

Author: Chatterjee, Arnab11 Centre for Study in Social Sciences, Kolkata, West Bengal, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61408276?accountid=14925

Abstract: The slogan 'Personal is Political' has been deployed by feminist social work as an invitation for all of us to take oppressive private matters for public-political redressal. What is glossed over in this urgency is that the personal has been allowed to coincide with the private! This article argues that the personal is not private and urges us to go beyond private/public binaries. It concludes that the personalist social work reckons better with this corrective to aid feminist social work in the latter's emancipatory journey. Adapted from the source document.

Dimensions of Vulnerability, Agrarian Communities and Social Work Intervention

Author: Kumar, Ajit11 Matru Seva Sangh Institute of Social Work, Nagpur, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61370777?accountid=14925

Abstract: Land, an issue fraught with political implications, is central to the quest for removing rural poverty. This article traces two themes - the evolution of village politics in selected villages in Nagpur District; and charting out a conceptual framework of social work intervention for an agrarian community. This framework for intervention was based on both qualitative and quantitative data. The study reveals that, numerically, there are more poor among the land-owning Kunbi caste than the backward castes. The problems of castes other than the land owning ones and the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes is as yet unacknowledged. Adapted from the source document.

Social Services Workers' and Supervisors' Perceptions of Domestic Violence Training

Author: Payne, Brian K; Carmody, Diane Cyr; Respass, Gina; Hoofnagle, Kara

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716567?accountid=14925

Abstract: The lack of college coursework on family violence has resulted in a need for professional development focusing on the role of social services workers in domestic violence cases. Very little research, however, has considered how workers define their experiences with domestic violence cases as compared to their perceptions of training in this area. To fill this void, focus groups and in-depth telephone interviews were conducted to assess how social workers and supervisors described their experiences with domestic violence cases and their perceptions of the appropriate forms of training. Results show differences between the experiences and perceptions of workers and supervisors. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Social+Services+Workers%27+and+Supervisors%27+Perceptions+of+Domestic+Violence+Training&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2006-01-01&amp;volume=9&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=4&amp;author=Payne%2C+Brian+K%3BCarmody%2C+Diane+Cyr%3BRespass%2C+Gina%3BHoofnagle%2C+Kara

The Children's Bureau Quality Improvement Centers: Knowledge Development Through Research Collaborations in Child Welfare

Author: Hafford, Carol; Brodowski, Melissa Lim; Nolan, Catherine; Denniston, Jack

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716164?accountid=14925

Abstract: With the renewed emphasis on evidence-based practice in child welfare the U.S. Children's Bureau has reinforced its commitment to empirically sound demonstration projects as a means of furthering best practices in this field. One critical thrust in this initiative has been the creation and funding of Quality Improvement Centers (QIC). Through involving intermediary organizations in grant making, managing the required research and disseminating findings, Children's Bureau sought to not only improve child protective practices but make demonstrations specific locality relevant and foster local and regional collaborations that would extend beyond the funding periods. This article summarizes finding from the interim national evaluation of the initial cluster of four QIC's focusing on some of the lessons already learned from this innovation and potentials for this model in future demonstrations. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Doctoral Students and Online Technology

Author: Swiefach, Jay S; Heft-LaPorte, Heidi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716570?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work practice today requires that practitioners be proficient in the use of online technologies. Although social workers can use information technology for such purposes as conduction research, sharing ideas, communicating with colleagues, and publishing work, very little is known about how social workers use these resources, and the extent to which online activities have supplemented and enhanced scholarly and professional capabilities. This article reports the findings of a study which examined the manner in which social work doctoral students use online technology, the patterns of its use, and perceptions regarding benefits and self efficacy. The implications and findings are discussed as well as some strategies to enhance the use of these resources among social work students, faculty and practitioners. Adapted from the source document.

University/Child Welfare Agency Partnerships: Building a Bridge Between the Ivory Tower and the State Office Building

Author: Collins-Camargo, Crystal; Hoffman, Kay

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716170?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article explores the potential for true partnerships between university social work programs and public welfare agencies. This partnership has a deeply moral foundation related to the purpose of social work which is potential symbiotic and nature. Social work education and public child welfare both have a stake in the generation of evidence based practice through collaborative research. A rationale for the development of child welfare agencies as learning laboratories, in which the partnership with universities builds upon but extends beyond Title Iv-E training and education programs, is offered. Aspects of this potential collaboration include field education, professional education of practitioners, informing and conducting applied research, development and testing of theory-grounded practice techniques and practice protocols, maintaining the relevance of social work education, integration of field innovations into the curriculum, engagement in non-voluntary practice, understanding and interpreting public policy decisions, and the use of practitioners as social work educators. The comprehensive exploration of such a partnership offers much to both child welfare and academia. Adapted from the source document.

Meeting the Addiction Education and Training Needs of Rural Master's Level Social Workers

Author: Conley, Timothy B; Schantz, David L; Shea, Sarah; Vaillancourt, Mavis

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716572?accountid=14925

Abstract: A comprehensive statewide survey of Licensed Clinical Social Workers (LCSW's) concerning graduate level and continuing education training needs in addictions finds inadequate preparedness for work with addicted constituents, and high interest in and need for training. Respondents advise that addiction training be infused throughout the MSW curriculum or be separately required. Survey respondents numbered 294 which is 76.9 percent of the entire population of LCSWs serving a large rural state, all of whom were surveyed. Selected for survey because they are experienced providers, the group received education in social work schools across North America. Results from this sample confirm calls by others for increasing social worker's addiction related education. Implications for social work educational environments concerning addictions training and work force development missions are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

An Online Course in Trauma for School Personnel World Wide: Collaboration, Challenges, and Opportunities

Author: Jackson, Helene; Elkins, Jennifer

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716150?accountid=14925

Abstract: In this paper we present an innovative, interactive online course in childhood trauma for school personnel worldwide. We identify and discuss the academic and cultural challenges and opportunities encountered in a university, public and community agency collaboration. The goal of the project was threefold; 1) to educate social workers, teachers, school counselors, and administrators to respond to the needs of students (K-12) whose lives have been disrupted by traumatic events; 2) to create a classroom of geographically and ethnically diverse participants in which a collaborative global community could develop; and 3) to evaluate the academic value of the course as reflected in participants knowledge acquisition, adoption and diffusion, and satisfaction. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Bride, Brian E; Jones, Jenny L

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716172?accountid=14925

Abstract: The purpose of this exploratory study was to examine relationships between symptoms of secondary traumatic stress and child welfare worker's perceptions of the culture of supervision in their organizations. A convenience sample of 307 child protection services workers responded to a web based survey that included measures secondary traumatic stress and supervisory culture and practice. Results suggest that action-oriented (active) rather than emotion-oriented (passive) support from supervisors is most helpful in preventing or reducing secondary traumatic stress among child welfare workers. Further, it is the qualitative aspects of supervision rather that the quantity of supervision that is most important in preventing STS. Adapted from the source document.

Personal and Organizational Correlates of Outcomes in Child Welfare: Implications for Supervision and Continuing Professional Development

Author: Ellett, Alberta; Collins-Camargo, Crystal; Ellett, Chad D

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716216?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article describes the finding from recent research focused on personal and organizations factors related to organizational outcomes in child welfare and discusses the implications of these findings for supervision and continuing professional development of child welfare staff. The results of several recent large-scale studies using quantitative and/or qualitative methods are reviewed as a continuing line of inquiry concerned with child welfare employee retention and organizational outcomes (including selected CFSR variables). The critical role that supervisors play in strengthening organizational culture and personal characteristics of staff (e. g. self-efficacy beliefs) as a means of enhancing organizational outcomes is emphasized and suggestions for future research are provided. Examining the Major Barriers to Employment Among TANF Recipients and the Role of Continuing Education in Preparing the Professional Workforce

Author: Thomas, Rebecca Leela; Fierro, Rita S; Novakowski, Scott

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716153?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper highlights the barriers to employment of TANF recipients. The dual goals of employment and family reunifications demanded clients to comply with the sometimes opposing demands of the service delivery systems. This paper underscores the importance of continuing social work education in informing workforce development efforts. These efforts include; 1) developing practice models of intervention; 2) creating a forum for service providers to network amongst themselves; 3) helping service providers understand and modify the demands placed on clients; and 4) developing monitoring and evaluation mechanisms for social programs. Continuing education programs can provide important training in all these areas. Adapted from the source document.

Making a Mission Statement a Realty in Child Welfare: Resiliency and Solution-Focused Therapy as Core Strategy

Author: Anderson, Kim; Sundet, Paul

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716218?accountid=14925

Abstract: Child welfare agencies regularly espouse a philosophy of 'family-centered' and 'strengths-based' practice but factors including traditional practice, court auspices and deficient technology combine to impede attaining the worthwhile goals contained in the typical mission statement. In a three-year demonstration project designed to promote organizational culture change and increase clinical competencies of workers, this issue was added by adopting a human behavior base of resiliency and care intervention strategy of solution-focused therapy. This article details the implementation of that process and the empirical results on worker attitude and case performance. Adapted from the source document.

From Isolation to Teamwork: Mississippi's Story of Cultural Change in Child Welfare

Author: Shackelford, Kim; Sullivan, Kathleen; Harper, Maxine; Edwards, Tiffany

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716220?accountid=14925

Abstract: Professional isolation is a major impediment to positive morale among public child welfare supervisors in rural settings. In this project in Mississippi supervisors in two regions were provided the opportunity for ongoing peer support by engaging in structured learning laboratories of their own design followed by regular mentoring sessions with university faculty. Using a quasi-experimental design an external evaluation team assessed the perceived changes in organizational culture, supervisee assessment of self-efficacy and worker turnover rates between the experimental and control areas and found significant positive impact from the model employed. The article offer practical suggestions on implementation of organizational change through supervisor development. Adapted from the source document.

Translating Group Learning into Individual Behavioral Change: The Role of Critical Analysis Tools in Professional Growth

Author: Sundet, Paul; Kelly, Michael

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716225?accountid=14925

Abstract: Improving supervisors' ability to teach, supervise and develop clinical skills in front line child welfare workers is critical to improving the quality of services and retention of skilled workers. However, Supervisory development presents a dilemma for the employing agency. Empowering supervisors to develop worker's critical analysis abilities, which are essential to effective case work, will likely involve questioning dearly held assumptions, values, and policies of the organization. This article explores the dilemma of training and development where such an approach is attempted. Should a staff development initiative for child welfare professionals be directed toward learning within agency defined boundaries, i.e. true learning? This article details a three year supervisory development programs designed to empower teaching and application of critical reflective skills in front line workers. Adapted from the source document.

Clinical Supervision in Public Child Welfare: Themes from Findings of a Multisite Study

Author: Collins-Camargo, Crystal

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716234?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article summarizes the themes from findings of a multisite study conducted in four states' child welfare agencies to test the impact of the implementation of clinical casework supervision. The studies were conducted through the work of a ten state collaborative administrated by the Southern Regional Quality Improvement Center on Child Protection and funded by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Overall quantitative and qualitative findings of the intervention's impact on satisfaction with supervision, organizational culture, worker practice in assessment and treatment, and client outcomes are summarized. While the outcomes varied across sites, the overall findings support the potential for clinical supervision approaches to be used in this setting. The utilization of learning collaborations on the site and multisite level was successful in promoting positive findings as well as comprehensive dissemination activities targeted toward impacting practice. In addition, themes regarding the use of a university, public agency, community partnership, and factors impacting the implementation and evaluation of the projects are described. Adapted from the source document.

Toward the Development of a Research-Based Employee Selection Protocol: Implications for Child Welfare Supervision, Administration, and Professional Development

Author: Ellett, Alberta J; Ellett, Chad D; Westbrook, Tonya M; Lerner, Betsy

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716230?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article describes components and procedures for the development of a new research-based child welfare Employee Selection Protocol (ESP). This protocol represents a model that child welfare agencies can use to better select employees with the requisite entry-level knowledge, skills, abilities, and values (KSAVs) that are considered minimally essential for effective job performance. The long-term goals of developing and implementing the new ESP are to: (a) improve the validity, reliability, and job-relatedness of current child welfare employee selection and hiring processes; (b) enhance the standardization of new employee selection who are suited for work in child welfare; (copyright) develop procedures to strengthen application screening of new employee who are suited for work in child welfare; (d) increase child welfare employee retention rates; and ultimately; (e) strengthen services provided to children and families. Implications for employee selection, supervision, and retention are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

A Complex Partnership to Optimize and Stabilize the Public Child Welfare Workforce

Author: Lawson, Hal A; McCarthy, Mary; Briar-Lawson, Katherine; Miraglia, Peter; Strolin, Jessica; Caringi, James

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716238?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article introduces a complex partnership developed in a Northeastern state. Its aim is to optimize and stabilize public child welfare workforce and thereby improve outcomes for clients as well as results for county and borough agencies. To achieve this aim, this partnership has implemented a comprehensive, multi-faceted strategy. Intermediaries play pivotal roles in this partnership system. Originating with a focus on social work education, this partnership quickly focuses on research. Participatory workforce research aimed at understanding turnover led to hybrid, complex intervention involving team-driven participatory action research and learning in local agencies. These design teams, facilitated by social worker, connect professional development and organizational development to retention planning and ultimately, to workforce optimization initiatives. Adapted from the source document.

Lessons Learned from an Innovative University-community Agency Collaboration: The Development of a Direct Practice for Training for Child Welfare and Mental Health Social Workers

Author: Boyd, Suzanne; Morrow, Deana F; Shobe, Marcia A; Tack, Frankie

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322715529?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article reports on the development and implementation of a 6-session child welfare and mental health training series developed in response to identified training needs by a local Department of Youth and Family Services and Department of Mental Health. Capabilities and Education

Author: Otto, Hans-Uwe1; Ziegler, Holger1 Faculty Educational Science, Center Social Service Studies, U Bielefeld, Germany hansuwe.otto@uni-bielefeld.de

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61393021?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues that the "capability approach" that focuses on the individual's ability to exercise agency has the potential to offer a more comprehensive idea of a "pedagogy of inclusion" within education. The capability approach's capacity to deliver "just education" in light of increased social heterogeneity & inequality is assessed. Special attention is given to distinctions between "O-capabilities" & "S-capabilities" as complementary parts of a person's "capability set" & the tendency of the capability approach to blur this distinction in favor of a relationally combined perspective. It is maintained that the capability approach emphasizes personal, social, economic, cultural, & institutional factors that allow individuals to do & to be what is needed for their fulfillment. The definition of freedom that is at the heart of the capability approach is examined, along with what "just education" should encompass; & the provision of democratic "capability inputs" in the field of education. It is concluded that education not only incorporates basic capabilities but also promotes & expands higher, more complex capabilities. Figures, References. J. Lindroth

Czech Republic: Is Social Work a Science or Is It Just a Profession?

Author: Chytil, Oldrich11 Zdravotne sociallni fakulta, U Ostrava, Czech Republic oldrich.Chytil@osu.cz

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61365671?accountid=14925

Abstract: A look at whether social work in the Czech Republic is a profession or a science focuses on the importance of education. The review of the history of social work education since the founding of the first school of social work in 1918 highlights post-1935 attempts to develop social work as both an independent profession & scientific discipline; recognition by physicians of the need for social workers in medicine; the 1945 establishment of university education in social work that included research clinics; the near liquidation of social work in the 1950s & early 1960s; political suppression of social workers by the Soviets; & social work research carried out by the Research Institute of Work & Social Affairs in the 1970s & 1980s. Since 1990, social work education has become one of the fastest growing fields in the Czech Republic. Newly created educational programs, including doctoral programs, are described, to conclude that social work in the Czech Republic is now both a profession & a theoretically grounded science. References. J. Lindroth

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Czech+Republic%3A+Is+Social+Work+a+Science+or+Is+It+Just+a+Profession%3F&amp;author=Chytil%2C+Oldrich&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=4&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2006-01-01&amp;spage=&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

What Price Social and Health Care? Commodities, Competition and Consumers

Author: Penna, Sue1; O'Brien, Martin1 Dept Applied Social Science, Lancaster U, UK s.penna@lancaster.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61397119?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines changes, problems, & controversies that affect the organization & funding of health & social care services (HSCS) in member states of the European Union. It is noted that health & social services were excluded from a Framework Directive on Services of General Interest that was adopted by the European Commission in 2004. These services are now the subject of further initiatives. The increased interest in HSCS among member states is explored, along with difficulties stemming from both ambiguities in the economic/legal status of HSCS & the need to reconcile cohesiveness & competitiveness. It is suggested that many of these problems are the result of tensions arising from the contradictory characteristics of the complex networks of cultural, political, & economic spheres of action within which HSCS are situated. Special attention is given to conflicts that arise between the often conflicting goals of expanding markets & stimulating competitive economic development while simultaneously attempting to deliver social rights & secure social solidarity. References. J. Lindroth

Dictionaries as Representations of the State of the Social Professions -- Some Preliminary Observations from an Italian Perspective

Author: Campanini, Annamaria11 Facoltadi Scienze Politiche, U Calabria, Italy annamaria.campanini@libero.it

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61396281?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the status of the social work profession in Italy where it has become a recognized profession but still lacks a clear disciplinary profile, is classified under Sociology, & offers limited opportunities for lecturers to undertake research or develop a theoretical foundation. However, numerous social work publications have appeared since the 1980s, including a "Dictionary of Social Work" that documents the profession's history, code of practice, theory, epistemology, & methodology in Italy. The Dictionary is used to consider the position of Italian social work in relation to the "European Platform for Worldwide Social Work" established in 2002 by the U of Parma in collaboration with 50 European partners, as well as other social work dictionaries published in France, Germany, Scandinavia, & Latin America. Cultural limitations involved in making valid comparisons are discussed, along with difficulties related to clearly defining the meaning of terms used in social work; efforts to develop a multilingual glossary; & the importance of identifying the point of view from which proposed definitions emerge. References. J. Lindroth

Co-Operation between Social Service Providers -- A Comparison between Germany and Greece

Author: Claudius, Petra

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61376905?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of this article is to provide an understanding of the co-operation between social service providers, delivering personal social services for the family as target group, in two municipalities in Germany and Greece. Based on a cross-national comparison between Germany and Greece, patterns of co-operation, and the influence of the socio-political context in terms of the respective legal framework, and the socio-cultural context in terms of the attitudes trust and solidarity will be explored. As methods, both analytical literature research and quantitative instruments, in particular a semi-structured self-completion mail questionnaire, were employed. As the German and Greek case shows, patterns of co-operation between social providers do not exclusively depend on the former stipulation by legal regulations. As in the Greek case, the existence of a wide range of forms and contents does not mean that there are a lot of linkages between the providers, and furthermore, that co-operation is frequent. As the Greek case shows, informal agreements as basis for co-operation implicate voluntary co-operation. Although the latter may be related to motivations of solidarity or contrary self-interest, they indicate stronger involvement in co-operation, and thus more action in terms of linkages and frequency. References. Adapted from the source document.

To Work with Households That Are Facing Eviction -- An Advice Bureau of Housing Rent and Its Outcome

Author: Holmdahl, Johan11 Dept Social Work, Stockholm U, Sweden johan.holmdahl@socarb.su.se

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61365625?accountid=14925

Abstract: A research note describes an evaluation of the effectiveness of a rental housing advice bureau in Solna, Sweden that is intended to help tenants in danger of eviction from losing their place of residence & becoming homeless. The evaluation was carried out within the frame of the Centre of Practical Knowledge established in 2002 through cooperation between the Department of Social Work at the U of Stockholm & eight municipalities in northwest Stockholm. A group of 76 clients who received help from the bureau was compared with a control group of 27 individuals that did not seek assistance. Data were gathered from both a quantitative analysis of information obtained from questionnaires & qualitative interviews with clients, landlords, & advice bureau staff members. The results showed no clear-cut difference in outcomes between those who received support from the advice bureau & those who didn't. However, it was indicated that households that contact the bureau have a good chance of avoiding the acute threat of eviction. The implications are discussed. References. J. Lindroth

Researching the Impact of Partial Labour Migration on a Child: Failure of Attachment Theory

Author: Malinauskas, Gedas11 Dept Social Work, School Social Work, Vytautas Magnus U Rovaniemi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61389763?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of the article is to introduce a research report revealing the peculiarities of children experience when their parents are in the process of partial labour migration. Partial labour migration is a specific form of migration when one or both parents leave to work abroad (for more than 3 months) and the rest of the family stays in Lithuania. In case of departure of both parents, children are looked after by grandparents or other family members (for example, aunt). The article is based on the data of the quantitative survey Trends and Peculiarities of Labour Migration in Kaunas undertaken in all kindergartens of Kaunas city (N=88). Parents who had the experience of working abroad were surveyed using questionnaire. A special focus in the article is on the review of the attachment theory drawbacks. With reference to the attachment theory, a hypothesis was put forward that children under 6 should experience separation difficulties when parting with one of parents for a long time since they loose the object of attachment related to safety. According to the theory, this should especially be revealed in cases when children are fostered by grandparents. The research showed that a quarter of children experienced short-term difficulties, whereas 10% of children were negatively influenced by the departure. The hypothesis that children who stayed with their grandparents experienced more problems was rejected for there was no differences between parents' opinion and that of grandparents found. The question is posed in the article: what theories are needed to define in greater detail the experience of children "in the family brake process" when parents work abroad for a long time. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Welfare Reform, Accumulation and Social Exclusion in the United Kingdom

Author: Grover, Chris11 Dept Applied Social Science, County Coll, Lancaster U, UK c.grover@lancaster.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61390545?accountid=14925

Abstract: Jordan (2000) notes how while there is a possible confluence between social work practice and New Labour's social inclusion agenda, social work has been excluded from it. The explanation for this lays in the narrow definition, focusing almost entirely on exclusion from paid employment that frames political concerns with social exclusion in the UK. However, the policies designed to tackle social exclusion even in this rather narrow approach should be of concern to social work because it is possible that they will exacerbate rather than tackle the exclusion that many social work clients face. To explore these issues this paper draws upon Penna's (2001) argument that there is a tension between the desire to tackle social exclusion at a national level and global economic governance that constructs neo-liberalism as being the only way forward to economic prosperity and stability because the operation of neo-liberal political economy creates social exclusion. The paper examines these tensions by focusing upon what Adler (2004) identifies as a new model - the employment model - for the relief of poverty in the UK. The paper discusses the antecedents of the employment model in the shift from Keynesianism to neo-liberalism. The paper demonstrates that the employment model is concerned with regulating a number dilemmas related to labour power and the wage relation that have emerged from the acceptance of the global neo-liberal economy as being the only viable economic paradigm. It then goes on to discuss the contingent nature of this process, highlighting the contradictions raised by the employment models in terms of economic development and the tackling of social exclusion. References. Adapted from the source document.

Migration, Urban Poverty and Underclass -- "Working in the Garbage"

Author: Acar, Hakan1; Akar, Seyhun; Akdemir, Gurhan; Aksakalli, Ulas; Alatas, Yilmaz; Engin, Mehmet1 School Social Work, Hacettepe U, Ankara, Turkey hacar@hacettepe.edu.tr

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61387306?accountid=14925

Abstract: With its socio-cultural and economic indicators and its location, Turkey has a contradictory social structure. At one hand, Turkey is one of the leading economies in the world. IMF (International Monetary Fund) informed that Turkey was the 21st biggest economy in 2004. It also indicated that Turkey would be the 17th biggest economy in 2006. It means Turkey will have a bigger economic power than Taiwan, Belgium or Switzerland. In contrast to its economic growth, governments of Turkey still fight for eliminating and reducing deep poverty rates. The State Statistic Institute (2004) stated that the number of poor people in Turkey has reached to 20 million in 2003. 23% of families and 37.8% of pre-school children live under poverty line. People need to find new strategies to cope and manage their lives. In this manner garbage collecting can be considered as a new employment field for the new urban poor in Turkey. Today, thousands of people and their families in Turkey have been involved in garbage collecting process as low-paid workers. This research aims to present one of the proofs of urban poverty and lack of social regulations towards the new urban poor. This study is a describing field research regarding the workers who work in city garbage in Ankara, Turkey. Research was conducted with 51 workers in 2003. Data were gathered by using a questionnaire prepared by the researchers. Researchers have used field observations and interviews as a secondary data gathering method in order to provide a rich presentation of results. At the end of the work, it is revealed that a majority of the workers in Mamak Garbage are adolescent and younger adults and have extremely low educational level. Significant numbers of the workers have immigrated to Ankara within the last 6 months from rural areas of the hinterland of Ankara. It is understood that these workers have been engaged in marginal jobs before. The garbage workers show typical characteristics that apply to members of the underclass. They have been living in poor conditions, generally employed in junk jobs for short-term periods and they continue to have little chance to develop their conditions. This can be characterized as typical poverty cycle. The workers have to work in difficult conditions such as long working hours and lower wages without social insurance. References. Adapted from the source document.

Robin Huws Jones C.B. E., UK, President of IASSW, 1976-1980

Author: Kendall, Katherine A

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61397158?accountid=14925

Abstract: Robin Huws Jones, President of the International Association of Schools of Social Work from 1976 to 1980, lived a life of challenge and change. Born in Wales in 1909, he often remarked that learning to speak Welsh at age two was such a challenge that he didn't bother to learn English until he was six. The death of his mother when he was three led to the first of many changes in a life that was not easy in the formative years. Robin remained in the care of his father while his sister became the ward of two aunts. With his father, a draper's assistant, he left Wales to live in a crowded boarding house in Liverpool. Three Decades of Social Work in France: From Security within the Welfare State to a State of "Disembedded Modernity"

Author: Ward, John11 IRTS, IDF Montrouge Neuilly sur Marne, France john.ward@gni.asso.fr

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61387578?accountid=14925

Abstract: An overview of the changing status of social work in France over the last three decades contends that the move from security within the Welfare State to a "state of disembedded modernity" has created uncertainty & controversy over the place of social work in French society. Historical factors & key trends that have contributed to this state of self-doubt include the increasing complexity of the various social work professions; decentralization of the state; & a more politicized definition of social work tasks. The new social work role as an agent of insertion is examined, along with a shift in social work objectives that targets the growing population living in poverty; complications arising from urban development; the diversity of training programs; & the replacement of academic paradigms with action-based knowledge. Consideration is given to the viability of traditional social work in light of these changes & the absence of what Anthony Giddens (1991) referred to as embeddedness. The need for a redefinition of the fundamental aims of social work is emphasized. References. J. Lindroth

Domestic Violence: Local Activities -- International Issue

Author: Bruckner, Margrit11 Department 4: Health & Social Work, U Applied Sciences Frankfurt/Main brueckn@fb4.fh-frankfurt.de

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61378980?accountid=14925

Abstract: Since violence against women in the family has been made public by the international women's movement beginning in the 1970ies in Western States and after 1989 also in Eastern Europe a rapidly growing number of institutions and networks emerged. There exists a growing number of networks on the level of the European Union, which supports the anti violence work and research on this topic. About 30 years of research mainly in Western post-industrial societies show that in the analysis of violence towards women it is important to differentiate between culturally induced individual (or group) oppression by men and the way this is made possible by societal structures based on gender inequality. Therefore hierarchical family relations and personal behavior of men are one aspect to look at, the structural societal set-up the other. The extent of gender-specific violence can be interpreted as an extreme consequence of the hierarchical construction of gender relations, which seem to justify a personal and sexual subjugation of women and in the extreme even violence towards women. Without this structural component individual violence would not all together fade away, but would lose its societal and cultural back-up. Cross-cultural studies show the interconnection between a comparatively equal gender structure and little gender and generation violence and vice versa. The complexity of gender violence makes a theoretical position necessary which analyzes individual aggression (mostly male) and individual suffering from violence (mostly female) - often over many years - on the background of structural and cultural conditions including the multifaceted connections and breaks between these backgrounds and personal social practices. References. Adapted from the source document.

Constellations of Disadvantage and Policy Dilemmas in Youth Transitions from School to Work in Bulgaria

Author: Kovacheva, Siyka11 Dept Social Science, Faculty Business & Social Science, U Plovdiv, Bulgaria

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61408053?accountid=14925

Abstract: An exploration of problems in youth transition from education to employment & social participation in Bulgaria draws on the results of a 2004 Thematic Study that obtained information from the Bulgarian National Statistical Institute, Eurostat, government documents, research reports, & expert consultations. Economic, social, & cultural barriers facing Bulgarian youth seeking sustainable employment include deficiencies in vocational training; gender & ethnic inequalities; rural/urban differences, segmentation of the formal labor market; & a high unemployment rate for young people. Attention is called to the growing number of young people of "undefined status" who are not part of the regular education system, do not have job, & are not registered in labor offices as unemployed. The insecurity of temporary & part-time jobs is examined. Various policy approaches intended to support disadvantaged youth are reviewed & evaluated. Emphasis is placed on the need to both develop programs to prevent young people from dropping out of school & to establish an efficient training & counseling system. Tables, References. J. Lindroth

Evidence Focused Social Care: On Target or Off-Side?

Author: Dore, Ian J11 School Social Work & Social Care, U Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, UK ianjdore@yahoo.co.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61407333?accountid=14925

Abstract: As contentions continue to engulf the evidence-based practice (EBP) debate within social care, consensus seems to be gravitating towards the softer term of 'evidence-aware' practice, although there is as yet no definitive concept on the horizon. Set against a back-drop of competing ideologies, heavily influenced by the natural sciences, what is at stake is the essence of social work: there is a real danger that social work practice be reduced to mere base elements, which seek to eliminate all notions of uncertainly, so essential and endemic to our social world; a characteristic of our very being. Underlying the surface arguments that an evidence-focused approach can realise better practice, are questions of power and control. In exploring the current position of EBP within UK social care, this paper argues that as an interpersonal profession, operating within the complexities of the social world, social work would be better suited to pursue an inclusive 'knowledge-aware' approach to practice, which may allow the profession to move beyond the restrictive and limiting polemics that surround it. Deliverance of a deserving future will require a brave and frank acceptance of our own fallibility, together with an openness which allows the profession to harness its key values. References. Adapted from the source document.

Useful Knowledge for Social Work Practice

Author: Cha, Theresa1; Kuo, Elizabeth; Marsh, Jeanne C1 School Social Service Administration, U Chicago, IL

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61376977?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social workers have a long-standing interest in the relation of knowledge and practice. Both the tasks of practice and the knowledge used to accomplish these tasks are defining characteristics of any profession. They are the basis by which professions differentiate themselves from one another and the means by which they legitimate their activities to the larger society and culture. Theorists and researchers of knowledge utilization have identified it as having both conceptual and instrumental aspects. To better understand knowledge utilization in the field of social work, a group of social work practitioners were asked to reflect on the utility of various types of formal information and knowledge and sources of that knowledge. Practitioner respondents expressed appreciation for theoretical knowledge, but gave highest utility ratings to knowledge that helps them solve problems they confront every day in practice, i.e., information about a social problem or information about the effectiveness of a particular social work intervention. Younger practitioners were more enthusiastic than older practitioners about the utility of formal knowledge. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Introduction: The Quest for Knowledge in Social Sciences

Author: Jayaram, N11 Centre Research Methodology, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61362905?accountid=14925

Abstract: In this introduction to the special issue on "Social Research Methods: Persistent Issues & Emergent Trends" the guest editor establishes the context theme of the journal as the quest for a knowledge about self & the circumstances in which one lives as the mother of all myths & doctrines, philosophies & sciences, including social sciences. The relatively recent emergence of humans quest for social science knowledge is contrasted with previous commonsensical knowledge handed down from generation to generation that, also taken for granted as knowledge, is frequently inconsistent & contradictory. The aspects of ontology, as the symbology, methodology, & methods are briefly define & related to subsequent articles that address issues about the debate on methodological perspectives, the distinction between quantitative & qualitative methodologies, & ethnography & fieldwork, & the relationship between research, social empowerment, & the ethical quandary. Although the 12 following essays cover a wide range of topics, know where the gaps remain and will hopefully be presented in subsequent issues. References. J. Harwell

Methodology of Social Sciences: Postivism, Anti-Postivism, and the Phenomenological Mediation

Author: Tharakan, Koshy11 Dept Philosophy, Goa U, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61400542?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article discusses the two dominant modes of social scientific enquiry by bringing out the philosophical underpinnings of positivism & its antithesis as exemplified by the interpretative school. Traversing the philosophical trajectory, it provides an account of the methodological discourse encompassing (a) the 'unity of method' cast in the positivist mould, (b) the methodological dualism advocated by the verstehen school, & (c) the new thesis of unity of method, implied in the hermeneutic mode. It is claimed that phenomenology is capable of effecting mediation between the two rival modes of social scientific enquiry by integrating the different goals of social sciences, such as explanation & understanding, by synthesizing the empirical & the interpretative dimensions of the social world. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Methodology+of+Social+Sciences%3A+Postivism%2C+Anti-Postivism%2C+and+the+Phenomenological+Mediation&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2006-01-01&amp;volume=67&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=16&amp;author=Tharakan%2C+Koshy

Constructivism in Social Science Methodology: A Reconsideration

Author: Hegde, Sasheej11 Dept Sociology, U Hyderabad, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61424943?accountid=14925

Abstract: Underlying the resurgence of theory & methods in social science research is the position that has been termed, broadly, 'constructivism.' This article is an attempt to critically engage with this position. Especially, it will be concerned to tackle the epistemological coordinates that attach to this position, while going on to reposition it in the context of debates in the history & philosophy of science & social science. The objective here is not to argue for one or other of the various sides to the methodological debate on constructivism, but to foreground how both critics & advocates can be addressing the question of scientific knowledge & truth in social science methodology. References. Adapted from the source document.

Space and Social Research: Some Methodological Issues

Author: Bhagat, R B11 International Instit Population Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61421223?accountid=14925

Abstract: Of late, there has been a resurgence of space in critical social theory. The post-modernists have been in the forefront to show how the neglect of space in social sciences has paved the way for the precedence of time in social analysis historically. Furthermore, space is also being used to vindicate that theory building is virtually impossible due to variations in the contexts. However, this has not dampened the positivist spirit to seek generalizations; on the contrary, seeking generalizations incorporating space has been undertaken with much rigor. This has been due to the advancements in the statistical techniques in social research. The present paper illustrates this. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Qualitative Research Methodology: Epistemological Foundation and Research Procedures

Author: Nakkeeran, N11 Centre Research Methodology, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61397414?accountid=14925

Abstract: As a method of social enquiry, qualitative research developed from the post-Cartesian intervention by Immanuel Kant. It is founded on the premises that the boundaries between the observed & the observer, & among reality, enquiry & representation are not unambiguous or unproblematic. It aims to discover new meanings & concepts rather than establishing causal relationships between narrowly defined variables. It proceeds with no a priori explicit conceptualization; its study design is flexible & open. Data for qualitative research is usually collected through in-depth methods, with long face-to-face interaction with subjects in the field. Data collection & analysis proceed concurrently with constant iteration between field, data & theory formation. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Qualitative+Research+Methodology%3A+Epistemological+Foundation+and+Research+Procedures&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2006-01-01&amp;volume=67&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=104&amp;author=Nakkeeran%2C+N

Global-Local Interface in Ethnography

Author: Mathur, Nita11 School Social Sciences, Indira Gandhi National Open U, New Delhi, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61421297?accountid=14925

Abstract: The presentation of cultures & lifestyles of people in ethnographic writing is greatly influenced by the major paradigms in the discipline of sociology & social anthropology. For long, ethnography remained confined to 'holistic descriptions' of cultures & ways of life of people representing 'little tradition' situated in territorially defined settings. Over time, there has been widespread acceptance of heuristic potential of post-modernism as a paradigm & the indelible impact that globalization as a force has on political, economic, & social relations of local cultures. Against this backdrop, sociologists & social anthropologists have had to shift focus from the elements specific to the culture being written about to juxtaposing local elements with global processes. The present essay seeks to trace the trajectory & explore the juxtapositions of the local elements with global processes in ethnographic writings. References. Adapted from the source document.

Continuing Engagement of Fieldwork and the Writing Machine

Author: Arora, Vibha11 Dept Humanities & Social Sciences, Indian Instit Technology, New Delhi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61397324?accountid=14925

Abstract: Fieldwork transforms our identities in the field, in our discipline (sociology/social anthropology), & the discipline itself. My fieldwork has not ceased with my physical exit from Sikkim, as by including archival data, worldwide web representations, audio-visual material, personal papers, & legal case files, my ethnographic engagement is a continuing one. Adopting the idea of 'writing machine' from George Marcus, I argue that ethnographic writing is a decision while fieldwork is not a trope of entry & exit but assumes an ever presence in us. References. Adapted from the source document.

Vicissitudes and Visuals: A Methodological Discourse

Author: Chakrabarti, Dalia11 Jadavpur U, Kolkata, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61404000?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work, both as an academic discipline & as a practice, both in the form of civil society initiative & individual enterprise, can gain enormously by using the visual method. If social work implies efforts to extend benefits in response to the evidence of need, then visuals may provide such evidence, though without any modernist claim of truth. It may generate new knowledge, & even sharp critiques of establishment. The appropriateness of remedial measures to cope with the vicissitudes of various social categories can also be better determined on the basis of images of privation, than politically skewed official statistics. Both images & figures may supplement each other, yielding a set of different but inter-related representations of sufferance & its negotiations. This article makes out a case for the visual method under the broad rubric of qualitative research, reconstructs its life history, & brings out its potentiality. References. Adapted from the source document.

Research As a Process for Social Empowerment: An Anthropologist's Boundary-Transcending Reflections

Author: Menon, Vineetha11 Dept Anthropology, Kannur U, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61406808?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article reflects on the process & product of anthropological research, focusing on issues of power & ethics. In this reflexivity, contextualizing the knowledge generated by a researcher in terms of her biography & her times is important. However, this gives rise to the 'subjectivity-objectivity dilemma.' To highlight how the multiple subjectivities of a researcher could interfere with the knowledge he/she generates & make that knowledge experientially more meaningful & richer, pertinent information from Verrier Elwin's biographical sketches are used. Considering how such knowledge could impact on policy, the article argues that the issue of subjectivity-objectivity resurfaces in action anthropology, a need of the changing times. Ignoring boundaries & paying attention to the processes that structure relations & reproduce structures, an enquiry into the transformative power of human agency could be brought center stage. References. Adapted from the source document.
