Ethical Issues in Social Research

Author: Thakur, Manish Kumar11 Dept Sociology, Goa U, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61390386?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article discusses some of the ethical issues in social research. It presents the key concerns of the ongoing debate on the complexity of interactions between the researcher & the researched. It also examines the relationship between the researcher & his/her peers, the sponsors & the public at large. While reiterating the need for a judicious balance between methodological rigour & ethical propriety, it questions the once-dominant belief that facts about social phenomena exist independently of our ethical subjectivity & that they can be discovered by using appropriate & objective techniques. References. Adapted from the source document.

Understanding and Promoting the Friendships of People with a Dual Diagnosis

Author: Dudley, James R11 Dept Social Work, U North Carolina, Charlotte jrdudley@uncc.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61365826?accountid=14925

Abstract: The friendships & other social supports of people who have a dual diagnosis of developmental disabilities & mental illness are very important to the quality of their lives. Yet, little is known about these friendships. The study reported in this article examined the best friend of 90 people with a dual diagnosis based on personal interviews with them. Questions explored the attributes that these people valued in their best friend, what they did together, & what they wanted to do. Questions also explored how staff members supported or discouraged these friendships. The study compared four general types of best friends. They were other consumers, staff members, relatives, & outsiders. The results suggest that each of these four types of best friends raise different issues & deserve different strategies for friendship-building. Overall, the results suggest that the friendships of people with disabilities deserve considerably more attention in continuing education & staff in-service training efforts. Several ideas are shared in the article for improving our understanding of their friendships. Recommendations are also offered for how continuing education efforts can help in enhancing their existing friendships & developing new ones. The results of the study can also be considered in furthering the friendships of other groups such as older adults, people with AIDS, & people with physical disabilities. 3 Tables, 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Distance Education: The Use of Blackboard Software in Practice Methods Courses Taught Over ITV

Author: Kleinpeter, Christine B1; Glezakos, Agathi; Potts, Marilyn K1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61361567?accountid=14925

Abstract: In this pilot study Blackboards software was introduced to supplement the traditional delivery of course content of a practice methods course taught over interactive television (ITV). Distance education (DE) students participated in a three-year, part-time MSW program taught utilizing 75 percent ITV & 25 percent face-to-face methods. This paper compares the utilization of case vignettes & discussion questions which were presented over the web to both DE & on-campus students. Case vignettes were employed to supplement course content in the areas of social work knowledge, values, & skills. Results indicated that a higher percentage of DE students utilized the web-based vignettes when compared to on-campus students. More research is needed to identify the most effective web-based teaching approaches in social work education, particularly, in practice methods courses. 1 Table, 40 References. Adapted from the source document.

Attitudes of Members in One NASW Chapter about Social Action: A 1972 and 2003 Comparison Study

Author: Dickinson, Janet C11 Dept Social Work McKee, Western Carolina U Cullowhee, NC jdickinson@email.wcu.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61371478?accountid=14925

Abstract: This survey of NASW members in one state of attitudes about social action replicates a 1972 survey. The 1972 & 2003 findings are compared. The 2003 response rate was 42 percent. Many agreed that social reform should be a high priority of the profession. Fewer agreed on tactics of social action. In 2003, respondents had greater agreement with many social action tactics, were more likely to voluntarily participate in social action before, during, & after graduate school, & felt greater obligation to clients & the profession than to their employer. Implications of these findings for continuing education are discussed. 7 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Child and Adolescent Sexual Abuse in Health Facilities

Author: Jaswal, Surinder11 Department of Medical and Psychiatric Social Work, Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61409383?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article reports the findings of an exploratory study conducted in 2001 on the magnitude and patterns of child and adolescent sexual abuse (GSA) reported in a cross-section of public health facilities near Mumbai. It describes the process of identifying GSA in public health facilities, the health seeking behaviour of those reporting to health facilities and the handling and management of GSA by health care providers. The results suggest that reporting of GSA in health facilities is age and sex specific; and is reported only on appearance of severe symptoms related to the abuse due to lack of information as well as feelings of guilt, shame and fear. This is compounded by the attitude and lack of training of health providers on issues related to CSA. Adapted from the source document.

Female Sex Workers and Clients: Contexts, Sexual Behaviour and Implications

Author: Kumar, K Anil11 Unit for Child and Youth Research, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61390066?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article examines the linkages between contexts and sexual behaviour among two high-risk groups: female sex workers and their clients. Using data gathered from 501 female sex workers and 215 clients, the study reveals a high level of sexual demand from clients, and severe economic pressure on the female sex workers. Contrary to the general belief, clients are from both lower and better off socioeconomic categories; the proportion of married clients is considerable; and one-third of the clients are youth aged 15-24 years. About 50 per cent of clients and sex workers have ever experienced symptoms of sexually transmitted diseases. The article discusses the immediate and long-term implications of the observed contexts and sexual behaviour. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Female+Sex+Workers+and+Clients%3A+Contexts%2C+Sexual+Behaviour+and+Implications&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2005-10-01&amp;volume=66&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=512&amp;author=Kumar%2C+K+Anil

Sexuality in Adolescents with Visual Disability

Author: Juvva, Srilatha1; Biswas, Bipasha; Rego, Anita1 Dept Family & Child Welfare, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61390104?accountid=14925

Abstract: Groups such as the 'elderly', the 'widowed', and the 'differently-abled' are often considered to be 'asexual'. Therefore, inadequate attention is paid to understanding sexuality in these groups. This is reflected in limited research, training models and intervention available for such groups. With the guiding principle that 'no one is too disabled to be sexual', an exploratory research was undertaken to capture the understanding, experiences and construction of sexuality in adolescents with visual disability in the city of Mumbai. Using the life history technique and in-depth interviews to collect data, themes were generated to provide an understanding of sexuality. This article discusses the findings of the study in the light of the differing components of sexuality and other factors which influence the adolescent's sexuality as experienced by the researched. Adapted from the source document.

The Complexity of Indigenization of Clinical Social Work Knowledge and Practice

Author: Lee, Mo Yee11 Coll Social Work, Ohio State U, Columbus lee.35@osu.ed

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61375826?accountid=14925

Abstract: Indigenization of clinical social work knowledge & practice is inherently a cultural encounter that entails a complex & evolving process. Neither a universalistic nor a culture-specific position can fully capture the complexity of such a process. The discussion examines clinical social work practice knowledge & its implicit values as originated based on Eurocentric experiences & values. Such knowledge is used to compare with cultural values & practices of viewing, expressing, & resolving problems of living among Chinese populations in Hong Kong in the context of continuity & change. Social workers & educators of the receiving culture would have to reflexively examine the attitude of cultural encapsulation, develop cultural self-knowledge, move beyond dualism, develop contextualized understanding, recognize the complexity of such a process, & develop research & practice models that gear toward these dimensions in their quest for developing culturally appropriate & viable modes of treatment for clients & families. References. Adapted from the source document.

Breaking through Barriers: The Political Actions of Hong Kong Outreach Youth Workers

Author: Ngai, Steven Sek Yum11 Dept Social Work, Chinese U, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61391261?accountid=14925

Abstract: Based on the narratives generated from in-depth interviews with 18 outreach youth workers in Hong Kong, this paper investigates the political actions of these youth workers & shows how they have invented strategies to construct their own style of emancipatory practice. Such strategies include (1) seeking new allies for development of community support networks; (2) establishing a research center for policy advocacy; & (3) organizing with youth for social change. The implications of the findings for realizing the liberating potential of youth work are discussed. References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Network Characteristics and Network Satisfaction of People with Psychiatric Disabilities Living in the Community

Author: Yau, Sania S W1; Leung, Bonnie Y L; Leung, Samuel S M1 New Life Psychiatric Rehabilitation Association, Kowloon, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61391284?accountid=14925

Abstract: Objectives: To understand the social network characteristics & network satisfaction of people with psychiatric disabilities living in the community in Hong Kong. Method: A modified scale was administered to 251 service users attending 5 Community Mental Health Link (LINK) Services measuring the above variables. Findings: The study suggested that people with psychiatric disabilities living in the community have a small social network. Moreover, network satisfaction is related to network size & physical proximity. The results are discussed in terms of their consistency with overseas findings & the implications for social work practice in network building for people with psychiatric disabilities. Conclusion: The results provided an initial understanding of social network characteristics & network satisfaction of service users receiving LINK service, with particular reference to network size & physical proximity. Tables, Appendixes, References. Adapted from the source document.

Don't Jump, Mother Loves You: The Rescue of Social Work from the Suicide of Its Own Research

Author: Epstein, William M11 School Social Work, U Nevada, Las Vegas

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61377951?accountid=14925

Abstract: Instead of trying to improve its very inadequate research by yet another rededication to rationality, social work should take cognizance of its consistent failure across fifty years to produce any scientifically credible social service assessments. The pursuit of rationality in social work obscures its political acquiescence, a fable of the Arctic midgerby. The corrective myths of its research stunt the professional coming of age of social work & may well lead to its demise. Rather than social science, social criticism is more consistent with the field's traditions, inclinations, & capacities. References. Adapted from the source document.

Grazing Land to Dalits in Madhya Pradesh: Social Opportunity and Political Cost

Author: Choudhary, S N11 Dept Sociology & Social Work, Barkatullah U, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61373388?accountid=14925

Abstract: Distribution of grazing land among the poor & dependent dalits, along with the right of ownership & one time material support, can lead to the empowerment of rural dalits in the country. At the same time, such an effort may contribute to social turmoil & displacement of the existing political system at the state level with the support of other forces. This article addresses some pertinent questions like the interface between land reform & dalits, the Bhopal Declaration, distribution of grazing land & social reaction, experience of dalit beneficiaries about the gains & pains of land distribution &, finally, displacement of the Congress-led provincial government. Quality of Life and Life Satisfaction: Perspective of Institutionalised Elderly Women and Men in Turkey

Author: Gonen, Emine1; Ozmete, Emine1 Dept Family & Consumer Sciences, Coll Home Economics, Ankara U, Turkey

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374105?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article evaluates the quality of life, life satisfaction, & the relationship between the quality of life & life satisfaction of institutionalised elderly women & men. The study covered a total of 132 elderly, consisting of 64 women & 68 men between the ages of 60-98 years, with sound mental health staying at three care & rehabilitation centres affiliated to National Social Services & Child Protection Institution in Ankara. The quality of life & life satisfaction of the elderly were assessed with scales, including Likert type sentences. Life quality perception of men in terms of physical health is more positive compared to women. Life quality perception of women in terms of physical & social environment is more positive compared to men. In general, women have better life satisfaction than men. A meaningful relationship has been determined between the quality of life & life satisfaction of the elderly. Comprehension of life quality & life satisfaction in old age & determination of the relation between quality of life & life satisfaction will contribute to the development of applicable long-term service programmes required for the improvement of the life conditions of the elderly women & men. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Packiaraj, John

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374149?accountid=14925

Abstract: HIV is an unprecedented epidemic & a public health emergency. In many resource poor countries & among marginalised groups of people, the number of new infections is on the rise. Injecting Drug Users (IDUs) have now become a significant risk group for the HIV infection & play a major role in its transmission. Harm reduction is the need of the hour. Although IDUs are a hard to reach population, social casework intervention yields good results. Networking with people & institutions is the need of the time. Scripting Survival, Irony and Vulnerability: Reflections on Civil Society Responses to the Mumbai Floods

Author: Nagaraj, Vijay K11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India vijay@tiss.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61348087?accountid=14925

Abstract: Personal experiences before, during, & after the floods in Mumbai (Maharashtra), India, are drawn on to analyze the role of the state & nonstate actors in recovery efforts following such natural disasters. The notion that the Mumbai floods were a "humanitarian crisis" is deemed "absurdly reductionist," arguing that "the suffering was natural, but the disaster entirely man-made." Blame is placed squarely on the multilevel failures of the city's public & civic agencies that were supposed to be responsible for health & development, not on their failure to perform, but on their inability to protect lives & property, failures that led both directly & indirectely to mass human rights violations. The activities of various nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) in disaster relief are described, noting their inability or unwillingness to address the issue of shelter. The role of the author's affiliation -- the Tata Instit of Social Sciences (TISS) -- in coordinating the services of local NGOs & community organizations, the government, & the media in relief efforts is described. It is argued that the involvement of organizations such as TISS requires a critical understanding of the socioeconomic & political contexts of contemporary disasters. K. Hyatt Stewart

Attitude towards Corruption: Causal Model and Path Analysis

Author: Sengupta, P B11 Dept Post-Graduate Studies & Research Sociology & Social Work, Rani Durgawati U, Jabalpur, Madhya Pradesh, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61391036?accountid=14925

Abstract: Corruption is a complex social problem & is present in both developed & developing countries. What is the cause of corrupt practices in some of the government offices in our country? Is it an indifferent office environment with some personnel having a corrupt disposition & who induce others? Or is the office environment itself charged with 'corruption-potential' that whoever enters that establishment picks up the habit in due course? It is difficult to probe into the causes & this study is an attempt to scratch at the surface of the hard-to-crack social problem. A difficult topic to research, due to its very nature, the small sample structure of this study is a drawback. The article does not make any tall claims; rather, the comments are open for revision. 18 Tables, 1 Figure, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Determinants of the Caregiver's Appraisal in the Context of Caregiving

Author: Banu, Nasreen1; Mayuri, K1 Dept Human Development & Family Studies, Coll Home Science, ANGR Agricultural U, Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61369312?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article seeks to examine the factors affecting the caregiver's appraisal of caring for a mentally ill relative. Two hundred & ten caregivers attending to a family member with chronic mental illness were interviewed for the present study. The results of path analysis indicate burden experienced in the context of caregiving, patient's illness characteristics, & kinship support to be the most significant factors contributing to the caregiver's appraisal of the caregiving experience. Implications of the findings were summarized. 3 Figures, 1 Chart, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Empowerment-Based Social Work Practice: Issues and Challenges

Author: Hossen, Mohammad Abul11 Faculty Social Work, Wilfrid Laurier U, Waterloo

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374131?accountid=14925

Abstract: All social work activity is concerned with social problems, that is, with alleviating, eliminating, or preventing social problems & the deleterious effects they have on people. It works with the people, organizations & groups who are marginalised, depressed, disadvantaged, powerless & voiceless. Its mission is to change society from one that creates & perpetuates poverty, inequality, & humiliation to one more consistent with social work's fundamental values of humanism & egalitarianism. In order to provide meaningful support to the client, social workers need to empower them. It is often argued that the key to rectifying common people's situation is the empowerment of those who are excluded from the development process & then to build political, economic & social structures which are more participatory & inclusive in nature. But this task is not easy as multiple factors & challenges are involved with this process. This article tries to discuss the various issues & strategies relating to empowerment process. The findings of the article confess that in order to develop social work as a competent profession, empowerment is not only needed for the client, but it is equally needed for the social work professionals themselves. 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Empowerment-Based+Social+Work+Practice%3A+Issues+and+Challenges&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2005-04-01&amp;volume=66&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=196&amp;author=Hossen%2C+Mohammad+Abul

Corporate Social Responsibility in the Globalised Business Environment

Author: Pradhan, Pitabas1; Parida, Subhas C; Rath, Babani P1 Dept Journalism & Mass Communication, Aligarh Muslim U, Uttar Pradesh, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61364678?accountid=14925

Abstract: The notion held by many corporate executives in the earlier decades of the twentieth century that 'the business of business is business' has changed substantially. They have realized that earning more & more profit alone is not sufficient for business survival -- they have some responsibility towards society & the communities in which they operate. As such, corporate social responsibility is viewed not as an expense but as an investment that results in long-term profit. For an organization, the community it operates in is very important as it supplies a major part of the organization's work force, raw materials, & provides an environment to prosper or perish. Community relations programmes are an outcome of the realization that organizations cannot survive in an island of affluence surrounded by a community, deprived of the minimum facilities of civilized life. There are a variety of ways in which an organization can involve itself in community relations & in bettering community life. This article explores the different dimensions of community relations practice by taking NALCO as a case study. 7 Tables, 1 Figure, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Socioeconomic Status of Scavengers Engaged in the Practice of Manual Scavenging in Maharashtra

Author: Beck, H1; Darokar, Shaileshkumar1 Dept Urban & Rural Community Development, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61391209?accountid=14925

Abstract: The socioeconomic status of people who practice manual scavenging in Maharashtra, India, is studied to develop policy programs for enhancing the socioeconomic status of such individuals. After providing an overview of legislation designed to curtail manual scavenging, the methodology used to ascertain the number of manual scavenging households in Maharashtra is detailed. Several findings are reported including the number of scavenging households, the various scavenging activities performed by individuals, the income generated by scavenging activities, & the caste identification of scavengers. Sundry recommendations for reducing manual scavenging throughout the region are highlighted including initiating programs for liberating & rehabilitating manual scavengers, utilizing improved construction techniques in the design of dry latrines, using suction technology to sanitarily remove excrement from dry latrines, extending the government's provision of benefits to Muslim manual scavengers, & prioritizing the educational & occupational needs of scavengers' children. It is concluded that the state has failed to monitor extant scavenging legislation & that improved enforcement is necessary to enhance scavenging households' quality of life. J. W. Parker

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Socioeconomic+Status+of+Scavengers+Engaged+in+the+Practice+of+Manual+Scavenging+in+Maharashtra&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2005-04-01&amp;volume=66&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=223&amp;author=Beck%2C+H%3BDarokar%2C+Shaileshkumar

Learning 'at Work' during Social Work Education: An Example of Practice Learning Opportunities from Sweden

Author: Bolin, Anette11 Dept Social Work & Behavioural Studies, U West, Trollhattan, Sweden Anette.bolin@hv.se

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61383826?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of this article is to describe & analyse the learning processes of Swedish social work students during & after periods of workplace-based learning. The article describes the process in which the practice learning opportunities that the students have been involved in are reflected upon, discussed, problematised & theorised, both in a series of workshops & via the process of the narrative description of critical incidents. Practice learning opportunities form an integral part of studies of social work in the Social Pedagogy program at the University West in Sweden, where a reflective approach to both campus & practice learning has been developed. In presenting the analysis of the reflective approach to studies of social work the article draws on both Scandinavian & international research & presents Saljo's theory of situated learning & Nielsen & Kvale's theory of Mesterlaerer in the analysis of the critical incident narratives of two individual social work students. References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Griffiths, Liz1; Sayer, Lynn; Ryan, May; Shia, Nessie; Fisher, Rick1 Department of Health and Social Care, Brunel University, Mary Seacole Building, Uxbridge UB8 3PH Elizabeth.griffiths@brunel.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61353463?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper sets out to explore the implementation of Personal Development Planning both in university and professional practice settings for community health nurses, as an action research project. This was achieved through a series of cycles of implementation, review and modification using a collaborative approach. The introduction of this process into the course design has enabled all those involved to record student progress in an effective manner. Our findings show that community health students and their assessors in practice have found the experience a very positive one and as a result some "tips for best practice" have been developed that will help take the process further. Back to School for Social Work Students: Developing Quality Practice Learning Opportunities in Schools

Author: Wilson, Lynne1; Hillison, Karen1 Hull School Health & Social Care, U Lincoln

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61391685?accountid=14925

Abstract: Every Child Matters: Change for children (DfES, 2004) places effective inter-professional working at the top of the child care agenda. Developing new opportunities for practice learning in different professional settings, therefore, is high on the agenda for all those concerned with the teaching of social work. Learning within a different professional setting can bring many benefits, but also challenges. This article outlines a well-established project in Hull, where student social workers have been experiencing practice learning opportunities in mainstream schools for the past four years. The project has been evaluated using an action research model & as such reflects the subsequent development & consolidation as the project has expanded. We highlight both the benefits & the challenges for all those concerned with these placements, addressing some of the issues for students, practice teachers, & work-based supervisors in their roles in this new approach. Improvement by degrees: Reflections on developing quality in practice learning for the new degree in social work in Northern Ireland

Author: Douglas, Harry1; Byrne, Mel1 Training and Development Unit, Southern Health and Social Services Board, 41 Abbey Street, Armagh BT61 7DY North Ireland harry.douglas@shssb.n-i.nhs.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61353524?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work academic institutions and social work agencies in Northern Ireland, in common with counterparts in England, Wales and Scotland, have been working hard to meet the challenges of developing and delivering the academic and practice learning components of the new Degree in Social work. This article highlights a number of developments which have occurred in Northern Ireland. Using findings from recent local research and the authors' own knowledge and insights, some of the broader implications of these developments are discussed and their capacity for learning and transferability is identified. Adapted from the source document.

Teaching Letters

Author: Cooper, Lesley11 School Social Administration & Social Work, Flinders U, Adelaide, Australia Lesley.Cooper@flinders.edu.au

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61358710?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article presents a hypothetical series of letters from an anonymous social work student at Flinders University describing their learning. The student is writing to Charles-Louis de Secondat, Baron de la Brede et de Montesquieu, in keeping with the Baron's famous, anonymously published Lettres persanes (Persian Letters). The student's letters highlight the progress of education in general & social work education in particular from the 18h Century to the present time. They illustrate the author's approach to teaching & learning, & some of her strategies for effectively teaching social planning & social work ethics. Montesquieu wrote his Lettres persanes in 1721 as a vehicle for commenting on life & culture in contemporary France. This paper presents a series of hypothetical letters to Montesquieu from a social work student at Flinders University describing her learning. These letters were presented at the Australian Universities Teaching Committee National Teaching Forum in 2002 to convey the educator's approach to teaching. While the letters conclude with a peroration in which the educator outlines the conceptual framework underlying her teaching, the article concludes with a reply from 'Montesquieu' on the letters & the student's response. References. Adapted from the source document.

Back to the Future: Evaluating a Project to Disseminate Practice Learning and Teaching in Ukraine

Author: Ambler, Steve; Black, Adrian

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61395745?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article reports on an experience of training social work practice educators in the Chernihiv law College in northern Ukraine. The purpose of the visit was to examine whether the UK values critical to UK social work training were able to transfer to other cultures. During their visit, the authors taught a five-day module on practice learning & used research tools of questionnaire, structural interviews & focus groups to collate & analyse data that sought to examine the transferability of values. Positive changes to practice teaching were brought about as a result of their visit. References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Gass, Eric

A Model for a Pro-Active and Progressive University-Community Partnership

Author: Fasenfest, David; Grant, Larry

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716543?accountid=14925

Abstract: Community redevelopment in a coherent and long-term manner that addresses the needs of its residents is a core agenda for many University projects. After briefly recounting the relationship of universities to their communities we identify what we call 'University against Community' and 'University with Community' initiatives -- the former in response to the university's agenda while the latter reflects that of the community. We argue that an effective University-Community Partnership must be of the latter variety, and must exhibit comprehensiveness, synchrony, integration, long-term perspective, and inclusiveness if it is to be truly transformative. We offer a proposal for a University-Community Partnership that has been developed in collaboration with University faculty and the active participation of community stakeholders. Focused primarily on food and nutrition, this proposed program known as the Lishe Compact involves faculty and students, coordinates community agencies, and pools limited resources to improve interagency planning, builds local capacity, and engages residents in rebuilding the community. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=A+Model+for+a+Pro-Active+and+Progressive+University-Community+Partnership&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2005-01-01&amp;volume=8&amp;issue=2-3&amp;spage=24&amp;author=Fasenfest%2C+David%3BGrant%2C+Larry

Merging Organizational Development and Social Work Practice to Mentor Organizations to Stability and Sustainability: The Resource Mentoring Project

Author: Busch, H Ted; Hopkins, Karen; Hyde, Cheryl A; Cohen-Callow, Amy; Fisher, Elizabeth; Miller, Shari

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716546?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article describes the implementation and evaluation of the Resource Mentoring Project, a university-community partnerships that aims to build organizational capacity in grassroots community and faith-based organizations. Using a casework approach in which an organization is the 'client,' RMP staff provide client agencies with access to a network of technical assistance providers, a capacity assessment tool, a tailored action plan for organizational development, and a match with organizational mentors that helped agencies build capacity in needed areas. The efforts yielded positive outcomes for many of the agencies and several important lessons for successful grassroots organizational capacity building. Adapted from the source document.

The Role of Leadership Development in Addressing Urban Community Challenges

Author: Musewicz, John; Pickron-Davis, Marcine; Harris, James T; Marczyk, Geoffrey

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716550?accountid=14925

Abstract: Widener University is an independent, metropolitan, doctoral granting institution whose main campus is located in Chester, Pennsylvania. Widener is committed to addressing the region's most pressing concerns by contributing to the vitality and well-being of the local community. Chester is a distressed city of 36,000 residents, and this leadership development initiative targeted members of the Sun Hill community, which is located within Chester and adjacent to Widener. Sun Hill residents reflect a multitude of diversity in terms of age, race, and resident status. Quality of life issues, such as trash, curfew violations, drug-related violence, and a general increase in crimes involving theft of property and violence have pervaded the community. This leadership development initiative was designed to catalyze neighborhood revitalization by enhancing the leadership skills of Sun Hill residents, helping them to contribute to the recreation of a viable community. Components of the leadership training included recruiting participants, assessing their leadership strengths and developmental needs, and delivering classroom based training and individualized coaching sessions. Analysis of aggregate data collected during the program indicated that participants have levels of emotional intelligence (an important contributor to effective leadership skill) comparable to the general population, but do not yet have the level of leadership competency exhibited by successful managers in corporate America. Discussion of these results and the program is provided, and conclusions and recommendations are made. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Role+of+Leadership+Development+in+Addressing+Urban+Community+Challenges&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2005-01-01&amp;volume=8&amp;issue=2-3&amp;spage=50&amp;author=Musewicz%2C+John%3BPickron-Davis%2C+Marcine%3BHarris%2C+James+T%3BMarczyk%2C+Geoffrey

University-Community Collaborations: A Case Study of an Effective Partnership

Author: Pardasani, Manoj

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716553?accountid=14925

Abstract: University-Community collaboration have become integral to the overarching missions of educational institutions nationwide. While this trend has always existed in schools of social work, to some extent, this current debate has encouraged the schools to re-assess their commitment to empowerment, advocacy and social action in the context of the communities in which they are located. This article presents a case study of a productive, meaningful and mutually beneficial partnership established between a community coalition and a school of social work. This partnership was initiative without any fiscal incentive, but prospered due to the commitment of the school and individual faculty members. The joint project implemented, the benefits and challenges of initiating and maintaining such collaborations, and lessons learned from this experience are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Empowering Young African American Males for the 21st Century: A Collaborative Model Between a University and an African American Church

Author: Moore, Sharon E; Collins, Wanda Lott; Golder, Seana; Heitzman, Judith C; Monroe, Jacquelyn

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716557?accountid=14925

Abstract: Young African American males exhibit resilience and strength despite being bombarded by numerous obstacles and barriers. The purpose of this article is to discuss a university/faith-based collaborative project, the "Canaan Conference Project," that was aimed at empowering young African American males toward academic achievement through life skills presentations by adult African American males who served as role models. This collaborative is a model for replication by others in social work and closely related professions. Adapted from the source document.

Role Changes, Learning Enhancements and Professional Development Through a University-School Collaborative

Author: Austin, Sandra; Briar-Lawson, Katherine; King-Ingham, Alice; Spicer, Jerry; Davis, Dorinda

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716558?accountid=14925

Abstract: Engaged Universities position Schools of Social Work to be campus hubs for new kinds of outreach scholarship, pedagogy and programming. This case study reports on one facet of the outreach work undertaken by a School of Social Work with its neighboring elementary school in an urban, inner city community. It delineates ways that professional development can emerge when social workers and teachers collaborate to addressing barriers to learning. Outreach pedagogy positioned students in several macro practice classes to acquire community-building skills. Outcomes from the pedagogical, outreach and capacity building work are reported along with recommendation for further development such as evaluation research. Adapted from the source document.

University Agency Collaboration to Design, Implement, and Evaluate a Leadership Development System

Author: Packard, Thomas; Tucker-Tatlow, Jennifer; Waechter, Jessica; Rahiser, Patti; Dudley, Donald E

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716561?accountid=14925

Abstract: A collaboration between two schools of social work and nine county human service organizations has provided opportunities for university service to communities and organizations, research for the counties, and the enrichment of university curricula. University staff facilitate and provide staff support for quarterly meetings of the nine directors, and have completed several action research projects for them. A leadership development initiative to chance succession planning for the departments has successfully developed 24 of their staff interested in promoting to executive management. The program and its evaluation finding are presented here, followed by lessons learned which may be useful to other collaborations. For the past four years, two schools of social work (San Diego State University and California State University, San Bernardino) have been engaged in an ongoing collaboration with the directors of nine county human service organizations in Southern California. The purpose of this paper is to present some of products, models, and lessons learned from this ongoing collaboration. Specifically, several major research and training projects have provided valuable technical assistance and capacity building for the nine involved organizations. One project in particular, a leadership development initiative, will be presented in detail as an example of training for organizational leadership. Research designs used included qualitative, quantitative, and case study methods. The knowledge gained from the projects has been useful not only to the involved agencies but also to university faculty, in the form of knowledge and insights about agency practice which have informed curriculum development in a social work administration concentration. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=University+Agency+Collaboration+to+Design%2C+Implement%2C+and+Evaluate+a+Leadership+Development+System&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2005-01-01&amp;volume=8&amp;issue=2-3&amp;spage=98&amp;author=Packard%2C+Thomas%3BTucker-Tatlow%2C+Jennifer%3BWaechter%2C+Jessica%3BRahiser%2C+Patti%3BDudley%2C+Donald+E

Social Work Professional Education and Workforce Development: A Ladder of Learning

Author: Morris, Teresa

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1322716563?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article suggests that university based social work programs can collaborate with work place based academies to create a new model of social work professional education providing life-long learning from high school to the doctoral level. A "ladder of learning" is proposed linking educational levels, competencies, work place requirements and organizational change. It is suggested that such a framework gives social work a conceptual tool to identify, discuss and promote educational and work place reform. Adapted from the source document.

Concepts for Contemporary Social Work: Globalization, Oppression, Social Exclusion, Human Rights, Etc.

Author: van Wormer, Katherine11 Dept Social Work, U Northern Iowa, Cedar Falls vanwormer@uni.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61373110?accountid=14925

Abstract: The society wrestles with mass social change congruent with economic globalization and the communications revolution. This change creates new challenges for the social work profession in the areas of social and economic justice. This article analyzes the terminology of the new global era, words that signify a paradigm shift in outlook, most of them a reaction to the new authoritarianism of the age. Globalization, oppression, social exclusion, human rights, harm reduction, and restorative justice are the representative terms chosen. References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work, Social Politics and Justice

Author: Sunker, Heinz11 Fachbereich Bildungswissenschaften, Bergische U Wuppertal suenker@uni-wuppertal.de

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61368379?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues that the reluctance of social workers to recognize the link between social work & politics has turned the profession into a sort of reproduction process of social inequality. The history of the connection between politics & social work is traced from the beginning of the modern age to the present time. The transition within social work practice from intervention to benefit management is examined, along with the contradictory constitution of the welfare state; the impact of discourses about justice; problems of universalization; the need for an egalitarian society to be free of domination; & the relationship of justice with politics, political conscience, & political action. It is contended that the lack of a political framework is harmful to everyday practice because it forces social workers to accept the political vocabulary, problem definitions, & fiscal restraints of others. Counter strategies to further enforcement of capitalist social formation on a global scale will only succeed if social work & social politics stop contributing to the reproduction of social relationships based on inequalities. References. J. Lindroth

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Social+Work%2C+Social+Politics+and+Justice&amp;author=Sunker%2C+Heinz&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2005-01-01&amp;spage=11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Social Work and the Quality of Life Politics -- A Critical Assessment

Author: Landhausser, Sandra1; Ziegler, Holger1 Center Social Service Studies, Faculty Educational Science, U Bielefeld, Germany

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61393422?accountid=14925

Abstract: The feature of this paper is a critical assessment of the current discourses about quality of life (QoL) and their implications for Social Work. At first it pictures some major historical backgrounds of the discussion on the improvement of life quality as an aim of societal development. In particular three crucial shifts in the politics of QoL--its 'individualisation', its 'informalisation' and its 'culturalisation'--and their implications for Social Work are critically examined, theoretically and empirically referring to the results of an own community-study. The paper concludes with an alternative suggestion reflecting the idea of an 'autonomy-based' approach of democratic equality. References. Adapted from the source document.

Resisting Postmodernity: Swedish Social Policy in the 1990s

Author: Gould, Arthur11 Dept Social Sciences, Loughborough U, Leicestershire, England Arthur.gould1@btinternet.com

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61377594?accountid=14925

Abstract: Looks at ideas that have emerged in the 1990s about Sweden's welfare state which is considered a prototype of modern society & an exemplar of social engineering/state planning. An overview of global social & economic changes over the last 20 years is intended to provide the context for the supposed system change that occurred in Sweden during the 1990s. The focus is on both the impact of the shift from modernity to postmodernity & the political, institutional, & cultural resistance that has made welfare changes less severe in Sweden than in many other places. The status of women, the elderly, unemployment, substance misuse, & welfare services/benefits between 1991 & 1998 is examined to argue that Sweden exemplified modernity because of its Apollonian culture that is defined by order/form, control, self-restraint, temperance, predictability, reason & rationalism. These traits have enabled Swedish welfare to resist the phenomenon of postmodernity that leans toward Dionysian culture characterized by disorder/chaos; excess; impulsiveness; unpredictability; & irrationality. Positive & negative aspects of Swedish resistance are discussed. References. J. Lindroth

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Resisting+Postmodernity%3A+Swedish+Social+Policy+in+the+1990s&amp;author=Gould%2C+Arthur&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2005-01-01&amp;spage=72&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Social Work and a New Social Order -- Challenging Neo-Liberalism's Erosion of Solidarity

Author: Lorenz, Walter11 Faculty Education, Free U Bozen-Bolzano, Italy Walter.Lorenz@unibz.it

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61373038?accountid=14925

Abstract: The world in which social work operates today is a very different world from that in which most of us took their social work training, and the changes we are facing are profound. This paper argues that these changes are not merely a regime change in social policy but that they are essentially about a re-ordering of social relationships and attempt to model them on neo-liberal ideas. In view of these pressures it is understandable that social workers often try to ignore those changes and withdraw into a private world of therapeutic relationships in which the methods they trained in are made to be still valid, or they simply go along with new service delivery designs without asking too many questions. Both reactions fail to question what the 'social' can still mean in the light of these changes and how social workers can fulfil their mandate to be responsible for the social dimension of public life. Nothing less than a head-on challenge of the basic presuppositions of neo-liberalism (Willke 2003) and their manifold applications to social service delivery systems will thereby suffice. References. Adapted from the source document.

The Development of Social Work as a Speciality and the Profession in Estonia

Author: Kiik, Riina1; Sirotkina, Reeli1 U Tartu, Estonia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61351552?accountid=14925

Abstract: An examination of the development of social work in Estonia notes that social work education has existed since the beginning of the 20th century but was not provided during the 50 years of Soviet occupation when social problems were denied because they were considered an affront to official communist ideology. An overview of social work in Estonia from 1935 to 1990 is followed by a look at significant changes in the system of social assistance since Estonia regained independence in 1991. Special attention is given to the Social Welfare Act of 1995; the status of social work education; & new occupational standards for social workers. Current problems include the need for more professionally educated social workers & the lack of an occupational organization to bring social workers together. Emphasis is placed on the requisite to improve social work education in order to enhance the delivery of social services & increase knowledge about the global processes of social policy. Tables, References. J. Lindroth

The Active Subjects of Welfare Reform: A Street-Level Comparison of Employment Services in Australia and Denmark

Author: Marston, Greg1; Larsen, Jorgen Elm; McDonald, Catherine1 School Social Work & Applied Human Sciences, U Queensland, Brisbane, Australia g.marston@socialuq.edu.au

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61378366?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper explores the similarities & differences between Denmark & Australia in adopting welfare reform activation measures in the field of employment services. In Australia & Denmark the discourse of welfare reform centres the 'activation' of citizens through 'mutual obligation' type requirements. Through various forms of case management, unemployed individuals are encouraged to act upon themselves in creating the right set of ethical dispositions congruent with 'active citizenship'. At the same time any resistance to heightened conditionality on the part of the unemployed person is dealt with through a range of coercive & disciplinary techniques. A comparative case study between these two countries allows us to consider how similar ideas, discourse & principles are shaping policy implementation in countries that have very different welfare state trajectories & institutional arrangements for the delivery of social welfare generally & employment services specifically. & in research terms, a comparison between a Nordic welfare state & an Anglo-Saxon welfare state provides an opportunity to critically examine the utility of 'welfare regime' type analyses & the neo-liberal convergence thesis in comparative welfare research. On the basis of empirical analysis, the article concludes that a single focus on abstract typologies or political ideologies is not very helpful in getting the measure of welfare reform (or any other major policy development for that matter). At the 'street-level' of policy practice there is considerably more ambiguity, incoherence & contradiction than is suggested by linear accounts of welfare reform. References. Adapted from the source document.

Workfare Work: The Impact of Workfare on the Worker/Client Relationship

Author: Handler, Joel F11 School Public Policy & Social Research, U California, Los Angeles handler@law.ucla.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61394409?accountid=14925

Abstract: An examination of the history of welfare reform in the US focuses on how the implementation of workfare programs has affected the relationship between clients & their social workers. The burdens that have historically faced social welfare offices are described along with the difficulties involved in having to execute programs that emphasize compliance & eligibility while simultaneously being responsible for the implementation of workfare programs which require intensive personal case management. Strategies used by welfare offices to deal with these contradictory expectations are explored. Steven Luke's three dimensions of power (1974) are drawn upon to explain how clients react to workfare programs & why they acquiesce to workfare contracts in spite of unmet needs. It is suggested that workfare programs could succeed if the client were allowed to become the subject rather than the object. Four steps are needed to make this happen: 1) workers must be rewarded for client success; 2) workfare offices must be separated from benefits offices; 3) sanctions should be eliminated; 4) a Basic Income Guarantee must be instituted. References. J. Lindroth

The Deprofessionalisation Thesis, Accountability and Professional Character

Author: Clark, Chris11 School Social & Political Studies, U Edinburgh, UK Chris.Clark@ed.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61373217?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is said that the deprofessionalisation of social work & other welfare occupations reduces workers' professional discretion & autonomy, & thus their capacity to act in the best interests of their client. Without necessarily regarding the deprofessionalisation thesis as conclusive, this paper will ask how the state's control of the role & task of social workers impacts on their role-implicated obligations as professionals. If workers are reduced (as claimed) to the status of mere functionaries in systems they neither approve of nor control, does this exonerate them from bad outcomes or service failures? How should we view the dramatic increase in formal regulation now seen in the UK--as professionalisation or deprofessionalisation? The paper will argue that whatever the drift of policy, workers remain in some measure personally accountable. Service failures imply faults of practical reason that are partly attributable to the moral & intellectual character of professionals as individuals. It is therefore up to professionals, & their organisations, to attend to the improvement of professional character. References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work as Laboratory for Normative Professionalisation

Author: Kunneman, Harry11 U Humanistiek, Utrecht, Netherlands w-mail: hk@uvh.nl

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61399869?accountid=14925

Abstract: In most Western countries, the professional status of social workers is unstable & insecure. Of course, most Western countries are themselves unstable, ridden with feelings of insecurity & in search of reassurance & promises of control. But social work hardly lends itself as a projection screen for visions of professional control & efficiency in the face of insecurity. On the contrary: within the present cultural & political climate, social work connotes primarily with unpopular social problems, with people unable to cope adequately with the competitiveness & the rate of change of post-industrial societies; that is to say: it connotes more with dependency & helplessness then with autonomy & control. Moreover, whereas public discourse in most Western country is dominated by a neo-liberal perspective & the intricate network of economic, managerial, consumerist & military metaphors connected with it, social work still carries with it a legacy of 'progressive politics' increasingly labeled as outdated & inadequate. Although the values of solidarity & social justice connected with this 'progressive heritage' certainly have not faded away completely, the loudest & most popular voices on the level of public discourse keep underscoring the necessity to adapt to the 'realities' of present-day postindustrial societies & their dependence on economic growth, technological innovation & the dynamics of an ever more competitive world-market. This 'unavoidable' adaptation involves both the 'modernization' & progressive diminishment of 'costly' welfare-state arrangements & a radical reorientation of social work as a profession. Instead of furthering the dependency of clients in the name of solidarity, social workers should stimulate them to face their own responsibilities & help them to function more adequately in a world where individual autonomy & economic progress are dominant values. This shift has far-reaching consequences for the organization of the work itself. Efficiency & transparency are the new code words, professional autonomy is dramatically limited & interventions of social workers are increasingly bound to 'objective' standards of success & cost-effectiveness. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Social+Work+as+Laboratory+for+Normative+Professionalisation&amp;author=Kunneman%2C+Harry&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2005-01-01&amp;spage=191&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Decentralisation and Social Services in England

Author: Lorenz, Walter11 Facolta Scienze Formazione, Libera U Bolzano, Italia Walter.Lorenz@unibz.it

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61373078?accountid=14925

Abstract: Although Great Britain is not normally credited with the achievement of having been the first nation state to implement measures characteristic of a welfare state (this honour goes to Germany & Bismarck's strategy of promoting social insurance in the 1880s) it nevertheless pioneered many models of welfare services in view of the early onset of industrialisation in that country & the subsequent social problems it created. Organisations like the Mutual Insurance & Friendly Societies, the Charity Organisation Society or the Settlement Movement characterised an early approach to welfare that is based on initiatives at the civil society level & express a sense of self-help or of self-organisation in such a way that it did not involve the state directly. The state, traditionally, dealt with matters of discipline & public order, & for this reason institutions like prisons & workhouses represented the other end of the scale of 'welfare' provisions. References. Adapted from the source document.

Differences in Internet Usage -- Social Inequality and Informal Education

Author: Iske, Stefan1; Klein, Alexandra; Kutscher, Nadia1 Fakultat Padagogik, U Bielefeld, Germany

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61395632?accountid=14925

Abstract: Information for an analysis of the implications of digital social inequality for internet education was obtained from 50 structured & surf interviews with young people aged 11 to 23; a quantitative questionnaire completed by 360 persons aged 14-24; & a content analysis of 164 postings on a feedback forum. Consideration was given to how social preconditions influence differences in internet use; the impact of technical equipment & social sites of access; the relationship between real life & virtual space; & preconditions needed to open new educational spaces on the internet. It was found that both social differences & processes of appropriation have an impact on online use. Challenges for the development of informal internet educational arrangements posed by differences based on social inequalities are pointed out. Although the digital divide tends to diminish with technical access, differences in usage of the internet remain largely unchanged. Emphasis is placed on the need to create & enhance online services that overcome inequalities in access/usage while structurally providing a space for education. References. J. Lindroth

Mothering Children or Soldiers: Advancing Paradigms of the Women's Movement in Former Yugoslavia

Author: Swindell, Marian11 Social Work Division, Mississippi State U, Meridian Mswindell@meridian.msstate.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61399913?accountid=14925

Abstract: The transition of political power in former Yugoslavia & the wars that followed have led to the country's reassessment of the proper role of women in society, culture, nation, & family. Advocates of a new vision of nationalist womanhood assert that the continued existence of the entire country depends solely on women carrying out their reproductive & nurturing roles. This new envisioning clearly serves a political purpose, solely at the expense of the women's movement, which has made significant strides in this nation. It is the purpose of this article to provide a brief historical overview of the development of the new idealized "mother of the nation" from a strengths-based social work perspective. References. Adapted from the source document.

Why Freeter and NEET are Misunderstood: Recognizing the New Precarious Conditions of Japanese Youth

Author: Inui, Akio11 Faculty Humanities & Social Sciences, Tokyo Metropolitan U, Hachiohji-shi jbb03316@nifty.ne.jp

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61385783?accountid=14925

Abstract: In developed countries, the transition from school to work has radically changed over the past two decades. It has become prolonged, complicated & individualized (Bynner et al., 1997; Walther et al., 2004). Young people used to transition directly from school to stable employment, or with a very short unemployed period. In many European countries, this situation has been changing since the eighties: overall youth unemployment has increased, & many young people experience long periods of unemployment, government training schemes & part-time or temporary jobs. In Japan, this change has taken a decade later to appear, becoming prevalent by the late nineties (Inui, 2003). The transiting process has become not only precarious for young people, but also difficult for society to precisely understand the risks & problems. Traditionally, we have been able to recognize young people's situation by a simple category: in education, employed, in training or unemployed. However, these categories no longer accurately represent young people's state. In Japan, most young people used to move from school directly to full-time employment through the new graduate recruitment system (Inui, 1993). Therefore, in official statistics such as the School Basic Survey, 'employed' includes only those who are in regular employment, while those who are in part-time or temporary work are covered by the categories 'jobless' & 'others'. However, with the increase in non-full-time jobs in the nineties, these categories have become less useful for describing the actual employment conditions of young people. Indeed, this is why, in the late nineties, the Japanese Ministry of Education changed the category name from 'jobless' to 'others'. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Why+Freeter+and+NEET+are+Misunderstood%3A+Recognizing+the+New+Precarious+Conditions+of+Japanese+Youth&amp;author=Inui%2C+Akio&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2005-01-01&amp;spage=244&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Community Research as a Factor Building Inclusive Community in Lithuania

Author: Barsauskiene, Viktorija1; Leliugiene, Irena; Vaidelyte, Egle1 Faculty Social Sciences, Kaunas U Technology, Lithuania

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61393536?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social & political change in Europe, increasing labour mobility, development of the new European social policy & increasingly global nature of social problems, has had a profound effect on the socio-cultural & socio-educational work in community & on its objectives. In order to keep these new communitarian standards of social policy, the first steps have to be made in fostering local community with the perspective it will reach the western European communitarian level. That is the reason why university in these changes started to turn more & more to the society & first of all has put a great emphasis on the community research. This initiative was induced by non-existence of civic tradition during the communist period, the gap in the development of civil society & its culture, the weakness & the poorness of the third sector. This paper is based on the analysis of the community & civil society research conducted during recent years by the researchers of Kaunas University of Technology, Faculty of Social Sciences. The paper involves a review of the research methodology, interpretation of the received data & summary of the results. It discusses both theoretical & empirical possibilities of building & developing inclusive community. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Skills in Working with Survivors of Earthquake: A Social Work Intervention -- Iran

Author: Iravani, Mohammad Reza1; Ghojavand, Kazem1 Islamic Azad U-Khomeinishahr Branch, Iran

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61385828?accountid=14925

Abstract: Loss, grief & other problems are events that most people experience during their life. Earthquakes are disasters that make people experience these problems simultaneously. These crises affect survivors as much as other dangers in their lives. Thus, most of them need to be supported until they can solve their problems & do their daily activities. We know that the aim of social work is to assist individuals who are seeking help. But there is a problem: how must social workers help their clients efficiently? Especially, those clients who are victims of earthquakes? To this end, the present paper tries to describe the process of social casework & those skills required for social workers to help these survivors. These skills include: situational supporting, hopefulness making, consoling, assuring, concentrating, developing solutions & referring. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Asian Challenges to Globalisation of Social Work Education

Author: Yip, Kam-Shing11 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Hung Hom Kowloon, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61369708?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article tries to describe the impact of globalisation on social work education in Asian countries. A historical review of the import of social work education from the United States of America to Asian countries like India, Japan & China is discussed. The dynamics & challenges in forms of homogeneity versus diversity, universality versus specificity, & independence versus interdependence are mentioned. Their impacts to the future development of social work education in Asian countries are also described & appropriate responses suggested. 1 Figure, 48 References. Adapted from the source document.

Effect of Social Work Intervention on Attempted Suicide

Author: Das, D. K. Lal1; Mathew, Anna; Mrudula, K1 Research Centre

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61349293?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article reports the results of a study evaluating the effectiveness of an intervention package on a male young adult who attempted suicide. Data indicate that cognitive therapy was found to be the most effective in the intervention package consisting of crisis intervention, cognitive therapy & developing problem-solving skills. 2 Tables, 3 Figures, 33 References. ____________________________________________________________

Doing Good but Making It Work: A Reflective Commentary on the Past Fifty Years

Author: Newman, Edward11 Temple U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61433575?accountid=14925

Abstract: National social planning ideas in the 1960s, & even before, were spearheaded by prominent social workers whose impetus came, in part, from 1962 social service amendments to federal public welfare legislation. Civil rights activities, urban disturbances, President Kennedy's 'New Frontier' & President Johnson's 'War on Poverty' heightened federal attention to the local scene. Although many initiatives were short-lived, their political & managerial problems drew attention to a new focus upon accountability in human services. Team processes, client participation & service outputs in targeted communities refocused energies in the 1970s & l980s. Since the l990s some core social work values have been challenged. Practitioners & managers at the start of the 21st century can promote consumer preferences & locally initiated planned change, consistent with the profession's reform traditions. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Doing+Good+but+Making+It+Work%3A+A+Reflective+Commentary+on+the+Past+Fifty+Years&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2004-10-01&amp;volume=7&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=4&amp;author=Newman%2C+Edward

Evaluation of a Social Work Continuing Education Curriculum in End-of-Life Care

Author: Csikai, Ellen L1; Raymer, Mary1 School Social Work, U Alabama, Tuscaloosa

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61517932?accountid=14925

Abstract: In response to the educational needs of social workers for competence in end-of-life care, a data-driven continuing education curriculum was developed, pilot-tested, & evaluated using multiple methods. A one-day seminar covered a range of topics, & was delivered primarily by a team of practitioners experienced in end-of-life & palliative care. Attendees rated both the comprehensiveness of content & effectiveness of delivery approach high, in the course evaluation, & suggested expansion of the curriculum into a two-day seminar to allow for additional content & more time for discussion. 4 Tables, 10 References.

Innovative Exchange Creates Global Continuing Education

Author: Borland, Kathleen Landreth1; Hockensmith, Janice M1 Circuit Court Cook County, Chicago, IL

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61535300?accountid=14925

Abstract: In a world that is simultaneously interconnected by technology & fragmented by cultural divisions, social workers face common professional challenges. NASW Illinois Chapter's International Activities Network addresses those common challenges & creates global continuing education. The Network's exchange programs give social workers an opportunity for "cultural discourse" to improve social services worldwide. Seasoned professionals often reexamination their assumptions, belief systems, & professional strategies. This article describes the development of this innovative program that has brought more than 600 social work professionals together from the United States, Germany, England, & South Africa. It demonstrates social work's global interconnectedness in relating to issues & challenges in our daily professional lives. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Views of NASW Members in One State toward Social Action

Author: Dickinson, Janet C11 Western Carolina U, Cullowhee, NC

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61528097?accountid=14925

Abstract: This 2003 survey of one state's NASW members explores the relationships between attitudes about social action & various demographic variables. The response rate was 41%. There was strong support for social action on the part of individuals, the profession, & social welfare agencies. Social action tactics involving demonstrations & strikes had minimal support while serving as expert advisor, writing letters to editors, speaking to lay groups, organizing client groups, & contacting policy makers had strong approval. Recommendations are made for stronger social action training in BSW & MSW programs & in continuing education programs for social workers. 11 Tables, 1 Figure, 25 References.

Facilitating a Reciprocal International Exchange in Social Work

Author: Mirsky, Julia1; Barasch, Miriam1 Dept Social Work, Ben-Gurion U, Beer-Sheva, Israel

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61557721?accountid=14925

Abstract: There is a growing recognition of the importance of exchanges between social workers from different countries, but the reciprocity of such exchanges is controversial. This paper describes an international exchange program that included a mediated cultural immersion & facilitated a reciprocal encounter between western & non-western professionals. Factors that enabled the successful encounter & conditions needed for the replication of such programs in other settings are delineated & discussed. 3 Tables, 36 References. Social Workers' Perceptions of How Participation in Continuing Education Activities Leads to Changes in Knowledge, Attitudes, and Behaviors

Author: Bliss, Donna Leigh1; Smith, Charles A; Cohen-Callow, Amy; Dia, David A1 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61551814?accountid=14925

Abstract: As family support programs grow in importance, North Carolina established a management information system to provide information for the purposes of management & evaluation of their family support/family resource programs. This article describes a training effort developed by a state university on behalf of the state to provide an outcomes-focused training to the local programs. Included was training of various levels of staff on the North Carolina Family Support Outcome Scales & definitions, the management information system, & outcomes' identification. Results showed that the training was well received. Suggestions are given for future training in the area of family support. 5 Tables, 18 References.

Professional Organizational Culture and Retention in Child Welfare: Implications for Continuing Education for Supervision and Professional Development

Author: Ellett, Alberta J1; Millar, Kenneth I1 School Social Work, U Georgia, Athens aellett@arches.uga.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61433572?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study was designed to understand linkages between new measures of professional organizational culture & employees' intentions to remain employed in child welfare. A survey was administered to all professional staff in two states, & 941 useable surveys were analyzed. The findings provide additional support for the validity of the measures & confirmed the hypothesized linkages between dimensions of professional organizational culture & intentions to remain employed. Implications of the findings for the professional development of supervisors & administrators to strengthen organizational culture in three areas (administrative support, professional sharing among subordinates, & articulating vision & professional commitment) are discussed. 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Testing, Treatment, and Trust: Social Work Professional Development and the Genomics Revolution

Author: Scheyett, Anna1; Strom-Gottfried, Kimberly1 School Social Work, U North Carolina, Chapel Hill

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61455359?accountid=14925

Abstract: Knowledge in the area of human genetics & genomics is expanding at an exponential pace, with significant implications for social work in health, mental health, & other settings. This article identifies some key roles social workers may play in the arena of genetics, discusses social workers' responsibility for ongoing professional development in this area, & describes a flexible genetics & genomics social work curriculum developed by the authors. We provide an evaluation of pilot curriculum implementation, discuss ongoing strategies & barriers to dissemination, & make recommendations for future actions to more fully incorporate genetics & genomics content into the social work professional knowledge base. 1 Table, 1 Appendix, 15 References.

Training Field Instructors: An Education Module for Field Instructors and Educators

Author: Short, Glenda F. Lester1; Priddy, Wanda Wahanee; McChesney, Marja-Leena; Murdock, Vicki; Ward, Jim1 School Social Work, Southwest Missouri State U, Springfield

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61453260?accountid=14925

Abstract: This training module addresses the need for continuing education of field instructors as required by the CSWE. This article discusses how to orient & train novice & experience social workers as field instructors. Present is over a decade history of collaboration, development, implementation, evaluation, & revision of the module that has been used to prepare field educators to function effectively as teachers. Following the literature review that gives a conceptual framework & knowledge base for the training that reviews teaching & learning in social work field education, this article discusses the evaluation process & effectiveness of this particular training. 58 References.
