Writing Apprehension among Social Workers: Addressing Internal and Structural Barriers to Writing about What We Do

Author: Hernandez, Virginia Rondero1; Dole, Robert; Chavkin, Nancy Feyl1 Dept Social Work Education, California State U, Fresno

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61551762?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article features the results of a survey of social work practitioners who voluntarily attended "Writing About What You Do" workshops at professional conferences. The workshop objectives were to sensitize participants to the individual experience of writing, to identify obstacles & supports for writing through the use of a standardized instrument, & to help participants reframe field experiences into a written format. Self-Plagiarism as a Social Work Concern

Author: Cheung, Monit1; Driver, Demori Currid1 Graduate School Social Work, U Houston, TX mcheung@uh.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61400566?accountid=14925

Abstract: Publication ethics in social work have received very little attention. As the research base of the field continues to expand, & as the pressure to publish among academic faculty increases, social work researchers need to examine the ethical issues that can arise in scientific publication, including self-plagiarism & redundant publication. This article examines the issue of self-plagiarism, including "salami-slicing," "text recycling," & duplicate submission. Noting that many researchers may be unaware of publication guidelines, manuscript submission policies were reviewed for 28 major social work journals. Of the journals, 71.43% (n=20) explicitly prohibited simultaneous submissions, & 67.86% (n=19) clearly stated that submitted manuscripts were required to be original. Suggestions are provided to help social work researchers avoid committing intentional & unintentional acts of self-plagiarism & redundant publication. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Self-Plagiarism+as+a+Social+Work+Concern&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2004-07-01&amp;volume=38&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=3&amp;author=Cheung%2C+Monit%3BDriver%2C+Demori+Currid

Group Work with Disaffected Students: A Reality Therapy Approach

Author: Steven, Ngai Sek-Yum11 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin syngai@cuhk.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61387262?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study evaluates a reality therapy group for students enrolled in the Form 1 classes of a low-band secondary school in Hong Kong who have exhibited signs of disaffection such as apathy toward study & school activities, repeated academic failure & disruptive classroom behaviour. The results, based on interviews with members & their teachers, indicate significant improvements in the self-esteem, life satisfaction & school performance of the adolescent participants. The results from a self-report evaluation questionnaire also show the members' satisfaction & their positive perceptions of the group in terms of goal attainment & the impact the group has had on them. The implications of these findings for future practice & research are discussed. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Translated title not available

Author: [Unknown]

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61396043?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper, based on a sample survey, analysed the social network of the marginal groups including the poor, the un-employed & people with unstable jobs in Hong Kong. The quantity & quality of social capital of the above groups were measured according to the size & homogeneity of their social network. Results showed that the size of social network of the poor was significantly smaller than that of the non-poor, especially in the network of job searching. This suggests that the social capital of the poor was less than that of the non-poor. It is more likely that the social network of the poor was constituted of the un-employed, that was why it was more homogenous. Social network of the un-employed & people with unstable jobs was smaller than that of the people with stable jobs. The un-employed or unstable job holders also induced homogeneity in their social network, the impact of which was greater on male than female. To alleviate the problem of poverty in Hong Kong, we should increase the social capital of the deprived people. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Impacts of SARS Crisis on Social Work Students -- Reflection on Social Work Education

Author: Man, Lam Ching-Man1; Hung, Wong; Terry, Leung Tse-Fong1 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin chingmanlam@cuhk.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61396662?accountid=14925

Abstract: The impacts of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) on the social work students were examined using a combined quantitative & qualitative method. A survey was conducted with 114 social work undergraduate students at The Chinese University of Hong Kong to assess their perception of the impacts of SARS on them at personal & professional level. Four focus groups had been conducted to examine the social work students' interpretation & their reflection of their experience. Results show that the SARS crisis has positive impacts on social work students. The findings indicate that students with direct exposure to SARS perceived themselves as becoming more appreciative in attitude & have greater involvement & devotion to the social work profession. Moreover, the result shows that three variables -- recognition of risk, commitment & devotion, & professional reflection are positively correlated. The findings articulate the relationship between experience (risk), profession reflection & meaning generation (commitment & devotion). The findings of this study provide us with insights to rethink on our social work education. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Impacts+of+SARS+Crisis+on+Social+Work+Students+--+Reflection+on+Social+Work+Education&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2004-07-01&amp;volume=38&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=93&amp;author=Man%2C+Lam+Ching-Man%3BHung%2C+Wong%3BTerry%2C+Leung+Tse-Fong

"Strength" Community -- The Role of Community Development Services in SARS

Author: Kwok-Kin, Fung1; Suet-Lin, Hung1 Division Social Studies, City U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61396715?accountid=14925

Abstract: Studies on disaster have been criticised as putting too much emphasis on individual therapy. The community perspective highlights the significance of the sociopolitical factors in causing disasters & intervention at the community level. This paper, examining the contribution of community development services during the SARS epidemic in Hong Kong, reveals the significance of establishing an extensive network of vulnerable groups & community organising groundwork in times of crisis. Intervention during the SARS crisis included crisis intervention, providing community education, promoting community care, community participation & supporting the unemployed. After SARS, the focus was on reinforcing the spirit of mutual help, anti-discrimination & reconstructing positive shared meanings of the disaster. In mobilising community resources, the concept of the "strength" community has been confirmed. The SARS experience has revealed that, although disasters are becoming complex & global, remedies can be found in the local community. Community is an important disaster resource. References. Adapted from the source document.

Translated title not available

Author: [Unknown]

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61405346?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study examines whether the Rheumatoid Arthritis Self-Management Course is effective in, as well as being able to achieve stabilizing effect on, enhancing participants' perception of control over the symptoms, improving health behaviours & health status, & reducing use of health care resources. This is a single group pre-&-post design with a sample of 70 participants. After the intervention & at 1 month follow up, participants show significant improvements in arthritis self-efficacy, self-management behaviour (exercise, cognitive symptoms management & communication with doctors), psychological well-being (sense of helplessness, mood & anxiety) & health status (pain & fatigue). These improvements become stabilized at 6 months follow-up after completion of the program. In addition, the program is found effective in reducing visits to general physician on problems related to arthritis. The results in this study clearly indicate that this community based patient education program can offer substantial benefits for the participants, particularly in terms of perceived self-efficacy on managing various aspects of arthritis, the establishment of positive health behaviour & its stabilizing effects. Therefore the complementary role of patient self-management education to traditional disease-oriented medical services can offer a valuable adjunct to medical care & we strongly advocate for its full implementation. Tables, Figures, Appendixes, References. Adapted from the source document.

Overview of Social Science Research in India: An Invitation for Dialogue

Author: Pandey, Vikash N

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61534645?accountid=14925

Abstract: The present note attempts to identify broad trends in social science paradigms, shifts in these paradigms, & their inter-linkages with the social scenario. The central concern is, the "if & how" of inter-linkages between social scientific theories & praxis on the one hand, & the emerging social concerns on the other. Therefore, this note is a historical overview to identify the direction of our movement, the crossroads & gaps that they reflect. 1 Box, 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Clinical Social Work Research: Quantitative versus Qualitative Methodology

Author: Stanley, Selwyn11 Dept Social Work, Bishop Heber Coll, Tiruchirapalli, Tamil Nadu, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61433748?accountid=14925

Abstract: One of the biggest predilections to plague social science research, has been the debate on the use of quantitative analytical procedures vis-a-vis qualitative methodology. Quantitative analysts claim superiority in terms of "scientific" validity & greater generalisability of findings, while the advocates of the qualitative perspective assert greater subjective insight, richness & depth of information, which is likely to be lost in a matrix of numbers. Clinical social work research has, in recent years, shown an overwhelming tendency to list towards the former approach often to the absolute exclusion of qualitative procedures as is evidenced by the numerous publications in the field & the instruments developed to quantify various psychosocial parameters. Several related issues from the stand-point of this paradigm debate have been discussed in this paper besides making out a case for using mixed research methodologies, blending both approaches to the optimum extent possible so as to get the best insight into the phenomenon being investigated. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Research%3A+Quantitative+versus+Qualitative+Methodology&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2004-07-01&amp;volume=65&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=341&amp;author=Stanley%2C+Selwyn

Demographic Transition and Gender Inequalities in Maharashtra

Author: Kanitkar, Tara1; Radkar, Anjali1 Institute Health Management, Pachod, Maharashtra

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61526074?accountid=14925

Abstract: With demographic transition, social development has to take place reducing gender inequalities. Demographic transition is almost complete in Maharashtra as it is one of the developed states in India. Unlike transition, gender inequalities cannot be quantified accurately. They have to be studied through the data available on the behavioral patterns of the people. Looking at attitudes of the people as expressed through behavior, an attempt has been made in this article to search for the gender inequalities. Unfortunately, the gap still persists. On the contrary, certain crude indicators like sex ratio even indicate that it has widened. Due to the small family norm & acceptance of terminal methods of contraception immediately after the desired family size is reached, son preference is becoming more visible. Family planning is absolutely women-centered & participation of men is negligible. In spite of an increase in the educational levels of women, as also their participation in the labor force, women get little support from the men, even when they are pregnant. Unless there is gender equity, demographic transition carries no meaning in the true sense. 3 Tables, 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Demographic+Transition+and+Gender+Inequalities+in+Maharashtra&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2004-07-01&amp;volume=65&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=373&amp;author=Kanitkar%2C+Tara%3BRadkar%2C+Anjali

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Demographic+Transition+and+Gender+Inequalities+in+Maharashtra&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2004-07-01&amp;volume=65&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=373&amp;author=Kanitkar%2C+Tara%3BRadkar%2C+Anjali

Socioeconomic Differentials among Major Social and Religious Groups in City Slums

Author: Das, Biswaroop11 Centre Social Studies, Surat, Gujarat, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61517615?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article examines some key socioeconomic differences among the Hindu, Muslim, Scheduled Caste & Scheduled Tribe population living in the slums of Surat, based on data drawn from a complete enumeration of slumdwellers. The analysis indicates that such settlements are essentially "heterogeneous" in character. The labor market -- especially in the "informal" or "unorganized" sector that draws much of its work force from within such settlements -- gets divided through participation of specific groups & communities in a wide range of jobs within select occupational categories. This reinforces the fragmentation of the urban informal labor market & tends to behave in an "inclusive-exclusive" mode by absorbing labor within specific sectors of immediate as well as larger city economies. 15 Tables, 1 Box, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Human Rights Education: Role of Teaching and Training Institutions

Author: Tiwari, Arvind11 Dept Criminology & Correctional Administration, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61560808?accountid=14925

Abstract: The World Conference on Human Rights held at Vienna in June 1993, declared that human rights education, training & public information were essential for stable & harmonious relations among communities. Human rights education implies the entire process of social life through which individuals & social groups learn to develop consciously within -- & for the benefit of national & international communities -- the whole of their personal capacities, attitudes, aptitudes & knowledge. The Government of India & the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) have initiated various programs to impart human rights education at various levels. This article outlines the status of human rights education at various levels & the role of the NHRC to give fillip to human rights education in the country. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Distance Education Evaluation: The Second Cohort

Author: Kleinpeter, Christine B1; Potts, Marilyn K1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61549433?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper describes a three-year, part-time distance education (DE) program taught using a combination of face-to-face & interactive television (ITV) methods. This is a partial replication study that describes results from the second cohort of a large DE program; results from the first cohort are described elsewhere (Potts & Hagan, 2000). The present study will focus on student characteristics, student satisfaction levels, & academic & field work evaluations. Implications for social work education are discussed. 6 Tables, 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Implementing Policy Change: Assessing Training Needs in Addictions Treatment and Criminal Justice Collaboratives

Author: Hohman, Melinda1; Weisner, Stanley; Chalmers, Virginia1 School Social Work, San Diego State U, CA mhohman@mail.sdsu.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61546422?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Substance Abuse & Crime Prevention Act of 2000, passed by CA voters, offers nonviolent drug offenders treatment instead of incarceration. In a training needs assessment, 57 county oversight collaborative teams were interviewed in a focus group format to determine concerns in policy implementation & subsequent training needs. A content analysis of the focus group discussions found that team members were concerned about clients with complex problems, lack of available treatment options, & interagency collaboration. Training needs identified included motivating clients & working in a collaborative fashion due to the multiple agencies involved in the implementation of this act. 4 Tables, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

CE Online: Use It or Lose It

Author: Dezendorf, Paul K1; Green, Ronald K; Krul, Ronald1 Dept Social Work, Winthrop U, Rock Hill, SC

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61433060?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article describes historical periods in the later 30 years of the 20th century in the development of continuing education (CE) in US social work, highlights the flexibility & adaptation of programs to changes, & suggests that the current period contains the greatest challenge to date in the form of CE online. The article suggests that while programs enjoy increased demand they also face greater competition, more specialization, & pressure for lower costs; at the same time, the development of CE online threatens to fundamentally alter their marketplace. The article provides recommendations for reacting to this new reality. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Reed-Ashcraft, Kellie1; Smithdeal, W Reid; Kittle, Cynthia Blanchard; Sharma, Nancy; McClune, David1 Appalachian State U, Boone, NC

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61536236?accountid=14925

Abstract: As family support programs grow in importance, NC established a management information system to provide information for the purposes of management & evaluation of their family support/family resource programs. This article describes a training effort developed by a state university on behalf of the state to provide an outcomes-focused training to the local programs. Included was training of various levels of staff on the North Carolina Family Support Outcome Scales & definitions, the management information system, & outcomes' identification. At the Border: Beginning Dialogue and Partnership between a California University and a Mexican Practice Community

Author: Mathiesen, Sally1; Carrilio, Terry; Rasmussen, Lucinda; Engstrom, David1 School Social Work, San Diego State U, CA smathiesen@sbcglobal.net

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61502137?accountid=14925

Abstract: A developmental model for international engagement is presented that incorporates key issues in the literature, including the need for faculty & practitioner expertise, challenges of international field placements, & reciprocity in partnerships. A case study is presented demonstrating a continuing education response to the knowledge, skills, & values demanded by the unique environment of the CA-Mexico border region. The initial dialogues & developing relationship between a San Diego university & social work practitioners resulted in reciprocal goal setting; visits to each country's social service agencies; steps toward international student exchanges; increased involvement of staff, faculty, students, & community practitioners on both sides of the border; & a binational roundtable conference. 2 Figures, 29 References. Urban Migrants and Rural Development

Author: Burman, J. J. Roy1; Das, Rajib1 Unit Research & Consultancy Social Policy & Social Welfare Administration

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61544819?accountid=14925

Abstract: There is a long-standing debate on urbanization & urbanism as a way of life. One view states that due to urban influence, rural migrants feel alienated & get disillusioned. Another view states that rural migrants in urban areas tend to cling together in specific pockets. They form welfare associations to take care of their interests -- mainly saving the slums (where a majority of them dwell), resist eviction by municipal boards, or being exploited by slumlords. There is another type of organization, which is not seen in most of the metropolises & other urban areas. Here, the rural migrants tend to form associations that primarily take care of their housing problems in cities, & also take up developmental activities back in their native villages. After dealing with the concept of urbanism briefly, the article will look into the functioning of a few of the rural development associations formed in Mumbai city. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Co-Dependency: Personality Correlates in Spouses of Alcoholics

Author: Stanley, Selwyn11 Dept Social Work, Bishop Heber Coll, Tiruchirapalli, Tamil Nadu, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61496190?accountid=14925

Abstract: One hundred & fifty co-dependent spouses of alcoholics were compared with an equal number of wives of non-alcoholics. Instruments to assess their self-esteem, neuroticism, & pessimism were administered. Data analysis showed that the co-dependents had lower self-esteem & manifested greater levels of neuroticism & pessimism than the subjects of the reference group. The findings substantiate the stress hypothesis of co-dependency, which advocates that the stress of living with an alcoholic is responsible for the personality deficits seen in the spouse. Implications for therapeutic intervention have been discussed. 3 Tables, 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Women Pensioners and Retirement Blues

Author: Pai, Vineeta B11 Dept Social Work, Karnatak U, Dharwad, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61434083?accountid=14925

Abstract: With an increase in the number of women entering the labor market, there is a corresponding increase in the number of women retiring from various job positions. Yet, very little is known about their reactions to retirement or about the implications of retirement. A probe into the lives of these pensioners shows that contrary to the general view that all women alike are happy to retire & relax, a significant number of them either dread retirement or are in an acute dilemma because of socio-psychological or economic reasons. The implications of such dread or dilemmas cannot be ignored for long as they are likely to have far-reaching effects on the quality of life of these retirees. So, alternatives have to be thought of to tackle this issue of women's retirement blues. 4 Tables, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Utilisation of Primary Health Care Services and Traditional Healing Practices of Lambanis

Author: Patil, Geeta1; Saroja, K1 Dept Human Development, Rural Home Science Coll, U Agricultural Sciences, Dharwad, Karnataka, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61434080?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study was conducted using data collected from 75 married Lambani respondents from randomized tandas of Gadag Taluka in Gadag District, Karnataka, regarding their traditional healing remedies. The opinion of four purposively selected, qualified & practicing doctors about these home remedies were then taken. A pre-tested interview schedule, an interview guide, personal observation & an interview schedule for doctors were the tools of data collection. Results revealed that only one tanda had a primary health center & auxiliary nurse midwives were found to visit the tandas rarely. More than 50% of the respondents did not use government health services. Respondents were found to use several traditional remedies for their illnesses & the illnesses of their neonates. Some of these home remedies were approved as effective by all four doctors. The results also implied the need to improve government health facilities, as well as an urgent need for identifying, validating, & propagating effective home remedies. 3 Tables, 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Globalized Consumer Culture: Its Implications for Social Justice and Practice Teaching in Social Work

Author: Besthorn, Fred H11 Dept Social Work, U Northern Iowa, Cedar Falls

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61396125?accountid=14925

Abstract: Globalised consumer culture & its corresponding ethos that accumulation of material possessions equates to happiness are having a profound impact on the physical, social & emotional health of human beings. For social work practitioners & field educators the issue is how we balance the charge to serve our clients without unwittingly forcing them into a system that is designed by its very nature to increase their dissatisfaction & alienation. This essay discusses these concerns & offers some initial suggestions for how social work may respond. References. Adapted from the source document.

Working towards Culturally Sensitive Ethical Practice in a Multicultural Society

Author: Weber, Zita11 School Social Work & Policy Studies, U Sydney, Australia z.weber@edfac.usyd.edu.au

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374830?accountid=14925

Abstract: In the last two decades there has been a lot of theorizing about multiculturalism & professional practice. Many practitioners are challenged by cultural diversity daily. Practicing from a culturally sensitive ethical perspective in a multicultural society is essential for good practice. Postmodem influences & critical questioning are seen to inform culturally sensitive ethical practice in their encouragement of practitioners' adoption of multiple belief systems & multiple perspectives & the need to pose questions challenging practice regarding awareness of cultural encapsulation & cultural sensitivity. The development of culturally sensitive ethical practice guidelines within the context of a multicultural society is proposed, firstly, by assessing the cultural sensitivity of the ethics codes & secondly, by balancing culture & ethical codes. References. Adapted from the source document.

Group Supervision for Social Work Students on Placement: An International Comparison

Author: McCafferty, Paul11 Partnership Care West, Derry Pmccafferty67@hotmail.com

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61386253?accountid=14925

Abstract: Partnership Care West is a voluntary organization that contracts with the Northern Ireland Social Care Council (NISCC) to provide ten placements for social work students. NISCC is a statutory organization, with responsibility for registering & regulating social care/work, improving standards in education & training & standardizing practice in Northern Ireland NISCC (2003). The students attend the practice learning centre & are then given placements in voluntary sector sites established by the centre. Traditionally, the students were supervised on a one to one basis using the long arm approach. In recent years however, the centre has developed a model for supervising these students in groups. Building on my positive experience of conducting group supervision & to further my knowledge, skills & values in this area, I recently undertook an international comparison with the School of Social Work in Haifa Israel. This School has an already well established model for supervising students in groups & I hoped that I could learn something to help me develop my model further. I would like to thank Nava Arkin at the University of Haifa for her willingness to take part in this comparison & for her encouragement throughout. This article aims to outline my findings of the comparison & outline the theoretical constructs that make international comparisons in social work possible. References. Adapted from the source document.

The Magnetism of Power in Helping Relationships. Professional Attitude and Asymmetry

Author: Schuyt, Theo N M11 Vrije U Amsterdam

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61376843?accountid=14925

Abstract: What makes helping relationships -- or social interventions in general -- so sensitive to abuse? These problems are directly related to the nature of the helping relationship. The core of this relationship is the inequality, the asymmetry, between the helper and the person being helped, and the dependence of the latter. Asymmetry is the driving force behind every social intervention and at the same time its weakest point. Handling asymmetry in an appropriate manner constitutes a major part of the work of the intervening party. This asymmetry makes heavy demands on the professional attitude of the intervening party i.e. the helper. Is s/he capable of dealing with dependence in an acceptable way? Is s/he well-versed in her/his profession? This article contains a comprehensive sketch of many of the possible dangers and pitfalls which beset asymmetric intervention relations. At the end it will be argued that, for a better understanding, the proximity of helping and power has to be taken into account. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+Magnetism+of+Power+in+Helping+Relationships.+Professional+Attitude+and+Asymmetry&amp;author=Schuyt%2C+Theo+N+M&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2004-01-01&amp;spage=&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

The Concept of Developmental-Tasks and Its Significance for Education and Social Work

Author: Uhlendorff, Uwe11 U Kassel

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61377266?accountid=14925

Abstract: The term "developmental-task" was introduced by Robert Havighurst in the 1950's. According to R. Harvighurst, the term refers to tasks which arise in a social context during an individual lifetime. Since the 1950's the concept of developmental-tasks has become an important theoretical approach in educational science and in theories of growth and development -- but not in social work and social pedagogy. In the following article I aim to show that this approach is very important to theory and practice of social pedagogy and social work. Adapted from the source document.

Welfare Lobby Groups Responding to Globalisation: A Comparison of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) and the UK Child Poverty Action Group (CPAG)

Author: Mendes, Philip11 Dept Social Work, Faculty Medicine, Monash U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61390363?accountid=14925

Abstract: The past decade has witnessed a period of intense economic globalisation. The growing significance of international trade, investment, production and financial flows appears to be curtailing the autonomy of individual nation states. In particular, globalisation appears to be encouraging, if not demanding, a decline in social spending and standards. However, many authors believe that this thesis ignores the continued impact of national political and ideological pressures and lobby groups on policy outcomes. In particular, it has been argued that national welfare consumer and provider groups remain influential defenders of the welfare state. For example, US aged care groups are considered to be particularly effective defenders of social security pensions. According to this argument, governments engaged in welfare retrenchment may experience considerable electoral backlash (Pierson 1996; Mishra 1999). Yet, it is also noted that governments can take action to reduce the impact of such groups by reducing their funding, and their access to policy-making and consultation processes. These actions are then justified on the basis of removing potential obstacles to economic competitiveness (Pierson 1994; Melville 1999). Adapted from the source document.

Youth and Health as an Issue of Research in Social Work -- Two Examples of Current Research

Author: Stumpp, Gabriele11 Instit Erziehungswissenschaft, U Tubingen

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61376933?accountid=14925

Abstract: Health issues under aspects pertaining to social work are currently being investigated in our department under two main perspectives. The study of Youth, Health, and Internet is based on experiences with a project of e-mail counseling for youths we have been running in our department for one year so far. Our thesis is that the internet has become an important platform for youngsters in general as well as concerning health issues specifically. So far, however, little is known about the ways youths address their health related problems in the net. We believe that research in this area is badly needed since future concepts of effective health improvement and prevention for youths cannot ignore this medium. Biography and Health is our second focus of investigation, addressing deficiencies in the empirical research of Aaron Antonovsky s salutogenetic concept that has lately become quite popular in many health discussions. Drawing from biographical methods we are currently investigating the development of the so called "sense of coherence" -- the center piece of salutogenesis. Adapted from the source document.

Professional Development of Social Work in Russia

Author: Iarskala-Smirnova, Elena; Romanov, Pavel; Lovtsova, Natalia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61377313?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of the paper was to get an understanding about how the profession of social work explains its relevance and legitimacy in today's Russia, to enlighten the importance of socio-political, professional and educational contexts in explaining the societal position of the social work profession in Russia. This paper begins with the analysis of the processes of legitimization, professionalization and constitution of social work in today's Russia. In addition to functionalist and critical perspectives on these three processes, in its second part the paper employs phenomenological approach looking into everyday life theory of social work that is constructed in routine work at the social service agencies. The third part of this paper talks about the issues of social services and social work with family and children in contemporary Russia. Adapted from the source document.

Neoliberalism, the Third Way and Social Work: The UK Experience

Author: Ferguson, Iain11 U Stirling

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61382287?accountid=14925

Abstract: For most of the past two decades, the notion that there is no alternative to the market as a basis for organising society has constituted a kind of global 'common sense', accepted not only by the neo-liberal Right but also by social democratic thinkers and politicians, in the form of 'the Third Way'. This paper will critically assess the central claims of neoliberalism in the light of experience in the UK and internationally, evaluate the ways in which Third Way policies are shaping social work in the UK, and in the final section, begin to explore some of the ways in which the anti-capitalist movement which has emerged in recent years might contribute to the development of a new, engaged social work, based on social justice. Adapted from the source document.

Different Levels of Policy Change: A Comparison between the Public Discussion on Social Security in Sweden and in Finland

Author: Kroll, Christian1; Blomberg, Helena1 Swedish School Social Science, Research Instit, U Helsinki christian.kroll@thelsinki.fi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61377990?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article compares & contrasts historical social-insurance debates in Finland & Sweden. Major topics surveyed include the different levels of policymaking & their implications, the justifications for changes in welfare policy, & different levels of change in the social-insurance system. Data is presented that reflects different types of suggestions of policy changes in the Swedish & Finnish debates on social insurance in 1987, 1993, & 1997. Data is also presented that reflects the different types of justifications in the Finnish & Swedish debates on social insurance from 1987 to 1997. There is also a discussion of different actors' suggestions of retrenchment in social insurance in Finland & Sweden in the 1990s. These actors include socialist politicians, socialist newspapers, non-socialist politicians, non-socialist newspapers, experts of various types, & other advocates. Using the available data, the article concludes that significant shifts in structural realities are necessary before any public debate on social-insurance retrenchment can gain significant traction. Tables, Figures, Appendixes, References. R. Young

Modernising Social Work and the Ethics of Care

Author: Meagher, Gabrielle1; Parton, Nigel1 U Sydney

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61398627?accountid=14925

Abstract: Recent attempts to 'modernise' social work have emphasised the importance of collaboration, partnership, and participation with individual users of services and the wider community. However, technical-rational aspects of managerialism have proved dominant. Managerialist approaches to social service administration and delivery threaten important dimensions of social work; specifically its caring and democratic-transformative dimensions. However, social work theorists have only recently begun to re-engage with ideas of care. We argue that closer attention to feminist debates about the ethics of care can make a significant contribution to not only rehabilitating the ideal of care for social work but also to moving forward the modernisation agenda itself. We develop a feminist critique of managerialism, and argue that the discourse of the ethics of care offers useful ways of framing arguments to counter some damaging impacts of managerial reforms. Adapted from the source document.

Changing Europe and the Relevance of Care and the Caring Professions

Author: Bruckner, Margrit11 Fachhochschule Frankfurt

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61382334?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of the paper is to introduce the challenges of the international care debate of the last ten years in order to grasp basic social needs, to analyse their treatment in the public and private sphere and to look at the orientation of professional answers by the care-professions. The concept of care enhances the societal dealing with -- or ignoring of -- different forms of dependency on informal and formal personal and social services throughout the life-cycle (child-care, nursing sick or handicapped persons, supporting the elderly) and in special life situations (from help to lone mothers and their children, via help to drug-addicts to help for homeless people). All societies have different approaches to deal with these life-situations, they do so by employing various mixtures of: familial support, mostly provided by women, social politics, organized by the state, & public and/or private social services. This welfare-mix shows different combinations of private and public obligations, paid and und unpaid work, professional and laymen's tasks based on a specific understanding of morality and justice embedded in the gender structure and intergenerational relationships. The importance of social work as a profession in this context differs according to the historical developments and cultural traditions. Characteristic for the profile of social work is the relevance of a care ethics and the existence of social rights, the tension of mothering and professional methods, the relationship between help, denial and punishment and the ways of institutionalisation. The actuality of this debate is closely intertwined with the restructuring of societal bonds in the face of globalisation, the political reorganisation of states, the changes in the living together of different generations and both sexes and the consequences for the organisation and contents of welfare. Looking at Germany and Eastern Europe two new phenomena of social relevance for the discussion of care work and care needs can be taken as an example: the extent of cheap illegal women laborers travelling between east and west, especially Polish women working intermittendly in private care for old people and the highly organized trafficking of women from Russia to Germany to work in the sex business. The care debate entails a reframing of welfare issues in the light of social justice between classes, ethnicities and gender groups. Adapted from the source document.

Social Support Quality in Internet Based Information and Communication: From "Digital Divide" to "Voice Divide"

Author: Klein, Alexandra

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61376991?accountid=14925

Abstract: National and international studies demonstrate that the number of teenagers using the internet increases. But even though they actually do have access from different places to the information and communication pool of the internet, there is evidence that the ways in which teenagers use the net -- regarding the scope and frequency in which services are used as well as the preferences for different contents of these services -- differ significantly in relation to socio-economic status, education, and gender. The results of the regarding empirical studies may be summarised as such: teenager with low (formal) education especially use internet services embracing 'entertainment, play and fun' while higher educated teenagers (also) prefer intellectually more demanding and particularly services supplying a greater variety of communicative and informative activities. More generally, pedagogical and sociological studies investigating "digital divide" in a differentiated and sophisticated way -- i.e. not only in terms of differences between those who do have access to the Internet and those who do not -- suggest that the internet is no space beyond 'social reality' (e.g. DiMaggio & Hargittai 2001, 2003; Vogelgesang, 2002; Welling, 2003). Different modes of utilisation, that structure the internet as a social space are primarily a specific contextualisation of the latter -- and thus, the opportunities and constraints in virtual world of the internet are not less than those in the 'real world' related to unequal distributions of material, social and cultural resources as well as social embeddings of the actors involved. This fact of inequality is also true regarding the outcomes of using the internet. Empirical and theoretical results concerning forms and processes of networking and community building -- i.e. sociability in the internet, as well as the social embeddings of the users which are mediated through the internet -- suggest that net based communication and information processes may entail the resource 'social support'. Thus, with reference to social work and the task of compensating the reproduction of social disadvantages -- whether they are medial or not -- the ways in which teenagers get access to and utilize net based social support are to be analysed. Adapted from the source document.

Seniors in Society. Strategies to Retain Individual Autonomy

Author: Louckova, Ivana1; Sykorova, Dana1 Zdravotne sociallni fakulta, Ostravske U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61373022?accountid=14925

Abstract: The research project on "Seniors in Society. Strategies to Retain Individual Autonomy" (2002-2004) is supported by the Grant Agency of the Czech Republic. It's importance is emphasized by the relevance of social and economic aspects of demographic ageing of the population and that of fundamental changes associated with the transformation of Czech society. The objectives of the research are (1) to find out seniors' material and social resources sup-porting their relative autonomy in everyday life, (2) to record their personal expectations from state, community, or formal and informal support and aid institutions, respectively, and (3) to uncover their engagement in social interaction and individual experiencing of the integration into social groups. The data acquired become the base for (4) identifying the typologies corresponding to the levels of seniors' social integration (i.e. groups of relatives, friends, neighbours, special-interest and professional groups). By applying qualitative methods, we explore (5) strategies of everyday life and coping with life cycle events and crisis within particular types. Special attention is paid to the family background of the seniors, including relatives in the vertical line. Specifically, we focus on (6) conditions under which family is capable and willing to help or actually is helping it's oldest members, as well as on their interpretation within (7) identified types of the relatives supportive systems. Adapted from the source document.

Some Considerations on the Potential Contributions of Intercultural Social Work

Author: Fook, Jan11 Deakin U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61390394?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work at global levels, and across international and intercultural divides, is probably more important now than ever before in our history. It may be that the very form our ideas about intercultural work take need to be re-examined in the light of recent global changes and uncertainties. In this short position paper I wish to offer some considerations about how we might approach the field of intercultural social work in order to gain new insights about how we practise at both local and global levels. For me, much of the promise of an intercultural social work (and for the purposes of this paper I see aspects of international social work in much the same light) lies in its focus on the way we categorise ourselves, our ideas and experiences in relation to others. The very notion of intercultural or international social work is based on assumptions about boundaries, differences, ways of differentiating and defining sets of experiences. Whether these are deemed "cultural" or "national" is of less importance. Once we are forced to examine these assumptions, about how and why we categorise ourselves in relation to other people in particular ways, the way is opened up for us to be much more critical about the bases of our own, often very deep-seated, thinking. This understanding, about how and why notions of 'difference' operate in the way they do, can potentially open our understanding to all the other ways, besides cultural or national labelling, in which we categorise and create differences between ourselves and others. Intercultural social work, taken as a potential site for understanding the creation of difference then, has the potential to help us critically examine the bases of much of our practice in any setting, since most practice involves some kind of categorisation of phenomena. Adapted from the source document.

International Social Work Education at the Crossroads

Author: Dominelli, Lena11 IASSW

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61395050?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work has been a player in the international arena since 1928 when the International Association of Schools of Social Work (IASSW) was founded alongside its sister organisations, the International Federation of Social Workers (IFSW) and the International Council for Social Welfare (ICSW). These divided their remit into education, practice and policy respectively. Their development has been an interesting one, but the details of it need not detain us here. I only want to lay aside the argument that having an interest in the international domain is a new phenomenon in social work. At the same time, I want to emphasise how impressive it is that a profession that has been so tied into modernity, linked to the modern nation-state (Lorenz, 1994) and rooted in local legislation and traditions has such a long-standing history of involvements that have crossed borders to promote understanding and knowledge-building. In these encounters, social work educators and practitioners have engaged with others who were different from them while struggling to make their interactions egalitarian and respectful ones. This aim has been thwarted by a range of factors that those acting in this domain had to address, namely, the contradictory position of the profession in negotiating its idealistic ambitions within the realities of the messy politics of practice as altruistic motives clashed with proselytising values and imperialistic adventures. For in the world of national aggrandisement embedded in the belief in the superiority of one particular people or 'race' and its culture excluding those outside its boundaries and 'doing good' to them were unquestioned assumptions that created great wrongs as languages, peoples and cultures disappeared under messianic and imperialistic rule. Consequently, some of social work's international initiatives have been successful in promoting egalitarian relations, others have not. In this paper, I will consider some of the issues that those promoting international social work today have to address if their efforts are not to become another means of propagating inegalitarian or neo-imperialist relations between educators and practitioners in high-income countries and those in low-income ones. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Education and Training in Europe and the Bologna Process

Author: Labonte-Roset, Christine11 EASSW

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61401192?accountid=14925

Abstract: A short review of the last three decades shows that social work programmes have developed similarly in (almost) all European countries, both in terms of structural and content-related characteristics. Here I would like to focus on the following aspects: (1) Increased academic focus of training, (2) Generalist programme, & (3) international/European orientation. Increased academic focus means that social work programmes have been established at universities or comparable higher education institutions, such as universities of applied sciences. The only exception is France where the approximately 150, generally fairly small colleges and the 14 larger instituts regionaux have a hybrid position between vocational colleges and universities and are roughly comparable to academies. Adapted from the source document.

The Impact of Job Characteristics on Social and Human Service Workers

Author: Allen, Reva I1; Lamberg, Eric G; Pasupuleti, Sudershan; Cluse-Tolar, Terry; Ventura, Lois A1 c/o Cluse-Tolar -- Dept Social Work, Coll Heath & Human Services, U Toledo, OH

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61355426?accountid=14925

Abstract: The work environment characteristics of job stress, job variety, job autonomy, & supervision are theorized to affect the job satisfaction & organizational commitment of social & human service workers. Most research to date has focused upon the impact of these variables on job satisfaction, with little attention being paid to organizational commitment. To determine the effects these characteristics have on both job satisfaction & organizational commitment, data from a survey of social & human service employees across Northwest Ohio were examined. In Ordinary Least Squares regression, all four job characteristics had a significant impact on job satisfaction, while only job variety & supervision had statistically significant effects on organizational commitment. Tables, Appendixes, References. Adapted from the source document.

Running Head: Social Work Developments in Lithuania

Author: Swindell, Marian L11 Mississippi State U, Meridian mswindell@meridian.msstate.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61399432?accountid=14925

Abstract: Following the end of a half-century of Soviet occupation, Lithuania, like other former Soviet republics, has been in socio-economic disorder. Now that Lithuania is free, the system of social welfare is characterized by under-funded health services & pensions, & a large number of institutions. Semi-structured interviews were conducted with students & practitioners focusing on community development, using Lofland's model of social setting analysis. Results indicate that the collaborative efforts successfully produced a revolutionary & successful social service program, a multi-generational living facility offering full-time social services to unwed mothers, infants, & elderly residents. This article is based upon the qualitative study of social work practitioners & social work students & chronicles the successes & difficulties encountered within the process of community development. References. Adapted from the source document.

Access for All? The Promise and Problems of Universalism

Author: Clarke, John11 Faculty Social Sciences, Open U, Milton Keynes, UK john.clarke@open.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61382198?accountid=14925

Abstract: In what follows, I explore why the question of 'access for all' is both important & difficult. Beginning by treating it as a contested claim, I will consider some of its political, institutional & professional implications. What do I mean by saying that access for all is a contested claim? First of all, it is a claim -- a demand that access for all needs to be created. It is a claim about change. To demand 'access for all' is to speak about, & speak against, social conditions that are unjust, unequal or excluding. At its simplest, then, to claim 'access for all' is to address social arrangements in which all people do not have access. Secondly, it is a claim made by -- or on behalf of -- specific social groups against their experience of exclusion, marginalization or subordination. I have added these other terms because I think that 'exclusion' is too simple, & too problematic, a term to capture all the aspects of unjust social arrangements that produce claims for 'access'. Access is a demand to be treated equitably in relation to a range of valued social resources, conditions & relationships. It is a claim to be a member: of the society, the polity or the nation. It is a claim to be a citizen: to possess rights & the capacity to make legitimate demands on the state. It is a claim on the apparatuses & agencies that sustain social citizenship: citizenship brings with it access to benefits, services & rights of 'fair dealing' or 'fair treatment'. As this last point suggests, it is a claim about equality: the expectation that all citizens will be dealt with by public agencies in ways that are not discriminatory or oppressive. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Access+for+All%3F+The+Promise+and+Problems+of+Universalism&amp;author=Clarke%2C+John&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2004-01-01&amp;spage=216&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

A Perfect 'Treatment-Society'?

Author: Jensen, Niels Rosendal11 Danish U Education, Copenhagen nrj@dpu.dk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61373792?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Danish Minister of Social Affairs is a very eager protagonist of quality in treatment, almost searching for the "perfect" treatment for children, youngsters, disabled, etc. Many expensive research projects dealing with quality management as well as developmental projects have been launched during the latest years in order to improve professional practice. Within that context this article will deal with the relations between paternalism & ignorance & between pro-social behaviour & anti-social treatment in order to grasp "why professions are doing vicious things." The main focus is concerned with the knowledge field of social pedagogy. References. Adapted from the source document.

KIWAKKUKI -- Women Fight against HIV/AIDS. An Encouraging Example for Social Work in Tanzania

Author: Strauch, Iris; Eickhoff, Anne Beatrice

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61397829?accountid=14925

Abstract: For 20 years, AIDS has continued its relentless spread across the globe. By the end of the year 2000, the United Nations' Joint Programme on HIV/AIDS reported that 36.1 million men, women, & children around the world were living with HIV & 21.8 million had died of it. Though AIDS is now found in every country, it has most seriously affected sub-Saharan Africa -- home to 70% of all adults & 80% of all children living with HIV, & the continent with the least medical resources in the world. Today, AIDS is the primary cause of death in Africa & it has had a devastating impact on villages, communities & families. In many African countries, the number of newly infected persons is increasing at a rate that is threatening to destroy the social fabric. Life expectancy is decreasing rapidly in many of these countries as a result of AIDS related illnesses & socioeconomic problems. Of the approximately 13.2 million children orphaned by HIV/AIDS worldwide, 12.1 million live in Africa. References. Adapted from the source document.

Structural Problems in the Development of Social Work in Central Europe under Transformation. The Case of Poland

Author: Szmagalski, Jerzy

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61397258?accountid=14925

Abstract: Socio-economic transformation the countries of Central Europe are undergoing since 1989 has brought new developments in social welfare systems of this region. Social work, which was in the countries of the region during their communist past either non-existent or a superficial activity, has come to be reated as an instrument of social welfare systems there. The collapse of authoritarian regimes in the region clearly induced political leaderships there to opt for transition to Western style civil society. Hence adoption of social work seemed to be natural choice for the countries in the region. Adapted from the source document.

Position, Professional Expertise and Functions of an Educator of Child Care Homes in Lithuania

Author: Rupsiene, Luidmila1; Leliugiene, Irina1 Dept Social Pedagogy, Klaipeda U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61382154?accountid=14925

Abstract: Speaking about professionals working with children at child care homes in Lithuania, first of all we encounter a problem of terminology. This problem arises because in various countries & languages we call these professionals differently. In Lithuania we call them "aukletojai". We also use the word "aukletojas" when speaking about both professionals working directly with children at kindergartens, & parents, as all parents are educators of their children. We suppose, that the word 'aukletojas' corresponds to the German "erzieher", & "aukleti" to "erziehen". Every "aukletojas" in Lithuania clearly realizes that he is a pedagogue, because in this country every professional, involved in educational work with children -- an "aukletojas", a teacher, a social pedagogue & a special pedagogue -- is called a pedagogue. In this context it is essential to conceive that in Lithuania an "educator" & a "social pedagogue" are different pedagogical professions & that none of the "aukletojas" identify himself as a social pedagogue. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

The Impact of Western Social Workers in Romania -- A Fine Line between Empowerment and Disempowerment

Author: Dumling, Bianca

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61355381?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores the impact of Western social workers in post-Communist Romania. The transition from a planned to a market economy meant ended full employment & significantly increased poverty & inequality. It is noted that Western involvement, which initially was mostly humanitarian, helped to alleviate human misery. However, as western social workers became more involved in training, community development, & prevention, their efforts often shifted from empowerment to disempowerment because of cultural differences. Emphasis is on the dilemma posed by the structure of international social work projects which are conditioned by Western grant guidelines that fail to consider root causes & inequalities that must be addressed before long-term, sustainable change can occur. The disempowerment experienced by Romanians working in international non-governmental organizations is described. It is concluded that empowerment can only take place if Western social workers recognize that their ideas are often incompatible with Romanian culture. Projects need to be re-designed with Romanians as the starting point rather than with concepts imported from the West. The implications for social work in other developing nations are discussed. References. J. Lindroth

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+Impact+of+Western+Social+Workers+in+Romania+--+A+Fine+Line+between+Empowerment+and+Disempowerment&amp;author=Dumling%2C+Bianca&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2004-01-01&amp;spage=270&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

About Social Work and Anti-Modernity

Author: Alayon, Norberto11 U Buenos Aires

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61395404?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article relies on the work of Gustavo Parra, as well as that of other social scientists, in order to argue that the character of social work in Argentina has always been conservative, often to the point of being anti-modern. The development of Argentine social work is traced from 1924 onward, with data presented from research conducted in 1934, 1977, 1992, & 1999. The data is complemented by contemporaneous observations. Argentine social work is found to be particular anti-modern in its attitudes toward public health & community well-being. Much of the blame is placed on the Roman Catholic Church, which held a good amount of political & social sway in Argentina throughout the twentieth century, & which used that power to impose a conservative & anti-modern imprint on social work & the social sciences in general. R. Young

Philosophy of Knowledge for Social Change

Author: Krishnaraj, Maithreyi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61434092?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article considers the essentials needed to link knowledge & social change. The author argues that a philosophy of knowledge that can promote social change has to have some normative goals. This knowledge has to be tempered by reason. Scientific inquiry, to the extent that it imposes the condition that its conclusions are backed by warrantable evidence, is a method that promotes reason. It does not claim that it can discover all of truth. The author stresses that knowledge has to be accessible to all so that individuals can make informed judgment. The more people participate in knowledge generation, the greater are the chances of progress in knowledge, a knowledge tempered by understanding. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Application of Qualitative Research Methodology for Developing Social Work Practice Models

Author: Mahtani, Rajshree P11 Unit Social Policy & Social Welfare Administration, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61496326?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article highlights the need to develop practice models in the field of social work so as to contribute to the overall development of social work knowledge. It is based on the assumption that both qualitative & quantitative methodologies rest on separate epistemological positions, which result in different goals of social research, as well as in divergence with regard to the manner in which the two methodologies pursue social knowledge. The article also recognizes the significant role of qualitative research methodology in developing social work practice models based on empirical research & discusses the nature of research design decisions required of this methodology. The essential features of qualitative research methodology, resulting from its epistemology, are first presented, so as to subsequently reflect on the essentially emergent nature of qualitative research design decisions, & their application to the development of social work practice models. Prior to discussing the nature of qualitative research design decisions, this paper examines the essential features of qualitative research methodology & outlines the nature of its contribution to knowledge development. 54 References. Adapted from the source document.

Cross Cultural Social Work in the Asia Pacific Rim

Author: Mehta, Kalyani1; Vasoo, S1 Dept Social Work & Psychology, National U Singapore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61509768?accountid=14925

Abstract: An introduction to this special issue notes the relevancy of this topic in light of the increased attention being given to the changing geopolitical map since the terrorist attacks against the US on 11 September 2001. Many Asian nations have had to deal with the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the heels of an economic crisis. When added to the Israel-Palestinian conflict, the North Korea nuclear issues, bombings in Bali, Jakarta, & Mumbai, & increased ethnic/religious conflicts, it becomes obvious that the need for crosscultural understanding has never been greater. Differences between social work & counseling are discussed, along with the impact of cultural factors on clients, & the need to make cultural understanding an integral part of policies, services, & legal provisions. Social workers are described as "ambassadors of crosscultural understanding" & suggestions are made for ways that they can enhance such understanding. Readers are asked to submit articles that describe innovative projects. J. Lindroth

Collaborative Practice across Borders: Experiences of Australian Social Work Practice in East Timor, 2000-1

Author: Rowlands, Alison11 Dept Social Work & Psychology, National U Singapore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61533253?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article describes aspects of social work intervention by Australian practitioners in Timor Loro Sa'e (East Timor) in 2000/01. It draws on the author's experience there & describes the role of an Australian government-funded community mental health service. East Timor is the world's newest nation & is in the process of rebuilding itself across all dimensions -- physical, economic, political, social, environmental, & personal. The author reflects on the contribution of social work to this development process & poses questions that challenged colleagues working in the agency. It is argued that a human rights perspective provides a framework for Western social work practice in situations such as the rebuilding of East Timor. 2 Tables, 44 References. Drawing Lessons from Local Designated Helpers to Develop Culturally Appropriate Social Work Practice

Author: Kee, Ling How11 Faculty Social Sciences, U Malaysia, Sarawak

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61538442?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper describes a study that explored the underlying cultural themes of the helping approaches of a group of local designated helpers in Sarawak, Malaysia. In drawing lessons for developing culturally appropriate practice, an important finding is the mutuality of worldviews between the cultural themes of the helpers & the help seekers. Insights can also be drawn from the creative synthesis of the "old" & the "new.". 2 Tables, 1 Appendix, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Service Needs Assessment in Global Work Environments: A Comparative Study between American Expatriates in South Korea and Korean Expatriates in the United States

Author: Choi, Soochan11 School Social Welfare, Yonsei U, South Korea

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61533289?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study examined social service needs of American expatriates in South Korea & Korean expatriates in the US on the basis of problems they experienced in the host country & services they would like to see developed. The findings suggested that the respondents were mainly concerned about language barriers, elderly parents back home, & children's schooling. Correspondingly, they desired social services such as language training, services for elderly parents, & school counseling for children. The results call for practical social work interventions for global workers. 3 Tables, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Traditional Confucian Concepts of Mental Health: Its Implications to Social Work Practice with Chinese Communities

Author: Yip, Kam-shing11 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61500438?accountid=14925

Abstract: The traditional Confucian concept of mental health has a strong impact on the mental health of Chinese people. It stresses submissiveness of individuals to achieve harmony of the collective. Harmony is defined by the social order & authority figures in various social systems. It encourages people to restrain their emotions, avoid interpersonal conflicts, & suppress individual rights so as to maintain a good harmony with others. Social workers should be aware of this cultural difference when working with the Chinese communities. They should recognize the dilemmas in empowerment vs tolerance, changing of social environment vs suppressive collective harmony, cognition & emotional change vs rigid moralization, self-actualization vs self-sacrifice, emotional ventilation vs emotional restraint, self-determination vs self-definition by others, & mutual support vs egocentric preservation. 1 Figure, 71 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Traditional+Confucian+Concepts+of+Mental+Health%3A+Its+Implications+to+Social+Work+Practice+with+Chinese+Communities&amp;title=Asia+Pacific+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02185385&amp;date=2003-12-01&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=65&amp;author=Yip%2C+Kam-shing

Making Stepfamilies Work: Step-Relationships in Singaporean Stepfamilies

Author: Webber, Ruth11 Faculty Arts & Sciences, Australian Catholic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61504366?accountid=14925

Abstract: The project sought to identify the issues facing Singaporean stepfamilies. It involved 54 service providers who attended "Stepfamily Training" workshops organized by the Asian Women's Welfare Assoc (AWWA) & Family Resource & Training Centre (FRTC). Results indicate that stepfathers were more likely than stepmothers to adopt the roles of authority figure & acquaintance, while stepmothers were more likely than stepfathers to adopt the roles of confidant, rival & opponent. 3 Tables, 33 References. Abstract: Community-based intervention with young offenders has been highly favored in recent decades. This paper presents a recent qualitative study on the effectiveness of such a service project in Hong Kong. This project has employed the social bond theory of Travis Hirschi (1969) as its conceptual framework. Interactions between Field Workers and Their Clients and Superiors in Non-Governmental Organisations

Author: Ahmad, Mokbul Morshed11 Dept Geography & Environment, Dhaka U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61554137?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article deals with the interaction between the field workers & their clients & between field workers & their immediate superiors. This discussion is important for three main reasons. First, it is important to know how field workers interact with their clients & their immediate superiors. Second, from a 'development' point of view, it is important to see how policies & decisions are filtered down from the top to the field workers & how field workers pass them on to their clients. Third, it is very important for the NGO management to know how or whether the problems or opinions of the clients are taken into consideration in the short- or long-term planning of the NGOs. 3 Tables, 15 References. The Social Work Profession's Concern for Gerontology

Author: Srivastava, Vineeta11 Udaipur School Social Work

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61494888?accountid=14925

Abstract: By analyzing the problems of the aged & the causes thereof, & identifying the factors contributing to satisfaction or dissatisfaction in old age, professional social workers can offer immense help to the aged in contemporary Indian society. Enabling the aged in reality perception & adjustment by providing the required information (role of an enabler); bringing about necessary changes in the attitude & behavior patterns through required guidance & counseling (role as a guide); getting the desired changes in public policy & social legislation introduced (role of an advocate & change agent); contacting different departments/organizations/agencies providing services for the aged & acting as a link between them & the aged (role of a liaison person); ensuring availability of different types of services in an integrated manner (role of a coordinator); mobilizing community resources to meet out the needs of the aged (role of a community organizer); protesting & lobbying against the unjust practices of various government & nongovernment organizations -- for example, not properly utilizing the funds meant for the aged, corruption or carelessness in disbursing the old age pension, employing nonprofessionals where social workers need to be employed -- (role of a social activist); & similar strategies may be adopted by the social workers to resolve the problems faced by the aged. This article is an attempt to analyze how far the social work profession has been successful in fulfilling its responsibilities towards the aged. The article begins by throwing some light on the international & national efforts to tackle the challenges of 'ageing populations.'. 3 Tables, 1 Figure, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Care or Control: The Struggles of Probation Officers in Working with Young Probationers Who Abused Psychotropic Drugs in Hong Kong

Author: Sim, Timothy11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499057?accountid=14925

Abstract: Psychotropic drug abuse among young persons below 21 years old has been increasing at an alarming rate in Hong Kong recently. Probation officers when working with young probationers who abuse psychotropic drugs need to contend not only with a complex phenomenon, but be challenged by the dilemmas of the nature of their profession between care & control. This article, by drawing from a discussion with a group of probation officers & feedback from a group of young probationers, raises some issues & questions for probation service in Hong Kong pertaining to working with young probationers who abuse psychotropic drugs. Some suggestions are made for probation officers to achieve more effective planning & interventions in working with young probationers who abuse psychotropic drugs. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Toward an International Society

Author: Mohan, Brij11 Louisiana State U, Baton Rouge swmoha@lsu.edu

Abstract: The chimeras of hope are fraught with delusions. However, social work education can truly universalize basic constructs of a society that transcends national boundaries toward world citizenship. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Analyzing Ten Critical Issues on the Development of Social Work Education in China

Author: Liu, Ji-tong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61548028?accountid=14925

Abstract: The revival & development of social work education in the People's Republic of China was a brilliant process evidencing achievements in the past 20 years. In contextual moves toward market orientation & welfare toward socialization, social work education faces debates & dilemmas. In terms of literature review, the article clearly shows ten critical issues for social work education development in China, briefly reviews their historical development, objectively describes all kinds of debate related to them, comprehensively analyzes the dilemmas in dealing with them, & theoretically summarizes the ideal category for them. The conclusion of the article is that Chinese social work education must respond to the special environments & varying needs of Chinese society & establish the partnership with the policy-making government departments, official welfare organizations & NGO in Chinese society. 54 References. Paradigm Shift: Social Welfare and Social Work in the New Society

Author: Fung, Ho-lup

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61534935?accountid=14925

Abstract: Under the new society of globalization, marketization, & programization, there was a paradigm shift in social welfare & social work. The two meanings of social welfare -- the state of well-being & the political relationship between the state & its people -- were being reconstructed. Productivity began to replace the sense of well-being, & "tough love" also replaced kindness. Professional autonomy & the close relationship of "worker-client" of social work were also deconstructed. What should social work, as a force of gradual social reform, do to this paradigm shift? 34 References. Adapted from the source document.
