A Critical Review of Social Work Practice with Post-Divorce Families in Hong Kong

Author: Lau, Yuk-king11 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin, NT yklau@cuhk.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499142?accountid=14925

Abstract: In Hong Kong, post-divorce families have long been conceptualized as "single-parent families," thereby overlooking the fact that some nonresident parents do have continuous participation in the postdivorce families. With this overgeneralized conceptualization, social services have been focusing on bringing about successful single parenting & have ignored the possibility of postdivorce co-parenting & nonresidential parenting in these families. It also reinforces the win-lose dichotomy in fighting over child custody. The author recommends reconceptualizing the post-divorce families as "binuclear families" to draw our attention to the possible participation & influence of the nonresident parents in these families. Promotion of forever-parenthood & family law reform would also help to induce change in the dominant social discourse. We need more empirical research on postdivorce families to clear the obscured picture & facilitate the formulation of an inclusive practice model with these families. Last but not least, as co-constructors of the social discourse on families in alternate forms such as postdivorce families, social work practitioners should enhance their reflexivity on family ideologies & beliefs in parent-child relationships. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Prevalence, Role and Functions of Self-Help Groups in Hong Kong

Author: Mok, Bong-ho1; Chau, Kin-lam; Fung, Ho-lup; Ngai, Ngan-pun1 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin, NT

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499082?accountid=14925

Abstract: Draws on 1999/00 structured self-administered questionnaire data from 100 self-help groups (total N = 719 members) in Hong Kong to explore the prevalence & characteristics of self-help groups, their role & functions, their life cycle, & their relationship to the social work profession. Some 211 self-help groups with 32,657 members were identified. The five most common objectives are to promote a spirit of self-help & mutual help, exchange information & knowledge, develop problem-solving ability & share experience, provide care & emotional support, & develop support networks. The five most common activities are recreational activities, group discussion & sharing, seminars, social service organization visits, & volunteerism. Effecting community or social policy change does not appear to be a concern. The extent to which members sensed individual change in feelings, thought, and behavior is examined, identifying three mechanisms for change: (1) social learning opportunities; (2) receiving & accepting the reality of having disabilities; & (3) social network expansion. Benefits of belonging to a group are noted, & member sense of collective empowerment is described. 6 Figures, 9 References. J. Zendejas

Psychosocial Adjustment of Chinese Adolescents with Economic Disadvantage: A Pioneer Longitudinal Study in Hong Kong

Author: Shek, Daniel T L1; Lam, C M; Lam, M C; Tang, M Y; Tsang, K M; Tsoi, K W1 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin, NT danielshek@cuhk.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61504878?accountid=14925

Abstract: Although studies have been carried out to examine factors associated with the psychosocial adjustment of adolescents with economic disadvantage, there are several limitations of the existing literature. (1) Available studies have been mainly conducted in Western contexts & scientific studies based on Chinese people are almost nonexistent. (2) A review of the literature shows that existing studies are mainly cross-sectional in nature & few longitudinal attempts have been carried out to understand the development of poor adolescents across time. (3) There are few existing studies in which a wide range of adolescent developmental outcomes is included. Finally, there have been to date few related studies in which both parents & adolescents are included in a single study. Against this background, this study attempts to examine the relationships between a number of factors at different ecological systems & psychosocial adjustment of poor Chinese adolescents over time. 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Quality Improvement Centers on Child Protective Services and Adoption: Testing a Regionalized Approach to Building the Evidence Base -- A Federal Perspective

Author: Brodowski, Melissa Lim1; Flanzer, Sally; Nolan, Catherine; Kaye, Elyse1 Office Child Abuse & Neglect, Children's Burueau, Administration Children & Families, US Dept Health & Human Services mbrodowski@acf.hhs.gov

Abstract: Each year, the US Dept of Health & Human Services, Administration for Children & Families, Children's Bureau spends approximately $110 million on discretionary activities to fund a variety of research & demonstration grants, training & technical assistance cooperative agreements, & multiyear research contracts with the purpose of building the knowledge base for child abuse & neglect & child welfare services. As part of this effort, the Children's Bureau manages more than 200 grants, cooperative agreements, contracts, & interagency agreements, with most individual awards ranging from $100,000 to several million dollars per year. Each project is testing a specific research question or service model, covering a wide range of topics related to child maltreatment, child protective services, child welfare, adoption, & child abuse & neglect prevention, treatment, & intervention (US Dept of Health & Human Services, 2003). Meeting Transformational Challenges: Continuing Education Leadership

Author: Kelly, Michael J1; Lauderdale, Michael L1 School Social Work, U Missouri, Columbia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61534964?accountid=14925

Abstract: Organizations & leadership are faced with challenges different for any of those of the 20th century. Changes in the fundamental relationships between all formal organizations & their environments are most pronounced in well-developed countries. The first year of the 21st century appears to have signaled the end of a two-decade-long economic boom & ushered in shrinkage of federal, state, local, & nonprofit spending. Organizations have adjusted by reducing the workforce or discontinuing programs. Important alternatives exist, but they require creating new structures that can transform existing organizations to re-couple with the environment in way that can cope with these new circumstances. Professional continuing education has an important role to play in creating transformational organizations through developing the tools & training the leaders. The authors' experience with the survey of organizational excellence (SOE) & related tools may provide an example of how this can be done. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Improving Clinical Supervisory Practice in Front Line CPS Supervisors: A Mentoring Model

Author: Griffin, Carol1; Shiell, Debbie1 MidSOUTH, U Arkansas, Little Rock cmgriffin@midsouth.ualr.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61558087?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Arkansas Division of Children & Family Services & IV-E training partners are implementing a model of supervision. This model will incorporate the interactional & educational components described by Shulman (1993) & Munson (1995) where supervision reflects the parallel process between worker-supervisor & worker-client relationship, along with the support element provide through a mentor. Specific techniques will be implemented, with the goal of improving the supervisor's knowledge & ability to enhance the supervisees' assessment skills. Workers will benefit from regular, structured, supportive contact with the supervisor that will improve the relationship between the worker & the supervisor. In theory, the enhanced relationship will result in greater job satisfaction & a decrease in worker turnover. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Role Demonstration Model of Supervision

Author: Sundet, Paul A1; Mermelstein, Joanne; Watt, J Wilson1 School Social Work, U Missouri sundetp@missouri.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61511006?accountid=14925

Abstract: Concern for the quality & effectiveness of child welfare supervision in MO has been a joint concern of the state agency & the U of Missouri-Columbia School of Social Work for some time. Twenty years ago these organizations collaborated on an intensive training project in this arena, the remnants of which are still impacting the system. Attempts to revive that initiative have since been hampered by the paucity of funds. However, when the Children's Bureau funded opportunity through the Quality Improvement Center at the U of Kentucky presented itself, both the administration of the Missouri Dept of Social Services & the School of Social Work saw a long-sought-for resource to draw on to address one of the most pressing workforce needs in this state. The challenges of developing a coherent model of supervision, imparting it to staff & rigorously evaluating its impact are considerable, but ones that the partners have eagerly accepted. The following paper details the model chosen, its rationale, & strategies chosen for implementation. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Vedic Theory of Clinical Social Work

Author: Wolf, David B11 Social Work Services Program, Dept Health, FL

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61494948?accountid=14925

Abstract: Using Fischer's model for the analysis & comparison of clinical theories of induced change, a theory of clinical social work based on Vedic principles & practices is presented & analyzed here. Vedic theory is consistent with social work values, & the theory provides, especially with regards to the three gunas as foundational psychological constructs, a strong basis for empirical verification. Additional research on the components of the Vedic model is encouraged, & application of Vedic philosophy & principles to social work environments is suggested as being useful & valid for social workers who are comfortable with the tenets of this model. 40 References. Social Welfare in Tamil Nadu Politics

Author: Rao, Vidya11 Dept Social Welfare Administration, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61494917?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social welfare, an all-encompassing concept, includes identity issues; opportunities for self-determination; well-being of the poor, vulnerable, & weak; a life with dignity & security; & not being coerced. This article traces the emergence of the party system in Tamil Nadu, a state in India, & highlights the fact that social welfare gets defined differently according to the political situation. It enumerates who raises which issues, how, & why. The article also points out that social welfare is inextricably intertwined with the political process, & that, ensuring social welfare is a political process. 2 Tables, 15 References. Living Conditions of Women Workers in Brick Kilns: Reflecting the Agenda for Social Work Intervention

Author: Mor, Singh11 Dept Social Work, Punjabi U, Patiala

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61507121?accountid=14925

Abstract: The present article looks into some of the aspects relating to housing, health, safety, education, & welfare facilities of women workers of the brick kilns industry. In spite of the pivotal role of this industry in the activities relating to the infrastructural development in the country, the living conditions of the workers in this industry are far from satisfactory. These women are unprotected & suffer from economic exploitation due to ignorance & illiteracy. They do arduous work for long hours, generally in unhygienic conditions effecting their health. Protective legislation in the critical areas of wages, maternity benefit, childcare, & social security have not benefited a great majority of them. The present article is based on a study done by the author on 54 brick kilns selected randomly out of a total of 547 units located in the five districts of the Hissar division of Haryana. 4 Tables, 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Kukanur, Huligeva1; Saroja, K1 Dept Human Development, Rural Home Science Coll, U Agricultural Sciences, Dharwad

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61553066?accountid=14925

Abstract: The present study was conducted during 1998-1999, where the sample comprising 52 Scheduled Caste (SC) & Scheduled Tribe (ST) & 48 non-SC & non-ST school dropouts & one of their parents or guardians. An interview schedule & personal observations were the major tools used for data collection. Results revealed that majority of the SC & ST school dropouts belonged to large-sized nuclear families with no landholding. They were found to have parents with little or no education, & who were engaged in agricultural labor work & caste occupation as compared to non-SC & non-ST dropouts. The SC & ST sample dropped out from school at a younger age than the non-SC & non-ST sample, because they were needed to work at home or to take care of younger siblings & graze the animals. A higher percentage of the SC & ST school drop-outs were found to be working as child laborers than the non-SC & non-STs. 9 Tables, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Hegemeony of Eurocentrism in Social Work Practice: From Race to Culture as Ecological Perspective vis-a-vis Southeast Asian Populations

Author: Hall, Ronald E11 Coll Human Medicine, Michigan State Coll, East Lansing

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61433983?accountid=14925

Abstract: Emergence of Southeast Asian populations in Western societies corresponds to Eurocentrism in social work practice. As per practice, race is assumed the universal, governing category of the social work clientele. It is on the basis of this hegemonic conceptual view that the construct of race is challenged by the emergence of alternative human population phenomena. For those who will engage in practice specific to the Southeast Asian populations, race must be reduced in proportion to its significance in their lives. The utilization of nonracial constructs includes the need for practitioners to acknowledge the ecological perspective & other culture specific belief systems. The outcome will contribute to the evolution of human well-being despite the prevalence of race constructs as hegemony vis-a-vis Southeast Asian populations. 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Changing Social Institutions and Their Impact on the Quality of Life

Author: Hebbar, Ritambhara11 Unit Rural Studies, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61507090?accountid=14925

Abstract: A report on the 2003 seminar, "Changing Social Institutions & their Impact on the Quality of Life," sponsored by the Indian Assoc of Social Science Institutions, presents an overview of the discussions related to the 11 paper presentations. Much attention was given to issues that helped place an understanding of social institutions in perspective, such as India's mixed economy that accommodates both the private & public sector in its vision of economic development; the failure of land reforms; the social/political dynamics of resistance & ethnic movements; & the impact of globalization/liberalization on economic, political, & social agendas. Other themes included decentralization, especially in regard to rural institutions, the importance of both formal & informal institutions, & the lack of financial autonomy for local bodies. The significant step toward democratic decentralization made by the 73rd Amendment Act 1992 is pointed out, noting that it grants decision-making powers to the village assembly. The discussions illustrated that administrative measures alone cannot ensure just & responsible governance, & effective institution building requires human resolve & endurance. J. Lindroth

Workplace Mobbing: A New Frontier for the Social Work Profession

Author: Reichert, Elisabeth11 School Social Work, Southern Illinois U, Carbondale ereich1234@cs.com

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61517777?accountid=14925

Abstract: In the US, abusive work environments perpetrated by a group against a target individual are well documented. Some European countries refer to this group action at the workplace as "mobbing." Mobbing can occur in any work environment & often leads to adverse emotional & other effects on both the individual & society as a whole. Because social workers are involved in workplace issues, they should be familiar with mobbing. However, the social work literature in the US does not address this issue. This article defines mobbing, examines characteristics & effects of mobbing, & explains why mobbing is a human rights violation. 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61481690?accountid=14925

Abstract: The need for staff trained in interdisciplinary settings is increasing in human services. Unfortunately, little distinction is made between teams that are multidisciplinary & teams that are interdisciplinary. This article describes an interdisciplinary internship effort in which social work & other students had opportunities to participate with various community multi- & interdisciplinary groups working with children with serious emotional disturbances & their families. The authors also describe the educational focus on delineating multi- vs interdisciplinary groups, & they present evaluation findings of these efforts. Finally, suggestions are provided for improving interdisciplinary educational opportunities in future community-based children's mental health initiatives. 2 Tables, 18 References. A Survey of County Public Child Welfare Agencies: Implications for Distance Learning

Author: Petracchi, Helen E11 School Social Work, U Pittsburgh, PA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61543984?accountid=14925

Abstract: Research on the potential utilization of multimedia in the distance education of public child welfare workers is extremely limited. This paper describes a survey of the presence of available information technology in PA's 67 public child welfare agencies, with special attention paid to administrative attitudes & the impact of this technology on distance education opportunities for the social workers in these agencies. With an 87% response rate, survey results suggest the technical capacity for onsite distance education of PA's public child welfare workers exists, in an environment in which there is also administrative support for this approach to training delivery. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 6 References. Tilting the Balance: The Case of Family Counselling Centres

Author: Majmudar, Sumant11 Dept Social Work, Gujarat Vidyapith, Ahmedabad

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61514413?accountid=14925

Abstract: The paper is an attempt to look at the newly developing service, the family counseling centers. They function in an enveloping ethos of severe problems in expressing oneself. It is observed in Gujarat that what is allowed is controlled expression under the constraints of 'family prestige' & 'compromise.' Skills development, hence, has to be oriented to the question: who is the client -- the woman or the family? The counselor's working alliance that also has to resolve the question of differing power potentials between the counselor & the woman client, then, is fraught with technical problems that highlight the need for continued training. Feminist social work has, of necessity, to be Indian culture specific & deal with the differing power potentials for egalitarian work to be a possibility. A change in the nomenclature to 'Family Crisis Centre,' in the above context, would open up channels of communication. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Counselling Families with Mentally Ill

Author: Anuradha, K11 Dept Social Work, S. P. Mahila U, Tirupati

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61514187?accountid=14925

Abstract: Mental illness, in general, & chronic mental health problems, in particular, cause a lot of distress to the affected individuals as well as their families. Families of the mentally ill experience emotional strain & a series of changes in their family functioning. A family counselor needs to understand the family dynamics, the emotional climate, & level of organization of the family. In this article, the author has outlined the purpose & goals for counseling families with mentally ill members. The skills required by a family counselor for such purpose are also given. The author has recommended a four-phased approach to counsel & empower families with mentally ill individuals. 1 Figure, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Integrated Team Model for Children and Youth Services: Yes or No?

Author: Lee, Francis W.-L.11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61558638?accountid=14925

Abstract: From ten Integrated Teams (ITs) established in late 1994 for the provision of children & youth services, with some eight years of development, in 2001 there were more than 60 ITs in the territory. At the end of June 2003, there were 130 ITs (or Integrated Children & Youth Service Centres -- ICYSCs) in the territory. It seems that employing an "Integrated Team Model" of the provision of children & youth services has gained the faith & confidence from the authority. However, the strengths & limitations encountered by youth workers in ITs have not been systematically explored. The present study, a questionnaire survey with all IT workers as targets, has mainly explored the workers' opinions on the effectiveness & feasibility of implementing ITs, the difficulties/limitations they have encountered & the suggested ways for improvement. Based on the findings, recommendations are made so that further development of the IT model for children & youth services could be more promising. 6 Tables, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

McSocial Work -- Professional Decadence in the United States

Author: Epstein, William M11 School Social Work, U Nevada, Las Vegas wepstein@ccmail.nevada.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61434263?accountid=14925

Abstract: Professional social work in the US is too often envied & too little understood. Its many failures of organization, scholarship, & purpose should encourage other nations to look to their own experiences in developing professions of helping. The process of professionalizing social services in the US has been impeded by widespread hostility to poorer & lower-status citizens. Yet social work itself is complicit with these attitudes, making free institutional choices that benefit the practitioner at the expense of the service recipient; by failing to develop a credible scholarship of service outcomes; by ignoring objective credentials in deference to implicit "experience"; by protecting mediocrity at the expense of quality; & by promoting psychological & individual explanations over structural explanations of social failure. Mortality may be the most hopeful vehicle of reform. 49 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Study of Marginal Youth's Likelihood and Delinquency in Hong Kong

Author: Ngai, Ngan-Pun1; Cheung, Chau-Kiu1 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61518787?accountid=14925

Abstract: A study of marginal youth living in Hong Kong examines delinquency theories; assesses the impact of social services, police, school, family, religion, & prevention work on delinquency; & forecasts delinquent involvement. Marginal youths are described as those who exhibit antisocial behavior or have committed criminal acts. Information was obtained from interviews conducted in 1999 with 229 Chinese residents of Hong Kong, aged 12-23, who were recruited by social work teams. Social control, social learning, strain, & cognitive development theories are considered in relation to the effect of experiences, perceptions, beliefs, & values on delinquent acts. The results of general linear modeling, regression analysis, & latent trait modeling show that social control, especially moral belief, significantly predicted a low likelihood of offenses. Social learning showed no significant effect on the likelihood of offense but cognitive development & strain, especially frustration, tended to significantly impact the decrease of the likelihood of offenses. Probation experience & counseling tended to decrease delinquent involvement & the use of psychotropic substances respectively; however, prior punishment by the police predicted greater delinquency involvement. The implications for intervention are discussed. 1 Table, 18 References. J. Lindroth

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=A+Study+of+Marginal+Youth%27s+Likelihood+and+Delinquency+in+Hong+Kong&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2003-01-01&amp;volume=37&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=229&amp;author=Ngai%2C+Ngan-Pun%3BCheung%2C+Chau-Kiu

Author: Evans, Jacquie11 North East Wales Instit Higher Education, Wrexham j.evans@newi.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61502775?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article sets out to look at the current interest in online learning & the uses it can have for students & practice teachers involved in professional social work training courses. It explores the difficulties that many people have in using online learning & also the advantages of taking part in this process. The author has studied the process of using online learning as a valuable teaching tool whilst the students are out on placement, & is keen to look at ways in which this would be a positive advantage to all involved in the training & development of social work students. Looking at a former model of the 'training team' the use of online learning is explored to see if this would enable a virtual training team to be established. Recent Trends in Multicultural Practice: Implications for Practice Teaching and Field Education

Author: Kaufman, Mark1; Love, Donna1 Dept Social Work, Washburn U, Topeka, KS mark.kaufman@washburn.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61513468?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article presents a three-part model for teaching students in the social service professions to become culturally competent practitioners from an Anglo-American perspective. It also discusses the importance of a multicultural perspective. The first part of the model emphasizes the importance of practitioner awareness of his or her own cultural values & biases. The second dimension of the model recognizes that a culturally competent practitioner seeks to understand the worldview & culture of the client, possesses some specific knowledge of diverse client groups & develops a basic understanding of sociopolitical influences. The final part of the model deals with the specific strategies, skills, & intervention techniques necessary to serve culturally diverse clients. 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Teacher or Supporter? The Social Work Tutor's Role in Students' Professional Development

Author: Degenhardt, Dorothy11 Dept Social Work, U Dundee d.c.degenhardt@dundee.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61479814?accountid=14925

Abstract: At a time of an ongoing review of social work education & training in Scotland it seems important to examine the role of the social work tutor in working with students & how their intervention is experienced as educative &/or supportive. Previous research has shown that tutorials, both group & individual, have scored low in students' perception of effectiveness in preparation for practice, as one of a range of teaching methods (Triseliotis & Marsh, 1996). A definition of the tutor's role will be considered from the author's experience across three social work programs in Scotland. Consideration is given to the interface between the tutor's role & practice teacher's role in helping students with issues on placement. The paper will argue that the tutor's role should be enhanced & clarified & could be pivotal in promoting students' professional development within the new social work programs proposed in Scotland. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

An Assessment of Multicultural Competence in Supervision: Implications for Continuing Education

Author: Smith, Sharon Hines11 School Social Work, Rutgers State U, Camden, NJ sash@camden.rutgers.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61539658?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study discusses findings from the administration of a self-assessment checklist of multicultural competencies in supervision to a group of 37 supervisors. The supervisors were from social-health agencies in NJ providing services to persons 65 years of age & older. Findings indicate that participants perceived themselves as competent in domains of cross-cultural knowledge, attitudes, & relationship building capacities but less competent in the application of cross-cultural skills. The implications of these findings for understanding distinctive multicultural interpersonal dynamics in supervision, conceptualizing cultural competence across multiple domains, & developing cross-cultural social work continuing education & training programs are also discussed. 1 Table, 40 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Emerging Field of Crime Victim Assistance: Are Social Workers Ready?

Author: Danis, Fran S11 School Social Work, U Missouri, Columbia danisf@missouri.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61511044?accountid=14925

Abstract: Assistance to victims of violent crimes is an emerging field of practice undergoing growth & expansion. Given a fit between social work generalist competencies & competencies needed for victim assistance, how well prepared are social workers for working with crime victims? A statewide survey of professional social workers was conducted to assess their academic preparation & their self-identified training needs. Despite a lack of specific course work, social workers have a great deal of experience in working with victims of violence. Survey respondents were also interested in a variety of topics focusing on direct practice with crime victims. 2 Tables, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Importance of Including Supervisors When Evaluating Child Welfare Workers' Training

Author: Mason, Susan E1; LaPorte, Heidi Heft; Frankel, Arthur1 Wurzweiler School Social Work, Yeshiva U, New York, NY

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61549533?accountid=14925

Abstract: Child welfare professional workers & their supervisors responded to surveys on training effectiveness three months after a series of staff development seminars. Participants in the seminars, which took place in the New York Metropolitan area, 1998-1999, volunteered the names of their agency supervisors & agreed that both they & their supervisors would be asked to complete a follow-up questionnaire on how attendees' professional behavior may have changed related to the staff development training. A total of 285 trainees & 115 supervisors returned mailed surveys with response rates of 82% & 47%, respectively. Training participants were more likely than their supervisors to think that co-workers & supervisors noticed changes in their work. Both groups thought that the training benefited clients but there was no formalized way of documenting this finding. Professional workers & their supervisors favored additional training even when perceptions of efficacy differed. This article demonstrates that in child welfare settings, workers & their supervisors may hold disparate perceptions about the specific benefits of staff development but are positive about its value in general. The authors suggest that good communication between professional workers & supervisors coupled with articulated & measurable agency goals would go a long way to enhance the long-term effectiveness of staff development. 3 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Importance+of+Including+Supervisors+When+Evaluating+Child+Welfare+Workers%27+Training&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2003-01-01&amp;volume=6&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=20&amp;author=Mason%2C+Susan+E%3BLaPorte%2C+Heidi+Heft%3BFrankel%2C+Arthur

Protective Services Caseworkers' Understanding of the DSM: Improving Risk Assessment through Professional Development Training

Author: Davidson, Jennifer C1; Levine, Joanne1 c/o Levine -- School Social Work, Wichita State U, KS

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61558130?accountid=14925

Abstract: Child & adult protective services caseworkers must be capable of understanding relevant information for risk assessment & care plans found in mental health evaluations that are formulated from information provided in the Diagnostic & Statistics Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV-TR). The literature suggests that many caseworkers are not trained to understand mental health assessments & the DSM-IVTR. Therefore, the vulnerable clients that these caseworkers serve may not receive optimal care. This article describes a professional development training module, designed to respond to this gap in training & knowledge often reported about protective services workers. The article provides an overview of the module as well as experiential exercises based on adult learning principles, which may support the transfer of participants' learning from the training room to their casework practice. The article also discusses the participants' ratings of satisfaction with this module, which indicated they perceived it as highly relevant. 1 Appendix, 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Impact of Training on Worker Performance and Retention: Perceptions of Child Welfare Supervisors

Author: Kleinpeter, Christine B1; Pasztor, Eileen Mayers; Telles-Rogers, Theresa1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61549581?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study examined the impact of training on children's social workers performance & retention. One hundred & thirty supervisors of the Los Angeles County Dept of Children & Family Services were surveyed. Results revealed that supportive supervision & caseload/workload size contribute most to worker performance & retention, & were more important than pre-service or in-service training. Seventy percent of the respondents indicated that training has an overall positive effect on worker performance, while only 52.3% indicated that training has an overall positive effect on worker retention. 4 Tables, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Turkey. A Generalist Approach in Social Work Education

Author: Bulut, Isil11 Dept Social Work, Health Sciences Faculty, Baskent U, Ankara, Turkey Ibulut@baskent.edu.tr

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61392009?accountid=14925

Abstract: A global review of social work education reveals considerable similarity among countries as well as significant differences. Historically, programs of social work education are informed by humanistic values and encompass knowledge of social problems, an understanding of individuals and their environment in interaction, and method of intervention into social and human difficulties. At the same time, structure of social work within the educational system and the length of training vary considerably from country to country. There is no serious international standards' setting for social work education, programs, educators and students around the world. Education programs exist at differing levels of education and for differing periods of time. There are no worldwide data on the number and qualifications of teachers of social work, the number and characteristics of social work students, variations in curricula and type of practicum (Hokeenstad and Kendall, 2001; Hokenstad, Midgley, 1998). References. Adapted from the source document.

Organisational and Methodical Aspects of Drug and Addiction Prevention among Young People. Developments in the Ukraine, in Germany, Spain and Russia (Project Description)

Author: Sting, Stephan11 Instit Social Work & Welfare Studies, TU Dresden

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61394967?accountid=14925

Abstract: From October 2000 to March 2003 the project has been coordinated by the institute of social work and welfare studies of the TU Dresden and financed by the European Commission (INCO-COPERNICUS-Programme). It was an international cooperation between the TU Dresden (Germany), the University of Internal Affairs and the National Technical University in Kharkiv (Ukraine), the research institute AREA in Valencia (Spain) and the Belgorod Juridical Institute of the Ministry of Internal Affairs (Russia) which was established for improving the knowledge base of drug prevention activities by the East European partners. The overall aim of the project was the analysis and elaboration of approaches to drug and addiction prevention. Under consideration of the specific conditions within the East-European countries this work should contribute to the development of pluralistic approaches towards health promotion which are embedded into an intercultural, European horizon. The Civil War in Southern Sudan and Its Effect on Youth and Children

Author: Biel, Melha Rout

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61375168?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Civil War in Sudan, which began in June 1983, has caused a numbers of social, cultural and economical problems for Sudan. Many social changes took place, not only in the southern Sudan, where the war has been fought since its inception, but also in the Sudanese Nation as a whole. In this contribution, I would like to give a short summary about the effect of the war on the Sudanese society, in general, and on youth and children, in particular. This is important, because youth and children are the future of every nation. Because the youth and children in southern Sudan are gravely affected by the current war, this article will specifically address these effects. Youth and children in the North of the country are, however, almost equally affected by the conflict. After discussing historical background of Sudan and its political and developmental condition, I will briefly summarize the social situation and the role of social work in Sudan during and after the conflict. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work in Republic of Buryatia

Author: Bazarova, Tatyana11 State U Buryatia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61387679?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Republic of Buryatia is situated in Eastern Sibiria, the eastern coast of Baikal Lake. The total area of the republic is 351 thousand square kilometers. The capital of Republic is Ulan-Ude. The modern social-economic situation in Russia is extremely paradoxical and multiaspectual -- negative processes take place almost in all spheres of the society. The introduction of market economy principles, the process of privatisation, and the last economic crises in the Federation of Russia have brought many social phenomena - among them increasing poverty, homelessness and still high rate of unemployment are the worst one. It makes the changes in the state social welfare programmes and functioning patterns be implemented. Social problems are especially very important in the so-called "depressive" regions of Russia (Buryatia Republic is among those regions). The most important is the staff supplement of social services and the level of professionalism of people who work there. This problem consists of two aspects: first, the number of specialists with professional education of social workers is not enough; second, the level of professionalism of the workers is very low. Adapted from the source document.

'Businessology' and Social Work

Author: Harris, John11 School Health & Social Studies, U Warwick

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61352888?accountid=14925

Abstract: There is a spectre stalking social work in many countries of the world. That spectre is the belief that social work needs to be reshaped in the image of capitalist business enterprises, what we might term business ideology or 'businessology'. Within that belief, the explicit or implicit assumption is that social work should, as far as possible, function as though it were a commercial business concerned with making profits. In those countries most affected, the culture of capitalism has colonised social work as business thinking and practices have been introduced. The embrace of businessology in social work is presented as a neutral trend, to which all social workers can be committed, namely, the modernisation of social work and making it more efficient through the application of distinctive and valuable expertise. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Businessology%27+and+Social+Work&amp;author=Harris%2C+John&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=1&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2003-01-01&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Policy Contexts of Social Work in Britain: The Wider Implications of 'New' Labour and the 'New Legal Regime'

Author: Penna, Sue

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61352834?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper aims to demonstrate the relationship of New Labour's modernisation programme to these new forms of legality by examining two main policy areas & the welfare implications they are enmeshed in. The first is privatisation, & the second is social policy in the European Union. Examining these areas allows a demonstration of how much of the New Labour programme can be understood as a local implementation of a transnational strategy, how parts of that strategy produce much of the social exclusion it purports to address, & how social welfare, & particularly social work, are noticeable by their absence within policy discourses of the strategy. The paper details how the privatisation programme is considered to be a crucial vehicle for the further development of a transnational political-economy, where capital accumulation has been redefined as 'welfare'. In this development, frameworks, codes & standards are central, & the final section of the paper examines how the modernisation strategy of the European Union depends upon social policy marked by an employment orientation & risk rationality, aimed at reconfiguring citizen identities. The strategy is governed through an 'open mode of coordination', in which codes, standards, benchmarks & so on play an important role. The paper considers the modernisation strategy & new legality within which it is embedded as dependent upon social policy as a technology of liberal governance, one demonstrating a new rationality in comparison to that governing post-Second World War welfare, & which aims to reconfigure institutional infrastructure & citizen identity. References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work, Mobility and Membership

Author: Jordan, Bill

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374994?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work is more involved in the collective life of its clientele than are other human service activities, because it is directly concerned with the bonds & conflicts between individuals, & the co-operative & competitive aspects of groups & communities. Hence it relies on being sited in organisations relevant to service users' lives, & on being able to influence these collectivities. This article argues that the 'organisational landscape' is being transformed, as commercial enterprises (more mobile & adaptable than either state or non-government organisations) take over important aspects of collective provision. The implications of this transformation for practice are analysed, by reference to examples from the United Kingdom in particular. References. Adapted from the source document.

Common Social Work Education Standards in the Nordic Countries -- Opening an Issue

Author: Juliusdottir, Sigrun; Petersson, Jan

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61370147?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article analyses the option of common Nordic Standards for social work education in these countries. The option is viewed through the lens of trends in education in the different countries. In the article the notion of an Integrated Field Model is used to indicate the starting point for a common model of education. This model covers the field characteristics of Denmark and Norway and their current move towards a more research-based education. It also covers the research characteristics of education in Finland, Iceland and Sweden and their current move towards a new field connection based on research-oriented education. Some thoughts on international requirements on comparability and compatibility in this setting are addressed in the final section. References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Workers Involvement in Taiwan's 1999 Earthquake Disaster Aid: Implications for Social Work Education

Author: Chou, Yueh-Ching

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61396009?accountid=14925

Abstract: On September 21, 1999, a strong earthquake devastated Taiwan's central areas and claimed more than two thousand casualties. Social work roles in the disaster aid were surveyed with standardized questionnaires six months after the earthquake; in addition, interviews of the key informants, documental research, focus groups and open-ended questionnaires were utilized to collect qualitative data. The study found that social workers had significant roles & functions in both rescue & recovery stages especially in linking the victims' needs with resources. Social workers, including from public & private sectors as well as from campuses including the faculties & students of social work departments, have been deeply involved in helping the victims. Regrettably, most Taiwanese social workers participated in the rescue aid with limited training in disaster aid; social work practice in disaster aid is not included in current curriculums of college level. This means that social work roles & functions in the disaster aid process have not been fully realized by Taiwan's society & professional education. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Practising Group Work: A Processual Account

Author: Sukhramani, Neelam1; Baig, Mohammad Imran1 Dept Social Work, Jamia Milia Islamia, New Delhi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61501515?accountid=14925

Abstract: Group work has been a vastly practiced, but minimally documented, method in the Indian context. The present article is an attempt to narrate, as well as use a theoretical framework to analyze the experiences of working with a group in an integrated school. Efforts have been made to detail out each phase by delving into the nature of activities undertaken, the involvement that it elicited from the members, the group dynamics, & the role played by the group worker. Author: Staral, Janice M11 Dept Social & Cultural Sciences, Social Work Program, Marquette U, Milwaukee, WI janice.staral@marquette.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61481259?accountid=14925

Abstract: Learning about & being involved in faith-based organizing increases awareness of social policy issues & provides another method of participation in social action & community organizing. Which Clinical Methods Are Associated with Better Preparing Social Work Students and Practitioners for Managed Care, State Licensing, and Other Important Practice Areas?

Author: Kane, Michael N1; Hamlin, Eldwood R, II; Hawkins, Wesley E1 School Social Work, Florida Atlantic U, Boca Raton mnkane@aol.com

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61451056?accountid=14925

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to identify which clinical methods were perceived as the most effective in preparing social work students & practitioners for the practice areas of managed care, state licensing, & others. The clinical methods were identified by ratings from a statewide sample (n=260) of licensed clinical social workers practicing in FL in 2002. Canonical correlation analysis (variate 1) found that the clinical methods of (1) task/secondary supervision in the field, (2) student reports/papers to the instructor, & (3) observation/feedback of client interviews in the field were significantly related to perceived higher levels of preparedness for work overall in managed care environments & for the specific skill of documentation. A second canonical variate found the clinical methods of (1) process recording, (2) audio-tapes, & (3) task/secondary supervision as significantly related to higher levels of preparedness for future practice areas, "work in the real world," & participation in an interdisciplinary team. Interestingly, process recording, audio-tapes, & task secondary supervision were inversely correlated to higher levels of preparedness for overall clinical social work practice & the state licensing exam. Implications & future research are discussed. 5 Tables, 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

How Victim Assistance Experts Rate Social Work Competencies for Professional Practice

Author: Danis, Fran11 School Social Work, U Missouri, Columbia danisf@missouri.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61505970?accountid=14925

Abstract: Crime victim assistance is an emerging field of practice. If social workers are interested in working with crime victims, what knowledge & skills do they need? Is there a fit between generalist social work competencies & those needed for work in this field? An expert panel of victim assistance professionals rated generalist social work competencies for their relative importance for practice with crime victims. The panel findings provide the social work profession with specific information on both the generalist & specific competencies necessary for practice with crime victims. Integrating Standardized Measures into Social Work Practice: An Exploratory Study of BSW, MSW, and Continuing Education Curricula

Author: Dennison, Susan11 Dept Social Work, U North Carolina, Greensboro

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61500961?accountid=14925

Abstract: Increased demands for rapid assessments, short-term treatment, & ongoing evaluation of client progress have necessitated that social workers more fully integrate standardized measures into their practice. Historically, however, the social work profession has not provided formal training on the use of standardized scales to students or practitioners. In this current outcome-based environment, social work education programs & social service agencies need to update their training to ensure that this area of practice is addressed. This article reports the results of a nationwide survey of BSW & MSW programs that examined (1) whether standardized measures were addressed in the current curricula; (2) the instructional formats being used; (3) how important social work educators view the inclusion of this material in courses; & (4) concerns that have surfaced around the integration of standardized measures into social work curricula. Implications for future research & training needs are outlined for both social work education programs & social service organizations. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Focus Groups: A Qualitative Solution Model of Evaluating a Web-Enhanced MSW Course

Author: Santhiveeran, Janaki11 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach jsanthiv@csulb.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61432419?accountid=14925

Abstract: The purpose of this study is to evaluate a Web-enhanced MSW course, to discuss focus group methodology for a solution model of evaluation, & to present findings & implications for continuing social work education. Overall, the students were very positive about the Web enhancements. Student benefits included the increased access to the instructor & ongoing feedback from the instructor. The challenges included time demands, task difficulty, technological challenges, & access. The students identified course documents, teacher's corner, & the digital drop box as the most useful Web components. Small group pages were rated as the least useful Web component. 1 Appendix, 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Choosing Non-Positivistic over Positivistic Approach in Exploring the Meaning of Community Participation: The Rationale Process

Author: Mathbor, Golam11 Dept Social Work, Monmouth U, West Long Branch, NJ

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61548715?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper analyzes the rationale process for choosing the research methodology in studying the 'Perception of Effective Community Participation in Coastal Development Projects in Bangladesh.' The analysis is based on ontological, epistemological, & methodological assumptions of two competing paradigms: positivistic (as an alternative approach) & non-positivistic (adapted in this research project) paradigms in scientific inquiry. Finally, the paper will conclude what characterizes the conceptualization of studying community participation in coastal development projects, & how these influence the choice of the methodology (non-positivistic approach), the specific method (grounded theory), & the data collection techniques. A comparison between positivistic & non-positivistic orientation toward this research project has also been made. 2 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Sex-Determination and Sex Pre-Selection Test: Abuse of Genetic Diagnostic Technology

Author: Das, Anandamohan1; Sinha, Debotosh1 Santiniketan Hospital

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499253?accountid=14925

Abstract: There are no commendable legislations or rules & regulations enacted by the government in our country to prevent the misuse of sex determination tests. In plenty of nursing homes & private clinics, sex determination tests are being performed by the sonologists without any legal identity. So, to stop this menacing manifestation of sex determination tests or rather the abuse of genetic diagnostic technologies; social workers, doctors, & the government should come forward on a common platform & to see how the astounding & blessed advancement of diagnostic technologies could be channelized in a constructive & purposeful way respecting the ethical aspects of medical profession. This paper, under this background will try to gloss over the concept of genetic diagnostic technology & amniocentesis, popularity of the test, controversy & the consequences around amniocentesis. Lastly, action to be taken against sex determination & sex pre-selection tests along with role of social worker, doctors, & government will be highlighted. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Managerialism and State Social Work in Britain

Author: Morgan, Steve1; Payne, Malcolm1 c/o Malcolm -- Manchester Metropolitan U, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61496545?accountid=14925

Abstract: Two forms of managerialism are distinguished: generalist managerialism, that which affects the daily experience of social work practice & policy managerialism, that which affects the development of policy. The development of social work in GB led social workers to adopt the role of bureau-professionals, mitigating the inflexibility of the bureaucratic provision of welfare in state social services. However, through case studies of local government social services & probation services, the impact on this conception of social work managerialism through its adoption by new Right governments during the 1980s & 1990s is demonstrated. It is argued that distinguishing the impact of inflexibility in services through bureaucratization from the impact of policy managerialism, the inclusion of a wide range of stakeholders & ensuring advocacy for the voices of service users & the community mitigates the effects of managerialist bureaucratization. 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Managerialism+and+State+Social+Work+in+Britain&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2002-07-01&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=27&amp;author=Morgan%2C+Steve%3BPayne%2C+Malcolm

Managerialism in Social Work -- An Exploration of Issues in the United States

Author: Tropman, John E11 School Social Work, U Michigan, Ann Arbor

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448521?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article examines the dimensions & importance of managerialism in social work. A three-part question -- "What?," "So What?," & "Now What?" -- forms an analytical frame that generates a frank deliberation on what actually takes place in social work agencies in the US. These social work agencies, as a whole, are found to be under-led, under-managed & over-supervised. In order to make improvements for quality service to clients, specific & concrete suggestions are outlined for social workers' consideration. 101 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Advent of Managerialism in Social Welfare: The Case of Hong Kong

Author: Leung, Joe C B11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong hrnwlcb@hkucc.hku.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61500400?accountid=14925

Abstract: Nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) have been the major provider of social welfare services in Hong Kong. Facing an economic downturn, the Hong Kong government decides to enhance cost-effectiveness & accountability in social service through the introduction of market values & business management practices. Market-oriented practices include contracting out, competitive bidding, performance monitoring, & lump-sum grant. The appeal of these practices lies in the possibility of lowering costs, but their long-term effect on quality & stability of services is largely uncertain. With the emergence of competition & deregulation in social welfare, NGOs have to face formidable challenges to change their traditional philosophies & mode of operations. The reform implicates the redefinition of the relationship between the government & NGOs, & between social workers & their NGO employers. This paper points out the need to adopt a cautious & consensus approach to introduce welfare reforms. 49 References. Adapted from the source document.

Determining Performance Standards for the Supported Employment Service in Hong Kong

Author: Chan, Charles C1; Wan, Deborah L Y; Lui, Wacy W S1 Dept Applied Social Sciences, Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499633?accountid=14925

Abstract: With the new managerial system of Funding & Service Agreement (FSA) in Hong Kong, the performance standards in social welfare services are still difficult to define. In this paper, the problems & difficulties arising from the current method of determining performance standards in the Supported Employment Service (SES) were first examined. The current formulation was also considered inadequate for the consideration of the actual service recipient outcomes. Research data from a university & a rehabilitation organization partnership revealed the complex relationship among service quality, service output, & service recipient outcomes. A conceptual model with variables considered as crucial by service operators & researchers was mapped out for better service accountability. This "percentage of best fit" model which was formulated by the empirically derived typologies of SES pathways & service recipients was suggested to form the performance standards. Significant implications include offering a workable alternative to the over-reliant, yet unsatisfactory use of mean discharge rates as the major performance standard in FSAs. This model also helps clarify information on who would fit into what kind of SES modules & for how long they would produce the best outcomes. The applicability of this empirically derived model to other social services should be further explored. Finally, this paper should be regarded as a practical response to the present demands for service quality & best value outcomes, based on an integrated use of clinical social work skills & empirical research methods. 2 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Determining+Performance+Standards+for+the+Supported+Employment+Service+in+Hong+Kong&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2002-07-01&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=95&amp;author=Chan%2C+Charles+C%3BWan%2C+Deborah+L+Y%3BLui%2C+Wacy+W+S

Interpreting Workers' Resistance to Welfare "Reform"

Author: Yi, Chan Fung1; Fan, Chu Shuk1 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61503770?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article presents & analyzes the background to the resistance of many frontline welfare practitioners against the recent introduction of reforms to the welfare management & subvention system & process in Hong Kong. The "progress" discourse optimistically engaged in by the government is challenged by a rather pessimistic assessment by workers, accompanied by a strong critique of the compromises welfare management groups have agreed to when accepting the Lump Sum Grant proposal. The context of the reform is interpreted as a strategic repositioning by the post-1997 government, intent at rebuilding its legitimacy & re-assigning the role of the welfare sector within its vision for the future. In the course of a long conversation between the two authors, one an academic, the other a core organizer in the "Alliance for the Protection of Welfare," several important areas of discourse were touched on: the nature of welfare & its normative underpinning; social workers' struggle to relocate themselves within the emerging managerial paradigm; the search for an environment in which dialogue between the various parties would allow open negotiation about a more positive reform of the welfare system. The relationships among workers, management, government, & service users are interpreted within a historical perspective, looking back at the constitution of the problem on both the level of Hong Kong as well as, more theoretically, on the level of (Western) welfare states. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Interventions on Garbage Pollution Using Integrated Social Work Practice Framework

Author: Nadkarni, Vimla V11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work, Tata Instit Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61523425?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper is based on the author's experience of applying the integrated social work practice (ISWP) framework to biological disasters in urban environments & to specifically strategize on the issue of garbage pollution with its public health consequences in a slum colony in Mumbai. This framework is based on the concepts developed by Goldstein (1973); Lippitt, Watson, & Westley (1958), & Pincus & Minahan (1973). Problem solving was based on the Pincus & Minahan model, which borrows from the systems model. In this particular case, it is the first time that ISWP has been demonstrated as a viable approach for dealing with garbage pollution within an urban, micro-community setting through mobilization of women & youth. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 19 References. Abstract: To empower Gram Panchayat members on issues related to population & health, a pilot training project was carried out by the Instit for Social & Economic Change in 1998 in one district of Karnataka state. Social Interventions for e-Governance, Decentralised Democracy, Panchayati Raj and Sustainable Development: Challenges and Opportunities

Author: Sivakumar, Damodaran11 Population Research Centre, U Kerala, Thiruvananthapuram

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61498781?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines how information technology can be used in social work practice & government in India with the goal of furthering sustainable development. Disaster Response in India: An Overview

Author: Parasuraman, S1; Unnikrishnan, P V1 Action Aid, Asia Regional Office

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61541123?accountid=14925

Abstract: 'Act of God' or 'Act of Man,' a mind boggling spectrum of disasters wreak havoc in the Indian subcontinent. Disasters are a shared reality spanning individuals, villages, blocks, districts, states, nations, & even regions, & have to be responded to with a multi-pronged approach. About 211 million people are affected by 'natural' disasters every year. According to the World Disasters Report, 67% of the people affected are from countries with low human development index (International Federation of Red Cross & Red Crescent, 2001). Experts note that the poorest are becoming more exposed to disaster risks. Political insensitivity, increasing poverty, climatic change, & globalization are the major factors that amplify the vulnerability & impacts of disasters. Disasters set back the development process by decades. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 2 Boxes, 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Disaster+Response+in+India%3A+An+Overview&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2002-04-01&amp;volume=63&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=151&amp;author=Parasuraman%2C+S%3BUnnikrishnan%2C+P+V

Institutional Response to Disasters: Changing Contours of the Role of an Academic Institution

Author: Andharia, Janki11 Dept Urban & Rural Community Development, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61432008?accountid=14925

Abstract: In developing countries like India, academic institutions of higher learning can contribute to disaster & rehabilitation in a variety of ways. This article attempts to capture the experiences of one such institute & its involvement in disaster situations over five decades. The changing contours of the role played by an academic institution & the gradual upscaling of its work illustrates how higher education & innovations in pedagogies can promote value orientation in the learning process, promote critical thinking, & contribute to social development. The modalities of this involvement, the nature of tasks performed, & the lessons learnt are discussed from the stand point of a social science institute imparting post-graduate education in practice-based profession of social work. 1 Table, 2 Appendixes, 9 References. Creativity and Practice Teaching

Author: Phillipson, Julia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499233?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article considers the need & opportunities for creativity in practice teaching & in practice. After alternative beginnings of examples, debate, & requirements for creativity, the article looks at the current context of social work & social care & the extent to which this context constrains & endorses creative approaches. A brief look at some ideas about the nature of creativity as a quality, skill, & approach are followed by suggestions for developing & naming creative practices in practice teaching. This article has grown out of an invitation to talk about creativity at a practice teachers' conference followed by a period of sporadically pertinent reading, writing snippets, musing, & trying to sustain personal creativity. The article is therefore a mix of personal experience, dialogue, exploration, & ideas for experimentation. As with much creativity, it is provisional -- unpicking ideas as well as weaving threads & seeking new understandings & practice; a journey with detours rather than an arrival at a known destination. 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Thomas, Ralph11 U Birmingham, Selly Oak, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448767?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article explores a range of issues about involving service users in student assessment. It provides methods of conducting further discussion about the issues by giving the scenarios & guidance information used successfully at six conference workshops to stimulate discussion among practice teachers. The hope is that others will make use of these & contribute to the development of good practice in this area. The existing literature about the issues is examined and, drawing from that literature & the workshop outcomes, the article provides guidance toward a model of successful inclusion of service users in student assessment. 13 References. Re-Shaping American Social Service Delivery for a New Millennium: A New Vision of Social Work Field Education

Author: Besthorn, Fred H1; McMillen, Diane P1 Dept Social Work, Coll Social & Behavioral Sciences, U Northern Iowa, Cedar Falls

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61429084?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article shall trace the history, values, & political dynamics which have influenced the development & current status of the American social service delivery system. It shall look at how a more holistic & structurally sensitive service delivery model might appear within the current system of managed care & privatization of human services. It shall review two existing frameworks that provide an alternative illustration of how future services might be organized & delivered. Finally, it shall also sketch the history & present challenges facing social work field education & review an innovative project for students that put into practice the provisions of a revised model of service delivery. 1 Figure, 74 References. The Voluntary Sector and Social Work Education: Distant Relatives?

Author: Worsley, Aidan1; Hardwick, Louise1 Dept Applied Community Studies, Manchester Metropolitan U, Didsbury

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61498320?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work at universities is at the critical interface of social welfare & social work as a profession. Social work education in England is required to prepare social workers for regulatory work, therapeutic work, meeting academic requirements, & the development of a critical perspective that distinguishes the social work role from other caring professions. Increasingly these complex & sometimes competing aspirations have placed the emphasis on universities meeting training requirements for statutory social work at the expense of developing these therapeutic skills & a critical autonomy. This article will argue that for too long universities have been content to deal almost exclusively with government & statutory agendas with the resulting loss of contact with the voluntary sector, & in turn service users, & communities represented by them. Social work as a whole is in danger of losing touch with the broad needs of welfare which are often found outside statutory social work especially at a time when the state is increasingly withdrawing from obligations to those in need of welfare. Any statutory social worker will testify to the broadening gap between need & provision & to fill that gap voluntary agencies are taking increasing responsibility for the elderly, the mentally ill, the socially excluded, young people, & childcare. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Voluntary+Sector+and+Social+Work+Education%3A+Distant+Relatives%3F&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Health+and+Social+Work&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=2002-01-01&amp;volume=4&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=48&amp;author=Worsley%2C+Aidan%3BHardwick%2C+Louise

The Advanced Practitioner: Beyond Reflective Practice

Author: Nathan, Jack11 Social Work & Care Section, Health Services Research Dept, David Goldberg Centre, Instit Psychiatry, London jacknathan54@hotmail.com

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499592?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper attempts to reconcile the practice realities faced by social workers & agencies on a daily basis, with the modernization imperatives set out by the State in requiring an enhanced social care service. The policy initiatives supporting this agenda represent an exciting historical opportunity for social work. To take up the challenge of creating a sound professional base for the provision of a high quality social work service, the organizational context & the relationship between the Agency, the Academy, & Practitioner will be explored. The paper will then look at what constitutes the Advanced Practitioner, using the conceptual framework provided by Schon's (1987, 1992) notion of the reflective practitioner. This paper presents a vision of a profession that has a unique contribution to make, among the other human service professions. It is argued that unless this challenge is taken up & made a practice reality, the professional base of social work could be further eroded. 4 Figures, 1 Appendix, 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Practice Teaching beyond the Caseload: Creating Opportunities for Practice Learning in the New UK Social Work Degree

Author: Shapton, Mike11 NE Worcestershire Coll, Bromsgrove, UK mshapton@ne-worcs.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61525772?accountid=14925

Abstract: In May 2002, the UK Dept of Health announced that one of the requirements of the new honors degree in social work would be for students to 'spend at least 200 days gaining required experience & learning in practice settings' (Dept of Health, 2002). This represents a big challenge when many programs struggle to provide the existing requirement of 130 days. This article offers some proposals for seeing this expectation as a chance to create a more differentiated approach to practice learning rather than seeking to provide more of the same. It argues that differentiation is essential to providing increased quantity but also an effective way to raise quality & improve readiness to practice. This could be achieved by building on existing piecemeal approaches to learning about practice in groups & other environments, coupled with moderating placement demands to ensure quality standards can be met consistently. 5 References. Adapted from the source document.

'A Virtual Placement.' The Creation of an Interactive, Web-Based Program to Prepare Students for 'Live' Placement

Author: Doel, Mark1; Cooner, Tarsem Singh1 School Social Work & RNIB Rehabilitation Studies, U Central England, Birmingham

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61494511?accountid=14925

Abstract: In this article, the authors tell the story of the creation of a Web-based program of learning for students preparing for practice. The program is called 'A Virtual Placement', & aims to prepare students for an actual placement. The authors do not promote virtual placements as an alternative to live placements, nor as some kind of 'imitation,' but as a complement to them, & possibly as a substitute for some of the functions that are currently expected of the live placement. The progress from screenplay to electronic format is charted, with discussion of the dilemmas which arose from harnessing the new technology appropriately. The authors reflect on the way in which their ideas for a virtual placement developed & changed, & the significance of metaphor & play in shaping these ideas. The article should help put the program itself in context, & the authors hope that readers will feel encouraged to visit the website, which is freely available at www.hcc.uce.ac.uk/virtualplacement. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Facing Exclusion: The Nomadic Communities in Western India

Author: Bokil, Milind11 Development Support Team, Pune

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61431939?accountid=14925

Abstract: Traditionally, nomadic communities in India have suffered from societal neglect, injustice, discrimination & even disrespect of their human rights. At present, their survival is threatened due to loss of traditional occupations. In spite of this, their plight is not sufficiently attended to by the existing social work policy & practice, which mostly focuses on sedentary communities. The peripheral nature of these communities & the transitional phase of development present a great challenge before social work today. 6 Tables, 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Development, Disasters and Displacement: An Appraisal of Policy for Resettlement

Author: Barnabas, A P

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61530114?accountid=14925

Abstract: The consequences of displacement of persons, whatever the cause (human made or natural disasters) are multidimensional. These include landlessness, joblessness, homelessness, marginalization, food insecurity, community disarticulation, & so on. Vulnerable groups (weaker sections, women, & so on) are more acutely affected. A policy for rehabilitation should be appraised from the viewpoint of whether it responds to these several impacts. The various policies for rehabilitation of displaced persons (due to development projects, natural disasters, deforestation, & so on) as presently operational are inadequate. The need is for a more humane approach. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work in India: A 'Bright' Future?

Author: Kumar, Ajit11 Matru Seva Sangh Instit Social Work, Nagpur

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61513697?accountid=14925

Abstract: The liberalization era is accompanied with criticisms of Indian achievements & by extension the state. Surmounting the complexities of caste, religion, language, & history, an industrial base & a democratic polity have evolved. Enormous problems remain & the market is seen as the panacea. Would these problems find a place in the new order when the existence of the nation-state is a question mark? Under conditions of deprivation & inequality, would weakening the ability of the state to mobilize resources & prioritize investment further the manifest goals of social work? Growth of the market economy will apportion the cast offs to the care of the social worker who, intentions notwithstanding, can play only a limited role in alleviating human misery arising out of structural forces. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.
