A Time to Support Fatherhood

Author: Dudley, James R1; Fagan, Jay1 Dept Social Work, U North Carolina, Charlotte jrdudley@email.uncc.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61551315?accountid=14925

Abstract: The lead article for this special issue draws attention to the dangers facing fatherhood in the US today. Several groups of fathers are identified whose parenting roles could be at-risk. They include fathers who are no longer in their children's lives, are functioning in underutilized ways, &/or are struggling with limited preparedness. At-risk fathers comprise several types of residential & nonresidential fathers identified in this article. Residential fathers could include lower income fathers without adequate employment, single custodial dads, & fathers with special needs children. Nonresidential fathers whose parenting could be at-risk include noncustodial fathers whom are divorced, teen dads, & unmarried adults. The article highlights the problems that these fathers could be facing, & some of the ways that they can be effectively helped. A special approach is called for that builds on their strengths, is culturally sensitive, considers many system levels of intervention, & promotes a broad base of support for fatherhood. 48 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=A+Time+to+Support+Fatherhood&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2001-10-01&amp;volume=4-5&amp;issue=3-1&amp;spage=4&amp;author=Dudley%2C+James+R%3BFagan%2C+Jay

September 11, 2001: Implications for Social Work Practice and Education

Author: Miller, Joshua11 Smith Coll School Social Work, Northampton, MA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61524339?accountid=14925

Abstract: The terrorist attacks on the US on 11 Sept 2001 & the ensuing domestic & international events have raised questions about how best to prepare for, & respond to, such large-scale disasters & the role of social workers in that process. This article considers the potential implications of 11 Sept for social work practice & education, particularly continuing education. The article describes the relief effort mounted to respond to the World Trade Center disaster in New York City & the service delivery problems that emerged. The article concludes with a number of recommendations: (1) placing US social work in more of a global context; (2) ways to prepare for future responses to acts of domestic terrorism; (3) the need for social workers to challenge civil rights infringements & ethnic & religious scapegoating; & (4) the need for a renewed commitment by social workers to advocate for health & income security for all Americans. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Developing or Enhancing Interdisciplinary Programs: A Model for Teaching Collaboration

Author: Maidenberg, Michelle P1; Golick, Toby1 Social Work House, Iona Coll, New Rochelle, NY

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61492827?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article explores the process & outcome of an interdisciplinary project titled "Law & Social Work Housing/Home Care Project," developed within the setting of a law school to provide social work & law students the opportunity to work together to assist vulnerable clients in need of both legal & social work services. This article describes how the project was developed & provides examples of clients served at the clinic. In addition, problems are identified that affect the ability of social work & law students to work collaboratively. Recommendations are provided by professionals in the field, former students at the clinic, & supervisors of the program in an effort to increase teamwork. This article describes a model for teaching collaboration when seeking to develop or enhance interdisciplinary programs within organizations. The hope is that detailing this experience will be of help to others who decide to replicate this model or establish similar collaborations within an organization that employs professionals. 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Federal and State Policy Initiatives to Strengthen Fatherhood: Issues and Implications for Practitioners

Author: Brotherson, Sean E1; White, Joseph M1 Dept Child Development & Family Science, North Dakota State U, Fargo

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61543833?accountid=14925

Abstract: The exploration of ideas & mechanisms for assisting men in their paternal responsibilities encompasses a wide range of possibilities. Demonstration research projects, grassroots educational programs, & community-led initiatives all have a role in shaping fathers' lives & activities. The development of state & federal-level policy approaches to strengthen fatherhood is an important trend among these efforts. This paper provides a brief conceptual & historical perspective on public policy initiatives related to fatherhood, reviews the status of current federal & state policy initiatives to strengthen fatherhood, & discusses implications for practitioners working in contexts where responsible fatherhood is an issue, including work with low-income fathers, teen fathers, incarcerated fathers, & fathers in other circumstances. 1 Figure, 64 References. Demystifying Client-Outcomes: Identifying, Monitoring, and Using Client Outcomes in Child Protection

Author: Litzelfelner, Pat1; Pierpont, John H1 Coll Social Work, U Kentucky, Lexington

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61483202?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work education programs invariably include courses in research methods. These courses may or may not include information about how to develop, measure, & monitor client outcomes. Nonetheless, when social workers enter the field, they will ultimately be faced with the responsibility of identifying program goals & objectives & monitoring client outcomes. This article describes the various processes pertaining to developing, measuring, & reporting client outcomes. Using child protective services as an exemplar, a model for initial development & use of client outcomes is presented. Implications for continuing education in social work are presented. 1 Table, 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Public-Private Mentoring for Leadership and Service Quality

Author: Kelly, Michael J1; Lauderdale, Michael L1 School Social Work, U Missouri, Columbia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482173?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper describes a mentoring program for public & private sector managers to introduce leadership skills & total quality management (TQM) methods. Managers experienced with TQM in the private sector were matched with public managers from a state human services agency & guided through a joint systematic development process to transfer leadership & quality management skills. The multiyear project was designed & supported by the professional continuing education staff of a research university with state & foundation funding. Evaluation results suggest that the project was successful, even though most of the mentoring relationships did not last throughout the project. 2 Tables, 34 References. Social Work Practitioners and Technology Transfer

Author: Scheyett, Anna1; Roberts, Amelia C; Kirk, Raymond1 U North Carolina, Chapel Hill

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482197?accountid=14925

Abstract: The application of new skills & interventions into the practice community is often slow & haphazard. A coaching intervention is proposed to augment traditional social work education techniques & maximize the integration of new knowledge into social work practice. This coaching model includes assessment of a practitioner's readiness for change, stage-wise coaching interventions, assessment of organizational barriers to the transfer of new information, & development of strategies to address these barriers. Implications for social work professional development & future research are discussed. 60 References. Adapted from the source document.

Perspectives of a Reform Commission: Ensuring the Role of Fathers in Their Children's Lives

Author: Clark, Kathleen A1; Leite, Randall W1 Ohio State U, Marion

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61543868?accountid=14925

Abstract: In 1998, the 122nd General Assembly of the State of Ohio created the Ohio Task Force on Family Law & Children (Task Force). The General Assembly had concluded that the parent-child relationship is of fundamental importance to the welfare of a child, & that the relationship between a child & each parent should be fostered unless inconsistent with the child's best interest. The Task Force was instructed to make recommendations on how to create a more civilized & constructive parenting process for children whose parents do not reside together. Qualitative & quantitative data regarding the impact of separation & divorce upon childhood development was obtained through six months of testimony from locally & nationally recognized experts & through reviews of the latest research findings. This article synthesizes the data concerning the importance of the father-child relationship, & delineates the role of social workers in a task force. 3 Tables, 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Distance and On-Campus MSW Students: How They Perform and What They Tell Us

Author: Glezakos, Agathi1; Lee, Cheryl D1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61429345?accountid=14925

Abstract: The debate over the quality of distance education (DE) in social work programs is ongoing. In an attempt to assess the relative merits of this emerging pedagogy, a questionnaire was administered to 56 DE & 44 on-campus (OC) graduating students. The instrument assessed practice competencies in the domains of knowledge, values, & skills. There were no competence differences between the two groups. In addition, the DE students were asked to rank their required courses for goodness of fit for DE instruction. Research & thesis courses were ranked as the least appropriate. Recommendations include increasing the amount of DE programs, developing refined outcome assessment tools, & continuing research. 3 Tables, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Distance+and+On-Campus+MSW+Students%3A+How+They+Perform+and+What+They+Tell+Us&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2001-10-01&amp;volume=4&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=54&amp;author=Glezakos%2C+Agathi%3BLee%2C+Cheryl+D

Nonresidential Never-Married Fathers: Policy Advocacy Opportunities

Author: Stone, Glenn11 Dept Family Studies & Social Work, Miami U, Oxford, OH stoneg@muohio.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61481596?accountid=14925

Abstract: The issues related to divorced fathers & their children have received considerable attention in the research literature. We have grown in our understanding of how to improve the post-divorce relationship between father, child, & mother. However, much less attention has been paid to the issues faced by nonresidential never-married fathers & their children. This is unfortunate, for the rate of children born into never-married relationships is on the rise. It is the purpose of this paper to provide a clearer picture of the issues faced by these fathers. In addition, this paper will explore micro & macro practice suggestions that could prove useful in maintaining a positive relationship between the nonresidential never-married father & his child, & the child's mother. Furthermore, the information provided in this paper could serve as a valuable aid in the professional development of social work practitioners, who need information on how to best serve these fathers. 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Strategies for Sustaining Paternal Involvement among Unwed Fathers: Insights from Field Research

Author: Johnson, Waldo E, Jr11 School Social Service Administration, U Chicago, IL wejohnso@midway.uchicago.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61516367?accountid=14925

Abstract: In-depth interviews with a Chicago sub-sample of both unwed fathers & mothers in the Fragile Families & Child Well-Being Study, conducted at six weeks & again at three months following the focal child's birth, builds upon subsequent survey analysis examining paternal involvement among unwed parents. Collectively, the findings form a conceptual framework for examining & facilitating paternal involvement & family development via the couple relationship context. Social work practice strategies, building upon a strengths-based perspective, are proposed with a focus on engaging an often overlooked & underserved member of the family in professional practice & advocacy-the unwed father. Findings are directed toward the development of promising social work interventions for children & families, while simultaneously advancing the aim of social work practice. 1 Appendix, 51 References. Abstract: This paper provides a brief overview of the tradition of the social work profession, its research trend in the past, & its present focus. The Maharashtra Rural Credit Programme: A Field Level Reconnaissance

Author: Acharya, Sarthi1; Bhide, Amita; Mammen, Rekha1 Cambodia Development Resource Instit, Phnom Penh

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61472633?accountid=14925

Abstract: The ultimate goal of the MRCP (Maharashtra Rural Credit Programme) Project is to contribute to poverty alleviation among the rural poor through improved financial services. This study is an assessment of the impact of the MRCP on: (1) credit delivery institutions, (2) project borrowers, & (3) social issues. The methodology used was a combination of quantitative & qualitative methods. The primary method of data collection was a survey conducted Mar-June 1999. During this time, 600 direct borrowers were selected for interviews. The authors outline the results of this survey & present a profile of the project area. It was determined that this project was more effective in its reach than almost all its predecessors because it has been able to increase the income & well-being of customers. E. Sanchez

Critical Issues in Multidisciplinary Child Sexual Abuse Allegation Investigations

Author: Cheung, Monit11 Child Welfare Education Project, Graduate School Social Work, U Houston, TX

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61497662?accountid=14925

Abstract: During the past ten years, research in the area of investigative interviews of child sexual abuse has focused on the child victim. Current literature in this area can be grouped into eight interrelated categories: (1) the developmental aspects of memory recall, (2) understanding children's language, (3) avoidance of repeated questioning, (4) validation & children's credibility, (5) false allegations, (6) videotaping interviews, (7) using anatomical dolls, & (8) interviewing techniques. A growing concern is the use of developmentally appropriate techniques to avoid false allegations. A dual-focus approach in conducting an investigative interview & 12 guiding principles are recommended for improving social workers' knowledge, skills, & attitude. 2 Tables, 71 References. Adapted from the source document.

Indigenization of Social Work in Hong Kong

Author: Yip, Kam-Shing11 ssksyip@polyu.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61485995?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work indigenization is a necessary reflection under the Western cultural imperialism. However, indigenization is a highly complicated & multidimensional process. The nature of social work is also controversial & diversified. In this paper, the process of indigenization of social work practice in Hong Kong is discussed, arguing that social work practice in Hong Kong gradually removed its attachment to the "Westernized model" to reflect local social & cultural contexts. In the 1990s, the debates on indigenization began to gain momentum for a more comprehensive & holistic reflection on social work practice in Hong Kong. 50 References. Nei Jin Etiology

Author: Ng, Siu-Man

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61513358?accountid=14925

Abstract: Inner Canon is the oldest Chinese medicine book in existence. It has detailed discussions on etiology & established the theoretical foundation of Chinese medicine. Due to its huge difference from the Western medical model, Chinese medicine itself is a unique academic system. This article attempts to compare the etiology models of Chinese & Western medicine, & discuss the implications for clinical practice. For over 2000 years, Inner Canon has established the holistic view & dual-factor etiology as the foundation of Chinese medicine. Chinese medicine practitioners have accumulated much clinical experience in multilevel & multidimensional treatment & rehabilitation approaches. Many of these approaches can be borrowed by social workers. Incorporating these interventions with Western theories & skills can provide more comprehensive services to persons suffering from mental disorders. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Measurement of Family Violence

Author: Bhatti, Ranbir S1; George, Tony Sam1 Dept Psychiatric Social Work, National Instit Mental Health & Neuro Sciences, Bangalore, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61429208?accountid=14925

Abstract: The measurement of family violence is beset with various difficulties, both methodological & theoretical. A sound theoretical model to conceive & understand family violence is still lacking. The multifactorial systemic model is proposed as a comprehensive framework to understand family violence. This model assumes that various societal, cultural, & sociopolitical developmental phases of a developing society bring a variety of changes in the value patterns of the system. Such transitional phases disrupt the traditional homeostasis. Many built-in programs of a system start diluting into an unknown search for new adaptations. During this period to develop morphogenesis becomes extremely challenging for the family as a system. In order to seek the desired conformity from a fellow family member, the family may use any means, including physical, verbal, emotional, or intellectual violence. This paper presents an attempt made to measure the components of family violence using a tool developed to measure the patterns, severity, & frequency of family violence among families with children having psychiatric & neurological disabilities. The overall development of the tool is presented with suitable theoretical background & field data. 4 Tables, 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abuse and Neglect of Elderly in Families

Author: Srinivas, S1; Vijayalakshmi, B1 Dept Social Work, Andhra U, Visakhapatnam, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61481692?accountid=14925

Abstract: Data were gathered from a quota sample of 140 elderly subjected to abuse &/or neglect by their family members in Visakhapatnam, India, using a modified form of the Conflict Tactics Scale. The results indicate that the most likely victims of elder abuse are widowed women, elderly with poor economic background, & dependent. As regards the forms of abuse, verbal abuse of the elderly was reported most frequently, followed by material abuse & neglect. A sizeable portion of the respondents have reported physical abuse. It was also found that abuse has negative implications -- social, psychological, & behavioral -- for the elderly. Further, the data indicated that the son, the daughter-in-law, & the spouse (in that order) are the most frequently reported abusers. It is recommended that programs should be designed to provide adequate opportunities for participation of the elderly to reduce their social isolation & to provide support services to families caring for the elderly to help reduce caregiver stress. 7 Tables, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Abuse+and+Neglect+of+Elderly+in+Families&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2001-07-01&amp;volume=62&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=464&amp;author=Srinivas%2C+S%3BVijayalakshmi%2C+B

Family Care of the Elderly: Abuse, Neglect and Abandonment

Author: Vaswani, Thrity G11 Faculty Social Work, M.S. U Baroda, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61492588?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the care of the elderly in a home setting & discusses the lack of quality of care resulting in abuse, neglect, & abandonment. Existing research on abuse is presented, followed by the study that investigated the prevalence of abandonment & neglect in 50 elderly slum dwellers in Gujarat, India. Results indicated physical, economic, & emotional neglect. Recommendations for future research & training on the care of the elderly are offered. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Perceptions of Responsibility for the Acquisition of Skills and Knowledge in Current Service Environments

Author: Kane, Michael N1; Hamlin, Elwood R, II; Green, Diane1 School Social Work, Florida Atlantic U, Boca Raton

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61530477?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work practitioners & administrators in public, private-for-profit, & private-not-for-profit agencies (total N = 66) rated 23 skill & knowledge items identified by Vandivort-Warren (1996) as critically important to managed care & privatized service delivery environments. Respondents ranked cultural competency (79%), systems thinking (77%), clinical case management (65%), client participation in treatment (64%), & practical research skills (58%) as the most important skill & knowledge items. Respondents believed it was the responsibility of the university to provide knowledge & skill training for these items. Items with lower rankings were viewed as a collaborative educational responsibility between the university & the agency. All knowledge & skills listed were analyzed in relation to gender, venue of instruction, employment setting, & agency type. Implications for classroom, field, & continuing education are discussed. 2 Tables, 54 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Perceptions+of+Responsibility+for+the+Acquisition+of+Skills+and+Knowledge+in+Current+Service+Environments&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2001-04-01&amp;volume=4&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=14&amp;author=Kane%2C+Michael+N%3BHamlin%2C+Elwood+R%2C+II%3BGreen%2C+Diane

Re-Thinking South Korea's Special Graduate Education as a Continuing Education Resource

Author: Shin, Junseob11 Dept Social Welfare, Konkuk U, Chungju-City, Korea jsshin01@kku.ac.kr

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61529233?accountid=14925

Abstract: The need for continuing social work education in South Korea is growing. A rapid expansion of social work education during the 1980s produced a large number of practicing social workers in the field. Some of them are currently at the middle-management level in a variety of social work agencies. Continuing education programs for social workers in the field, however, have not been well developed. Based on a survey of 216 graduate students enrolled in both general master's programs & special graduate programs in social work, this study analyzed characteristics & functions of each program. An exploration of the special graduate program as a continuing education resource was then approached & possible implications for activating continuing education in South Korea were drawn. 8 Tables, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Using a Pretest-Posttest Design to Evaluate Continuing Education Programs

Author: Barton, Thomas R1; Dietz, Tracy J; Holloway, Linda L1 Dept Rehabilitation/Social Work/Addictions, U North Texas, Denton barton@unt.ecu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61530554?accountid=14925

Abstract: To retain licensure or certification, social workers throughout the nation are required to participate in continuing education programs that, at a minimum, attempt to impart new knowledge. The pretest-posttest design is a simple, yet methodologically flawed, way to evaluate such programs. Reported are the results of an experiment that evaluated the impact testing has on pretest-posttest evaluations. We find that participants who completed both a pretest & posttest have virtually the same posttest scores as participants who completed only a posttest. Findings suggest that this design can be used to conduct meaningful evaluations of programs intending to increase participants' knowledge. 2 Tables, 1 Appendix, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Using+a+Pretest-Posttest+Design+to+Evaluate+Continuing+Education+Programs&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2001-04-01&amp;volume=4&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=32&amp;author=Barton%2C+Thomas+R%3BDietz%2C+Tracy+J%3BHolloway%2C+Linda+L

Inside-Outside: Boundary-Spanning Challenges in Building Rural Health Coalitions

Author: Dunlop, Judith M1; Angell, G Brent1 c/o Angell -- School Social Work & Criminal Justice Studies, East Carolina U, Greenville, NC

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61524283?accountid=14925

Abstract: Trends in reforming human services systems challenge social workers to become effective boundary spanners. As government strategies of decentralization & devolution are implemented, social workers interested in leadership roles will need to understand how to manage the multiple external organizational relationships created by coalition building. This paper presents a conceptual framework for understanding boundary-spanning functions & issues, applies this framework to rural health coalitions, & offers guidelines for teaching about how community practitioners, as boundary spanners, can be more effective in managing the institutional & interpersonal relations involved in coalition building. An understanding of the dual roles that social workers play inside their own organizations & outside -- as members of coalitions -- offers an opportunity for social workers in rural health settings to play a major leadership role in building collaborative networks. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Indigenising Social Work Education: A Case Study from Baroda

Author: Patel, Chhaya11 Faculty Social Work, M. S. U Baroda, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61425423?accountid=14925

Abstract: This case study consists of critical narratives covering such aspects as composition of students, recruitment, training, & upgrading of teachers & structure of curriculum. Indigenous practice opportunities were created by founding, initiating, supporting, or using the existing infrastructural laboratory, such as an institutional network of social defense, social welfare, medical & rural development service agencies, & other centers in & around Baroda. This institutional network of the school proved highly beneficial to all involved: students, teachers, researchers, agency personnel, functionaries receiving training, & the clients among the wider community of Baroda region. The indigenizing ethos, values, & philosophy enshrined in the foundation of the school are described. The article concludes by commenting on the impact of a newly added self-financed Master of Human Resource Management degree program. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Interpersonal Dynamics in Alcohol Complicated Marriages

Author: Stanley, Selwyn11 Dept Social Work, Bishop Heber Coll, Tiruchirapalli, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61476415?accountid=14925

Abstract: Wives of alcoholics & of nonalcoholics (N = 150 each), matched on key sociodemographic variables, were compared using instruments to study the manifestation of communication apprehension & their marital adjustment. Data analysis revealed that wives of alcoholics showed statistically significant greater communication apprehension toward their spouses & reported poorer marital adjustment than the reference group. Therapeutic implications are discussed. 2 Tables, 48 References. Adapted from the source document.

National Seminar on Rural Development and Human Rights Violation in Western India

Author: Barik, B C1; Katare, P M; Seth, Supriya1 School Social Sciences, Swami Romanand Teerth Marathwada U, Nanded, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61475200?accountid=14925

Abstract: The proceedings of this seminar, organized by the School of Social Sciences at Swami Ramanand Teerth Marathwada U in Nanded in Feb 2000, are summarized. The focus of the 16 papers presented was on the effects of the massive development schemes for rural areas on the rights of the rural population, especially those marginalized. It was concluded that despite landmark progress in the agricultural sector in western India, the fact that 33% of the population live below the poverty line is a civil rights violation. M. Pflum

How a Minority Tribal Group in Nepal Has Reacted to Oppression -- A Book Review Essay

Author: Visvesvaran, P K11 Madras School Social Work, Chennai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61475172?accountid=14925

Abstract: A review essay on a book by T. B. Subba, Politics of Culture: A Study of Three Kirata Communities in the Eastern Himalayas (Chennai: Orient Longman, 1999), which recounts the efforts of the heterogeneous Kirata tribal group to recreate their culture, religion, & languages despite the lack of tolerance for diversity in Nepal. The Kirata history, culture, & political, economic, & social organization are discussed, & compared with those of the Hindus & other groups in Nepal. The overall ethnographic methodology is commendable, but the author's theory of marginalization, that outsiders have severely marginalized the Kirata through inmigration, is weak. The author warns that a situation of confrontation is brewing. This fascinating narrative has both academic & practical import. 5 References. M. Pflum

Is Good Will Enough? Practice Teaching in the Voluntary Sector

Author: Irvine, Julie1; Hubbard, Anne1 Division Adult/Community/Primary Care, U Northumbria, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482257?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article investigates the perceived rewards of practice teaching for social work practitioners working in small voluntary sector organizations. It is argued that this sector is often ignored in social work education, & that the views of those playing a key role in assessing practice competence have been marginalized in practice teaching literature. Through interviews with a number of practice teachers from a North East voluntary sector consortium, the rewards of practice teaching as a distinct activity are identified from a personal & organizational perspective. These views are placed in the context of changes in the way social work services & social work education are currently organized & delivered. The findings suggest that practice teachers gain several benefits from teaching students, but also use practice teaching as a means of promoting particular forms of social work & the voluntary sector itself. Strategies to improve the profile of practice teaching & relationships with other partners in social work education are discussed. 3 Figures, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Night Porters: A Portrait of Practice Teaching and Placement Provision in One Scottish Local Authority, 1998-2000

Author: Henery, Neil

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61445871?accountid=14925

Abstract: There is widespread recognition that current arrangements are unsatisfactory in relation to the quantity & quality of practice placements. CCETSW attempted to tackle the issues with its accreditation policy 12 years ago. This study looks at the provision of placements in one Scottish local authority & concludes that accreditation has not worked. Practice teachers identify lack of workload relief & lack of management support as key factors discouraging them from providing placements. It is suggested that the structural separation of placement provision from organizational work plans is at the root of the problem. The metaphor of practice teachers as the night porters of social work education helps to explore the causes & implications. Bringing practice teaching into the daylight means improving the visibility, status, & group identity of practice teachers. If this is done, current efforts to establish a competent social work service stand a better chance of success. 2 Figures, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Developing Poverty Teaching and Practice for Social Work Students: A Community Profiling Approach

Author: Ferry, Alan1; Watson, David1 Glasgow Caledonian U, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482275?accountid=14925

Abstract: Poverty is an issue that has always proved problematic for social work both at a policy & practice level. It has caused controversy & debate within the profession around whether it is a circumstance to be challenged by social workers, & if so, in what way. However, with the inception of the Diploma in Social Work in 1991 & its revision in 1995, this debate took another turn with the requirement that qualifying students should have a knowledge & understanding of the impact of poverty on service users. Social work courses were now required to move poverty into the mainstream of their teaching strategies. This paper outlines the planning processes & thinking involved in the development of a module titled "Poverty, Deprivation & Discrimination" on the BA/DipSW for mature students with family commitments at Glasgow Caledonian U. In particular, it considers the issues involved in developing the teaching of the module away from traditional methods, towards a more reflective & experiential approach, where students assume greater responsibility for their own learning. Central to this approach was the development of a Community Profiling exercise, which was used as a tool to bridge the gap between theory & the beginnings of an anti-oppressive practice. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Developing+Poverty+Teaching+and+Practice+for+Social+Work+Students%3A+A+Community+Profiling+Approach&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Health+and+Social+Work&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=2001-01-01&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=41&amp;author=Ferry%2C+Alan%3BWatson%2C+David

Attitude and Participation of Farmers under Water Users' Associations in Kerala

Author: Chandran, K Madhava1; Varadan, K M; Valsan, T1 Centre Water Resources Development & Management, Kozhikode

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61466954?accountid=14925

Abstract: A study was conducted to quantify the relationship between attitude of farmers & their participation in the activities of Water Users' Associations under the Command Area Development Authority (CADA) in Kerala. There is a significant relationship between the two. The participatory activities have been explained through relevant social theories applicable to irrigation management. Lack of activities like provision of farm channels, rotational water supply, consolidation of landholdings & group farming, were found to be the reasons for low farmer participation. Based on the study, factors relevant for Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) for decentralized irrigation have been identified. 5 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Disasters and Mental Health

Author: Jaswal, Surinder11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar, Bombay, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61496487?accountid=14925

Abstract: The 1990s were recognized as the decade for natural disaster reduction by the United Nations General Assembly in 1987 (World Health Organisation, 1992). Besides the death caused by natural disasters such by earthquakes, windstorms, tsunamis, floods, landslides, volcanic eruptions, wildfires & other calamities, it is being increasingly recognized that the definition of disaster has widened to include human-made events such as riots, fires, industrial disasters, building collapses, mass dislocation due to political unrest, insurgency, conflict, & internal displacement. Further, it is also recognized that "the smallest & poorest countries are affected most severely by both natural & man-made disasters, & the poorest & most disadvantaged members of a disaster affected community are likely to experience the most serious consequences" (United Nations Disaster Relief Organisation, 1984). Therefore, in the majority of developing countries, consequences of disasters, due to their severity & frequency, represent a real public health priority. 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Disaster Mental Health: A Current Perspective

Author: Juvva, Srilatha1; Rajendran, P1 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458767?accountid=14925

Abstract: Disasters, both human-made & natural, are a very sorrowful experience. It is even more so when one becomes a hapless victim to a disaster. The consequences & aftermath of a disaster leaves behind a plethora of issues to target & handle. Often, mental health work occupies a lower priority in disaster management. It is also a widely neglected area with very few disaster mental health professionals to offer their services. In the wake of recurring disasters all over the world, many helping professionals have woken up to the reality facing us, & current scientific literature abounds in information & materials in disaster management, preparedness, mitigation, relief, & rehabilitation. Yet, literature on disaster mental health is scarce. Drawing from the experiences in a recent disaster, the authors highlight the role of disaster mental health work & its impact in disaster management. The need to incorporate disaster mental health strategies in training of relief workers, officials, & trainers at both the governmental & nongovernmental organizations will also be highlighted. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Political Unrest and Mental Health in Srinagar

Author: Ali, Nasir1; Jaswal, Surinder1 c/o Jaswal -- Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mambai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458255?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper reports on the impact of the ongoing political unrest on the mental health of low-income urban people in Srinagar. The Kashmiri translation of the Self-Reporting Questionnaire 20 (SRQ-20) was used to assess current psychiatric morbidity in the respondents in Baramulla. The SRQ-20 was validated against the ICD-10, which was used as a gold standard. A cut-off of 11/12 was arrived at by testing for sensitivity & specificity. The findings of the study indicate high mental health morbidity in the respondents, especially in homemakers & in unskilled workers as a result of the ongoing long-term unrest & the consequent trauma in the region. 2 Tables, 3 Figures, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Killari: Psychosocial Health of a Village Ravaged by an Earthquake

Author: Gandevia, Katy11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61504333?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper begins by highlighting the events following the devastating earthquake that struck the Marathawada region of Maharashtra on 30 Sept 1993. Killari, a once flourishing village, was reduced to a heap of rubble overnight. Destruction to life & property was immense, but the psychological trauma faced by the people was no less. Many families had to cope not only with complete destruction of their homes but had to come to terms with death of their loved ones. After the initial rush of material relief, the families found themselves lonely & then despair struck many of them. Psychological evaluation undertaken by the Maharashtra Instit of Mental Health, Pune, indicated a high level of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, especially among the women & children. The author then tries to outline the coping mechanisms adopted by the villagers of Killari, the changes that took place due to housing & other policies, & the effects they had on the social fabric of the village. 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Killari%3A+Psychosocial+Health+of+a+Village+Ravaged+by+an+Earthquake&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2000-10-01&amp;volume=61&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=652&amp;author=Gandevia%2C+Katy

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Killari%3A+Psychosocial+Health+of+a+Village+Ravaged+by+an+Earthquake&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2000-10-01&amp;volume=61&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=652&amp;author=Gandevia%2C+Katy

Teaching Disaster Management: Addressing Complexities of Social Work Practice

Author: Pereira, Maveen Soares11 Dept Urban & Rural Community Development, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458501?accountid=14925

Abstract: A course on "Disaster Management" is offered to social work students at the Master's level in the Dept of Urban & Rural Community Development at the Tata Instit of Social Sciences. The experience of teaching the course has been extremely interesting. Since much of the literature on disaster management is restricted to the postdisaster situation, the course has had to bring in the development perspective in a bid to seek sustainable solutions -- be they physical or psychosocial. Hence, the challenge is to prepare the mindset of students to address disaster issues not just on humanitarian & management principles, but with a perspective that includes foresight, relating to the intricacies of development processes, understanding vulnerabilities, & working within the dynamics of the nation-state. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Strategies for Empowerment of Self-Help Groups: "Participatory Research" and "Organizational Development"

Author: Mok, Bong Ho; Suen, Lai Sun; Tang, Chi Wing

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61533503?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper discusses the empowerment strategies of self-help groups from the perspectives of participatory research & organization development, with two practice projects carried out by the authors as illustrations. Results of the projects indicated that the self-help groups involved were empowered at individual & group levels, but not at social & policy levels. The authors point out that the function of self-help groups in Hong Kong is at present limited to saving social resources, resulting from self-help & mutual help. Self-help groups have a long way to go to achieve the goals of promoting equality, changing community power relationships, & redistributing social resources. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Strategies+for+Empowerment+of+Self-Help+Groups%3A+%22Participatory+Research%22+and+%22Organizational+Development%22&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2000-07-01&amp;volume=34&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=1&amp;author=Mok%2C+Bong+Ho%3BSuen%2C+Lai+Sun%3BTang%2C+Chi+Wing

Welfare Philosophy and Reform of Medical Finance of Hong Kong Government

Author: Yeung, Agnes; Yu, Wai Kam

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61484076?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of this paper is to discuss the Hong Kong government's welfare philosophy & how it is manifested in medical finance reforms. The first part introduces the positive noninterventionism policy upheld by the Hong Kong government & how it is related to the four "prohibited areas" to the development of social welfare. The second part illustrates the Hong Kong government's strategy for strengthening these "prohibited areas" with regard to medical finance reforms. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 21 References. Growing Up Poor: Why Adolescents with Economic Disadvantage Succeed or Fail

Author: Shek, Daniel Tan-Lei1; Lam, Ching-Man; Lam, Mang-Chow; Tsoi, Kcon-Wah; Tsang, Sandra Kit-Man1 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin danielshek@cuhk.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61495996?accountid=14925

Abstract: Although studies have been conducted to examine the impact of poverty on child & adolescent development, they are plagued with conceptual as well as methodological limitations, & no systematic studies have been conducted in the Chinese culture. This study attempts to (1) examine the personal coping resources & stresses, particularly economic stresses, faced by poor adolescents; (2) understand the family environment of adolescents living in poverty; (3) investigate the extrafamilial environment of adolescents experiencing economic hardship; (4) examine the psychosocial adjustment of poor adolescents; (5) study the influences of individual, family, & extrafamilial factors on the psychosocial adjustment of adolescents in poverty; & (6) understand what characterizes poor adolescents who show signs of good adaptation (resilience) vs maladjustment (vulnerability). Adapted from the source document.

The Implementation of a Sustainable Social Work Exchange Program: The University of Georgia and the University of Veracruz

Author: Boyle, David P1; Cervantes, Bertha Murrieta1 School Social Work, U Georgia, Lawrenceville Dboyle@arches.uga.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61507316?accountid=14925

Abstract: Over a period of 8 years, the U of Georgia (UGA) & the U of Veracruz (UV), Mexico, developed a model of a sustainable exchange program. The Schools of Social Work of the two universities took the lead in implementing the program, which included short intensive courses for graduate students, faculty members, & alumni in Jalapa, Veracruz, hosted by the School for Foreign Students (Escuela para Estudientes Extranjeros) of UV; intensive brief classes for UGA undergraduates at the two Schools of Social Work of UV; jointly sponsored continuing education seminars; semester-long social work practicum experiences for UGA students at sites in Veracruz; faculty exchanges; & publishable research by faculty & students of the two institutions. This paper summarizes the activities, the developmental processes involved, & the lessons learned with some recommendations for similar programs. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Implementation+of+a+Sustainable+Social+Work+Exchange+Program%3A+The+University+of+Georgia+and+the+University+of+Veracruz&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=2000-07-01&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=11&amp;author=Boyle%2C+David+P%3BCervantes%2C+Bertha+Murrieta

The Use of Debriefings in Response to Disasters and Traumatic Events

Author: Miller, Joshua11 School Social Work, Smith Coll, Northampton, MA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467418?accountid=14925

Abstract: A debriefing is a structured group process that responds to the collective experience of trauma as a consequence of disasters. This paper considers what a debriefing is, why it should be used, & then compares different debriefing models. A detailed example is provided of a debriefing model developed by a community-based team. The article concludes with an examination of how debriefings are consistent with social work theory & practice & offers suggestions for continuing education. The paper is informed by the author's experience as a member of a local community crisis response team. 2 Tables, 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Single-System Evaluation of Child Protective Services Training

Author: Smith, Thomas Edward1; Schinke, Steven Paul; Springer, David W1 School Social Work, Florida State U, Tallahassee tsmith@mailer.fsu.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61468045?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes a study of training methods for child protective services workers in which 34 child protective services workers were tested before & after a 5-day clinical training program. A subset of workers was repeatedly tested within a multiple-probe research design to evaluate the effects of instruction, modeling, & practice. Posttraining gains were seen for workers' knowledge of child development & behavior change principles, facts about child abuse & neglect, & self-control & anger management abilities. Observational data on the subset of workers during protective services interviews showed increasingly more specificity, reinforcement, modeling, & rehearsals with a client as the workers learned each training method. Along with their observed clinical skills, workers in the subset reported progressively less anxiety, greater effectiveness, & higher predictions of future success with the child protective services client. Consumer feedback from all protective services workers supported the relevance, applicability, & value of clinical training. The behavioral training presented here can be replicated in practice settings. Innovating & evaluating child protective services curricula can be accomplished with single-system designs. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Status of Women in India: An Interstate Comparison

Author: Kanitkar, Tara1; Mistry, Malika1 Instit Health Management Pachod, Pune Centre, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61663854?accountid=14925

Abstract: Uses data from the 1992/93 National Family Health Survey to explore the status of women in India. The indicators used were literacy & education, exposure to mass media, work status, age at marriage, fertility, & use of family planning methods. Analysis reveals that women in two states, Himachal Pradesh in the extreme North & Kerala in the extreme South, enjoy higher status per these indicators. The state of Rajasthan occupies the last rank. The analysis also shows that economically progressive states need not be socially progressive. Maharashtra occupies first rank as far as economic indicators are concerned; however, it does not fare well on other aspects of social development. 3 Tables, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Level of Development-Orientation in Educated Unemployed Young Men: The Reality

Author: Singh, Lal Bahadur1; Kumari, Renu; Kumari, Meera1 Dept Psychology, T. M. Bhagalpur U, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61672482?accountid=14925

Abstract: A randomly selected group of 400 highly educated young men, ages 25-35, equally divided into four categories -- technically & non-technically educated unemployed, & technically & non-technically educated employed -- were compared in terms of their level of development orientation & its dimensions measured by a 41-item 4-point Development Orientation Scale (Nasir, Rani, & Singh, 1995). All the groups were found to differ significantly from each other. It was apparent that the non-technically educated unemployed young men, followed by the technically educated ones, were clearly less development oriented, but, similar to their employed counterparts, they were not below moderate level. Moreover, both the unemployed groups scored high on risk-taking & low on liberal & progressive views. The employed groups were also high on risk-taking, but, unlike the former, low on egalitarianism. 2 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Challenges for Modern Social Work in Russia: Problems and Prospects

Author: Tregoubova, Tatiana11 Research Instit Professional Education, Moscow, Russia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61468882?accountid=14925

Abstract: Because social work as a profession appeared in Russia only in 1991, there is a deficit of social work experience & qualified personnel to solve the social problems of the Russian population. To what extent is real deterioration in social services, education, health care, & culture in the Russian society observed, or an explosion of negative information regarding persistent problems rather than an actual increase in the magnitude of those problems being seen? Moreover, to what extent are the negative features of the contemporary social situation in Russia the result of the politics of reform, & to what extent are the inevitable consequences of the USSR's totalitarian past? The normal functioning & development of social work & social services in Russia can be secured through radical changes in the people's attitude. It may be necessary to carry out public relations activities that will attract people's attention toward the social work role & challenges in Russia. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Rudolph, Claire S11 Syracuse U, NY

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61503305?accountid=14925

Professional Social Work Education in Child Welfare: Assessing Practice Knowledge and Skills

Author: Scannapieco, Maria1; Bolen, Rebecca M; Connell, Kelli K1 U Texas, Arlington

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467916?accountid=14925

Abstract: Historically, the profession of social work has held a leadership role in the field of child welfare. There has been a history of collaborations between schools of social work & child welfare & state child welfare agencies. Today, hundreds of these partnerships throughout the country (Zlotnik, 1997) are spending millions of federal dollars to professionally educate Bachelor of Social Work & Master of Social Work students for careers in child welfare. Unfortunately, there is not a corresponding proliferation of evaluation research that attempts to measure the effectiveness of these partnerships. This article provides a comprehensive description & evaluation of a partnership between a school of social work & a state (TX) department of child protective services. The evaluation focuses on student learning & an exploratory examination of practice changes in the agency. 5 Tables, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

World-Wide Beginnings of Social Work Education

Author: Kendall, Katherine A

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61665207?accountid=14925

Abstract: Records the evolution of social work education from the efforts of Victorian reformers in the late 19th century to remodel charity work as scientific philanthropy. To the extent possible, the story is told in the words of all the people involved. The very first school of social work, with a 2-year full-time program, was established in Amsterdam, Netherlands, in 1899, but the real beginnings of social work education are found in Octavia Hill's training of volunteers in housing management & "friendly visiting" in London, England, in the 1870s. Expansion of this training in the 1880s, in cooperation with the Women's University Settlement, led in 1890 to an organized 1-year program of courses & field practice that evolved, under the direction of the Charity Organization Society, into the London School of Sociology, launched in 1903. In addition to the school already established in the Netherlands, the early 1900s saw a blossoming of schools or programs of social work in the US, the UK, & Germany. The first in Asia, Africa, & South America, which came later, are also described along with the legacies of these many beginnings. 1 Reference. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=World-Wide+Beginnings+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2000-04-01&amp;volume=61&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=141&amp;author=Kendall%2C+Katherine+A

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=World-Wide+Beginnings+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2000-04-01&amp;volume=61&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=141&amp;author=Kendall%2C+Katherine+A

Internationalising Social Work Education

Author: Cox, David11 Regional Social Development Centre, La Trobe U, Melbourne, Australia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61620672?accountid=14925

Abstract: The time has come to make a conscious & concerted effort to internationalize social work practice & education in line with global developments. The three core global problems are poverty, conflict, & ecological degradation. Behind these problems are several root causes, eg, economic & political globalization, & flowing from the core problems is a wide range of more specific social problems, including displaced persons, prostitution, child labor, & rapid urbanization -- all with some global dimensions. If the world's core problems, their root causes, & consequent social problems are all international to some degree, social work is obliged to respond. Here, an analysis of the situation & of social work suggests that social work can contribute at all three levels depicted above, provided that social work education paves the way. 22 References. Teaching of Social Sciences in Schools for Social Work

Author: Kulkarni, P D11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61620698?accountid=14925

Abstract: Emphasizes that the relationship of social science to social work is umbilical; eg, social work is applied social sciences. Applied syllabi can be prepared realistically & taught effectively only by the teachers having direct exposure to socioeconomic problems in the field. Multidisciplinary, separate, & parallel teaching is not enough; it must be integrated into this interdisciplinary approach. Scientific social research should be regarded as essentially useful for diagnosis & estimation of the dimensions of social problems, as a database for planning social programs, & for evaluation of social welfare services. 1 Reference. Admission Criteria and Internal Assessment in a School of Social Work: An Analysis

Author: Visvesvaran, P K11 Madras School Social Work, Chennai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61655285?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examining admissions data (N = 308 candidates) from a school of social work, it is established that candidates' past performance (Bachelor's Degree) determines the outcome of the entrance test in a significant manner. Moreover, variations in grades received by the trainees seem to stem from differences in the teachers' approach to evaluation, rather than from true differences in performance. For greater transparency & fairness, a regular & candid appraisal of the evaluation process by teachers themselves is essential. 9 Tables, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Hamara Club: A Project for Street Children

Author: Rane, Asha J

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61665965?accountid=14925

Abstract: The creation of the Hamara Club, a project supported by India's Tata Instit of Social Sciences & designed to address the problem of street children in Mumbai City, is examined. An overview of the Hamara Club's historical background & primary objectives is presented. Additional information concerning the intervention strategies used & the services & programs offered through the Hamara Club is reported. The major achievements of the Hamara Club are identified: (1) having a positive effect on the lives of thousands of street children by providing health care, education, & training to them; (2) placing individuals with graduate degrees in social work in the program; & (3) permitting street children to participate in several local & national social campaigns. Different training modules used for training social workers & officials in addressing the street children problem are discussed. After considering the project's need for survival, it is concluded that the program should be turned over to a respectable nongovernment organization. 6 References. J. W. Parker

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Hamara+Club%3A+A+Project+for+Street+Children&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2000-04-01&amp;volume=61&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=285&amp;author=Rane%2C+Asha+J

An Ongoing Journey: Learning from a Field Action Project in the Police System

Author: Dave, Anjali11 Dept Family & Child Welfare, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India Special Cell Women & Children, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61621175?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Special Cell for Women & Children, a program designed to study & intervene in domestic violence & violence against women, is explored. The program's 15-year history, extent of learning that has taken place between women & professionals, fund raising projects, & creation of a collaborative project between local police & the Special Cell are discussed. The role of the Tata Instit of Social Sciences in Mumbai, India, in training social workers assigned to the collaborative project is reviewed. The Special Cell has contributed to research in violence against women & children & has facilitated the introduction of gender issues into the police system. It is noted that police who participated in the project & then transferred to other regions of India implemented gender analysis into the new police departments. Although the Special Cell has gained the attention of the Indian state, it is concluded that the government has failed to provide additional support & resources for the project. J. W. Parker

Social Work Education and its Application to General Unversity Education: An Interview with Prof. Armaity S. Desai

Author: Desai, Armaity S

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61646952?accountid=14925

Abstract: Desai discusses the issue of social work education in India. Topics include the current status of social work education, the connection between social work training & practice, the influence of liberalism & globalization on social work instruction, the future objectives for social work education in India, differences in the administration of social work education & other academic programs, & the implications of incorporating social work training into the general education requirements at Indian universities. Several attention is given to the need to encourage cooperation between educators & practitioners, the lack of management training received by social workers, the establishment of distance education & international social work courses in Indian universities, & the need to decentralize university examinations. J. W. Parker

Research into the Role of the Practice Assessor

Author: Schumann, Catherine1; Barraclough, John1 North London Practice Teaching Consortium, c/o Islington Social Services Staff Training & Development, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61494156?accountid=14925

Abstract: The research on which this article is based came about because the writers were aware of a discrepancy between practice teaching portfolios that were failed or referred by their program's assessment panel, but who were given positive recommendations by their practice assessor. The standard of the portfolio was not therefore being reflected in the practice assessor's recommendations. We wanted to know if this was happening on other practice teaching programs, & whether there were any internal factors within programs which contributed to more, or less rigorous practice assessment processes. The article contains statistical data from practice teaching programs throughout CCETSW's England Regions. We have also included some qualitative data gained from canvassing practice assessors from three different practice teaching programs & to their views about the practice assessment process. The research findings confirmed our experience in relation to the discrepancy between assessment panels & practice assessor recommendations, but threw up some surprises about how practice assessors function. Adapted from the source document.

The Assessment of Incompetence: Practice Teachers' Support Needs When Working with Failing DipSW Students

Author: Sharpe, Mavis

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458941?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper describes a research project that examined the support & training needs of practice teachers as they work with failing DipSW students. It was based on discussion & interviews with a sample of accredited practice teachers working on a "singleton" basis (ie, practice teachers who are practicing social workers, based in the same workplace as the student, offering usually only one placement at any one time). An account is given of the aims, background, methodology, & main findings of the study. The conclusions have implications for practice teacher training in respect of the fuller integration of the possibility of failure. They also indicate the need for more & different support systems for practice teachers that incorporate an understanding of the mourning process in an educational setting. The study was exploratory, & limited in scope. Thus, while it identified some issues appropriate for immediate implementation, it also highlights pertinent areas for further research. 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Practice Teaching and Learning on an Interprofessional Course

Author: Davis, Jean1; Rendell, Pauline; Sims, Dave1 Faculty Health, South Bank U London, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61483796?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores the assessment of practice learning on a joint Nursing & Social Work Studies course. Various models of placements have been developed to provide an appropriate learning environment, & three case examples are described & analyzed. Key issues particularly relevant to practice teaching in an interprofessional context are identified. Students' practice learning is assessed by an interprofessional practice assessment panel in an integrated competency framework meeting both social work & learning disability nursing requirements. Some general principles of practice teaching & learning in the training of the joint practitioner are discussed. 3 Figures, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Involving Service Users in the Assessment of Students in Professional Practice

Author: Cuming, Hilary1; Wilkins, Judi1 School Health & Social Sciences, U Wales Instit, Cardiff

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61469307?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper offers guidance for professionals on the involvement of service users in providing feedback about students on professional training programs in health & social care. It has resulted from recognizing the need not only to involve service users in the assessment of students, but also to develop the associated processes, &, therefore, some guidelines for service users, students, & practice teachers. We also wanted to provide the opportunity for service users to evaluate their experience of giving feedback about the involvement of Diploma in Social Work students in their lives. A small-scale research study, funded by the Wales Office of Research & Development of Health & Social Care, allowed this evaluation to take place. This work not only promoted & validated the current procedures used on placement in the practice agencies, but also enabled us to suggest these generic guidelines. 1 Figure, 1 Appendix, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Assessing Reflective Practice: New Research Findings

Author: Ixer, Graham11 CCETSW, London, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61504165?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper explores the responsibility that practice teachers have in facilitating students' professional development through reflection. It puts forward the view that students must take responsibility for their own learning. There are differences in the needs of students & experienced workers, but both need the opportunity to reflect & develop. However, we need a shared understanding, both of what reflection is, & of the difficulties for workers in ensuring that they use that process to maintain professional practice of the highest standard. 23 References. Practice Teachers as a Learning Community: The Experience of a Practice Teachers Training Programme in Social Work

Author: Tsang, Nai-Ming11 Dept Applied Social Sciences, Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470471?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article reports the organization & evaluation of a Practice Teachers Training Programme in Hong Kong. The course objectives, content, pedagogical design, & feedback from participants are elaborated. The joining together of a group of practice teachers for a common purpose brings an end to their "lonely & private business." Cognitively, they are asked to locate their practice in relevant current literature. Emotionally they are exposed to the tension created by the role switch from "teachers" to "learners." They feel more connected in mutual sharing & support as a community of learners. Peer review of taped supervisory sessions with students is deemed valuable. Judgments & assumptions are examined. They are exposed to a variety of approaches, conception, & skills as seen from their professional colleagues in action. It is hoped that the experience in running this course will provide a useful reference for other educational institutions. 2 Figures, 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Practice+Teachers+as+a+Learning+Community%3A+The+Experience+of+a+Practice+Teachers+Training+Programme+in+Social+Work&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Health+and+Social+Work&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=2000-01-01&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=21&amp;author=Tsang%2C+Nai-Ming

On-Site Supervisors: The Unsung Partners in the Training Team?

Author: Burgess, Robin C1; Phillips, Rena1 Dept Applied Social Science, U Stirling, Scotland r.c.p.burgess@stir.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61457982?accountid=14925

Abstract: There is very little research on on-site supervisors, who carry the detailed day-to-day work-based support of social work students. This model is increasingly being used as placements become more difficult to find & the need for a wide variety of learning experiences has been recognized. The authors provide the findings from a study in which face-to-face interviews were held with 27 on-site supervisors in both statutory & voluntary agencies within three Scottish regional consortia. The themes explored are training, perceptions of roles, supervision of students, contribution to the assessment process, relationships with practice teachers, communications with academic institutions, & benefits & difficulties of on-site supervision. Recommendations are offered which could enhance the important contribution made by on-site supervisors to the training of students. 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

AP(E)L and the Practice Teaching Award: Regulations, Experiences and Lessons

Author: Slater, Phil11 School Social Science, Middlesex U, Enfield, England P.Slater@mdx.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61469148?accountid=14925

Abstract: The development of flexible assessment systems must balance two competing demands: on the one hand, the maintenance of common academic or professional standards, &, on the other, the provision of effective learning opportunities tailored to discrete groups. AP(E)L routes to assessment for CCETSW's Practice Teaching Award have been at the cutting edge of such developments in the social work profession since 1989. After reviewing both the general meaning of AP(E)L systems & the specific background to the Award, this article distills the experiences of a pioneering Practice Teacher Program over the past 11 years. In particular, the article draws out the strategic significance of candidate self-evaluation, & reports on innovative approaches to teaching & learning in this area. 3 Tables, 1 Figure, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Developing Practice Learning: The Practice Teachers' Perspective

Author: Wilson, George11 School Social Work, Queen's U, Belfast, UK g.wilson@qub.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61468619?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article presents a detailed study of the management, training, & support of practice teachers in one Area Health & Social Services Board in Northern Ireland. The article highlights the major strengths of practice teaching in Northern Ireland, including the high percentages of staff holding the Practice Teachers Award. The study, however, identifies similar problems to other parts of the UK in relation to practice teaching turnover & workload easement. Through exploring the perceptions of practice teachers, the article provides an analysis of these problems, & identifies the main ingredients of a comprehensive strategy for improving & developing practice learning. It is argued that the recommendations, arising from the study, are also applicable to other agencies seeking to develop the organizational & professional conditions essential for delivering high quality practice learning. 1 Table, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Let's Develop Practice Learning in Eastern Europe: Innovation in Ukraine and Armenia

Author: Bridge, Gillian11 Dept Social Policy, LSE, London, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61505871?accountid=14925

Abstract: After the collapse of communism & the dissolution of the Soviet Union, many countries in Eastern Europe, including Armenia & Ukraine, turned to the West for help in developing social work training as a solution to their burgeoning social problems. As the integration of theory & practice was central to the success of these innovative projects, expertise in practice learning was required. The author was one of many academics & practitioners recruited from the UK to participate. This article describes & analyzes different strategies used to develop practice learning within the Eastern European context. The conclusion reached is that attempts to develop training in practice teaching were inappropriate, but that there remains considerable potential for nurturing practice learning initiatives within the surviving state funded agencies & the growing nongovernmental organization sectors of social welfare. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Ethical Issues in the Assessment of the Value Base in Social Work Students

Author: Deacon, Lynda11 Open U, Leeds, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61429586?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues that student social workers must demonstrate personal & professional values & ethics that will make them culturally competent & allow them to practice in an anti-oppressive, antidiscriminatory manner. It is contended that oppression & prejudice are evident in college courses & social work practice. The CCETSW value requirements for social workers are delineated. The notion of "reflective practice" is discussed, emphasizing the need for educators to work at understanding reflection so they can teach students to assess & articulate their own value base to develop personal & professional values that will allow them to practice without inflicting damage on users or colleagues. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Police Checks, Placements and Paedophiles

Author: Smith, Joanne M1; Thomas, Terry1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work, U Plymouth, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61525585?accountid=14925

Abstract: Criminal record checks have been an accepted form of pre-employment vetting for those with access to children for some years but their role in social work placements remains variable across Diploma in Social Work programs. The police check system itself is not without criticism, but in the realm of placements, it becomes even more problematic. The authors of this paper highlight some of the complexities enmeshed in both the history of policy surrounding the police check & the implications for current implementation, particularly for social work students undertaking placements. 39 References. Continuing Education across Boundaries: Exploring the International Exchange of Social Work Knowledge and Practices

Author: Traub-Werner, Beatrice11 School Social Work, U Toronto, Ontario

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467277?accountid=14925

Abstract: Internationalization has produced a situation where events in one part of the world has a direct impact on the rest of the globe. In all professions, especially social work & human services enterprises, the need for information exchange & cooperation has become necessary for collective survival. Upheaval in parts of the world has forced welcoming nations to search for ways to address the diversities that migrations entail. This journal has attempted to develop a journalistic dialogue that will help neighborhood life where social work exists to assist societal intervention. Internationalizing the professional development of social workers is the next step. There is a need for international exchanges in continuing education, & it is proposed that the journal devote a section or an entire issue to the discussion of a certain topic, problem, or situation from as many geographic & social settings as possible. 8 References. E. Larsen
