The "Warmth" Profession: Societal Perceptions of Social Work Practice

Author: Hall, Ronald E11 Michigan State U, East Lansing

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61492037?accountid=14925

Abstract: Perceptions of social work evolved from a history of social services, including child welfare & mental health (Carlton-LaNey, 1999). Yet, critics have challenged its occupational status as a profession. According to critics, social work training is less rigorous, & its status less esteemed, giving its practitioners less right to privileged communication. In the aftermath, social workers are perceived as warm but not particularly intelligent. In fact, the generalist approach & grounding in ethics qualify social work training as rigorous & their practitioners as intelligent professionals. By & large, social work has arrived at professional status. However, it needs to further clarify & codify its technology. 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Using Focus Groups to Design an Interagency Training Program for Child Welfare Workers

Author: Packard, Thomas1; Jones, Loring; Gross, Elizabeth; Hohman, Melinda; Fong, Terri1 School Social Work, San Diego State U, CA tpackard@mail.sdsu.edu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470711?accountid=14925

Abstract: A five-day interagency training program for child welfare, domestic violence, mental health, & substance abuse workers was conducted six times over two years. Interagency collaboration was the underlying emphasis of the training. To ensure the relevance & utility of the training, five focus groups were held with professionals from various disciplines & agency settings to receive suggestions on session content. Themes included cultural factors, definitions, assessment, intervention methods, & available community resources. Collaboration issues included roles, conflict resolution, consensus building, confidentiality, team building, & cultural dynamics. The groups also seemed to serve a marketing function, creating interest in the training, & they helped reinforce the credibility of the trainers & their design. Training content is identified; the focus group process should be of use to other training designers. 4 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Exploring "The Managed Behavioral Health Care Provider Self-Perceived Competence Scale." A Tool for Continuing Professional Education

Author: Hall, Michael L1; Keefe, Robert H1 c/o Keefe -- School Social Work, Coll Human Services & Health Professions, Syracuse U, NY

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470728?accountid=14925

Abstract: "The Managed Behavioral Health Care Provider Self-Perceived Competence Scale" was adapted from prior work on self-perceived competence & self-efficacy. The adapted scale emerged from a sample of private practitioners surveyed for their responses to questions concerning their self-perceived competence in interacting with managed behavioral health care organizations. The results indicate the development of a psychological dimension along which practitioners are operating as they balance their responsibilities to clients & managed care organizations. Continuing education programs may wish to use the scale to assist in evaluating workshops for practitioners working with managed behavioral health care organizations. 4 Tables, 1 Figure, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Distance Education: Teaching Practice Methods Using Interactive Television

Author: Kleinpeter, Christine Hagan1; Potts, Marilyn K1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61492062?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study compares 35 on-campus & 41 distance MSW students enrolled in two summer block practice methods courses. The distance students were located at two rural universities linked through interactive TV. The comparison group was located at an urban university, taught in traditional classrooms. Comparisons were made on student grades, faculty evaluations, & field instructors' evaluations. Results indicate that no significant differences were found between on-campus & distance learners. 2 Tables, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Globalisation: An Opportunity for Dialogue between South African and Asian Social Work Educators

Author: Drower, Sandra J11 School Social Work, U Witwatersrand, South Africa

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61646109?accountid=14925

Abstract: During the second half of the 20th century, the developing world has borne the brunt of the negative consequences of globalization. With respect to social work education & training, globalization has often resulted in inappropriate training, practices, & services. Through describing the various themes that arose during a visit by a South African social work educator to a number of centers in Asia, explored here is the pertinence of developing a dialogue between South African & Asian social work educators & trainers. It is concluded that such dialogue has the potential to be more empowering & beneficial for social work in these developing countries than continued deference to Western models of social work education & training. 1 Table, 26 References. Attitudes of the Student Youth and Middle Aged Persons towards the Elderly

Author: Rao, K Visweswara1; Prasad, B Devi; Avataramu, Ch1 Dept Social Work, Andhra U, Visakhapatnam, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61665106?accountid=14925

Abstract: Scale data from 75 university students & 114 rural, middle-age respondents (Rs) in Andhra Pradesh, India, are drawn on to assess their attitudes toward the elderly. Results indicate that the students & Rs not living with old people in their families, men, Rs belonging to disadvantaged sections of the society, & Rs from low-income groups hold more negative attitudes toward the elderly as compared to their counterparts. More specifically, poverty appears to be significantly associated with negative attitudes toward the elderly, which may be the consequence of lack of financial resources to care for them. It is recommended that programs be designed to integrate the aged into the family & social fabric, to bring the younger generations closer to the elderly, & to provide families with support services so as to enable them to take better care of old people. 3 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Attitudes+of+the+Student+Youth+and+Middle+Aged+Persons+towards+the+Elderly&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2000-01-01&amp;volume=61&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=42&amp;author=Rao%2C+K+Visweswara%3BPrasad%2C+B+Devi%3BAvataramu%2C+Ch

Is Education a Priority for Scheduled Castes? A Study of Three Districts of Bihar

Author: Pant, S K11 Govind Ballabh Pant Social Science Instit, Allahabad, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61646151?accountid=14925

Abstract: Though literacy has been unanimously accepted as a very potent & significant social variable for bringing about socioeconomic & cultural transformation, & planners in India have placed significant importance on it, analysis of 4 decades of planned development shows that literacy has still to find a place among the weaker sections of the society, particularly the Scheduled Castes, who are ruled by social issues like poverty, unemployment, backwardness, apprehensions, & morbidity. Data obtained through the participatory rural technique are used to investigate the status of primary-level educational services for children in 54 villages in 3 districts of Bihar, & suggestions for improvement are offered. 10 Tables, 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

Focus on NGOs as Agents of Social Development: A Book Review Essay

Author: Mahtani, Rajshree P11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61657159?accountid=14925

Abstract: A review essay on a book edited by M. C. Nanavatty & P. D. Kulkarni NGOs in the Changing Scenario (New Delhi: Uppal Publishing House, 1998) regarding nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) in India. The volume consists of two sections: voluntarism, & professional education & development. While it is noted that important issues are raised, the work is criticized for the lack of integration between the two sections & the disjointed papers that were previously written for specific purposes other than the topic at hand. It is posited that this rather gloomy portrait of NGOs is not substantiated by any systematic research. Further, it is concluded that multipronged interventions will be needed to address the concerns raised. T. Noland

Social Workers and Technology: Challenges of the Multidisciplinary Team

Author: Cauble, A Elizabeth1; Dinkel, Janice M1 Dept Sociology/Anthropology/Social Work, Kansas State U, Manhattan

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470695?accountid=14925

Abstract: As social workers start using technology for continuing education program development & training, they are teaming with technical disciplines. This departure from traditional teamwork creates a new working environment with many challenges. A multidisciplinary training project using interactive multimedia technology is described. The benefits & challenges for social workers as well as other team members are discussed. The authors propose using social work practice methods to plan for & resolve difficulties as they arise in the multidisciplinary team. 1 Table, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Educating Social Workers about Changes in the American Family: Evaluating the Impact of Training

Author: Buttell, Fred11 Coll Social Work, U South Carolina, Columbia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61468021?accountid=14925

Abstract: Reports on SC's efforts to educate social work practitioners about various trends influencing the structure of the US family. Analysis of the pretraining data indicated that the participants were largely ill-informed about the rapidly changing family structure in the US. However, analysis of the posttraining data demonstrated that there was significant improvement in their knowledge of the program material. Implications of the findings for using continuing education as a forum for disseminating information about changing family structures are explored & discussed. 1 Table, 1 Appendix, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Personality Comparison between On-Campus and Distant Learners: Implications for Continuing Social Work Education

Author: Hagan, Christine B1; Potts, Marilyn K; Wilson, Ginger K1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61416811?accountid=14925

Abstract: The NEO-Personality Inventory (Costa & McCrae, 1989) was used to compare 37 distance learners & 53 on-campus MSW students on five facets of personality: neuroticism, extraversion, openness, agreeableness, & conscientiousness. Findings indicated minimal differences between off-campus & on-campus cohorts. Among distance learners, personality factors had negligible effects on student satisfaction. These findings suggest that personality factors have little influence on the successful recruitment & retention of distance education students. Such efforts might focus more productively on improving the learning environment in distance education classrooms. 2 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Collaborative Training Effort between a Continuing Education Program of a Graduate School of Social Work and a Volunteer Mentoring Youth Service Agency

Author: Cullen, Carolyn T1; Champagne, Vae L; Zischka, Pauline C1 Education & Community Services, Big Brothers Big Sisters New York, New York

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61463542?accountid=14925

Abstract: As youth mentoring emerges as a rapidly growing field, social work continuing education can play a significant role in providing the specialized training necessary for individuals who supervise volunteer mentors. A new partnership model between a social work continuing education program & a mentoring agency is described which provides training to social service staff in the area of youth mentoring. The authors discuss the increasing need for mentoring staff training, benefits of such a collaboration, & feedback from training participants. The development of a standard curriculum by which individuals may earn credit could be a major contribution to the mentoring field. 1 Table, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Human Services Training Effectiveness Postcard (HSTEP): A Tool for Research and Evaluation of Human Services Training

Author: Curry, Dale1; Chandler, Theodore1 Northeast Ohio Regional Training Center, Summit County Children Services, Akron

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61468867?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes a brief mail survey questionnaire postcard used as an outcome indicator to promote research & assess training effectiveness for human service personnel. A study of almost 600 child protective social workers utilized the Human Services Training Effectiveness Postcard (HSTEP) to assess perceived impact of training on the job & to explore factors that influenced training application. Information on the reliability & validity of the tool is discussed. A survey questionnaire that assessed 11 transfer factors (Transfer Potential Questionnaire) provided supportive data, which helped strengthen the validity of the HSTEP. As information technology begins to spread rapidly & widely, its impact on social work is inevitable. 7 Tables, 2 Figures, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Model for International Continuing Education: Cross-Cultural, Experiential Professional Development

Author: Boyle, David P1; Barranti, Chrystal1 School Social Work, U Georgia, Lawrenceville

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61525902?accountid=14925

Abstract: Since 1995, groups of social work practitioners have participated in a professional education experience, sponsored by the U of Georgia Continuing Education Program in association with the U of Veracruz (Mexico) for 10 days of language instruction, cultural immersion, home stays with Mexican families, visits to social service agencies, & daily social work seminars. The goal of the experience is to expand the skills of practicing social workers toward becoming bilingual & culturally competent for work with Hispanic/Latino clients. The program is described & results are summarized. 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Hong Kong Satellite Children in Canada: An Exploratory Study of Their Experience

Author: Irving, Howard H1; Benjamin, Michael; Tsang, A K Tat1 Faculty Social Work, U Toronto, Ontario

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61511256?accountid=14925

Abstract: Astronaut Chinese families are those in which one or both parents spend much of their time in Hong Kong or Taiwan, leaving their satellite adolescent children to complete their education in Canada. To explore the experiences of these children, interviews were conducted with 68 of them living in Toronto, Ontario. Responses were examined using thematic analysis & the software program -- NUD-IST. Three meta-themes emerged, concerned with ethnic identity development, the socially constructed character of immigrant adolescent experience, & the salient role of time in their adjustment to resettlement. Practice/policy implications are discussed. 74 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Hong+Kong+Satellite+Children+in+Canada%3A+An+Exploratory+Study+of+Their+Experience&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1999-07-01&amp;volume=33&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=1&amp;author=Irving%2C+Howard+H%3BBenjamin%2C+Michael%3BTsang%2C+A+K+Tat

Personal Epistemology of Social Work Students

Author: Tsang, Nai-Ming11 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61535043?accountid=14925

Abstract: The issue on theory practice integration in social work brings attention to the difference between positivist & social construction epistemology. The "Attitude about Reality Scale" developed by Unger et al (1986) tries to measure the personal epistemology of students toward logical positivism & social constructionism. A modified form of the scale was used to measure the personal epistemology of 723 social work students or graduates. Significant differences were detected between diploma & degree students. As social work knowledge is increasingly affected by social constructionism, the implications for further research are discussed. 6 Tables, 1 Appendix, 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Marxist Approaches to Western Psychiatry: A Preliminary Examination

Author: Mondal, Parthasarathi11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61625150?accountid=14925

Abstract: Mainstream psychiatry, with its progressivist undertones, has recently come under attack from some viewpoints that draw their inspiration from Marxist tenets. According to their understanding of human behavior, mental illness, & the nature of the community's responses to the problem, the critiques become identifiable as reformist, environmentalist, structural, labor theory, & democratic psychiatry. They show how economic considerations & class forces have been important guiding factors in societal responses to mental distress across the ages, & how mainstream psychiatry has played a role in controlling mental distress as a part of the overall needs of socioeconomic & political governance in Western capitalist societies. 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social and Educational Problems of Scheduled Castes: Some Critical Insights

Author: Wankhede, G G11 Unit Research Sociology Education, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61625177?accountid=14925

Abstract: Critically analyzes the social & educational problems of the Scheduled Castes in India, with particular reference to the educated members of this caste in their social contexts. Statistical data & previous research demonstrate how social problems obstruct the motivation level, quality, & utility of education. Although education carries inherent handicaps, it has proved to be the best means for the overall development of the Scheduled Castes. However, their emotional achievements must be analyzed within the parameters of their sociocultural & economic conditions. Therefore, their past must be linked with the present, which directly affects their educational progress. 8 Tables, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Convocation Address

Author: Shiva, Vandana11 Research Foundation Science Technology & Ecology, Dehradun, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61619908?accountid=14925

Abstract: Outlines some of the social & ecological disasters faced in India as a direct result of globalization. The oppressive roles of the World Bank & World Trade Organization, as well as the inherently political nature of globalization, are discussed. The total control agendas of multinational conglomerates, comprising patent rights, intellectual property rights, & technological tools, constitutes a rejection of both social & environmental responsibility on the part of the firm; specific examples are cited. It is argued that such corporate monopolization of the vital basis of life necessarily engenders a corresponding disintegration of democracy. It is suggested that globalization will also create democratic opportunities that must be seized if India is to reclaim its social & ecological heritage. T. Noland

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Convocation+Address&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1999-07-01&amp;volume=60&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=462&amp;author=Shiva%2C+Vandana

Globalization, Technology and Continued Professional Education

Author: Kelly, Michael J1; Lauderdale, Michael L1 School Social Work, U Missouri, Columbia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61503273?accountid=14925

Abstract: This special issue on social work continuing education explores some of the more salient factors seen to be influencing the direction of professional continuing education. Briefly, there are four analytically separable but intertwined changes that will, when taken together, influence how CE professionals will conduct their work. The first factor is globalization of business & social services including changes in consumer demand. The second is the resulting changes in organizations as they respond to competitive pressures via staff involvement & continuous learning. The third is the computerization of the workplace &, finally, the fourth, the "blurring" of the distinction between formal education, credentialing, in-service training, & continuing education. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Failed Promise of Hypertechnology in Social Work

Author: Kreuger, Larry W1; Stretch, John J1 School Social Work, U Missouri, Columbia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467396?accountid=14925

Abstract: The authors argue that the "worldwide hypertechnology assemblage" has not lived up to its promise. They are concerned about a shift from worker-client face-to-face dynamics to impersonal photographic images. The importance of nonverbal cues has been greatly diminished, as a further example of quantitative over qualitative. The authors have adapted a set of nine recommendations, developed in 1992 by Mander, which suggest ways in which the social work profession should respond. 52 References. Adapted from the source document.

Paradigm Shifts and E-Training Preparedness

Author: Pittman, Sharon Weaver11 School Social Work, Andrews U, Berrien Springs, MI

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467408?accountid=14925

Abstract: E-training opportunities abound. Organizations that remain entrenched in traditional methods will find themselves obsolete. Shifts in approach to staff training & development may be nominal or radical depending on the organization's historical responsiveness to the infusion of technology. Adapting Tapscott's (1996) model for defining paradigm shifts, the author suggests parameters that organizational leadership can use to develop a value-added approach for 21st-century staff development & training. Also provided is a Training Shift Readiness Assessment Tool that can be useful in evaluating an organization's preparedness for the next millennium. Survey outcomes can suggest areas where the equipment or software may need to be updated. 1 Table, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

New Information Technology and Social Work Education in South Korea

Author: Kim, YoungJong11 Graduate School Social Welfare, Kyung Sun U, Pusan, South Korea

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61525827?accountid=14925

Abstract: The author describes the current state of technological development & its impact on social work education in South Korea. During the 1990s, there has been a general consensus on the usefulness of borrowing information technology for the social work profession & education. The idea has not, however, been fully developed because of various obstacles, including the high costs of utilizing those technologies. Now the costs are being lowered at rapid rate, & as information technology begins to spread rapidly & widely, its impact on social work is inevitable. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Landuyt, Noel11 School Social Work, U Texas, Austin

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61468008?accountid=14925

Abstract: The author focuses on the task of upper-level management in mentoring & in guiding the development of lower-ranking supervisors. This may include overseeing areas of continuing education. These tasks require access to accurate & pertinent data. The author explains how a general assessment of organizational functioning, using the Survey of Organizational Excellence, creates a need for specific continuing education. The use of Internet technology captures employee perceptual data basic to successful work with the supervisors. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Intercaste Marriage and Social Dynamics in India: A Critique

Author: Saroja, K11 Dept of Human Development, Rural Home Science Coll, U of Agricultural Sciences, Dharwad

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61619457?accountid=14925

Abstract: Identifies adverse social dynamics acting overtly & covertly against the expected growth of intercaste marriages in India, despite the forces of modernization, increased education & employment of women, & increased social interaction of young people of different castes. The nexus between the adaptations of the caste system to the needs of the young people & the continuation of both arranged marriage & caste endogamy is elaborated. The emergence of opposition from caste & communal forces to intermarriage is also noted. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Exparte Divorce: An Overview

Author: Badiger, Manavva S1; Krishnaswamy, Saroja1 AICRP, Dept of Human Development, Rural Home Science Coll, U of Agricultural Sciences, Dharwad

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61613202?accountid=14925

Abstract: Exparte cases constituted 33% of all divorce cases in Dharwad District, India, 1986-1990, & 91% of all exparte spouses were found to be homemakers, childless, mainly from rural areas, & ignorant of the legal implications of exparte divorce & their loss of claims for husband's property & alimony. Here, through a detailed case study approach, these cases are examined to highlight the sociocultural & legal dynamics leading to divorce & the consequent hardships to exparte wives, emphasizing the imminent need for enhanced legal awareness. 5 Tables, 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Far Cry? Revisiting the Prospects of Community Cooperation in Rural South Asia

Author: Khan, Niaz Ahmed11 Dept of Public Administration, U of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61649642?accountid=14925

Abstract: Sheds light on the practical premise of community cooperation & reexamines the contextual (administrative & social) realities in South Asia with an end toward assessing how conducive these realities are in fostering cooperation in rural frontiers. It is argued that any cooperative effort has to be understood & appreciated in light of the contextual conditions. It is concluded that, given the generally unfavorable context, community cooperation is most likely to be selective & limited. 56 References. Adapted from the source document.

Towards Gender Equity: Reflections of a Police Officer

Author: Chakravarty, S11 Administration of Maharashtra Police

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61640060?accountid=14925

Abstract: Based on 25 years experience working in the Maharashtra (India) Police, it is argued that interrelated & reinforcing patterns of sex inequality exist not only in police work, but throughout the institutions of family, community, market, & state. Discussed is how women can be empowered through education, economic independence, & gender awareness. A plea is made for Indian legislation barring sex discrimination in the workplace, similar to the UK Sex Discrimination Act (1975), & gender sensitivity training for government employees is advocated. Author: Allen, Robin1; Nimmagadda, Jayashree1 School Social Work Boise State U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61612746?accountid=14925

Abstract: Addresses the struggle of social work practitioners in working toward social justice while maintaining cultural & ethnic sensitivity. Issues specifically related to social work practice with Asian Indian women who have immigrated to the US are explored from a strength-based perspective. Possible directions for practice with the growing Asian Indian immigrant population that are both ethnically sensitive & empowering are suggested. These approaches were generated through developing an understanding of the rich history & sociocultural context of the lives of women in India. By understanding how Asian Indian women have struggled against oppression in their own country, opportunities for assisting them in overcoming oppression in the US can be discerned. 34 References. Life Satisfaction of Single Parents in Hong Kong

Author: Lee, Mo-Yee1; Law, Chi-Kwong; Tam, Kwok-Kwan1 Coll Social Work Ohio State U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61671520?accountid=14925

Abstract: Concepts derived from North American studies are used in developing a model to investigate the contributions of various factors to the life satisfaction of single Chinese parents in Hong Kong. Path analysis of mail questionnaire data (N = 230 respondents) indicate that household income & time sufficiency in child care positively predict life satisfaction of single parents. Perceived difficulty in child care negatively predicts life satisfaction, while employment has both positive & negative effects. Implications for assisting single parents are discussed. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 49 References. Adapted from the source document.

Supervisor or Superhero: New Role Strains for Frontline Supervisors in Human Services

Author: Jones, Martyn11 Social Work U Exeter

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61630726?accountid=14925

Abstract: Representing a meeting point between professional & organizational interests, supervision has become a contested site of change & resistance in the reconfiguration of human services. Culturally Specific Causes of Delinquency: Implications for Juvenile Justice in Hong Kong

Author: Wong, Dennis S W

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61642573?accountid=14925

Abstract: Based on a review of Western research & personal experience in social work, an integrated interactional model is constructed to identify culturally specific causes of delinquency in Hong Kong. Results of 33 in-depth interviews with delinquents & nondelinquents suggest that reintegrative shaming practices, spirit of brotherhood, & an interdependent social environment are crucial factors pulling or pushing youngsters into or out of delinquency. Appropriate ways to reintegrate offenders into society in a Chinese cultural context are discussed, & a restorative justice approach is advocated for the better development of juvenile justice in Hong Kong. 1 Figure, 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Culturally+Specific+Causes+of+Delinquency%3A+Implications+for+Juvenile+Justice+in+Hong+Kong&amp;title=Asia+Pacific+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02185385&amp;date=1999-03-01&amp;volume=9&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=98&amp;author=Wong%2C+Dennis+S+W

In Defence of Long-Arm Practice Teaching

Author: Bridge, Gillian11 Dept Social Policy, London School Economics & Political Science, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61493698?accountid=14925

Abstract: Long-arm practice teaching has been developed in the UK as a strategy to create practice placements for DipSW students. It has also been seen as an unfortunate emergency arrangement. There has been little substantive research to evaluate this teaching method. This paper, based on the author's experience of supervising four students in this way, argues that with careful planning & anticipation of difficulties, long-arm practice teaching may be considered to be an acceptable alternative model rather than a regrettable aberration. 29 References. Confidentiality, Client Autonomy and Students' Use of Case Material

Author: Quinn, Ann1; Burns, Keith1 Dept Professional Education Community Studies, U Reading, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61483772?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work students frequently use confidential information obtained from clients for their own educational purposes. This raises ethical issues that are relatively unexplored. We believe that students have a duty to uphold the confidentiality of client information, & that current procedures are often inadequate. Anonymizing identity may not be sufficient to preserve confidentiality, when a client has not consented to the use of case material for educational purposes. Equally, in situations where reflection on practice is particularly important, such as with unwilling clients or failed interventions, consent may be unobtainable. We argue that a reflective morality coupled with a respect for client autonomy is more appropriate to resolving such dilemmas. Such an ethical stance can also help students address the inequality of power within the professional relationship. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Confidentiality%2C+Client+Autonomy+and+Students%27+Use+of+Case+Material&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Health+and+Social+Work&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=1999-01-01&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=20&amp;author=Quinn%2C+Ann%3BBurns%2C+Keith

Reflections in the Pool: An Evaluation of a Long-Arm Practice Teaching Strategy for Social Work Placements

Author: Moss, Bernard11 Instit Social Work & Applied Social Studies, Staffordshire U, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61525479?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper is based on a small evaluation study on the effectiveness of the long-arm practice teaching model for DipSW students. Staffordshire U has developed a pool of experienced long-arm practice teachers that enables them to provide placements in a wide range of settings. This article describes how the pool was established, & goes on to discuss its effectiveness, through the responses of the long-arm practice teacher, the job supervisors, & the students involved. It concludes with some recommendations for good practice. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Challenges for the Role of Mentoring in Promoting Reflective Practice

Author: Smith, Pauline11 Instit Education, Crewe, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61653775?accountid=14925

Abstract: Personal experience in British schools is drawn on to examine the skills & processes of mentoring & to identify issues for discussion that are more widely transferable to other occupational areas, eg, health & social work. The thrust of the argument is that schools, as learning organizations, should be able to build on the investment made in work-based mentoring, particularly in relation to the initial & induction phases of teacher development, to promote the culture of reflective practice across the whole organization & beyond. However, the present political & funding context is not fully supportive of more continuous mentor development, & the lack of quality time available for the mentoring process appears to dominate the educational workplace. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Providing Social Work Field Education: Attributes for the Job: A Research Report from New Zealand

Author: Maidment, Jane11 School Social Enquiry, Faculty Arts, Deakin U, Geelong, Victoria, Australia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61525538?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article reports the findings of research conducted in New Zealand during 1996 on field educator attributes that enhance clinical education for social work students during placement. Students were polled immediately before their first placement began (N = 78), & immediately after their first placement concluded (N = 73), to ascertain opinion on what attributes were "most important" for a field educator to demonstrate. Field educators (N = 123) were polled during the placement using the same instrument. Student & field educator responses have been compared. Data analysis yielded two main results. Field educator training influenced attribute selection; neither students nor field educators selected attributes specifically related to social work practice as being "most important.". 3 Tables, 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Evaluation: A Practitioner's Perspective on Continuing Education Programs

Author: Meyers, Raymond C11 Dept Human Services, Philadelphia, PA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61468031?accountid=14925

Abstract: Evaluations are an essential part of continuing education programs & social service agencies, allowing them to plan ahead & providing information on individual & organizational functioning. Also, they provide information on how to achieve established goals, identify attainable benchmarks, & project reasonable timelines. Change in program evaluation is discussed in terms of shift from client process & satisfaction to outcome measures, & the future of such evaluation is forecast centering on developments in methods, services, & technologies. R. Larsen

Evaluation: A Faculty Member's Perspective on Continuing Education Programs

Author: Milner, Lois11 School Social Administration, Temple U, Philadelphia, PA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467263?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses the evaluation of programs & practices of continuing education programs from an academic perspective. Also considered is how continuing education maintains & develops practitioner evaluation skills in an age of rapid technological advance. Historical & current approaches to evaluation research are briefly delineated in terms of the pursuit for desirable research paradigms & the impact on furthering empirical knowledge by limiting published works to those that adhere to traditional models. Continuing education is essential in enabling practitioners to provide the best possible interventions by facilitating evaluation research via providing insight into the relative merits of research tools, methods, & models apace with current technological change. 8 References. R. Larsen

The Role of the Site Coordinator in a Social Work Distance Education Program

Author: Hagan, Christine B1; Wilson, Ginger K; Potts, Marilyn K; Wheeler, Donna; Bess, Gary1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61463553?accountid=14925

Abstract: The authors describe the role of the site coordinator in a social work distance education program. The 3-year part-time MSW program links rural off-campus sites to a host urban university campus, using interactive TV. Site coordinators serve as teaching assistants, field placement coordinators, academic advisors, & community liaisons. Additionally, the site coordinator provides an administrative link to the host campus, serves as an advocate for students, & provides socialization of students to the values of the social work profession. R. Larsen

Mentoring and Organizational Learning

Author: Kelly, Michael J1; Lauderdale, Michael L1 School Social Work, U Missouri, Columbia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61507268?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article describes a multi-year collaborative project, Mentor +, between a university extension program & a state human service agency that was designed to address the need for skilled leadership in social service agencies in today's sociopolitical environment. The project was founded on two hypotheses: (1) Formal mentoring would be a new management development method that would help senior managers develop mid-level managers. (2) A university, as an entity specializing in learning & development, could serve as a unique catalyst for the development of organizational learning. The authors discuss the findings, which suggest that supported formal mentoring is an attractive management strategy for public human service agencies. 3 Tables, 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Professional Development and Certification for Child Protective Services Supervisors: A Follow-up Study of the Texas Initiative

Author: Scannapieco, Maria11 School Social Work, U Texas, Arlington

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61439416?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article provides background, implementation, & follow-up of the Texas Dept of Protective & Regulatory Services' efforts, in collaboration with the Children's Protective Services Training Instit, to expand training & certification for child welfare supervisors. The author presents research findings about how supervisors perceive certification, how others perceive supervisor certification, & how supervisors utilize certification. The implications of the training & certification are explored in light of the fact that the program is currently voluntary, but could become mandatory in the future. 2 Tables, 9 References. Author: Sharma, Satish11 School Social Work, U Nevada, Las Vegas

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61663500?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores freedoms & unfreedoms as applied to individuals, families, organizations, communities, nations, & the global world in the contexts of social welfare planning & practice. Millennium Talk and the Future of Social Work

Author: Forster, Michael11 U Southern Mississippi, Hattiesburg

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61650806?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is argued that social work should avoid popular "millennium talk" for three overlapping reasons: (1) such talk is tied to ideological confusions with elitist, violent, & apocalyptic elements; (2) social work's nonideological commitments to pragmatism, common sense, history as human made, & the open society depart radically from millennial consciousness; & (3) the future of social work lies with a fundamental recall & reaffirmation of its historically grounded commitments, not with a leap into a new age. 48 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work: A Profession in Search of a Paradigm

Author: Soifer, Steven11 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61663535?accountid=14925

Abstract: Entering its second century as a profession, social work is still grappling with its identity. It is contended that social work has no guiding paradigm, & hence is left to the vagaries of 100+ different approaches, frameworks, models, perspectives, & theories, most of them emanating from the social sciences. Here, conceptual terms are clarified, & the profession's philosophy & epistemology are given a brief historical overview. A social work classification system is also devised. 75 References. The Future of Social Work: A Revision and a Vision

Author: Tsui, Ming-sum1; Chan, Raymond K H1 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61650846?accountid=14925

Abstract: Revisits the social work of the 20th century & outlines alternatives for the 21st in terms of three aspects: (1) the origins & nature of social work, (2) the alienation of social work from its mission in the process of development, & (3) the challenges of globalization & postmodernism. It is argued that the roots of social work are values. Social work of the 20th century, as a product of modernity, was dominated by science & rationality. In its "second century," social work will tend to be more of an international, culturally sensitive, personal, moral, & affective practice. Humanities, instead of social sciences, will become the major knowledge base. The profile of a social worker in the next century will be a person who helps with head, heart, & hands. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Future+of+Social+Work%3A+A+Revision+and+a+Vision&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1999-01-01&amp;volume=60&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=87&amp;author=Tsui%2C+Ming-sum%3BChan%2C+Raymond+K+H

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Future+of+Social+Work%3A+A+Revision+and+a+Vision&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1999-01-01&amp;volume=60&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=87&amp;author=Tsui%2C+Ming-sum%3BChan%2C+Raymond+K+H

Addressing the Future of Professional Social Work in India

Author: Srivastava, S P11 Dept Social Work, Lucknow U, Uttar Pradesh, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61639318?accountid=14925

Abstract: An overview of the past & future of social work in India. Weak spots in social work education & practice are identified, discussing (1) the persistent burden of Americanism; (2) the obsolescence of teaching methods, practicum, reading material, & course curricula; (3) the proliferation of schools/departments of social works; (4) the large number of indifferently trained graduate students; (5) the marginalized status of the profession; (6) the loss of the profession's traditional battle grounds; (7) fierce competition faced by social work graduates in the job-market; (8) weak & ineffectual performance of professional bodies; & (9) the lessening of people's faith in the competence of professional social workers. Some suggestions are offered for revamping & reorganizing the profession's frontiers to overcome stagnation. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Toward a Synthesis of International Social Development

Author: Lusk, Mark W1; Horejsi, Charles1 U Montana, Missoula

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61617069?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social workers in developing nations face much different conditions than their counterparts in industrial economies. With few state resources, they have begun to develop innovative approaches to dealing with the enormous social & economic problems of their clientele. Moreover, social work in the developing world is setting aside its long-standing preoccupation with political ideology & has shifted to a paradigm effort to ameliorate poverty & social injustice. Conversely, social welfare in the developed economies has turned away from state entitlements & is in search of a new set of measures to combat the dislocations of advanced postindustrial society. There would seem to be room for accommodation & convergence between the two perspectives. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work: The End or a New Beginning?

Author: Mohan, Brij11 Doctoral Programme, School Social Work, Louisiana State U, Baton Rouge

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61633008?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues against the "end of social work" thesis, seeking to reaffirm the ideals & practice of democracy, diversity, & social justice -- the main constructs that legitimize discursive practice, an alternative paradigm. The future of social work, it is contended, depends on the future of social justice. The millennium angst offers an opportunity to reflect on the deconstruction of social reality & developmental transformation. A therapeutic culture promotes professional dissonance, narcissism, & dysfunctionality. An alternative, Foucauldian-inspired epistemology is proposed. 36 References. Feminist Social Work: An Expression of Universal Human Rights

Author: Dominelli, Lena

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61443282?accountid=14925

Abstract: Considers the development of feminist social work in the UK, focusing on how it has altered from being concerned with "women's issues" to being deemed an integral part of the social work curriculum. Moreover, the subject of its analysis & practice has shifted to how gendered relations in social work both privilege & problematize masculinity. At the same time, women have become a more differentiated category with the valuing of differences between women occupying center stage. Strengths & weaknesses of feminist social work are assessed. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444332?accountid=14925

Abstract: Efforts toward gender equality have exposed the unfavorable social status of women by spreading gender awareness, facilitating access, mobilizing support & resources, & contesting discrimination. Rather than focusing on equal rights or particular needs to combat women's unfavorable conditions, gender ideology needs to be undermined, because equality targets universal values & difference targets particular needs with neither challenging the structure of dominance. 27 References. Gender Awareness in Field Instruction

Author: Muzumdar, Kalindi S

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444312?accountid=14925

Abstract: Draws on personal experience teaching at an Indian college of social work to argue that problems caused by prevalent gender discrimination necessitate the gender awareness training of social work students. Fieldwork, including field instruction, provides an excellent opportunity to enable students to be sensitive to gender issues. Hence, the concept of gender awareness should be woven into different areas of fieldwork, ie, selection of fieldwork agencies, task assignment to students, student teamwork, supervisory conferences, & student recordings. 3 References. Marital Dynamics in Alcoholism: Implications for Gender Aware De-Addiction Management

Author: Stanley, Selwyn11 Dept Social Work Bishop Heber Coll, Tiruchirappalli India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444280?accountid=14925

Abstract: Compares marital dynamics between wives of alcoholics & nonalcoholics (total N = 300) in Tiruchirapalli, India, via scale data. Poor marital adjustment & higher conflict levels were seen in alcohol-complicated marriages. Further, these wives reported less marital satisfaction, cohesion, consensus, & affectional expression & a higher prevalence of violence & verbal aggression. Implications for social work intervention indicate the need for heightened gender sensitivity in de-addiction management. 2 Tables, 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work Project with Women in a Rural Community

Author: Singh, Surendra11 Dept Social Work Lucknow U, 226007 Uttar Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444274?accountid=14925

Abstract: Reports on a project in the village of Khajuron, India, to promote integrated development & encourage gender equality through the empowerment of women. Programs were aimed at health, nutrition, education, employment, & social security issues, as well as reducing intercaste differences. Gender discrimination in India is discussed, along with major problems in Khajuron, where women are generally illiterate, frequently abused, & deprived of adequate health care & economically gainful work. Political factionalism, predominance of the Muslim culture, & adherence to the caste system help exclude women from education & political/social involvement. A baseline survey was used to assess the perceived needs of the villagers & a large variety of programs were established that have improved women's health, economic & educational status, & social awareness. Problems encountered are discussed, along with the positive & negative implications of such intervention. 5 References. J. Lindroth

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Social+Work+Project+with+Women+in+a+Rural+Community&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1998-10-01&amp;volume=59&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=1034&amp;author=Singh%2C+Surendra

____________________________________________________________

The Special Cell for Women and Children of the Mumbai Police Commissionerate

Author: [Unknown]

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444263?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses the Special Cell for Women & Children formed in 1984 at the Office of the Commissioner of Police in Mumbai, India, to deal with violence against women by placing trained social workers in police stations. A long-term goal of the program was to broaden the scope of the law to change the unequal power balance between men & women. The roles of the police & social workers are discussed, along with the nature of the intervention from the initial police response to an act of violence, through counseling, education, & community involvement. Identification & elimination of violent behavior by men involved changing cultural & social beliefs about the role of women, & helping women to develop a positive self-image & become more assertive. Working with the police has helped to legitimize the work in the eyes of men who are learning that violence will not be tolerated. Insights gained in the 14 years of the program's operation are addressed, along with its limitations. J. Lindroth

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Special+Cell+for+Women+and+Children+of+the+Mumbai+Police+Commissionerate&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1998-10-01&amp;volume=59&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=1052&amp;author=%5BUnknown%5D

Women's Interest News

Author: [Unknown]

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444256?accountid=14925

Abstract: Reports on The Women's Interest Group (TWIG) of the International Assoc of Schools of Social Work that was launched in 1992 to combat the association's failure to address women's needs & agendas. Events leading up to TWIG's formation & its activities are described. Women Participating in Global Change, a compilation of 24 papers presented at the Women's Symposium in Jerusalem, Israel, published by TWIG in 1998, stresses the important role of social work in the social change process, highlighting the ascendancy of women in international social work research, practice, & education. Suggestions that came out of the symposium are described, along with the formation of a cross-cultural resource exchange of books, syllabi, & teaching materials. The Women's Interest News is a newsletter that focuses on mutual sharing & learning among social work educators interested in promoting gender issues. Specific items solicited by the editorial team for inclusion in the newsletter are noted. J. Lindroth

Social Network and Subjective Well-Being of the Elderly in Hong Kong

Author: Boey, Kam Weng11 Dept Social Administration & Social Work, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61488683?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the relationships of demographic characteristics & social network with the subjective well-being of 554 old-old (mean age 77.0) in Hong Kong. Questionnaire data show significant gender differences in all measures of subjective well-being. Family network & interdependent support make greater contributions to the psychological well-being of the old-old than do friends. 5 Tables, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Sharing of Roles between a Social Worker and Members of a Self-Help Group for Mental Ex-Patients in Australia

Author: Yip, Kam-Shing11 Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61488660?accountid=14925

Abstract: Reports a qualitative study on the collaboration of social workers & the members of GROW (a self-help group for current or former mental patients) in South Australia. Participant observation in 2 such groups revealed that professionally trained social workers collaborated well with members, as they had similar backgrounds & experiences. Also, the social workers' roles in running these groups were shared by group members who took up roles as initiators, facilitators, leaders, evaluators, organizers, & problem solvers. The strengths & weaknesses of this model for the rehabilitation of former mental patients & its implications for social work interventions are described. 4 Figures, 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Job Performance Model for Professional Social Workers

Author: Tsui, Ming-Sum11 Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61442119?accountid=14925

Abstract: Defining job performance as a social construct from different perspectives -- eg, standards, behavior, & process -- a comprehensive model is constructed to explain the multiple realities of the job performance of professional social workers. The different perspectives of job performance -- organizational performance, staff performance, & quality of service -- are examined, & the dynamic relationships among various factors behind these components identified. Supervision & professional development for social workers, goal setting & strategy formulation for human service organizations, & program evaluation for service delivery are proposed as guidelines for improving job performance of professional social workers. 2 Figures, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Adjustment to Illness for Medical Social Work Practice

Author: Ma, Joyce L C1; Boey, Kam Weng1 Chinese U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61488637?accountid=14925

Abstract: Contending that social work can be better assessed with the aid of a standardized instrument, an attempt is made to evaluate the reliability of four measures of adjustment: the anxiety & depression subscales of SCL-90, a measure of social maladjustment to illness, & patients' perceived health status. Implications for oncology social work practice are discussed. 3 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61488607?accountid=14925

Abstract: The evaluation of social work practice is distinguished from most other research in that its purposes & treatment are different. Community Development and Social Support Networks of Families in Singapore

Author: Tiong, Tan Ngoh1; Lee, Alexander; Ow, Rosaleen; Liang, Ngiam Tee; Hong, Ong Teck; Mehta, Kalyani; Tan, Vicky; See, Chew Yee1 National U Singapore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61442111?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social support & its impact on community development are important issues in the daily lives of Singaporeans, yet little research has been done among this population, & it is doubtful that Western research frameworks would be applicable. Reported here is a project to develop appropriate scales to identify & measure social support in Singapore so that databases can be constructed for extensive research in this area, differentiating among the various segments of this multicultural society. An Indigenous Psycho-Educational Group for Chinese Bereaved Family Members

Author: Chan, Cecilia L W1; Chow, Amy Y M1 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61430040?accountid=14925

Abstract: Detrimental effects of bereavement on physical, mental, social, & psychological aspects of individuals can be found among bereaved Chinese. The authors have developed an indigenous practice model to work with bereaved family members among Chinese people in Hong Kong. The concept of bereavement was recast to include the idea that bereavement is a challenge that can aid in personal growth. Strategies were created to deal with the feelings of loss & separation positively. Programs in a "growth-oriented" psychosocial-educational group using multiple cognitive, behavioral, & spiritual strategies were introduced. Throughout the sessions, messages of "Letting Go," "Self-Love," "Forgiveness," & "Transformation" were embedded in the programs by culturally relevant terms & concepts. A pre- & post-group questionnaire as well as long interviews were used to evaluate the impact of the group on the participants. Participants of the bereavement groups showed significant improvements in somatic symptoms, anxiety, depression, mood, self-acceptance, letting-go, & transformation. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 51 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Work with the Addictions -- Can the Profession Deliver?

Author: Ng, Ho-Yee11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482550?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper reviews management problems of drug addiction in Hong Kong. Given the lip service paid so far to social work input in the drug rehabilitation scene, an argument is made for an expansion of the role of social work. But it is contended that social work will only be relevant if addiction work is placed squarely within the totality of an individual's life functioning, the area of concern to social work. This would entail, however, a reconceptualization of addiction from that of the prevailing medical view, which sees it as a disease process, to that of seeing addiction as a cognitive choice. 33 References. Moral Values, Judgments, and Intentions of Youths in Hong Kong

Author: Chan, Wing-tai,1; Cheung, Chau-kiu; Lee, Tak-yan; Leung, Kwan-kwok; Liu, Suk-ching1 Dept Applied Social Studies, City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61471550?accountid=14925

Abstract: Data collected in 1997 via a survey of a stratified random sample of 1,500 youth (ages 15-24) & 1,000 children (ages 10-14) across Hong Kong (70% total response rate) are drawn on to explore their moral values & the relation of these to their moral & delinquent intentions. Significant relationships emerged between moral values, judgments, & intentions, though respondents (Rs) were generally ignorant or confused about the concept of morality. Significant gender differences were evident, as was the impact of associating with moralistic vs delinquent peers. Results demonstrate the centrality of moral values & peer relationships in moral judgments & intentions, supporting cognitive-developmental theory. 11 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

Author: Kanuha, Valli11 School Social Work, U Hawaii, Honolulu

Abstract: Professional social work has both a distinguished & troubling history in the development of domestic violence policies & programs in the US & internationally. The Evolution of Professional Training in Accord with Pedagogical Change to Meet Growing Child and Family Needs

Author: Ross, Jean W1; Wright, Lois; Skipper, Anna V; Valentine, Deborah P1 Center Child & Family Studies, Coll Social Work, U South Carolina, Columbia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61463530?accountid=14925

Abstract: Since the 1960s, child maltreatment concerns have prompted federal funding for partnerships between social work schools & public welfare agencies to train professionals working with the escalating & increasingly complex problems facing children & families. Training models at the Center for Child & Family Studies at the U of South Carolina have evolved in several stages from traditional methodology, giving scant voice to trainees, to a facilitation model, with maximum participant input assuring accountability while meeting participants' self-articulated needs & objectives. In this evolution the Center's training has paralleled the pedagogical movement from "banking" to "midwife" methodology, incorporating constructivist changes from adult education, feminism, & postmodernism. 4 Tables, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abstract: It has been estimated that approximately one-third of all social workers in child welfare resign each year, which results in discontinuity of service for clients & is detrimental to worker morale. Locating Women in Migration Studies: An Overview

Author: Lingam, Lakshmi11 Unit Women's Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

Female Migration in India

Author: Singh, D P11 Dept Research Methodology Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61440757?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines migration patterns in India using 1961-1991 census data, with focus on migration level, reasons for migration by type of migration streams, & workforce participation rate & education level of migrants. Analysis indicates that the % of migrants to total enumerated population is consistently declining among both the male & the female population. Employment among males & marriage among females are the most dominant factors behind their movement, irrespective of the type or distance of movement. 5 Tables, 1 Figure, 21 References. Costs and Benefits of Female Labour Migration

Author: Sundari, S1; Rukmani, M K1 Mother Teresa Women's U, Kodaikanal

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61440749?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the trend, causes, & pattern of female migration from Tamil Nadu to Delhi, India, 1951-1991, drawing on census data & interviews conducted with 250 migrant households. Findings suggest that the most important push factor was lack of employment opportunity & the pull factor was the continuous demand for the labor of women in Delhi for domestic work. Though the migrants have made some gains, problems such as housing, illiteracy, indebtedness, job insecurity, & school dropout among children demand immediate policy prescriptions & actions. 6 Tables, 2 Figures, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Re-Examining the Resettlement Question in the Context of Migrant Women's Security and Urban Poverty in Bangladesh

Author: Afsar, Rita11 Bangladesh Instit Development Studies, Dhaka

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61440740?accountid=14925

Abstract: In response to the growth of shanties, slums, & squatter settlements, which is inextricably linked with rapid urbanization & the emergence of megacities in developing countries, resettlement measures have been implemented as part of poverty alleviation programs, particularly in Bangladesh. Draconian measures have been taken to remove the migrant poor from the center of the city, both by the government & vested interest groups with a view to taking control of the land. These measures are discussed here with focus on their implications for poor women, drawing on a review of Asian Development Bank findings, relevant survey data, rapid appraisal of selected bastis (settlements), interviews, & group meetings. It is argued that resettlement can neither resettle the poor nor reduce urban poverty, & moreover, has negative implications for poor women by threatening their security & job opportunities. To be meaningful, poverty reduction programs in urban areas must address the issues of women's security, identity, the protective umbrella of social networks, & work opportunities, & must involve poorer communities as partners while implementing housing & shelter programs. 5 Tables, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Re-Examining+the+Resettlement+Question+in+the+Context+of+Migrant+Women%27s+Security+and+Urban+Poverty+in+Bangladesh&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1998-07-01&amp;volume=59&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=824&amp;author=Afsar%2C+Rita

Author: Pabon, Edward11 Social Work Program, Richard Stockton Coll New Jersey, Pomona

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61526401?accountid=14925

Abstract: The interaction between traditional juvenile justice service providers & Latino youngsters & families in US society has been somewhat impersonal, structured, & formal, with minimal give-&-take questioning & relevant discussion. The resultant evidence continues to suggest that services have not been sufficiently responsive to the needs of minority clients, especially Latino youngsters. Juvenile justice providers need to understand & incorporate cultural value preferences, such as familialism, allocentrism, & personal distance, in their relationship with Latino clients in terms of building therapeutic contacts. 16 References. http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448850?accountid=14925

The "New Opium War": Welfare Dependency of Lone Mothers in Hong Kong?

Author: Leung, Lai Ching1; Chan, Kam Wah1 Dept Applied Social Studies, City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482579?accountid=14925

Abstract: Welfare dependency is becoming a conspicuous problem in Hong Kong. Welfare claimants are accused of being overly dependent on welfare & lacking incentive to work. Welfare is even equated with "spiritual opium," that which erodes work incentive. Lone parents & the unemployed are among the groups blamed the most. This paper produces evidence, based on our research on lone mothers in Hong Kong, to refute the accusation of welfare dependency. The arguments that lone mothers are consciously maximizing their social security benefits & that they are better off on benefit, as postulated in rational choice theory, is fallacious. We should therefore try to understand the welfare dependency of lone mothers not by reference to an alleged "dependency culture," but rather through a more holistic appreciation of the interactions among a variety of structural forces such as discrimination in the labor market, gender inequality in marital relation, low wages, inadequate child care facilities, & the poverty traps within the social security system. 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+%22New+Opium+War%22%3A+Welfare+Dependency+of+Lone+Mothers+in+Hong+Kong%3F&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1998-01-01&amp;volume=32&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=117&amp;author=Leung%2C+Lai+Ching%3BChan%2C+Kam+Wah

Coping with Resettlement Difficulties: A Qualitative Analysis of Coping Strategies Used by Mainland Chinese Immigrants in Hong Kong

Author: Wong, Daniel Fu Keung11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61484620?accountid=14925

Abstract: A qualitative study was undertaken to explore the coping strategies used by mainland Chinese immigrants in Hong Kong to handle psychosocial stressors experienced during the resettlement stage of the migration process. It was revealed that coping strategies employed were stage-specific & culture-specific. While problem-solving strategies & compromise were used by immigrants to deal with recurring, daily resettlement difficulties, cognitive strategies of positive comparisons & positive & optimistic thinking were utilized to change the meanings of these difficulties. Acceptance & avoidance strategies were culture-specific, & were useful in reducing the stress associated with the resettlement difficulties encountered. It was also found that strategies such as acceptance, compromise, & avoidance might have deleterious effects on the longer-term adjustment of immigrants. Implications for counseling the immigrants were suggested. 3 Tables, 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Development of the Student Worker in Field Practice Training

Author: Leung, Anna Y L11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61483949?accountid=14925

Abstract: Findings from a pilot study on the field practice experience of undergraduate social work students give support to the postulation that in field practice, students go through a developmental process with stages, through which they learn to master practice knowledge & skills, develop personal awareness & establish a professional identity. The stages are roughly identified as "looking for certainty," "chaos," & "finding one' place." In each stage, common patterns of trainee needs, characteristics, & emotional experiences are highlighted. Suggestions are made on how field instructors can provide the facilitating conditions for the students' learning & development through an understanding of these stages. 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Assessment of Family Functioning in Chinese Adolescents in Hong Kong

Author: Shek, Daniel T L1; Lai, Kelly; Lai, Angie F Y; Chan, L K1 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin New Territories

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61471562?accountid=14925

Abstract: With the growing emphasis on the importance of enhancing family functioning when working with families, the demand for objective family assessment tools has increased. In addition, with the increase in family problems in different Chinese contexts, there is an obvious need to develop family assessment tools so that the relevant phenomena can be objectively understood & the related intervention can be properly evaluated. However, a survey of the literature shows that objective instruments that assess family functioning in Chinese adolescents are almost nonexistent. The present study was conducted to examine the psychometric properties of several translated measures of family functioning & an indigenous scale on family functioning. 1 Table. Managing Unsuccessful or Uncompleted Placements

Author: Burgess, Robin1; Campbell, Vivien; Phillips, Rena; Skinner, Kate1 Dept of Applied Social Science, U of Stirling, Stirling FK9 4LA, Scotland

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61648009?accountid=14925

Abstract: Offers a preliminary account of the first phase of an ongoing Scotland-wide study examining why & in what circumstances placements on social work programs are unsuccessful or uncompleted. The study's background, aims, & methods are described, & emerging issues identified. Data collection, which is ongoing, is based on interviews with students, practice teachers, tutors, & link workers (term adopted to describe the person who supervises the day-to-day practice of the student, where the practice teacher is based elsewhere). A total of 43 interviews had been conducted with 39 respondents regarding 18 placements. The perceptions & experiences of study participants & ways of more effectively managing unsuccessful or uncompleted placements will be explored, deriving recommendations for good practice. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Disabled Students: Barriers to Practice Learning

Author: Phillips, Rena11 Dept of Applied Social Science, U of Stirling, Stirling FK9 4LA, Scotland

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61648056?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores the perceptions & experiences of disabled social work students in institutions & placements, based on interviews with 8 students, 7 course tutors, & 8 practice teachers. Barriers to training were identified in five main areas: the disabling environment; problems of typification, whereby global assumptions of impairment are made about individuals; the failure of equal opportunities policies; the practice of treating all students in the same way; & self-censorship on the part of students. It is argued that the reluctance of some students to declare an impairment is a rational response to the disabling policies pursued, albeit inadvertently, by institutions & agencies. Themes are identified & action points suggested to provide a more accessible educational & practice environment for disabled students. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Disabled+Students%3A+Barriers+to+Practice+Learning&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Social+Work+and+Practice&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=1998-01-01&amp;volume=1&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=13&amp;author=Phillips%2C+Rena

Creativity and Competence: Reconstructing Social Work for the Millennium

Author: Knight, Theo1; Worsley, Aidan1 Staff Development Section, Rm 95, Stockport Social Services, Lisburne Lane, Offerton, Stockport SK2 7LL

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61647108?accountid=14925

Abstract: Criticizes recent discourses on social work & suggests an alternative paradigm for the new millennium. The recent history of social work is dominated by a managerialist discourse emanating from Thatcherism, containing certain views about realism & value for money that restrict creative thinking. The competency frameworks developed in GB by CCETSW may be seen as examples of this discourse. The discourse arising from academia challenges the value of such competency frameworks because of their narrow view of social work. Academia is criticized for its role in creating social workers as experts, which distances them from the experiences of users. A view of the competency frameworks is presented that suggests how they can be used creatively. However, so long as social work continues to be defined by managers or academics, real change will be difficult to achieve. It is shown how the competency frameworks can be used to address user involvement, & thus create a third paradigm for defining social work. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Changes to the DipSW: One Step Forward, Three Steps Back

Author: Barraclough, John11 North London Practice Teaching Consortium, Islington Neighborhood Services, 292, Essex Rd, London, N1 3AZ

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61629910?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues that CCETSW revisions to the CQSW (Certificate of Qualification in Social Work) -- providing an overhaul of professional social work training qualifications in GB -- specifically, Paper 30 & 26.3, resulting in the Assured Quality documents, have been detrimental. It is argued that three fundamental areas of practice training are adversely affected: antioppressive practice, direct observation of student's practice, & the integration of theory & practice. It is contended that the changes have resulted in social workers' improper understanding of the theories underpinning social work in the same way that the prior CQSW courses produced theoretically illiterate practitioners. Adapted from the source document.
