The Use of Business Planning in Practice Teaching

Author: Peddar, Jenny11 Learning Centre, Cugle House, 118a High St, Newport, Isle of Wight PO30 1TP

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61656850?accountid=14925

Abstract: Following local government reform & restructuring within the Isle of Wight (England) Social Services Dept, & in line with a corporate move toward the use of business planning within the agency, a decision was made in 1996 to develop a business plan for practice teaching. This move was undertaken by the group of practice teachers established by the department in 1990, which follows policies & a code of practice aimed at achieving & maintaining high standards of practice. The initial plan has now been in operation for just over a year & is due for updating. The outcomes have included a more businesslike manner for the service provided both within the agency & for partnerships. New areas have been highlighted, notably finance & resource maximization. Existing good practice areas became apparent & have been incorporated, with regular proactive updating systems. Achievable & measurable targets have been set for the improvement & maintenance of practice standards. Outcomes have included the maintenance of a high profile for practice teaching within the agency, & also the consideration of group members extending their own qualifications. 1 Reference. Adapted from the source document.

Learning and Practising or Just Saying the Words? Anti-Discriminatory Issues in Social Work Training

Author: Trotter, Joy11 School Health, U of Teesside, Middlesbrough, TS1 3BA, England

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61636439?accountid=14925

Abstract: Content analysis of 128 placement reports written by final-year (1993/94) CQSW (Certificate of Qualification in Social Work) & DipSW (Diploma in Social Work) students & practice teachers in GB are used to explore consideration & appreciation of antidiscriminatory practice issues. Preparation for practice, definitions of terms, & acceptability of focus are discussed. Results reveal that CQSW students & practice teachers displayed a considerable awareness of gender issues & that DipSW students & practice teachers displayed a considerable awareness of race issues & antidiscriminatory practice generally. The majority of students failed to deal with more than one area of discrimination, & very few referred to issues of class, religion, culture, or sexuality. The failure to recognize heterosexism & homophobia is discussed in some detail. Despite the frequency of allusions to antiracism, antisexism, & antidiscriminatory practice, students demonstrated poor understanding, awareness, & skill in these areas. It is concluded that gaps in resources, personal fears, & obsequious leadership combine to prevent students from learning & practicing in antidiscriminatory ways. 5 Figures, 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Learning+and+Practising+or+Just+Saying+the+Words%3F+Anti-Discriminatory+Issues+in+Social+Work+Training&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Social+Work+and+Practice&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=1998-01-01&amp;volume=1&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=31&amp;author=Trotter%2C+Joy

Social Work Training within the Voluntary Sector

Author: Justice, Mark11 Lookahead Housing Assoc Ltd, Whitechapel Project, 17 Varden Rd, London E2 2AW

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61652998?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses the provision of social work student placements in a voluntary setting in Tower Hamlets, a deprived London (England) borough. The practice teacher uses action research as a placement tool, which enables him/her to practice teach three students at any one time & ensures that the practice curriculum is met. It is argued that the benefits of this approach accrue both to the students & the organization. Adapted from the source document.

Developing a Conceptual Framework for Teaching and Assessing Law within Training for Professional Practice: Lessons from Social Work

Author: Preston-Shoot, Michael1; Roberts, Gwyneth; Vernon, Stuart1 School of Law, Social Work & Social Policy, John Moores U, Josephine Butler House, 1 Myrtle St, Liverpool L7 4DN

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61647060?accountid=14925

Abstract: Uses a case study illustration of an elderly women with senile dementia to describe the development of a conceptual framework for teaching & assessing social work law. This framework begins with a distinction within social work law between the relevant legal rules, their relationship with professional values, & the context of administrative law. It then focuses on the interactions between law & practice, & on the skills necessary for competence. Research that highlights the difficulties experienced by practice teachers in providing appropriate learning opportunities is reviewed. These difficulties are addressed by a careful distinction between interim & final competence, the introduction of particular teaching & learning methods, attention to partnership between the different stakeholders in social work education, & the development of a post-qualifying program. It is suggested that this model might also be useful for other health & welfare professions. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Developing+a+Conceptual+Framework+for+Teaching+and+Assessing+Law+within+Training+for+Professional+Practice%3A+Lessons+from+Social+Work&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Social+Work+and+Practice&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=1998-01-01&amp;volume=1&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=41&amp;author=Preston-Shoot%2C+Michael%3BRoberts%2C+Gwyneth%3BVernon%2C+Stuart

Practice Placements That Go Wrong

Author: Burgess, Robin1; Phillips, Rena; Skinner, Kate1 Dept of Applied Social Science, U of Stirling, Stirling FK9 4LA, Scotland

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61647155?accountid=14925

Abstract: Presents findings from a Scottish-wide study of 13 social work programs on unsuccessful & uncompleted placements. The interrelated factors that can contribute to failed placements are examined, along with the processes involved, both formal & informal, the reactions to problems, & the availability of support. The implications for all the parties involved are considered, highlighting issues of communication, power, & discrimination. Suggestions are offered to better manage failed placements. 5 Tables, 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Perspectives on Welfare Reform Part One: Social Work -- Welfare and Work: Some Suggestions on How the Two Can Mesh, from a Public Policy Administrator

Author: Florey, David C11 Bureau Employment & Training Programs, Office Income Maintenance, Pennsylvania Dept Welfare, Harrisburg

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61439407?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social workers & public administrators must find common ground in revising the current welfare system in the US. In the past, the general view was that people were on welfare because they could not navigate postmodern society on their own. Recently, the common viewpoint is that many people are on welfare because it is there. There is some movement to put limits on the length of time that welfare services are available, & there is a strong push toward welfare recipients entering the job market as exemplified by recent changes in PA welfare law. The goal is to put able people to work & on the path to supporting themselves & their families. It is argued that public welfare administrators realign their attitudes toward case management so that social work's holistic approach becomes the ideal instead of the benefit-generating caseload management that characterized the pre-reform welfare system. E. Larsen

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Perspectives+on+Welfare+Reform+Part+One%3A+Social+Work+--+Welfare+and+Work%3A+Some+Suggestions+on+How+the+Two+Can+Mesh%2C+from+a+Public+Policy+Administrator&amp;title=Professional+Development%3A+The+International+Journal+of+Continuing+Social+Work+Education&amp;issn=10974911&amp;date=1998-01-01&amp;volume=1&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=4&amp;author=Florey%2C+David+C

Perspectives on Welfare Reform Part Two: Welfare and Work: The Need for New Practice Skills

Author: Beresin, Constance Goldman11 Jewish Employment & Vocational Service, Philadelphia, PA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467367?accountid=14925

Abstract: PA is pioneering some new laws concerning the need for welfare recipients to go to work. At present, there is a five-year lifetime limit on federal Temporary Assistance to Needy Families (TANF)-funded assistance. This article explores how employment & training providers are affected. It details four areas where organizations & social workers are impacted & implications for continuing education of social workers: financial management; marketing; communication; & information technology. Social workers must keep current on all the changes. E. Larsen

Social Work and Managed Behavioral Health Care: We Don't Want to Be Your Darlings Anymore

Author: Angell, G Brent1; Rohrer, Glenn E1 School Social Work, East Carolina U, Greenville, NC

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61507207?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social work is a profession under moral & ethical siege as a result of its favored position with respect to the delivery of fee-for-service mental & behavioral health services under managed care. The authors look at how social workers, in becoming the "darlings" of managed behavioral health care, have compromised their professional autonomy & their ability to advocate in the best interest of consumers of mental & behavioral health services. The authors call for a professional identity check-up & suggest alternative approaches to practice within managed behavioral health care that have ramifications for teaching & continuing education. 70 References. Adapted from the source document.

Psychopharmacology Knowledge and Use with Social Work Professionals: A Continuing Education Evaluation

Author: Dziegielewski, Sophia F1; Leon, Ana M1 School Social Work, U Central Florida, Orlando

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61439411?accountid=14925

Abstract: This continuing education program was designed to increase social worker knowledge in regard to mental health medications in the practice setting. This full-day workshop presented the basics of medication use & the effects these medications can have on the counseling environment. The intention of the workshop was to explore the knowledge level social workers possess & how comfortable they feel in relationship with other professionals when it comes to the use of medications. One hundred & sixty-nine participants were surveyed, resulting in approximately 137 usable surveys that addressed general knowledge of medications as well as pretested/posttested responses in regard to whether they felt the workshop was helpful in increasing their current levels of understanding & impressions in regard to medication use. Significant relationships were noted between several study variables as well as between pretest & posttest scores. Suggestions for future research & education in this area are presented. 1 Table, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Interfacing with Managed Behavior Health Care Organizations: An Emerging Scale of Private Practitioner's Self-Perceived Competence

Author: Keefe, Robert H1; Hall, Michael L1 School Social Work, Syracuse U, NY

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467980?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Wagner & Morse Measure of Individual Sense of Competence was revised & administered to 168 social workers, 158 psychologists, & 256 psychiatrists in private practice. The scale measured the practitioners' ability to interface with managed care organizations. Although seasoned private practitioners were sampled, they indicated that they do not perceive themselves as competent in their interactions with managed care organizations. These conclusions have pronounced implications for the practitioners' ability to advocate strongly for their clients & for continuing education programs to focus on the interface between managed care organizations & private practitioners. 2 Figures, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Monteiro, Anjali1; Lingam, Lakshmi1 Unit Media & Communications Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444926?accountid=14925

Abstract: In an introduction to this special journal issue, an overview of social sciences theorizing on movements is presented, with attention to the debates on new social movements & nonparty political formations in India. Also explored is how these struggles grapple with difference, & how they strategize their relationship to the state, development, & the realm of the cultural & the symbolic. Development and Marginalisation: Global and National Scenario

Author: Kurien, C T11 Madras Instit Development Studies, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61445671?accountid=14925

Abstract: Illustrates how economic growth has been jobless, ruthless, voiceless, rootless, & futureless under the institutional arrangements of capitalism; further, it is flawed by the inner contradiction that marginalization or exclusion of some people is accompanied by the enrichment of others. In contrast to the conflict between capital & people in the current development paradigm, an alternative paradigm of development is recommended in which people use capital for the achievement of their defined objectives. A precondition for the success of this approach is people's awareness of their rights & of their power to bring the development process under their collective control. 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Development+and+Marginalisation%3A+Global+and+National+Scenario&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1998-01-01&amp;volume=59&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=35&amp;author=Kurien%2C+C+T

Author: Iyer, V R Krishna

The People versus the System

Author: Sharma, B D11 Bharat Jan Andolan, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61445656?accountid=14925

Abstract: Presents a historical analysis of people vs the political economy, from the dawn of civilization through the great industrial revolution & colonization, to contemporary globalization. Three broad situations are discussed: the world of victors, the world of the vanquished, & the intermediate zone. Two genres of reaction to the malfunctioning of the system are identified: violent revolts against the state & resistance of the infolding of the logic of the system & the imperial paradigm. It is argued that the movement of village self-governance in the tribal areas has the potential of graduating into a pan-Indian people's movement, which may force a basic structural transformation. Adapted from the source document.

Women, Empowerment and the State

Author: Jandhyala, Kameshwari11 National Project Office Mahila Samakhya, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61445609?accountid=14925

Abstract: Addresses the place of the empowerment of women on the official agenda of the Indian state, with focus on the experience of the Mahila Samakhya program, a centrally sponsored program with the explicit agenda of women's education & empowerment, primarily in Andhra Pradesh. Described is how this program has attempted to create the same space & opportunity for growth & empowerment of women in the organization as for the rural women it works with. The program's strategy of enabling women to raise questions about problems, consider various ways of dealing with them, & acting on them has resulted in a wide array of issues being addressed, through the structure of sanghams, or collectives. 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Contemporary Struggles of the Tribal Peoples of India

Author: Pathy, Jaganath11 South Gujarat U, Surat India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61445598?accountid=14925

Abstract: Critically examines the available literature on tribal movements, suggesting that exploitation of tribals is premised on the epistemology of individualism, which has destroyed their survival base; statist ideology & the nation-building process, which threaten their linguistic & cultural survival; & capitalist paradigm of development, which has expropriated natural resources. In this context, the state has emerged as the chief enemy of tribal people. Here, a case is made for the right of internal self-determination for tribal regions in the state system. The alternative development paradigm would involve struggles against imperialism & domestic reactionary forces, toward the emergence of multiple coexisting civilizations. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Tribal Movements: Resistance to Resurgence

Author: Prabhu, Pradeep11 Kashtakari Sanghatana, Dahanu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61445591?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores the terms of discourse of present tribal movements in India, focusing on the emergence of new leftist formations. The new realms of action articulated by these movements include a reaffirmation of identity, struggle to recapture control over resources, rethinking of the political domain, & redefinition of development. The notions of development, nation building, & human (individual) rights have been the prime factors in the progressive destruction of the survival systems of tribal peoples. The emerging perspectives in tribal movements signal a shift from resistance to resurgence, toward ethnodevelopment. 54 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Context and Community Perception of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Care among IDUs and Their Communities

Author: Thomas, Joe11 Community Research AIDS Centre Clinical Trials & Epidemiological Research Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin New Territories

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61447984?accountid=14925

Abstract: Draws on a broad array of quantitative & qualitative analyses to assess the current preintervention situation of human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS) awareness & prevention among injecting drug users in Manipur, India. Results show a rapid spread of HIV among users in several districts across the state. Interviews conducted in 1994 with 45+ church, ethnic association, & tribal leaders, as well as representatives of law enforcement & the military, reveal a complex range of social conflicts concerning the epidemic, preventing any single type of prevention program to serve as an all-inclusive solution. Policy & program suggestions include the dire need for the state & society to perceive the socially marginalized life of those infected with the virus as a human rights issue; discouragement of discrimination through community action; & avoidance of legal avenues, detention, & punishment as means of deterrent. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Violence against Women, with Reference to 498 A and 304 B, Indian Penal Code

Author: Gandhi, Anjali11 Dept Social Work Jamia Milia Islamia, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61447981?accountid=14925

Abstract: Reviews current theories on why women continue to stay with abusive husbands, drawing on three case studies of working-class marriages in New Delhi, India. Three theoretical models explaining gender-based violence are briefly outlined: (1) the interpersonal perspective, maintaining that the source of the violence lies in the abnormal psychological relationship; (2) the sociocultural view that abuse is largely a response to adverse socioeconomic conditions; & (3) the feminist perspective, holding that abuse extends from the perpetuation of patriarchy. The cases of the 3 New Dehli women illustrate the psychological entrapment, learned helplessness, & reasoned action involved in the abusive relationship, along with the women's means of escape & support. India's 1983 & 1986 penal code additions (498A & 304B) are discussed in terms of the country's attempts to recognize & rectify the long-suppressed problem. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Violence+against+Women%2C+with+Reference+to+498+A+and+304+B%2C+Indian+Penal+Code&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1997-10-01&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=582&amp;author=Gandhi%2C+Anjali

Author: Datar, Chhaya; Joshi, Shruti

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61447965?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes a government-supported community development project in Maharashtra, India, to improve the supply & quality of drinking water. The social, structural, & managerial challenges of the 1991 program are analyzed, along with the overall aims of incorporating community involvement in all levels of design & construction. Training programs are outlined for state, district, & village personnel. Particular attention is paid to the gender strategies of the project, because the arduous task of water gathering has traditionally been designated as women's work by Indian society. Abstract: Addresses the meaning of & necessity for empowerment of older people. Policy advocacy & other proposals, including mobilizing older people for policy changes, raising older people's awareness of elderly rights, training in understanding the policy process & skills in advocacy, promoting political participation, organizing senior citizen coalitions, & advocating for the legislation of rights of older people, are suggested. 1 Figure, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Teenage Drugs Subculture: Implications for Preventive Strategies in Social Work Practice

Author: Lai, Kwok-Hung11 Technical Instit Vocational Training Council, Dept Sociology, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61471522?accountid=14925

Abstract: Rapid social change due to emigration & the development of new towns has weakened parental bonds & the social support networks of families & clans. These changes may lead to an immense increase in teenage drug abuse & suicide. The drug dependence of teenagers is not simply a result of curiosity, but a reflection of stress management in the form of escape from reality. This paper gives an account of the stages of adolescent drug dependence, & the levels of intervention where social work practitioners can play a more active role in drug prevention. Strategies related to primary, secondary, & tertiary prevention are discussed. 1 Table, 81 References. Adapted from the source document.

The "Night Drifting Teens" -- A Quest for Social Work

Author: Lee, Francis11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration, U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61511185?accountid=14925

Abstract: In Hong Kong, the phenomenon of young people hanging around individually or in groups in public places throughout the night has become prevalent. This has drawn much attention from the public & the media because the behavior of these "night drifting teens" (eg, chasing around, vandalizing, harassing people passing by, behaving promiscuously) is becoming a public nuisance. Moreover, they also risk running up against the law. Based on a recent exploratory study of "night drifting" youths, this paper introduces their social background & situation. The causes of their engagement in these nocturnal activities are also explored. Services for this group of youths are proposed, & recommendations for the direction & development of relevant service programs to meet their needs are suggested. 7 Tables, 1 Figure, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Liu, Elaine Suk-Ching11 Dept Applied Social Studies, City U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61471536?accountid=14925

Abstract: Task analysis is applied to school social work in Hong Kong to examine, first, how school social workers conceptualize the functions & ideologies of their work. Secondly, it argues how they can better meet the needs of the students & the community. Conception of Learning among Social Work Students

Author: Tsang, Nai-Ming11 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61483883?accountid=14925

Abstract: The responses of 723 students & graduates from the social work course in the Dept of Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U, to 30 statements on the conception of learning are examined. A factor analysis reveals five underlying dimensions: learning as perception; learning as a dynamic process that transcends time & space; the significant others in learning; the instrumental functions of learning; & learning as a rational & emotive process. Nonparametric tests reveal significant differences between (1) those with & without social work experience & (2) those with or without a diploma. Findings of second-order tests of significance are discussed also. 7 Tables, 2 Appendixes, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Exploring the Parenting Difficulties of Stepmothers in Hong Kong: Implications for Social Workers and Teachers

Author: Lam, Gladys L T11 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61483903?accountid=14925

Abstract: The number of divorce cases in Hong Kong has soared in recent years, & the stepfamily is an emerging family structure. This exploratory study is aimed at examining difficulties of parenting in stepfamilies through interviews with stepmothers, social workers, & teachers. Reports of these stepmothers reveal that they feel overloaded in the stepfamilies & that their spouses do not give them enough support. They complain that their in-laws & relatives create stress rather than offer help in child management. The findings indicated that there are difficulties in communication between the couples, problems between stepmother-stepchild, & in-law relationships. It is suggested that social workers & teachers should cooperate to deal with cultural stereotyping of the stepfamily & change negative social attitudes toward members of stepfamilies. Efforts should also be made by these professionals to identify stepmother-stepchild relationship problems with greater sensitivity & regularity. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Exploring+the+Parenting+Difficulties+of+Stepmothers+in+Hong+Kong%3A+Implications+for+Social+Workers+and+Teachers&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1997-07-01&amp;volume=31&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=97&amp;author=Lam%2C+Gladys+L+T

Maternal and Child Health Services and Adoption of Family Planning Methods

Author: Raju, K N M11 Instit Social & Economic Change, Bangalore 560072 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61526409?accountid=14925

Abstract: Assesses estimates of the socioeconomic & demographic parameters across Indian states made by the 1992/93 National Family Health Survey & the effectiveness of family planning & maternal & child health services. State-level data on fertility, adoption of family planning methods, mortality, women's issues, & others were found to be consistent, thus meeting the goal of providing reliable data. A negative association between fertility & antenatal care is cited as an example of how maternal & child health services can regulate fertility & achieve widespread adoption of family planning methods. The relationship between infant & under-age-5 mortality demonstrate the importance of raising marriage ages & lack of impact of maternal & child health policies on child mortality. Female literacy was found to be the strongest determining factor in seeking maternal & child health services, with sterilization as the most likely service sought. This paints maternal & child health services as simply a way to achieve family planning targets. It is recommended that maternal & child health policies should reach all women via their greater emphasis in the overall health package. 6 Tables, 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Maternal+and+Child+Health+Services+and+Adoption+of+Family+Planning+Methods&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1997-07-01&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=403&amp;author=Raju%2C+K+N+M

A Historical Perspective of the Social Work Profession

Author: Gore, M S

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61545375?accountid=14925

Abstract: Traces the beginning of the social work profession to the rise of the middle class in the latter 19th century, comparing the Western & Indian experiences. Social work, as a profession, worked on behalf of the society or the establishment, adopting social action as a program in the 1960s. When professional social work was set up in India by a US missionary, its interests followed the launching of programs by the government. Dialogue between the Gandhian workers & graduates of professional schools were held but did not lead to any new initiatives for common action. Trends in & limitations of social action as a new area of work are considered. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=A+Historical+Perspective+of+the+Social+Work+Profession&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1997-07-01&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=442&amp;author=Gore%2C+M+S

Analysis of Literature on Social Action

Author: Siddiqui, H Y11 Dept Social Work Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444987?accountid=14925

Abstract: Reviews the literature on social action in India, 1940-1995, to identify the process of its development, current trends, & the future possibilities. Changing social characteristics of social work suggest that the scale of militancy in the profession will decrease rather than increase. Social action as a method, therefore, will remain on the periphery. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Muzumdar, Kalindi11 Coll Social Work Nirmala Niketan Instit, Mumbai India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444980?accountid=14925

Author: Prasad, B Devi11 Dept Social Work Andhra U, Visakhapatnam India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444970?accountid=14925

Abstract: Compares undergraduate social work education programs in India & the US to shed light on relevant problems & issues pertaining to the Indian context, drawing inferences in terms of historical emergence, objectives, curriculum content, course pattern, professional membership, & organization. Factors Influencing Anxiety of Working Women Hostellers of Bangalore City

Author: Krishnaswamy, Saroja1; Kulkarni, Leena V1 Dept Human Development Rural Home Science Coll U Agricultural Sciences, Dharwad

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448166?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview data from 200 residents of 19 working women's hostels in Bangalore, India, indicated that 41% of them suffered from high levels of anxiety. Age, education, income, & perception of one's own rural background as an obstacle in adjusting to hostel life were found to be significantly correlated with anxiety. Respondents having difficulty in commuting to work & those who were prior hostellers as students were found to have significantly more anxiety than others. As the cumulative intensity of problems related to hostel life increased, anxiety also increased significantly. Results imply the necessity of using hostel rules & regulations with discretion & empathy along with service & living condition improvements in the working women's hostels. 4 Tables, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Factors+Influencing+Anxiety+of+Working+Women+Hostellers+of+Bangalore+City&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1997-01-01&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=1&amp;author=Krishnaswamy%2C+Saroja%3BKulkarni%2C+Leena+V

Sugarcane Harvest and Transport Workers of Sugar Cooperatives in Maharashtra

Author: Jugale, V B11 Dept Economics Shivaji U, Kolhapur

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448159?accountid=14925

Abstract: In the farm sector, sugar workers are termed sugarcane harvest & transport workers & categorized into five groups: head center, bullock cart center, tire cart center, truck/tractor center, & hired, where more than six lakh workers are involved in cane harvesting & transport. Their wages, fixed by the Tripartite Awards for every 3 years, do not even cover regional minimum wages for agricultural workers. Workers are exploited at various levels by labor brokers & mukadams (head harvester gang men). Poor physical health, strains, & poverty are major problems for workers. Of late, industrial relations have changed because of court verdicts centered on the concept of a worker in the sugar industry. Sugar worker unionization is difficult because of the migratory & seasonal nature of their job. 3 Tables, 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Field Instruction in Social Work Education in India: Some Issues

Author: Prasad, B Devi1; Vijayalakshmi, B1 Dept Social Work Andhra U, Visakhapatnam

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448134?accountid=14925

Abstract: Field instruction, a crucial component of social work education, is recognized as an educational process to facilitate integrative & experiential learning. Though the pattern & organization of social work practicum have some universality, the microbased practice model adopted in the Indian context has led to inappropriately designed field education programs, producing students unsuited to meet the developmental needs of the Indian. Efforts made to restructure field instruction to prepare students for macrobased practice roles have been too slow to find their way into the educational program of most Indian schools of social work. Major problems, eg, scarcity of field placements, nonavailability of qualified agency-based field instructors, inadequate linkage between classroom teaching & field realities, & poor faculty positions, still prevail. Here, crucial areas for change in field instruction are examined, & alternative strategies suggested in light of emerging socioeconomic concerns & recent trends in the profession. 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Field+Instruction+in+Social+Work+Education+in+India%3A+Some+Issues&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1997-01-01&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=65&amp;author=Prasad%2C+B+Devi%3BVijayalakshmi%2C+B

Author: Sheela, J1; Audinarayana, N1 Dept Population Studies Bharathiar U, Coimbatore India

Household and Community Response to HIV/AIDS: Executive Summary of a Study in Mumbai

Author: Bharat, Shalini11 Unit Family Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448118?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interviews with 34 people with human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS) & 25 household members & 18 focus groups with low-income individuals are used to assess responses to HIV/AIDS in lower-income households & communities in Mumbai, India. Data indicate that household responses are generally supportive. However, responses vary with the gender & relationship of the HIV+ individual: they are more positive for men than women & for sons more than daughters. Knowledge of HIV/AIDS at the community level is poor. Implications are discussed, & recommendations for HIV/AIDS caregivers, educational initiatives, & policy are presented. J. Ferrari

Women's Rights at the Workplace: Emerging Challenges and Legal Interventions

Author: Bajpai, Asha11 Unit Women's Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448103?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses the effects of economic liberalization on women in India, suggesting that structural adjustments may increasingly marginalize women, especially in the informal economic sector. Legal & policy recommendations to protect the rights of women in the workplace are presented, including the creation of a guiding government policy, establishment of an Equal Opportunities Commission, legislation directed against sexual harassment, registration of women employees, the assurance of basic social security benefits for women, & better access to child care. These reforms must be accompanied by legal literacy programs informing women of their rights. Specific areas of concern for women in the construction, plastic & diamond, export, domestic, & sex industries also are addressed. J. Ferrari

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Women%27s+Rights+at+the+Workplace%3A+Emerging+Challenges+and+Legal+Interventions&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1997-01-01&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=111&amp;author=Bajpai%2C+Asha

Survey of Self-Employed Women with Special Reference to Tutors

Author: Wadia, Hilla11 Shreemati Nathibai Damodar Thackersey Women's U, Bombay 400020 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61587862?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines factors contributing to self-employment among Indian women, drawing on 1992 questionnaire data from 220 women tutors in Mumbai. An analytical model identified family characteristics, eg, family responsibility, cultural inhibition & taboos; infrastructural characteristics, eg, space & time constraints; & individual characteristics, eg, educational qualifications & feelings of job satisfaction, as motivations to seek self-employment. It is found that the majority of tutors were unmarried, took up tutoring because they had an interest in teaching, & wanted to support the family income. There are a number of disadvantages to tutoring, eg, unexpected visitors, staying home to work, & the inability to relieve the stress of everyday work. Self-employment is described as a time-consuming effort calling for strong self-discipline & cooperation from family members. 26 Tables, 2 Figures. Adapted from the source document.

Factors Affecting the Adoptation of Simple Maternal and Child Health Interventions by Women

Author: Sood, A K1; Nagla, B N1 Dept Education & Training National Instit Health & Family Welfare, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61553299?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes the level of adoption of simple maternal & child health interventions by 162 rural mothers in the district of Rohtak in Haryana, India, drawing on index data. It was observed that adoption of maternal & child health & family planning interventions was positively & significantly correlated with educational levels of women & with exposure to mass media. The total intervention knowledge score was significantly & positively correlated with adoption index for maternal & child interventions. Women living near functional health institutions displayed a higher index for interventions than women living away from such institutions. It is argued that existing beliefs pose a barrier to intervention adoption; thus, educational, motivational, & reward systems should be developed to maintain individuals' progress through the process. 6 Tables, 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Policy Contradictions in Capitalism: An Illustration with the Hong Kong Government's Proposed Reforms on Cost-Recovery in Hospital Services

Author: Yu, Sam Wai-kam11 Division Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61577405?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores background issues underlying the Hong Kong government's proposed cost-recovery reforms in hospital services, arguing that they do not exist in isolation, but are part of a long-term strategy of dealing with the decommodifying effects of social services. Therefore, the importance of these proposed reforms are not just limited to changes in hospital services, but are also related to other wider issues, eg, the contradictory social services-capitalism relationship & how the government deals with it. 42 References. Indigenization of Social Work Values in Hong Kong: A Brief Review

Author: Lam, Chiu-Wan11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61600895?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues that there is no systematic discussion on indigenization of social work values in Hong Kong, drawing on an analysis of related discourse. Chinese culture is often stereotyped as a uniform entity that is static, authoritative, & reactionary. It is contended that this is not true, & a global understanding & evaluation of Chinese culture & its manifold forms in Hong Kong is deemed necessary. Such assessment could mean more value alternatives for contemplation on indigenization, ie, to reflect on, enrich, or even replace the tenets of conventional social work values. 2 Figures, 37 References. Local Knowledge, Indigenous Practice: Linking the Cultural, the Personal, and the Professional in Social Work Practice

Author: Kwong, Wai-man11 Dept Applied Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61575287?accountid=14925

Abstract: The accepted means of developing culturally sensitive practice -- the successive modification of intervention theories & approaches through empirically examining their compatibility to the local cultural context & testing their effectiveness in working with Chinese clients -- is rejected. Instead it is argued that social workers have been, & still are, creating knowledge for a "Chinese social work." Large abstractions, in the form of formal theories, provide inadequate guide for practice. Social workers improvise & create context-specific & practice-relevant local knowledge that accounts for client expectations, cultural knowledge, & personal & professional experiences. 54 References. Adapted from the source document.

Mental Health Service in Hong Kong: A Call for a New Policy

Author: Ma, Joyce L C11 Dept Social Work Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin New Territories

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61542304?accountid=14925

Abstract: A critical review of mental health service in Hong Kong shows that the readmission rate has been about 60% in the past 20 years, & quality of life for the mentally ill & their families is far from satisfactory. There are inadequate channels at the organizational & policy levels for policymakers to account for the views of the mentally ill & their families in service design & implementation. Here, a policy focus shift is proposed: rather than fostering dependency of the mentally ill & their families, mental health professionals should enhance self-care abilities via empowerment at the individual, organizational, & policy levels. 1 Table, 48 References. Adapted from the source document.

Involvement of Community in Rural Development: Experience in SAARC Countries

Author: Dubey, A K1; Tyagi, Ajay1 Ministry Rural Development, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61550502?accountid=14925

Abstract: Introduces the features of the agrarian economy that eventually necessitate the prioritization of the utilization of limited resources in a given socioeconomic situation, offering examples from India, Nepal, Bangledesh, & Pakistan. Work options available in the given economies are discussed, & the politicoadministrative setup for the execution of the programs is outlined. It is postulated that the complementary role of the community could be more pronounced in creation of awareness, selection of sites & beneficiaries of various programs, execution of schemas & maintenance, & in decision making & feedback. 3 References. Trends in Articles Published in The Indian Journal of Social Work, 1971-1990

Author: Vijayalakshmi, B1; Prasad, B Devi; Rao, K Visweswara1 Dept Social Work Andhra U, Visakhapatnam India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61489985?accountid=14925

Abstract: Analyzes the content of a stratified random sample of 194 articles published in (The Indian Journal of Social Work, 1971-1990, to identify authors' background characteristics & to document trends in empirical content, subject area, & methodological characteristics. Analysis reveals that social work/social science educators contributed significantly & a majority of the articles were written by men. Around 50% were empirical articles, but the % of nonempirical articles showed a slight increase over the years. A majority of the articles focused on areas such as family, child & social work, community development, & personnel management; less than 15% were devoted to women's issues. Quantitative descriptive studies, mostly employing survey research designs, were more common, while qualitative & analytical studies were less common & only a few articles used control/comparison groups. Of the 95 articles that mentioned sampling procedures, nonprobability sampling plans were most common. It is suggested that methodological improvements are needed to improve research quality. 10 Tables, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Bureaucracy and Rural Development

Author: Harish, R11 Dept Studies Political Science Karnataka U, 580003 Kharwad India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61579649?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the current problems & potential benefits of refined bureaucratic participation in rural development in Third World nations. Bureaucracy is commonly depicted as detrimental to rural development, a perception attributed to various circumstances: limitations of the central planning process, a legacy of suspicion regarding bureaucratic mechanisms in colonized nations, lack of coordination between state & local government, & the tendency for bureaucratic institutions & officers to favor state dictates over local needs. However, it is argued that effective rural development demands the expansion of bureaucracy to the local level. This form of bureaucracy is characterized by local leadership with real power, decentralization, & improved coordination & cooperation between & among the higher & lower echelons of society & government. The success of such a system relies on the ability of local leaders to challenge & reject politically motivated decisions by national ministers, politicians, & administrators. 1 Figure, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Methodological Issues in Studies on Resettlement and Rehabilitation of Project Displaced People

Author: Parasuraman, S11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61551269?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses means of assessing the impact of resettlement & rehabilitation on people & communities displaced by development projects. Many such assessments lack information concerning the location & condition of displaced people & face such methodological problems as quantifying the effects of displacement & rehabilitation & determining the significance of host community environments & time involved in rehabilitation. Based on an extensive review of available methodologies, it is argued that evaluation of displacement must pursue a variety of goals: compensation for loss prior to moves, assistance during the moving process, efforts to improve living standards in new communities, resettlement of entire social units (family or village), provision of infrastructure in resettlement areas, & social & economic integration into host communities. Assessing this process must include baseline & follow-up surveys, consideration of the impact of resettlement on host communities, qualitative & quantitative evaluation, & recognition of the social, economic, cultural, & psychological aspects of resettlement. 4 Tables, 1 Appendix, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Socio-Economic Condition of the Houseless Population in Rural Areas

Author: Samuel, M Johnson1; Lingaraju, M; Bhat, T N1 Population Research Centre Instit Social & Economic Change, Bangalore 560072 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61579603?accountid=14925

Abstract: The socioeconomic characteristics of homeless people in rural areas are examined based on census data from Raichur District, India. The majority of the rural homeless belonged to scheduled castes & could be categorized as migrants changing location in search of farm jobs during peak seasons, & nonworkers who earned a minimal income through begging. The children of the rural homeless were rarely sent to school, & the population was characterized by early marriage, high fertility, high mortality, low literacy, & low skills. Overcoming these problems requires housing & employment programs targeted at the rural homeless in addition to health, nutrition, family planning, education, & job training services. The nonworking population needs extensive rehabilitative efforts, while migrant workers could benefit greatly from enforcement of minimum wage & labor protection laws, provision of state-funded schooling, & establishment of flexible housing & education programs that accommodate the migrant lifestyle. 6 Tables, 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Decision Making Behaviour of Women in Farm Sector: A Study

Author: Pattnaik, Tilottama11 Krishi Vigyana Kendra, Baliapal Balasore Orissa India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61585853?accountid=14925

Abstract: The participation & decision-making roles of Indian women in farm-related activities were examined in a survey (N = 180) in Balasore District. Women participated most actively in decisions concerning farm produce storage, animal care, harvesting, crop weeding operations, & labor management. The extent of participation was correlated with both status in the family & size (or lack of) land holdings. Partial participation in decision-making activities averaged 50%; fewer than 20% claimed full participation. The most significant constraints faced by farm women were, in order of importance, inadequate exposure to necessary mass media resources, lack of contact with extension personnel, social restrictions, lack of time, & illiteracy. It is concluded that the participatory role of women can be improved through the provision of necessary information to farm women by extension workers, government & social recognition of women's potential role in farming, & self-employment programs for rural women. 3 Tables, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Psychosomatic Problems and Social Support: Perception of Women Whose Husbands Are Abroad on Job

Author: Kaila, H L11 Dept Psychology Shreemati Nathibai Damodar Thackersey Women's U, Mumbai Bombay 400020 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61550009?accountid=14925

Abstract: The psychosomatic health & social support of 30 Indian women with husbands employed abroad were examined via questionnaire. Although the overall level of psychosomatic problems was low, many respondents (Rs) experienced significant problems with low energy, lower backaches, nervousness, tension, sleeplessness, &/or chest constriction. Psychosomatic problems were significantly correlated with a high number of children, longer duration of husband's absence, & the presence of in-laws. Rs received support from work, children, neighbors, & relatives; women with lower educational qualifications tended to perceive more support than their more educated counterparts. It is concluded that the psychosomatic health & support of such women could be improved through enhanced workplace support mechanisms & social recognition of their special needs & circumstances. 6 Tables, 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Professionalisation of Social Work in the United States and India

Author: Shetty, Lata

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61585797?accountid=14925

Abstract: A discussion of the professionalization of social work (SW) in the US & India focuses on the means & implications of this process. The debate over SW professionalization has evoked numerous concerns regarding its potential to reduce the moral status of the profession, increase distance between workers & clients, &/or subject social goals to market forces. However, professionalization has the advantages of enhancing the prestige & possible support of SW, refining SW skills, & attracting a more competent workforce. In the US, the increasingly scientific orientation of SW has facilitated its professionalization. SW in India remains highly dependent on Western models, & must be adapted to the special circumstances & needs of the Indian environment. India lacks the practical education mechanisms & code of ethics required by certain definitions of professionalism. However, the lack of professionalization in India may enhance services through closer communication & trust between workers & clients. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Male Emigration and Changes in the Family: Impact on Female Sex Roles

Author: Sekhar, T V11 Policy Research & Voluntary Action Instit Social & Economic Change, Bangalore 560072 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61551215?accountid=14925

Abstract: The impact of male (M) emigration on female (F) roles, responsibilities, & behavior both during & following M absence was explored in an interview survey of 132 wives of Persian Gulf returnees in 2 Indian villages. In terms of guardianship of family, residential arrangement, & management of household activities, M absence did not lead to family disintegration. Although Fs faced significant problems, almost 50% remained independent during the absence & the majority benefited from the support of extended kinship networks. Under these circumstances, Fs were called on to make decisions, take on responsibilities, & interact with the outside world in ways that transcended their former roles & experiences. They gained self-confidence & self-esteem, & improved their status within the family during M absence. Although some of these gains were lost on return of M partners, it is concluded that M absence generally improved the long-term independence & decision-making authority of these respondents. 4 Tables, 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

Economic and Social Status of Female Heads of Households -- Need for Intervention under New Economic Policy

Author: Shanthi, K11 U Madras, 600005 Tamil Nadu India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61600462?accountid=14925

Abstract: The social & economic difficulties faced by female heads of households (FHHs) in India are discussed in reference to appropriate means of overcoming the social marginalization & economic deprivation of this rapidly expanding population. Drawing on census data from Madras, it is argued that the majority of FHHs come from underprivileged socioeconomic backgrounds. In addition to economic hardship, these women experience social exclusion & have difficulty finding jobs due to their lack of skills & education. India's new economic policy targets its education & employment programs at male workers at the expense of FHHs. Improving the socioeconomic conditions of FHHs requires a number of reforms: government-supported research & acceptance of the special needs & circumstances of FHHs; economic development & transition interventions aimed at FHHs; employment training & guarantees for this population; & transformation of public attitudes, beliefs, & actions regarding FHHs. 3 Tables. Adapted from the source document.

Demographic Correlates of Poverty in Tribal Households

Author: Rao, N Baskara11 Instit Social & Economic Change, Bangalore 560072 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61600413?accountid=14925

Abstract: The relationship between poverty & a variety of demographic variables was examined via interviews with 504 households from the Marati, Malekudiya, & Koraga tribes in Dakshina Kannada District, India. Approximately 50% of the tribal households were defined as poor, & 22% as very poor. Although only a small minority failed to receive two adequate meals a day consistently, 68% experienced significant food shortages on a seasonal basis, usually during the rainy season. Poor households were characterized by smaller household size, younger heads of household, & lack of extended kinship networks. Females, especially as household heads, comprised a greater proportion of the poor & very poor groups. School attendance for girls & literacy levels for both genders were adversely affected by poverty. Accessibility of potable water, modern health facilities, & household electricity was inadequate for all households, especially among the poor. It is concluded that tribal development schemes must take into account the seasonal nature of food shortages & the greater vulnerability of females to poverty. 13 Tables, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Demographic+Correlates+of+Poverty+in+Tribal+Households&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1996-04-01&amp;volume=57&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=337&amp;author=Rao%2C+N+Baskara

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Demographic+Correlates+of+Poverty+in+Tribal+Households&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1996-04-01&amp;volume=57&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=337&amp;author=Rao%2C+N+Baskara

Adolescent Suicidal Ideation, Social Support and Effective Means of Help

Author: Ho, Wui-shing1; Ho, Kit-wan; Li, Man-chiu1 Dept Applied Social Studies Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444389?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the relationship among adolescent suicidal ideation, social support, & effective help for adolescent suicidal ideation in Hong Kong, drawing on scale data from 225 subjects, ages 12-21, with suicidal ideation or who had been approached by someone who had suicidal ideation in the past 2 years. Results showed that family & opposite-sex relationship problems, parental neglect & abuse, & academic problems are the main causes of suicidal ideation. Adolescents with suicidal ideation had weaker social support, particularly familial. Implications are discussed. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Lone Mothers and Poverty: Challenges to Social Security Policy

Author: Leung, Lai-ching11 Dept Applied Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444371?accountid=14925

Abstract: Prior research (eg, interview studies) underpins an examination of three interlocking factors related to the poverty of lone mothers in Hong Kong: social & financial barriers to paid employment, failure of policy designed to encourage welfare recipients to seek labor participation & risky loss of social support concomitant with low-paid employment. Other employment barriers are addressed. Social policy needs to address the gendered division of labor in the family, labor market, & social security system. 18 References. Safe Use of Medicine by Older Adults in Hong Kong

Author: Chi, Iris1; Ip, Frances; Lo, Eva; Chui, Ernest1 Dept Social Work & Social Administration U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444355?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines drug use & safety issues among older adults in Hong Kong, drawing on in-depth interview & observation data from 6 elderly persons & their families, as well as interview & questionnaire data from geriatricians & a pharmacist representative. Findings reveal that insufficient advice is given to the elderly regarding proper use of medicines; most elderly lack a personal record of medicinal intake/history; & elderly are unaware of their patient rights & often fall prey to uneven power relations, resulting in poor communication. Positives & negatives of drug labeling are addressed, & the role of pharmacists in medication supervision is outlined. Recommendations are made, particularly with respect to the role of social workers. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Longitudinal Study on the Inter-Relationships amongst Family Factors, Family Stress and Adolescent Mental Health: A Study on School Youth in Hong Kong and Guangzhou

Author: Ngai, Ngan-pun1; Law, Simon Wai-on; Xiaogang, Liu; Feng, Zhou1 Dept Social Work Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin New Territories

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444345?accountid=14925

Abstract: Longitudinal scale & questionnaire data are used to explore the effects of family structure, family stress, & adolescent mental well-being on secondary school students in Hong Kong & Guangzhou, People's Republic of China (total N = 2,142). Findings reveal that a higher % of Hong Kong subjects (Ss) were psychologically at-risk & exhibited depressive & anxiety symptoms; male Ss were less inclined to be psychologically at risk; female Ss demonstrated less ability in coping yet received more social support from friends. Implications for social work service, policy making, & future research are considered. J. W. Parker

A Longitudinal Study on the Inter-Relationships amongst Family Factors, Coping Resources, and Psychosocial Adjustment in Hong Kong Adolescents

Author: Shek, Daniel T L1; Chan, Lai-Kwan; Lee, Tak-yan; Ngai, Ngan-pun1 Dept Social Work Chinese U, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444366?accountid=14925

Abstract: Longitudinal questionnaire data from 429 Hong Kong families are used to examine (1) effects of multiple family factors on children's coping resources & psychosocial adjustment, (2) connections between family factors, & (3) the relationship between family factors, coping resources, & psychosocial adjustment in adolescents. Findings indicate that lower levels of family competence were associated with high psychiatric morbidity & low self-esteem in adolescents; families with positive marital relationships more frequently produced positive developmental & mental health outcomes for adolescents; & high availability of coping resources resulted in decreased psychiatric morbidity & mental health difficulties. Similar to previous research, it is concluded that family factors strongly influence the development of adolescents. Adapted from the source document.

Bringing Development Issues to Life in the Classroom: A Simulation Approach

Author: Wegner, Susan D1; David, Gerson1 c/o David -- Graduate School Social Work U Houston, TX 77204-2162

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61623482?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Machakos Village Development Simulation Game, based on a case study of a human development project initiated in Kenya in 1978 by the Instit of Cultural Affairs, is presented as a curriculum tool for stimulating dialogue about international development issues. The evolution of development practice is traced since the 1950s, the Machakos simulation's origin in the early 1980s is summarized, the four phases of game play & arenas of classroom dialogue are outlined, & concepts utilized during the course of game play & postgame relations are clarified. The game focuses on human factors, integrated development, & local involvement. Participants gain factual information about village development concerns, & process & change their perspectives & attitudes toward development-related world issues. Use of the Machakos Game is advocated as a tool in US social work curriculum. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Concept of Empowerment in Social Work Practice

Author: Parsloe, Phyllida11 U Bristol, BS8 1TH England

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61431398?accountid=14925

Abstract: Empowerment, when used by the political Right to signify power by citizens over their own lives & an increase in the caring responsibility of families, tends to individualize citizens & operates at the level of service provision. When used by the far Left, empowerment has a collective focus that clients should have a greater say in the nature of the services they receive & the way in which they are provided. Explored here is whether power-sharing might be a more honest, albeit more difficult, aim for social work. The utility of the concepts of partnership, participation, & user involvement is considered. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Intensive Family Services: A New Old Approach to Social Work Practice

Author: Glasser, Paul11 Rutgers U, New Brunswick NJ 08903

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61424377?accountid=14925

Abstract: A review of changes in social work philosophy in the US during the twentieth century notes that, in the early part of the century, through the work of activists such as Jane Addams, social work focused on the family & the provision of resources for those in need. During mid-century, the focus moved to the individual & internal psychic processes, & is now moving back toward an emphasis on the family & interpersonal relations. These new developments are discussed, with an emphasis on how previous perspectives are innovated in the contemporary context. Focus is placed on a new orientation to practice -- intensive family services -- that emphasizes work with the family unit. Implications for an application of this approach in other regions, particularly Hong Kong, are also discussed. 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Intensive+Family+Services%3A+A+New+Old+Approach+to+Social+Work+Practice&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1995-07-01&amp;volume=29&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=12&amp;author=Glasser%2C+Paul

Social Work Practice in a Chinese Society: Reflections and Challenges

Author: Chau, Kenneth L11 Dept Social Work Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin New Territories

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458439?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is claimed that attention to cultural imperatives is a prerequisite to effective practice; by linking social work practice & services more closely to the social & cultural contexts of the practice environment, social work can be made more culturally sensitive, enhancing its effectiveness. Major developments in indigenizing social work in Hong Kong are highlighted, based on a review of local literature, & future challenges are identified. Ways of moving forward in developing practice formulation & technologies most relevant to the cultural uniqueness of Hong Kong as a Chinese society in transition are considered. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Healing in the Chinese Temple: A Challenge to Clinical Social Work Practice

Author: Ng, Ho-yee11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61493529?accountid=14925

Abstract: Awareness of the relevance of spiritual & religious dimensions in social work practice has been renewed & cogently argued in overseas literature. In Hong Kong, temple going & healing rituals are common. Here, a temple healing ritual is analyzed, based on a tape-recorded instance. A parallel is drawn between psychotherapeutic work & temple healing. It is argued that temple healing challenges the foundation of clinical social work with Chinese clients. 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Healing+in+the+Chinese+Temple%3A+A+Challenge+to+Clinical+Social+Work+Practice&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1995-01-01&amp;volume=29&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=10&amp;author=Ng%2C+Ho-yee

Social Work Education in the United Kingdom: Implications for Hong Kong

Author: Yeung, Audrey1; Choy, Ray; Ngai, Karen; Cheung, Siu-kau; Fok, Shiu-yeu; Li, Dorothea1 Division Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61582489?accountid=14925

Abstract: Observations of a group of 6 social work teachers in Hong Kong regarding their 1994 study tour of the UK are drawn on to examine social work educastion in the UK. Focus is on the professional training qualification in social work (ie, the Diploma in Social Work), & the features of the training programs. A teaching & learning method, Enquiry & Action Learning (EAL), is also examined, along with the strengths & merits of the single professional qualification system, the establishment of an official professional body, & the use of EAL in social work education. Implications for the social work profession & training in Hong Kong are discussed. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Study of Sexuality of Adolescent Girls and Boys in Underprivileged Groups in Bombay

Author: Bhende, Asha A11 Dept Population Policies & Development Programmes International Instit Population Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61640706?accountid=14925

Abstract: Focus group survey data from 20 underprivileged adolescents from 6 slum settlements in Bombay, India, indicate that girls seem ill-informed about reproductive physiology, sexual aspects of marriage, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, & sexually transmitted diseases. Boys, though better-informed, also carry much misinformation regarding these topics. Implications for the development of an educational intervention program for this population are discussed. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Patterns of Extramarital Affairs in Hong Kong

Author: Young, Katherine11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61630577?accountid=14925

Abstract: Proposes a framework for assessing the diverse patterns of extramarital affairs, in Hong Kong, noting implications for marriage counseling. It is suggested that an understanding of the type of affair that is affecting a marriage enables the counselor to identify the issues in the marriage that need attention. Counseling then focuses on the specific marital issues shaken up by the affair. 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Skills Training Groups for Young Adolescents in Hong Kong

Author: Leung, Kwok-keung1; Ko, Lee-yau; Kwok, Yuen-ching; Lee, Chi-hung; Yeung, Ka-ching1 c/o Yeung -- Dept Applied Social Studies Hong Kong Polytechnic, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61575794?accountid=14925

Abstract: Four social skills training groups were conducted in 1991-1993 in Hong Kong for adolescents with interpersonal difficulties, ie, being socially withdrawn, unassertive, & ridiculed by their peers. Content of training included conversation skills & assertive skills. Issues concerning the program adaptation to adolescents' characteristics, skill selection, training techniques, & transfer of learning are discussed. 4 Tables, 37 References. Developing a Post-Graduate Course in Family-Centred Social Work: Personal Reflections

Author: Lam, Gladys L T1; Sung, Pauline P L1 Coll Degree Studies Hong Kong Polytechnic, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61638356?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes the planning process involved in the design of an experiential & reflective curriculum for the training of the lexical experienced family social workers in Hong Kong. It is argued that students who are motivated to pursue postqualification training should not only be taught new theories & techniques, but should develop abilities to reflect contextually, affirm their value stance, learn & practice competently, creatively synthesize theories & practice, & begin to evolve a personalized approach to practice. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Dreams and Reality: Case Study in Urban Grassroots Environmental Protection in Hong Kong's Philistine Society

Author: Bar-On, Arnon A1; Ng, Hang-Sau1 Dept Social Work & Social Administration U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61594761?accountid=14925

Abstract: While the Hong Kong government has stressed the importance of environmental protection, in reality, serious threats to the safety of the population are evident. Here, a case study is presented of the collective action organized by the Tsing Yiu Concern Group in the past ten years. To safeguard the population from siting of hazardous industrial installations. Focus is on the grass-roots mobilization process, involving information, legitimation, lobbying, community education, government assurances, mobilization, & reverberations. 1 Table, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Police and Social Workers: The Possibility of Cooperation in Helping Juvenile Delinquents

Author: Lee, Francis Wing-lin11 Dept Social Work Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin New Territories

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61607035?accountid=14925

Abstract: Results of interviews reveal that patrol police officers (N = 30) in Hong Kong utilize a social & welfare approach in explaining the causes & methods of handling juvenile offenders. This orientation, which is similar to that of the social work profession, suggests areas of possible cooperation between the two professions in the helping process, which are discussed here. 6 Tables, 16 References. Advocacy, Empowerment, and International Collaboration: An Experiment for Rural Development in India

Author: Singh, Ram N11 School Social Work Grand Valley State U, Grand Rapids MI 49401-9403

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61633937?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes an experiment in an Indian village, designed to organize a society & work for rural development through international teamwork. Author: Garain, Swapan11 Dept Social Welfare Administration Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61591541?accountid=14925

Abstract: In the absence of a clear NGO (nongovernmental organization) policy of the government, explored here is the role of the government in the promotion of the NGO sector in India. Author: Ojha, S N

Abstract: Progressiveness in agriculture is mostly used to express innovativeness, modernity, & entrepreneurship. Women Managers in Transition: From Homes to Corporate Offices

Author: Parikh, Indira J1; Shah, Nayana A1 Organisational Behaviour Area Indian Instit Management, Ahmedabad 380015 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61578717?accountid=14925

Abstract: The entry of Indian women into management, their career paths, & the obstacles to those paths are explored using data on 600 women managers obtained in programs, seminars, & workshops conducted over a 15-year period. The entry of women into management was a product of industrialization & the trend toward universal education. In the 1950s, many women entered work organizations for monetary reasons. They tended to be job- (vs career-) oriented & ran traditional homes. During the 1960s-70s, women entered management in larger numbers & were better educated. They tended to be career-oriented & broke social stereotypes. In the 1980s, both women & men managers became more professionally oriented. They held corporate notions, but worked to redefine social & work spaces & roles. Barriers to women have included traditional agrarian images, patriarcy, family responsibilities, & internal socialization. An integrative approach to the lives of women managers can improve their situation & performance. 1 Table, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Women+Managers+in+Transition%3A+From+Homes+to+Corporate+Offices&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1994-04-01&amp;volume=55&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=143&amp;author=Parikh%2C+Indira+J%3BShah%2C+Nayana+A

Promoting Sustainable Livelihoods for the Poor: What NGOs Have to Learn

Author: Mahajan, Vijay

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61608493?accountid=14925

Abstract: Nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) need to improve their qualitative & quantitative performance if they are to reduce poverty & promote livelihood, employment, & income generation. NGOs should specialize, concentrate on larger-scale projects, assist producers' groups rather than emphasizing their own programs (which are often paternalistic), seek more effective management, establish connections with technological & governmental institutions & agribusiness, raise capital from mainstream sources, & recruit & train high-quality personnel. Encouraging & materially assisting groups & communities to generate employment & income will have a longer-term positive impact on poverty than will relief, welfare, & awareness-building efforts. 1 Table, 7 References. HRD for Societal Systems: A Social Identity Based Approach

Author: Agrawal, N M11 HAL Staff Coll, Vimanapura Bangalore India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61343052?accountid=14925

Abstract: The causes for the failure of national development efforts in India & the widening gap between rich & poor are analyzed using a construct of social identity. Many development efforts have taken a conventional modernization approach that disregards social identity factors such as historical & geographical perspective, status, education, socialization, & self-perception. In order for development efforts to succeed, they must change the social identity of India's poor. Oppressed groups must be made aware of their current social identity & its negative consequences. Literacy & self-confidence must be raised, & the poor must be empowered with the assistance of those who care about their well-being. Voluntary organizations are better positioned than the government to attempt this; action research strategies are recommended. 1 Figure, 67 References. Adapted from the source document.
