Ecology of Social Administration in India

Author: Barik, R K11 Indian Instit Public Administration, India Prastha Estate New Delhi 110002

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61604407?accountid=14925

Abstract: Assesses the contributions of Herbert Spencer, Karl Marx, Max Weber, Emile Durkheim, & Mohandas Gandhi to the creation of the Indian welfare state. Classical liberalism held that the state's responsibilities were to protect individual rights to property & life, but academic activists have fundamentally challenged that idea. Spencer was perhaps most important in constructing welfare polices for the poor because he shifted the focus of administrative theory from civil to social administration. Marx then brought economic questions to the forefront by demonstrating that poverty stems from capitalism, while Weber helped advocates of social administration argue that welfare policies can function objectively. Finally, Durkheim's concern with the moral fabric of society & Gandhi's concept of public trusteeship helped facilitate a "moral marriage" between the ruling class & the state on a sustained basis. 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Ecology+of+Social+Administration+in+India&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1994-01-01&amp;volume=55&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=77&amp;author=Barik%2C+R+K

Migration Pattern and Occupational Change (A Study of Palamur Labour in A.P.)

Author: Chakrapani, C1; Kumar, S Vijaya1 CD Deshmukh IMPART Centre Council Social Development, Hyderabad 500013 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61610245?accountid=14925

Abstract: Using census data collected on 6,891 migrants living in Mahbubnagar District, Andhra Pradesh, India, examined are problems & issues associated with large-scale outmigration in both urban & rural areas. Findings reveal that: drought conditions force people to migrate in search of work; continuous migration leaves people out of developmental programs; interdistrict migration seems to be the dominant flow in the direction of urban areas; the major shift in occupation is to nonagricultural labor; & incomes of migrants have increased substantially. Provision of self-employment opportunities & distribution of land are measures suggested by migrants to check large-scale migration. 8 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Case Studies on the Impact of Stress Inoculation Training in Working with Chinese Clients Having Stress and Anxiety

Author: Cheng, Long-chi Rinna11 Division Humanities & Social Sciences City Polytechnic Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61604840?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores the mechanism of change in the treatment process of stress inoculation training (SIT) via an examination of its impacts on 4 local Chinese clients having stress & anxiety. Thirty-three audiotaped interviews revealed that the technical activity of SIT was best described by the therapist verbal response of direct guidance & information & the intention of change & giving information. Among all treatment components, both the worker & the clients rated the education on the transactional nature of stress, cognitive restructuring, & relapse prevention on stress recurrence as helpful; relaxation training as nonhelpful, though with delayed effect; & behavioral rehearsal & problem solving with inconsistent reaction. As for the impact, the worker showed more concern with the treatment-specific tasks of skills training in problem solution while the clients emphasized insight, awareness, & nonspecific features of the treatment. 1 Table, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Case+Studies+on+the+Impact+of+Stress+Inoculation+Training+in+Working+with+Chinese+Clients+Having+Stress+and+Anxiety&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=21&amp;author=Cheng%2C+Long-chi+Rinna

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Case+Studies+on+the+Impact+of+Stress+Inoculation+Training+in+Working+with+Chinese+Clients+Having+Stress+and+Anxiety&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=21&amp;author=Cheng%2C+Long-chi+Rinna

Engaging Outreaching Clients

Author: Leung, Chi-fai11 Dept Social Work & Social Administration U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61627293?accountid=14925

Abstract: Strategies for social worker outreach to marginal youth clients in Hong Kong are based on reinforcement theory & exchange theory. The goal is to minimize the costs & maximize the rewards of worker-client interactions. Client-related costs include skepticism, apprehension, fear of criticism, stigmatization, & concern of having illegal activities reported. Social workers face costs associated with client testing behaviors. Other costs arise from differences between worker & client (eg, communication patterns, values). Several specific suggestions are offered for social workers to minimize costs & maximize rewards. 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Engaging+Outreaching+Clients&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=42&amp;author=Leung%2C+Chi-fai

Indian Muslim Women: Post Divorce Problems and Social Support

Author: Siganporia, Munira

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61588487?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview data from 100 divorced Muslim women from Bombay & Pune (India) are used to describe postdivorce problems as well as extent & forms of social support. Most respondents (Rs) had little education, belonged to the lower socioeconomic class, & were employed mostly in unskilled jobs. Most returned to live with their parents after the divorce. Findings also indicate that husbands exerted greater control over divorce strategy & outcome than wives. In most cases, Rs suffered postdivorce financial hardship & socioemotional & parent-child relationship problems. Emphasized is the importance of family support, along with women's self-reliance. Despite the difficulties, 88% were happy that the marriage ended. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Indian+Muslim+Women%3A+Post+Divorce+Problems+and+Social+Support&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;volume=54&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=355&amp;author=Siganporia%2C+Munira

Training Grassroots Level Workers in Empowering the Rural Poor: The Case of an Indian NGO

Author: Garain, Swapan11 Dept Social Welfare Administration Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61636143?accountid=14925

Abstract: Because empowerment of the disadvantaged in Third World countries is central to development, the role of empowerment workers & activists is crucial. Described here is the activist training program of the Rural Communes, a nongovernmental organization (NGO) established in 1976 in Maharashtra, India. NGO objectives include: increasing social & political consciousness, promoting agriculture & production, & implementing government plans. Reported are job profile, attributes, & training of empowerment activists, focusing on trainee selection, & program methodology. The activists' work includes generating discussions of community issues, encouraging group action, facilitating task-identification, & self-performance assessment. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Socio-Economic and Demographic Factors Influencing Child Morbidity

Author: Dhanalakshmi, N; Murthy, M S R

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61620854?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interviews were conducted with 400 women from a drought-prone area & 400 from an agriculturally developed area in India, each with at least 1 child under age 5, to explore the relationship between child morbidity & several socioeconomic/-demographic factors. Findings show that in the drought-prone area, morbidity was mostly related with type of family, while in the agriculturally developed area, morbidity was related more to household size, father's occupation, & family type. 8 Tables, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Medical Ethics and Patients' Rights

Author: Jesani, Amar11 Centre Enquiry Health & Allied Themes, 310 Prabhu Darshan Amboli Bombay 400058 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61629908?accountid=14925

Abstract: Medical ethics refers to doctors' duties toward patients, ie, the rights of the patient. The autonomy of the profession is based on the assumption that it regulates itself. In India, the medical council is the regulatory body of the profession. Following a review of the council's origin & role, described are the code of ethics & patient's rights implied in it. 1 Appendix. Adapted from the source document.

Understanding and Enhancing Family Communications

Author: Mane, Purnima11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61631069?accountid=14925

Author: Thudipara, Jacob Z11 Indore School Social Work, Madhya Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61636269?accountid=14925

Abstract: One of the consequences of rapidly increasing urbanization in India has been rapid growth of slums & informal settlements, where people live without physical amenities like water, sanitation, roads, drainage, education, health, or opportunities for socioeconomic development. Traditionally, municipal agencies have been saddled with the task of the provision & maintenance of these facilities. However, experience has revealed that local self-governments alone cannot undertake the enormous task of urban development. Examined here is the participatory approach adopted by the Indore Habitat Improvement Project for slum upgradation in Madhya Pradesh. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 1 Reference. Mental Illness and Family Response: A Study of Coping Techniques

Author: Vijayalakshmi, B1; Ramana, K V1 Dept Social Work Andhra U, Visakhapatnam 530003 Andhra Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61584317?accountid=14925

Abstract: Structured interview data from 1 significant member in each of 100 families are drawn on to explore the adjustments made by family members when a member develops mental illness. Several coping techniques are identified, with families frequently having moved from one to another during the prehospitalization stage. The coping techniques used are a function of the family's reaction to abnormal behavior. The use of multiple coping techniques is inevitable due to the lack of clarity regarding appropriate help sources. 2 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Impact of Intervention on the Parental Perceptions and Expectations of Their Mentally Retarded Children

Author: Madhavan, Thuppal1; Narayan, Jayanthi1 National Instit Mentally Handicapped, Secunderabad 500011 Andhra Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61596086?accountid=14925

Abstract: Semistructured questionnaire data from 100 parents of mentally retarded children in Secunderabad, India, are used to assess the effects of professional intervention on parental perceptions & expectations of their children. From among 10 major perceptions, significant changes were noted in the areas regarding poor brain development as a cause for the condition, & the possibility of improvement in the child with training. Out of 14 different expectations, significant changes were noted in the areas of total cure, & need for special education & speech development, where the number asking for the former reduced & for the latter, increased. Results are discussed with a focus on the importance of the parental perceptions & expectations in the training of mentally retarded persons. 5 Tables, 2 Figures, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Family: Some Reflections on Future Policy

Author: Blackstone, Tessa11 Birbeck Coll U London, WC1E 7HU England

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61625933?accountid=14925

Abstract: Arguing that divorce signifies the dissolution of a marriage, not of a family, specialist counseling & conciliation services are recommended. These require high professional standards & should have some government support. Child care, flexible working arrangements, & child benefit & income support are three main policy areas where adjustment is required to take into account the needs of single-parent families. Personal experience on the management committee of a family policy studies center in London, England, is drawn on to support these arguments. 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Re-Organising the Experience of Self and the Spouse: An Integrated Model Based on N.L.P. and Meditation

Author: Singh, Ram N11 School Social Work Grand Valley State U, Grand Rapids MI 49401-9403

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61642189?accountid=14925

Abstract: A treatment model for marital couples in conflict is presented that highlights training each partner to develop the capacity to experience the real self & differentiate it from the "pseudo-self" that contributes to blaming & feeling victimized. Three levels of self -- the mundane, the intermediary, & the higher -- are differentiated. Some techniques of meditation & neurolinguistic programing are presented to facilitate reorganization of the experience of self, which, it is argued, will ultimately reduce interpersonal conflicts & promote self-growth. 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Change and Family Planning in Kenya

Author: Pillai, Vijayan K11 Dept Sociology & Social Work U North Texas, Denton 76203

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61656368?accountid=14925

Abstract: A critical overview of population policies in Kenya is presented, & some suggestions for improvement are offered, focusing on the areas of women's status & health care as a basis for family planning policies. Extant family planning programs are evaluated, considering factors such as cultural dimensions & influence on existing power structure. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Ecology and the Law

Author: Nadkarni, Vimla V11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work Tata Instit Social Sciences, Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61612314?accountid=14925

Abstract: A critical evaluation of post-1972 legislation governing ecological conservation in India, drawing on the classification framework of Chattrapati Singh ("Environment and the Law" in Nathawat, G. S., Shastri, Satish, & Vyas, J. P., Man, Nature and the Environment, Jaipur: RBSA Publishers, 1988, 97-103). Singh's framework classifies laws affecting citizens, according to structural & functional categories with a protective vs planning focus. Water, pollution, & forest conservation laws are classified, & gaps in coverage & other drawbacks are indicated. It is concluded that India has largely failed to translate international environmental policy into law. Suggestions are made for actions that can be taken by social workers & activists to encourage the enactment of effective environmental protection laws. 1 Table, 1 Appendix, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Child Workers: An Analysis of Their Terms of Employment

Author: Das, D. K. Lal1; Sekhar, S F Chandra1 Coll Social Work, Red Hills Hyderabad 500004 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61596499?accountid=14925

Abstract: With the rapid growth of Indian industry has come an increase in child labor. Child workers have very little say in choosing their occupation, have no rights as workers, & cannot join labor unions to protect themselves against exploitation. Here, data obtained during interviews with child workers at 26 industries in Vishakapatnam, Andhra Pradesh, are drawn on to describe their terms of employment. Analysis reveals that child workers in lower age groups working on a temporary basis react to their terms of employment differently than do those in higher age groups who work either as casual or contract workers. 2 Tables, 7 References. Child Abuse in India: A Theoretical Overview

Author: Segal, Uma A11 Dept Social Work U Missouri, Saint Louis 63121

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61648356?accountid=14925

Abstract: Cross-cultural literature has brought awareness that child abuse is a phenomenon that occurs internationally, both in developed & developing countries, across the globe. Awareness & knowledge of child abuse in developing countries is relatively recent & its recognition is often camouflaged by the norms, values, & expectations of differing sociocultural traditions. It is suggested that the 1988 definition of child abuse adopted by the first National Seminar on Child Abuse in India is an important first step in the process of intervention. The definition, however, does not differentiate between societal abuse -- perpetuated in the form of child prostitution, child labor, child beggary, & child marriage -- & intrafamilial abuse resulting from parental action/inaction. Consequently, human service practitioners may be more responsive to the harmful effects of societal abuse. Much greater focus needs to be placed on the effects of parental abuse, perceptions of Indian nationals regarding this area should be assessed, & consciousness-raising efforts must be directed to address the rights of children within boundaries of the family structure. Literature on child abuse in India is reviewed, & implications for researchers, human service professionals, & policymakers are discussed. 35 References. AA

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Child+Abuse+in+India%3A+A+Theoretical+Overview&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-07-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=293&amp;author=Segal%2C+Uma+A

Agricultural Modernisation, Value of Children and Fertility Behaviour

Author: Murthy, P V11 Population Studies Centre Sri Venkateswara U, Andhra Pradesh 20166 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61649060?accountid=14925

Abstract: An examination of the effects of both economic & noneconomic (social, psychological, cultural) costs & benefits of childrearing in family-size decisions among Indian rural parents, in the context of agricultural modernization. It is assumed that parents' evaluation of costs & benefits of children determines fertility behavior. Analysis of interview data obtained from 300 couples from developed & 300 from backward villages in Andhra Pradesh, India, reveals a negative relationship between (1) perception of economic costs & desired family size; & (2) agricultural modernization & fertility. 4 Tables, 2 Appendixes, 21 References. I. Shagrir

The Suburbs of Bombay

Author: Das, Manjurika1; Sita, K1 c/o Sita -- Dept Geography U Bombay, 400032 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61621390?accountid=14925

Abstract: Among Indian cities, Bombay has long had the best mass transit facilities in the form of suburban railways & a good road transport network, which led to large-scale suburbanization, particularly after 1950. Here, based on census data supplemented by field observations, the distinctive features of the suburbs are contrasted to the city, with focus on demographic change over the last few decades. In particular, the characteristics of western vs eastern, & inner vs outer, suburbs are compared. 12 Tables, 3 Figures, 1 Appendix, 5 References. Adapted from the source document.

College Student Volunteers in Mental Hospital Programmes

Author: Ranganathan, M1; Reddy, G N Narayana; Shariff, I A; Parthasarathy, R; Kaliaperumal, V G1 Dept Psychiatric Social Work National Instit Mental Health & Neuro Sciences, Bangalore India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61627660?accountid=14925

Abstract: A comparative study of 30 college student volunteers working in mental hospital settings (MHS) in India as part of the National Service Scheme, vs a control group of 30 students involved in activities other than mental health. The MHS students were solicited to offer their services to 30 long-stay patients for a period of 9 months. Changes in students' attitudes & improvement in patients' behavior were assessed at 3 & 6 months, & the results compared with those of controls. Results are discussed in the context of psychiatric social workers' contribution toward involvement of volunteers in mental health services arguing that paraprofessional & volunteer services need to be better utilized. 5 Tables, 1 Appendix, 10 References. Homelessness: An Empirical Assessment of Poverty amongst Plenty in Nevada, U. S. A.

Author: Davis, Edward W11 Dept Social Work U Las Vegas, NV 89154

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61601423?accountid=14925

Abstract: To explore the social & demographic characteristics of the homeless in Las Vegas, Nev, interview data were obtained from 120 homeless persons & administrators &/or representatives of 22 community organizations. The findings are discussed in the context of 4 available theoretical frameworks explaining homelessness in the US, pertaining to: (1) deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill; (2) shortage of low-cost housing; (3) national economic trends, including rising unemployment; & (4) change in social policies & public values, especially decreased social welfare spending. 22 References. Female Labour Force in the Unorganised Sector of Mat Industries -- Some Evidence

Author: Manimekalai, N1; Sundari, S1 Bharathidasan U, Trichy Tamil Nadu 620024 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61632077?accountid=14925

Abstract: Structured interviews were conducted in 1989/90 with 110 female (F) workers employed in the mat weaving industries of Amoor & Ayyampalayam, Tamil Nadu, India, to explore their working conditions & problems. Data regarding the general population, the labor market, & employment trends are also reported. Labor force participation of Fs is greater than that of males (Ms) in the unorganized mat weaving sector, but despite these Fs' employment, 90+% were found to be living below the poverty line. Recommendations are made for: improved working conditions; a minimum wage based on a time rate equal to that of Ms; increased training in weaving, dyeing, & related skills; & government commitment to women's work issues & poverty eradication programs. 3 Tables, 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Female+Labour+Force+in+the+Unorganised+Sector+of+Mat+Industries+--+Some+Evidence&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-04-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=195&amp;author=Manimekalai%2C+N%3BSundari%2C+S

Rural-Urban Differences: The Migrants' Perspective

Author: Kamra, Sarita11 Panjab U, Chandigarh 160014 Union Territory India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61601382?accountid=14925

Abstract: Rural-urban differences in India are examined in relation to prevailing rural-urban typologies developed in the West, questioning whether these differences are perceived as inequitable by the people, or are just sociological constructs. Views of urban social reality held by 100 male migrants are compared to those of rural reality expressed by 65 (most male) head of households in open-ended interviews, exploring trends in religion, kinship, caste, & occupation. Conclusions partly confirm stereotypical notions about rural-urban differences. It is argued that the contemporary "no difference theory" obscures the reality of age-old Indian urban culture & also underestimates the urban area changes over the past thirty years. 6 Tables, 2 Appendixes, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Rural-Urban+Differences%3A+The+Migrants%27+Perspective&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-04-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=215&amp;author=Kamra%2C+Sarita

Progress in Literacy in India -- A Statistical Analysis

Author: Karkal, Malini

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61632639?accountid=14925

Abstract: Literacy in India is examined by rural vs urban areas, sex, & different states, using census reports for 1961-1981. The data show that while the literacy rate increased proportionately, with the increase in population, the actual number of illiterates rose from 325.3 million to 424.3 million. It is also found that much of the gain in literacy rates was among urban populations; the bias against the rural population was greater than that against females. 15 Tables, 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Progress+in+Literacy+in+India+--+A+Statistical+Analysis&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-04-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=229&amp;author=Karkal%2C+Malini

At the Cross Roads: Whither Social Policy?

Author: Viswanathan, N11 School Social Work Adelphi U, Garden City NY 11530

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61654401?accountid=14925

Abstract: A discussion of the debate over approaches to development -- the state-centric vs the market model -- focusing on the case of India. The alleged shortcomings & uneven distribution of benefits resulting from state or government intervention have increased the pressure to consider alternative routes to development via privatization & market-oriented mechanisms. It is concluded that the direction of social policies will be influenced by the way in which the questions raised in the debate are addressed & resolved. 1 Figure. Adapted from the source document.

Whither Personnel Management

Author: Randeria, K N

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61627488?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is argued that the personnel function must expand to synthesize corporate interests & worker welfare needs, thereby enabling the individual to become a self-reliant & responsible citizen. This goal is discussed relative to legal, industrial relations, collective bargaining, & business knowledge aspects of organizations. A network approach of interdisciplinary functioning & enhancing organization synergy is advocated. A schematic presentation of stages in industrial relations is included. V. Wagener

Workers' Participation, Self-Management and Workers' Control

Author: Sarma, A M11 Unit Labour Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, POB 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61637656?accountid=14925

Abstract: Differing interpretations of the concepts of worker participation, self-management, & control are illustrated by a review of: workers' participation in management in the UK since 1920, the Federal Republic of Germany's codetermination system, the Japanese system of providing worker security, the Gandhian concept of constructive capital/labor cooperation & trusteeship in India, & social self-management decision making in Yugoslavia. Case studies on workers' control at Dynavac Project Limited in Melbourne, Australia, Regent Knitting in St. Jerome, Quebec, & Kamani Tubes Limited in India are compared. It is concluded that an infrastructure of participative work culture must be built in an organization for successful worker participation in management & human resource development. Furthermore, workers should be encouraged to start small self-managed firms & universities need to provide self-management counseling & appropriate curricula. V. Wagener

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Workers%27+Participation%2C+Self-Management+and+Workers%27+Control&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1990-04-01&amp;volume=51&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=279&amp;author=Sarma%2C+A+M

Changing Pattern of Social Work Education in Developing Countries with Special Reference to India -- Need for Alternative Models

Author: Nanavatty, Meher C11 Social Welfare & Development Greater Kailash II, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61614877?accountid=14925

Abstract: A brief review of the Western model of social work education utilized by developing countries is followed by an account of efforts to adapt it or develop alternative models in Latin America, Africa, & Asia. The curriculum design in schools of social work in India has reflected the US pattern. In respose to growing concerns about the suitability of the model for both India's social work educators & practitioners, three models of social work education -- change-oriented, mixed, & professional interest-based -- are charted. 1 Chart, 18 References. V. Wagener

Social Development and Issues of Distributive Justice

Author: Robins, Arthur J11 School Medicine U Missouri, Columbia 65211

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61658071?accountid=14925

Abstract: Nation building unifies diverse groups in a plural society while social development distributes resources among diverse groups. The greatest potential for conflict occurs when ethnic differences are coterminus with religious differences. In order to provide guidelines to further social development & obtain consensus for nation building, management of conflict is examined, with respect to selection of canons of distributive justice, equality as a goal, & aspects of equality as a state policy. 1 Table, 6 References. V. Wagener

Shifting Cultivation: An Aspect of Tribal Exploitation

Author: Burman, J. J. Roy11 Unit Social Policy Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61601426?accountid=14925

Abstract: Shifting cultivation in India is practiced predominantly by tribal groups & is the dominant method of production of 12% of the tribal population. The method is highly organized & efficient & produces yields in inhospitable uplands inappropriate to modern sophisticated technology. Though development agencies criticize shifting cultivation as unscientific, wasteful, & resulting in depletion of forests & the environment, little authentic evidence exists to support this position. Government policies to replace shifting cultivation with such alternative practices as the construction of terraces & individual ownership rights have been met with resistance, & seem to stem from the state's desire to gain control over tribal community lands. 3 Tables, 17 References. D. Generoli

Changing Tribal Scene through Development Programmes in Kerala

Author: Khan, M Z1; Thomas, M E1 Dept Social Work Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61626725?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview data are used to examine the impact of development programs on the socioeconomic conditions of tribal & nontribal groups (N = 107 & 93 respondents, respectively) in Wayanad District, India. On the whole, tribal development programs have been largely ineffective. Whereas 53% of tribal households are literate or educated, the rate for nontribals is 95%. Nontribals tend to work in business & agriculture, & tribals often work for daily wages or in agriculture. Despite being targeted for development programs, tribals have had significantly less exposure to them than have nontribals & their participation is relatively low. Tribals perceive themselves as showing significantly less economic, nutritional, & educational betterment & increases in leisure time as compared to nontribals. 4 Tables, 10 References. D. Generoli

Developing Entrepreneurship in Remote Rural-Tribal Communities

Author: Setty, E Desingu11 Asian Instit Technology, POB 2754 Bangkok 10501 Thailand

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61626682?accountid=14925

Abstract: The development of indigenous entrepreneurship among rural tribal populations in India is examined using a field approach to study community physical conditions, political & economic structures, human resources, & cultural patterns. Three levels of problems in developing entrepreneurship are noted: (1) individual characteristics, eg, lack of motivation, inhibition, & ignorance of opportunities; (2) group problems, eg, lack of awareness, preference for traditional occupations & professions, & apathy, fear, & insecurity toward government; & (3) institutional problems, eg, vague & unrealistic policies unsupported by action, & lack of teamwork & internal coordination in agencies. A five phase approach to enhancing entrepreneurship is outlined. 1 Reference. D. Generoli

The Economic Impact of the Integrated Rural Development Programme

Author: Tripathy, S K1; Bhuyan, B; Pradhan, P N1 Orissa U Agriculture & Technology, Bhubaneswar 751003 Puri India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61627457?accountid=14925

Abstract: The impact of the Integrated Rural Development Programme in alleviating poverty in the Dhenkanai district of Orissa, India, during the Six Plan period (1980-1985) was examined through an interview survey of 977 beneficiary households. Analysis reveals that 38% of households below poverty level prior to onset of the program crossed above the poverty line after program assistance. Service & business sectors performed better than any others. Problems with the implementation of the program included improper identification of beneficiary households, technical & economic infeasibility of schemes, lack of working capital, supply of inferior & diseased animals in the animal husbandry scheme, lack of proper supervision, inappropriate use of assistance, & inadequate loan accounting. 3 Tables, 5 References. D. Generoli

Community Based Rehabilitation for the Mentally Handicapped -- A Model

Author: Narayan, Suma11 Thakur Hari Prasad Instit Mentally Handicapped, Hyderabad India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61614844?accountid=14925

Abstract: A working model for community-based care for the mentally retarded in India is proposed that aims at three levels of intervention. Primary intervention focuses on lowering the incidence of mental retardation through improved health education, dietary corrections, proper antenatal care, & preschool education & care for children. Secondary prevention aims at early identification of retardation, & reduction of its negative effects. Tertiary prevention aims at reducing the disabilities of retardation through training. Major components of the model include establishing a model center, training & development of personnel, community approach to rendering services, home-based programs, day-care centers, vocational training, follow-up, coordination of services, & evaluation & replication. 3 Figures, 3 References. D. Generoli

Role of Development in the Aid of the Handicapped

Author: Krishnaswamy, S

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61618970?accountid=14925

Abstract: The role of science & technology in the prevention of handicaps & in the alleviation of problems faced by the handicapped in India is examined. Despite the implementation of immunization & other health programs, increased food production, & provision of science & technology-based rehabilitation services, the plight of the handicapped remains acute. No targets of the government's 1987 Expanded Programme of Immunization have been achieved, & only 17.7% of children under age one have been immunized against polio; the immunization rate for other childhood diseases ranges from a high of 38.2% for diptheria to nearly 0% for measles. Food consumption has remained the same for the past 2 decades & evidence exists of a serious distribution imbalance. Maternal, child health, & obstetric practices cover only a small amount of the targeted population, & low birthweight is found in 33% of all children. The ratio of road accidents per 10,000 vehicles is the highest in the world. Education & training services benefit only 30,000 of the population of disabled children. The chances of achieving "Health for All by 2000 AD" are very pessimistic. 3 Tables, 17 References. D. Generoli

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Role+of+Development+in+the+Aid+of+the+Handicapped&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1990-01-01&amp;volume=51&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=165&amp;author=Krishnaswamy%2C+S

The Needs of Children and School Social Work Services

Author: Gokarn, N A11 Dept Family & Child Welfare Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61622000?accountid=14925

Abstract: Ways school facilities can be enhanced through social work services (SWS) to meet the developmental needs of children are described, citing various types of counseling programs. The introduction of school SWS in Bombay, India, beginning in the late 1950s is reviewed, centering on the roles of the state, school staff & teachers, & parents. It is argued that fully developed school SWS provide for children's needs, & serve as a platform for adults to design schools as "growth-oriented experiences." A five-day workshop held in 1987 for school counselors & child guidance workers to discuss effective counseling methods, theoretical approaches, & programs relevant to the local culture is described. 20 References. Play Materials in Therapeutic Work with Children

Author: Kashyap, Lina

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61655211?accountid=14925

Abstract: Because communication with children through words alone is frequently difficult, it is proposed that social workers can make effective use of therapeutic play in working with child clients. The importance of play in a child's life, & a history of its evolution & function as a therapeutic medium, are described. Three types of play materials -- raw, construction, & finished -- are discussed, & examples given of their use in therapy, drawing on case studies. Particular focus is on the importance of art as a form of self-expression & communication, & as a means of recalling the past. When selecting games, it is recommended that social workers be aware of their own goals, the therapeutic outcome desired, & the interpretive implications involved in this choice. 9 References. S. Dilts

Developmental Work with Children's Groups

Author: Gandevia, Katy Y11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61652619?accountid=14925

Abstract: The importance of the group concept in children's development & a brief history of working with children in therapeutic groups are discussed, focusing on two types of children's group therapy: growth-centered groups for children considered "normal"; & problem-centered groups, which offer more structure. To ensure that both types of groups produce positive outcomes, the importance of selection of members, size, length, & frequency of sessions, & duration of the group session, are stressed. Key therapeutic concepts common to both types of groups are examined, & suggestions for organizing groups are offered, highlighting important factors in both the initial & working phases. Although the group format is considered effective in many areas, problems that require outside attention are also outlined; recommendations are made for working with families & teachers, & for tapping outside resources. Finally, examples of four group sessions are provided. 2 Tables, 4 References. S. Dilts

Workers Education Scheme -- An Evaluation

Author: Sarma, A M11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400 088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61582741?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Central Board for Workers Education was established in India to administer the Workers Education Scheme. Interviews were conducted with 370 persons involved with the work of 2 units, including 8 worker-teachers, 75 trained workers, 207 untrained workers, 40 union officials, & 40 management executives, to assess views of the working of the scheme. A number of suggestions from various sources for the improvement of the scheme are noted. Certain improvements are needed in the Scheme of Workers Education to make it more result-oriented. 10 Tables. Modified HA.

Some Problems of Home-Based Piece-Rate Women Workers

Author: Chaudhary, S N1; Chaudhary, Pratima1 Dept Sociology Bhopal U, 462026 Madhya Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61562045?accountid=14925

Abstract: Secondary source data are drawn on to examine home-based, piece-rate women workers in India, examining some of the socioeconomic & environmental problems they encounter & the support mechanisms they draw on to deal with them. Analysis reveals two types of worker -- independent & dependent -- with the latter facing more problems than the former. Neither, however, has their work recognized, & both have poor economic gains. Ways to uplift their status are suggested. 10 References. Modified AA

Psychiatric Social Work with Emotionally Disturbed Children and Adolescents: Content Analysis of Case Records

Author: Rao, R Natasha1; Parthasarathy, R1 Dept Psychiatric Social Work National Instit Mental Health & Neuro-Sciences, Bangalore India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61532861?accountid=14925

Abstract: To identify emotional & psychosocial problems of children & adolescent clients handled by psychiatric social workers, a content analysis was conducted of 100 case records from 1969-1984 at the National Instit of Mental Health & Neuro-Sciences in Bangalore, India. Results show little difference between male & female clients; most were in low socioeconomic groups. Problem families demonstrated interactional difficulties, poor parental attitudes & personalities, low academic performance, & learning & social adjustment difficulties. Implications for social workers are detailed. 8 Tables, 18 References. M. Malas

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Psychiatric+Social+Work+with+Emotionally+Disturbed+Children+and+Adolescents%3A+Content+Analysis+of+Case+Records&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1989-07-01&amp;volume=50&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=271&amp;author=Rao%2C+R+Natasha%3BParthasarathy%2C+R

Sexist Bias in Occupational Prestige

Author: Kanekar, Suresh11 Dept Applied Psychology U Bombay, Fort 400032 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61551398?accountid=14925

Abstract: Students (N = 486) from several colleges & universities in Bombay, India, were asked to rate 16 occupations in terms of respectability. Results showed that males were rated more respectable by both male & female Ss, with greater differences for higher- than for lower-ranked occupations. Discrepancies between others' & self-ratings (ie, between inferred social norms & personal norms) varied with sex. 3 Tables, 9 References. M. Malas

The Indecent Representation of Women (Protection) Act (1986)

Author: Gandhi, Nandita

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61539582?accountid=14925

Abstract: The historical background & implementation problems of the 1986 Indecent Representation of Women (Protection) Act in India are presented. It is concluded that state intervention has been inadequate in regulating pornographic materials, offensive advertisements, & other obscene representations of women; this may be due to the Act's vagueness. 5 References. Beyond Social Service Administration

Author: Ramachandran, P11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61593800?accountid=14925

Abstract: Two viewpoints persist about the training of future social workers in the context of social change: one espousing perpetuation of the current system in India of training social workers for curative remedial social work; & the other favoring changing the system in order to train social workers for social action & reform. A transitionalist perspective is advocated that incorporates elements of both viewpoints, while encouraging promotional & holistic social work, in order to effect changes that will benefit society as a whole. V. Wagener

Voluntary Organisations and Women's Struggle for Change: Experience with BCT

Author: Vindhya, U1; Kalpana, V1 Dept Psychology & Parapsychology Andhra U, Visakhapatnam 530003 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61579600?accountid=14925

Abstract: An investigation of whether the widespread, development-oriented voluntary organizations in India subsume women's equality & rights. Programs in which the family is considered as a unit of development, & the inequality of women within the family is ignored, are described. Particular focus is on a case study of the Bhagavatula Charitable Trust (BCT), an organization formed in 1976 to assist the integrated development of 50 villages of Andhra Pradesh. In the remote village of Marripalem, BCT attempted to involve women in all developmental changes because it was perceived that they could be effective change agents in spite of their status in the caste & class structure. Utilizing an economic approach, the BCT model empowered the women to become vocal participants in community affairs & social change. 2 Tables, 19 References. V. Wagener

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Voluntary+Organisations+and+Women%27s+Struggle+for+Change%3A+Experience+with+BCT&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1989-04-01&amp;volume=50&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=183&amp;author=Vindhya%2C+U%3BKalpana%2C+V

Repertoire of Interventions in the Field of Drug Abuse

Author: Nadkarni, Vimla V11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61589525?accountid=14925

Abstract: Social workers & de-addiction workers need to be aware of the wide repertoire of interventions required to deal with the problem of drug addiction. A holistic response operates at both the microlevel, representing the interaction among the individual, the drug, & the environment, & the macrolevel of the social, economic, & political realities that predispose & perpetuate the problem. Although few social workers view the problem as structural, such an understanding is needed in order to influence macrolevel decision making. Various modalities of interventions are discussed along with influencing parameters, from helping addicts with their problem-solving capacities to working with governments in the development & improvement of social policies. 2 Figures, 7 References. A. Waters

Preventive Education in Drug Abuse

Author: Jaswal, Surinder K P11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work Tata Instit Social Sciences, Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61587115?accountid=14925

Abstract: Today, the misuse & abuse of drugs is one of the world's most widespread & critical problems. Working with the Families of the Addicts

Author: Mane, Purnima11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467565?accountid=14925

Abstract: Work with the families of drug addicts is examined in terms of (1) dealing with family pathology underlying addiction & the fostering of healthy interaction to smoothen the path to recovery, (2) helping the family to cope with the impact of addiction on the family, & (3) fostering family understanding of addiction & ensuring its contribution to the recovery of the addict. Focus is on the concept of "family power": ie, the family is viewed as the major unit providing strength & support for the addict through the process of treatment & rehabilitation, & one that can provide relief & support to itself as well as to other families in similar situations. 1 Figure, 12 References. Rehabilitation in the Field of Drug Abuse

Author: Gandevia, Katy Y11 Dept Medical & Psychiatric Social Work Tata Instit Social Sciences, POB 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61589327?accountid=14925

Abstract: Various approaches, settings, & models used in the field of drug addict rehabilitation are outlined, including hospital detoxification programs & religious group membership. The experiences of Burma, Malaysia, & GB are described in order to provide a background for planning rehabilitation programs for drug addicts in India. In Burma, a month's stay in a detoxification center is followed, in selected cases, by several months in rehabilitation centers in which the client receives vocational training & psychotherapy. The Malaysian program emphasizes after care & a unique client management system. In GB, drug users are treated by community agencies that emphasize self-help. 7 References. Modified HA

Relationships among Task Complexity, Structure, Job Performance and Satisfaction in Social Service Organizations

Author: Dubey, Sumati N1; Meller, Yasef1 Jane Addams Coll Social Work U Illinois, Chicago 60680

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61437749?accountid=14925

Abstract: The relationship between task complexity & centralization/formalization, & its impact on job performance & satisfaction are examined in social service organizations that provide child welfare services, services to the elderly, employment counseling, & crisis intervention. Analysis is based on questionnaire data collected from a purposive systematic sample of 183 social workers & their immediate supervisors; organizational documents were also examined. Findings indicate that people-changing technologies were heterogeneous across different social service organizations & different programs within these organizations. Congruence between technology & organizational structure does not explain variance in job satisfaction & performance. 6 Tables, 37 References. Modified HA

Tribal Tradition and Modern Development in North-East India

Author: Burman, J. J. Roy11 Unit Social Policy Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61594974?accountid=14925

Abstract: The traditional socioeconomic institutions that characterize the tribal societies of northeastern India are usually regarded as impediments to modern development. However, many of the community-initiated autogenous growth processes are based on the very same institutions. Some state governments & voluntary agencies have begun to appreciate such institutions, & are encouraging the thrust of development through them. It is suggested that development workers must play a mediatory role between traditional & modern society, drawing on the experience base of the communities with which they work, & giving due consideration to new demands & aspirations. 5 References. Modified HA

The Influence of Horizontal and Vertical Fragmentation on Social Welfare Policy: The Case of Israel

Author: Lazin, Frederick A11 Dept Behavioral Sciences Ben Gurion U Negev, Beersheva 84105 Israel

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61594123?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is often assumed that unitary political systems like Israel are better able to implement social policy than federal systems marked by political fragmentation. It is argued that Israel's unitary political system, despite its monopoly of authority, exhibits significant difficulties in the policy-making process, such as the constraints in the formulation of a single or even coordinated national policy in many substantive areas. To illustrate, an analysis of Project Renewal, the major social welfare & Ur renewal program of the Begin administration, shows how political institutions influence the establishment of administrative arrangements, the setting of priorities, the attainment of declared objectives, & the allocation of resources. 18 References. Modified HA

Single Parent Families -- Consequences for Single Parents

Author: Bharat, Shalini11 Unit Family Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470050?accountid=14925

Abstract: The economic, social, & emotional consequences for single-parent families in a slum area of Bombay, India, were examined via interview responses of 28 single parents & a comparison group of 28 intact-family mothers. Results show that the major problems were in the economic & emotional areas rather than in the social sphere. It is suggested that single-parent families be treated as high-risk families, & that welfare services be designed mainly to help them economically. 3 Tables, 5 References. Modified HA

Meditation Subculture and Social Skills

Author: Ganguli, H C11 Dept Psychology U Delhi, 110007 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61601569?accountid=14925

Abstract: Self-report questionnaire data are used to investigate the outcomes of an organized meditation program involving 230 young white Ms & Fs from Canada. Benefits reported by 66+% of participants (excluding those related to drug use) concern the nature of social skills & refer to improvement in coping skills & in social & interpersonal relatonships. It has been hypothesized that member interaction within the mediation group subculture, rather than the practice of the meditation exercise per se, is responsible for these social skills benefits. This hypothesis is supported by these results & those from small group studies. 3 Tables, 19 References. Modified HA

Aspirations of Decision-Makers for the Education of Girls, Bihar, 1980-81

Author: Kanitkar, Tara11 International Instit Population Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61578817?accountid=14925

Abstract: Analysis of 1981 Indian census data reveals that girls' education is neglected in various states, especially in Bihar, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, & Madhya Pradesh. Here, an attempt is made to study the aspirations of parents/decision makers in the family regarding girls' education in Bihar. Analysis of the data obtained during a survey of 10,721 households in 1980/81 indicates that the education aspired for girls is invariably lower than that for boys in Ru as well as in Ur areas. About 23% of Rs believe that girls should be given only the barest education, ie, to make them just literate. Differences in educational aspirations by caste, religion, & parental literacy/educational attainment are discussed. 6 Tables, 18 References. Modified HA

Levels of Social Work Provisions in Relation to Needs in a Developing Society

Author: Gore, M S

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61587263?accountid=14925

The Impact of HIV/AIDS on the Food Consumption of Households

Author: Falleiro, Savio P1; Noronha, Silvia M1 Department of Economics, Rosary College of Commerce and Arts, Navelim, Goa

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1463025718?accountid=14925

Abstract: The paper explores the impact of HIV/AIDS on the food consumption pattern of households through empirical research and comparative analysis. The findings highlight that HIV/AIDS households are at a significant disadvantage despite spending a relatively greater proportion of household income on food. Unlike non-HIV/AIDS households, where female-headed-households were at a disadvantage, food-expenses are gender-neutral in HIV/AIDS households. These women make up their income disadvantage by depending significantly on 'partly/fully sponsored' food and 'unrequited and/or unrevealed' income. Adapted from the source document.

Sanitation Costs and Services in Selected Villages of Andhra Pradesh

Author: Snehalatha, M1; Reddy, Ratna, V; Jayakumar, N1 Country Coordinator

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1463025704?accountid=14925

Abstract: Despite a decade of the Total Sanitation Campaign 1 in India, sanitation still remains a big challenge. Findings from selected villages in Andhra Pradesh reveal that open defecation is rampant, and access to sanitation facilities is far from the reach of many households. Lack of space to construct toilets, availability of water, lack of awareness, and traditional practice of "open defecation" are the major constraints. The varied use of toilets across the Nirmal Gram Puraskar 2 and non-Nirmal Gram Puraskar villages indicate the intensive steps needed for demand generation. The solid and liquid disposal systems often receive low priority and the Panchayats do not receive sufficient money to tackle sanitation related issues. Cost data analysis reveal that capital costs take a lion's share of the funding, while planning and budgeting for indirect and direct support, and capital maintenance costs are negligible or missing. This paper argues for a life-cycle approach for funding with long term targeted efforts for behaviour change and higher allocations for sanitation. Adapted from the source document.

Exploring Patriarchy in Sex Workers' Intimate Relationships: A Case Study from Mumbai

Author: Karandikar, Sharvari; Frost, Caren

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1463028722?accountid=14925

Abstract: This qualitative study compared perceptions of gender-based violence among female sex workers and male intimate partners of female sex workers in the Kamathipura red-light area of Mumbai, India. In-depth interviews with 13 female sex workers and 10 intimate partners of female sex workers revealed differences in perceptions of violence and sex work. While female sex workers reported severe violence from male members of the community, particularly their intimate partners, male members perceived their use of violence against their partners as a household issue. Male perceptions indicated patriarchal beliefs demonstrated by the need to control their female partners, and violence was used as a tool to exercise power over female bodies and behaviours. The study addresses a major gap in the literature on gender-based violence among sex workers of Kamathipura and makes recommendations for future practice, policy and research. Adapted from the source document.

Ethnic Cleansing, Displacement and Resettlement: Case of Bhutanese Refugees in Nepal

Author: Jacob, Mathew11 Currently working as a Senior Researcher with Human Rights Law Network, New Delhi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1463019280?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Bhutanese refugees came to the camps in Nepal around 18 years ago after they witnessed a brutal ethnic cleansing in Bhutan. They initially moved towards India seeking shelter and protection; however, for geo-political considerations, India failed to take any positive step to resolve the issue. Instead, she deported the refugees to Nepal, thereby indirectly supporting Bhutan's act of ethnic cleansing. The fight for repatriation has been diplomatically suppressed not only by India and Bhutan, but also by the inaction of the international community. Nepal did not have much to say on the matter either. Resettlement emerged as an option despite initial resistance from the refugees, especially the older ones, who considered repatriation as their only durable solution. However, political developments led to the failure of the realisation of repatriation and the emergence of resettlement in the third countries as the primary durable solution. Adapted from the source document.

Participation of Women in Panchayti Raj Institutions in Jammu and Kashmir

Author: Kumar, Ashwani11 Ashwani Kumar is a Research Scholar with the University of Jammu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1463019284?accountid=14925

Abstract: Panchayati Raj Institutions had been largely dominated by men until the 73rd Amendment was passed in 1993 to ensure 33 percent reservation for women. However, the provisions of the 73rd Amendment were not extended to Jammu and Kashmir because of Article 370. Jammu and Kashmir has introduced 33 percent reservation in its halqa panchayats through the Jammu and Kashmir Panchayati Raj (Second Amendment) Act, 2003. In 2011, around 10,000 women were elected as panches through panchayat elections. In a state where the number of women in the party and electoral politics has been negligible, this is a process of great transformation. Adapted from the source document.

Feasibility of Introducing Jowar in Midday Meal Programmes: A Study in Three Regions of Andhra Pradesh

Author: Lakshmidevi, N1; Usharani, M; Umadevi, K; Kalpana, K1 Research Associate with the Department of Foods and Nutrition, Post Graduate and Research Centre

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1463026159?accountid=14925

Abstract: The authors conducted the study in three regions of Andhra Pradesh to evaluate the benefits of jowar (sorghum vulgare) on the growth and nutritional status of school children. The study sample covered six schools comprising 900 children selected from Anantapur (Rayalaseema), Mahbubnagar (Telangana) and Vizianagaram districts. The basic recipes selected for supplementation were standardised to meet one third of the daily calorie requirement for school going children. The results showed that the acceptability of jowar recipes was good and, therefore, could be considered for supplementation in the school Mid-day Meals programme of Andhra Pradesh. Adapted from the source document.

MICROCREDIT, CIVIC NETWORKS AND WOMEN'S POLITICAL INVOLVEMENT IN BANGLADESH

Author: UDDIN, MOHAMMAD JASIM11 Department of Sociology Shahjalal University of Science and Technology, Sylhet, Bangladesh mjauddin@yahoo.com

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1622293156?accountid=14925

Abstract: The social capital school has proposed that one of the key mechanisms for generating good democratic outcomes is participation in voluntary associations. Of late, group-based microcredit programmes are considered as effective policy instruments for generating and strengthening civic networks of the community. However, on the micro-level we do not know enough about how membership in microcredit programmes promotes civic engagement, nurtures democratic learning process and makes their members more cooperative. In this paper I investigate whether microcredit providing NGOs have run through and nurtured democratic practices at the local level and whether they mobilize citizens politically and promote leadership among the women. The results indicate that microcredit organizations in the area that I studied failed to promote women's political capabilities or civic engagement since these organizations mainly concentrate on the services of credit distribution and installments collection, and have deviated or shifted away from community mobilization. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=MICROCREDIT%2C+CIVIC+NETWORKS+AND+WOMEN%27S+POLITICAL+INVOLVEMENT+IN+BANGLADESH&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2012-07-01&amp;volume=47&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=3&amp;author=UDDIN%2C+MOHAMMAD+JASIM

Travelling Culture: The Role of Migration in Imaginative Construction of Culture

Author: Dwarak, Irina1; Leelaram, Sunanda1 Vedanta Cultural Foundation, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1438554261?accountid=14925

Abstract: The paper looks at the construction of culture in relation to the social phenomenon of migration. It focuses on the phenomenon of forced mass migration of Jewish students from the Russian Empire to Western Europe in the beginning of the 20th century. The paper views migration as the trigger for cultural, political and socioeconomic transformations among migrants. These transformations were brought about by a radical rethinking of homeland, nation, culture and identity and, as a result of which, a new powerful culture emerged. The paper describes culture as an imaginative construction. Culture is thus not a static and fixed entity contained within strictly defined boundaries of state, nation, religion, traditions and origin, but is subject to new definitions in changing socio-political contexts. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Travelling+Culture%3A+The+Role+of+Migration+in+Imaginative+Construction+of+Culture&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2012-07-01&amp;volume=73&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=301&amp;author=Dwarak%2C+Irina%3BLeelaram%2C+Sunanda

The Determinants of First Birth Interval: The Misings of Assam

Author: Mahanta, Amarjyoti11 Department of Economics, Dibrugarh University, Assam

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1438554365?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper explains the socioeconomic and demographic determinants of the first birth interval among the Misings, the second largest tribe of Assam. The findings of the multivariate regression analysis were significant when determining the effects of the wife's age at marriage, use of contraceptives, the educational level of the couple, family type, nature of wife's occupation and the income level on the first birth interval. Government intervention for socioeconomic progress can raise the quality of living and put restraints on population growth. Adapted from the source document.

Sexual Behaviour among Persons Living with HIV/AIDS In Gujarat: A Qualitative Study

Author: Patel, Sangita V1; Baxi, Rajendra K; Patel, Shilpa; Golin, Carol; Diwanji, Mansi; Shringarpure, Kalpita; Bakshi, Harsh N; Modi, Ekta; Conoor, Priyanka; Mehta, Kedar G1 UNC Sheps Center for Health Services Research, University of North Carolina, USA

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417524382?accountid=14925

Abstract: The authors conducted a formative study to adapt a US based intervention programme SAFETALK-"prevention with positives" to be culturally relevant in Gujarat. In-depth interviews for 30 People Living with HIV/AIDS selected from the Integrated Counselling and Testing Centre in Vadodara, Gujarat, were conducted to assess their sexual behaviour and experiences. All female participants stated that they had been infected by their husbands; only few male participants were infected by their wives. The other male participants believed they had acquired HIV infection through their premarital or extramarital sexual relationships, or as a result of visiting commercial sex workers. Among participants with knowledge of condom use, this knowledge did not translate into practice, even among those who were also health workers. Reduction in sexual activity after HIV diagnosis was seen in majority of the cases. Adapted from the source document.

Perception of Sexual Harassment among Female Hotel Employees in Malaysia

Author: Alagappar, Ponmalar N1; David, Maya Khemlani; Rao, Ramesh1 Section for Co-curricular Courses, External Faculty Electives and TITAS (SKET)

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417521565?accountid=14925

Abstract: Malaysians from diverse ethnic backgrounds interpret verbal and nonverbal cues in relation to sexual harassment differently. This arises from differences in religious and socialisation practices despite a shared commonality of a Malaysian culture (Li and Lee-Wong, 2005). The study investigates perceptions of female hotel employees in Malaysia concerning sexual harassment. It explores how age, race, marital status, educational level, occupational position, department, and the number of years employed influence perception of sexual harassment. Understanding hotel employees' perceptions of sexual harassment will help managers prepare appropriate sexual harassment policies and know what areas of the issue to focus on during training and in the long run, help reduce sexual harassment lawsuits (Agrusa and others, 2002). http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417524261?accountid=14925

Abstract: Consistent with Belsky's (1984) theoretical model, the authors explored whether the contextual, paternal, and child characteristics would have cumulative effects on the quality fathering behaviours of young children. Rashtriya Swasthya Beema Yojna: A Public Health Perspective

Author: Bajpai, Vikas1; Saraya, Anoop1 Research Scholar with the Centre for Social Medicine and Community Health, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417523414?accountid=14925

Abstract: The latest insurance scheme, the 'Rastriya Swasthya Beema Yojna' is based on a business model that equally benefits all stakeholders. This paper analyses the scheme from the perspective of public health and political economy. Based on an analysis of the available data, the paper tries to burst the myth of the much eulogised technology of the Rastriya Swasthva Beema Yojna, which is out of sync with the social, economic and political context of poor people's lives and has grossly fallen short of the declared objectives. The access of this technology driven scheme is limited to the better off sections of society. Adapted from the source document.

Addressing the Issue of Disadvantaged Youth Seeking Work

Author: Hollywood, Emma1; Egdell, Valerie; McQuaid, Ronald1 Employment Research Institute, Edinburgh Napier University, United Kingdom

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417524889?accountid=14925

Abstract: In the UK a significant number of young people do not make successful transitions into further education, training or employment on leaving school, which has been exacerbated further by the current economic crisis. Drawing on in-depth qualitative interview data, this paper examines two Third sector programmes in the UK that can be seen moving away from 'work-first' employment activation and focusing instead on promoting the individual capabilities of disadvantaged, unemployed youth in finding work. When this move is considered through a capability approach perspective, questions are raised about the voice of young people, as their aspirations can be limited because of the social contexts in which they live. It is argued that enabling unemployed youth to choose the work that they have reason to value cannot be achieved without taking into account the importance of the external context; and so while young people's choices may be developed through providing role models etc. it is still a choice shaped and restrained by the context of wider labour markets and education and training opportunities; and the personal and social barriers that inhibit young people from entering work. Adapted from the source document.

Pedagogy Back on Track; Enhancing Capabilities for Young People in Education and Work

Author: Jensen, Niels Rosendal1; Kjeldsen, Christian Christrup1 Department of Education, Aarhus University, Denmark

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417520749?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Danish case study presents findings and considerations derived from an empirical approach based on interviews with young persons, teachers and leaders of four participating institutions. The study discusses the official definition of the "target group" and points to structural and social circumstances. It further returns to an old idea of a "youth moratorium" as an alternate to the "work first"-agenda -- not least in the shape of "realistic counseling". The study shows how adaptations to market and to the "work first"-agenda seems to be counterproductive or even a negative conversion factor for the capability for work. The study points to "critical transitions", not only understood as "misleading trajectories", but as "coincidental trajectories", too. The study concludes in summing up the general problems. In addition the study invites to a discussion concerning pedagogy. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Sztandar-Sztanderska, Karolina1; Zielenska, Marianna1 University of Warsaw, Poland

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417524233?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article presents results of a case study of educational programme, which was designed to answer the structural problems of vocational schooling in Poland. Establishing Caseness, Institutional Selves and "realistic perspectives" -- A German Case Study on the Transition from School to Work

Author: Duker, Jan1; Ley, Thomas1 Faculty of Educational Science, Bielefeld University, Germany

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417523852?accountid=14925

Abstract: This case study will focus on the institutional and normative framework of the German transition sector and one of its programmes -- namely 'Competence Agencies' -- its organisational forms and logics of action and the local context they operate in. Main questions will address their identification of problem groups and constructing 'troubled selves' and what they offer for young people in terms of capabilities for work, education and voice. The case study begins with a short framing of the resources, commodities and social policy agenda of the German transition sector and an illustration of the pedagogical programme (chapter 1). Basic research questions are outlined and the research methods are described (chapter 2). The modelling of the object of research embeds it analytically into the current social policy agenda (chapter 3). Three empirical findings are highlighted: Beginning with the questions of which pedagogical space is constituted and how 'caseness' is established, maintained and transformed, the aspects of identity work and institutional selves within these programmes are pointed out. The handling and negotiation of 'realistic perspectives' is a crucial point within this work and provides a link between an institutional and a subject-oriented level (chapter 4). The three capabilities for work, education and voice are the basis for an analytical review of the case study and the conclusion (chapter 5). Adapted from the source document.

From the Lisbon Strategy to Europe 2020: the Statistical Landscape of the Education and Training Objectives Through the Lens of the Capability Approach

Author: Vero, Josiane11 Centre d'Etudes et de Recherche sur les Qualifications, France

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417521074?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of this chapter is to bring together and comment official statistics and indicators that make up educational targets that are increasingly favoured in the European Union Policy context from the Lisbon Strategy to the Europe 2020 strategy. Focusing on the call for making young people more employable, the chapter relies on Amartya Sen's Capability Approach and in particular on his key idea of 'informational basis of judgement' to reveal the postulates behind the benchmarks that assess progress toward the Education and Training Strategy. Taking up this plea, the chapter starts out by giving a brief description of the Lisbon Strategy as well as the Europe 2020 Strategy. In this perspective, it reports what progress in education and training -- or lack of it -- has taken place. The subsequent section introduces the concepts of "capability" and "Informational basis of judgement" derived from Amartya Sen's Capability Approach (CA) in order to shed light on the normative postulates underlying the benchmarks promoted by the European Commission. One main focus lies in addressing limitations of these indicators with the aim of providing a practical instrument with which to assess and compare education and training performance. The chapter concludes by offering some thoughts for an alternative set of indicators that employs insights from the capability approach drawn from the work of Amartya Sen. Adapted from the source document.

Capabilities Without Rights? The Trespassing Project in Naples

Author: Bifulco, Lavinia1; Monteleone, Raffaele; Mozzana, Carlotta1 Universita di Milano-Bicocca, Italy

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417525169?accountid=14925

Abstract: The aim of this paper is to analyze a project for young NEET in southern Italy in terms of capabilities. Our objective is to examine to what extent it is possible to promote capabilities for work, for voice and for education in a context of lack of resources and rights as the one the project is rooted in. The paper focuses on the institutional, social and individual factors that hamper or promote the conversion of formal resources and rights into capabilities, and tries to understand what the outcomes are for beneficiaries. It highlights on the one hand the critical elements, and on the other the creation of innovative itineraries designed to promote such capabilities, trying to sum up lessons and indications in terms of policies, as well as theoretical and analytical implications for the capability approach. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Berthet, Thierry1; Simon, Veronique1 Centre Emile Durkheim-Cereq, Universite de Bordeaux, France

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/1417524149?accountid=14925

Abstract: This case study focuses on innovative regional policies fighting early school leaving (ESL) in two French regions, Aquitaine and Rhone-Alpes.
