Author: Dandekar, Ajay11 Rural Campus, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Tuljapur, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61364015?accountid=14925

Abstract: The spate of suicides in Indian states of Andhra Pradesh, Punjab, Karnataka & Maharashtra -- coupled with the declining share of agriculture in the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) & increasing burden on the agrarian system -- belies the lofty, almost ideal, claims put forth in the National Policy on Agriculture. These suicides point to a greater crisis in the agrarian system, as a whole, where the suicide is a symptom of a greater malaise that threatens millions of farmers & the landless agricultural labourers in the subcontinent. http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61349064?accountid=14925

Abstract: Although population ageing is now regarded as a world-wide priority, research in this field is just beginning in Nepal. The objective of this paper is to examine the socioeconomic & health status of the elderly in Nepal, specifically those living in Kathmandu. A total of 121 elderly individuals were interviewed from Kathmandu. Our findings show that majority of the elderly reported serious health problems in the last one year; most of the elderly lived with their children; a significantly higher number of elderly women lived alone as compared to men; & the monthly income of the elderly was significantly low. 5 Tables, 16 References. What Is the Relation between Human Practical Action and an Accompanying Discourse? Discussing the Status of Practical Theory

Author: Brinkkjaer, Ulf1; Norholm, Morten1 Dept Educational Sociology, Danmarks Paedagogiske U, Kobenhavn ulf@dpu.dk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61393471?accountid=14925

Abstract: An important part of the discussion of the relation between theory and practice seems not to forget what practice is. This discussion often becomes rather 'theoretical' or 'philosophical', tending first of all to focus on speculative (that is ideological) interpretations of the word 'theory'. This underscores the importance of not losing oneself in discussions of different forms of theory, or in discussions of what ought to be regarded as 'proper' theory. Instead it seems important to concentrate on a much more important issue: What is practice? What does practice consist of? The present article tries to develop this discussion. References. http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61399837?accountid=14925

Abstract: Globalisation, this is my thesis, change first the trade of goods and services, produce a mercantilist pressure on different political fields and affect finally as a consequence effectively our normative comprehension of education. Also Education policy is changing its focus. Risks and Responsibilities? The Individualisation of Youth Transitions and the Ambivalence between Participation and Activation in Europe

Author: Walther, Andreas11 Dept Social Pedagogy, U Tubingen, Germany Andreas.Walther@uni-tuebingen.de

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61368333?accountid=14925

Abstract: This report provides insight on the situation facing young people in contemporary European societies in their transitions to work and citizenship. On the one hand, risks of exclusion have increased, while on the other, responsibilities for coping with such risks have been individualised, a state of affairs reinforced by the trend towards activation labour market policies. Drawing on the findings of a EU-funded study across nine European regions, the report gives evidence of the resulting biographical and policy dilemmas. Furthermore, it explores if and under what conditions the concept of participation may open new ways of reconciling systemic imperatives and individual needs in the social integration of young people. References. Adapted from the source document.

Integrating a Traditional Minority into a Nordic Society: Elite Discourse on the Finnish Roma

Author: Nordberg, Camilla11 Dept Social Policy, Abo Academi U, Finland camilla.nordberg@abo.fi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61393508?accountid=14925

Abstract: Contemporary citizenship studies have been more concerned with the theory & philosophy of citizenship than with empirical studies. The general objective of this contribution is to broaden the understanding of how notions of citizenship are constructed & re-valued in the social world. The study draws on a qualitative analysis of political elite discourse on Romani issues in the Finnish Parliament from 1989-2003. How issues concerning the Roma are debated elucidates the dilemmas of universal rights & duties within the Nordic welfare model, & the possibilities for cultural diversity within this framework. While the Finnish parliamentary debate accentuated tolerance & the acceptance of difference as strengthening factors for Finnish social citizenship, it was not before the new millennium that the political discourse changed to increasingly stress notions of discrimination & structural inequalities in relation to the incapability to provide for a full an inclusive citizenship as regards the Romani minority. References. Adapted from the source document.

Abstract: This article is based on a detailed inquiry into the circumstances & factors that led adolescents committing homicides. Child Care Alternatives Adopted by Mothers Working Nightshifts

Author: Gokhale, Jayanti11 Faculty Arya Vidya Mandir Education, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374970?accountid=14925

Abstract: Industrialised & urban societies have increasingly drawn women into the labour force as night shift workers. However, while childcare during the day has received considerable attention, childcare at night remains an unexplored area of investigation. The present paper, thus, aims to explore childcare alternatives within & outside the family, when mothers work nightshifts. Given the exploratory nature & survey design of the present study, 250 staff nurses were interviewed with an in depth interview schedule as a tool for investigation. The findings highlight that within the family, husbands are the main caretakers of children at night, other than mothers or mothers-in law. Outside the family, the respondent nurses depended on maids, friends & the community for childcare at night where the quality of childcare remains unsatisfactory. The need for a 24-hour quality childcare service within the community or at the place of employment is emphasised. 2 Tables, 58 References. Adapted from the source document.

Sexuality Research and the Position of the Researcher

Author: Genesh, Indira Maya

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61517702?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article emphasizes that research in sexuality requires many new dimensions -- more creativity & debate, a deeper & more realistic approach to understand the psychology of human personal growth & the anatomy of risk behavior. This will focus attention on the reduction of HIV transmission & the advocacy of a healthy lifestyle. This article addresses three key aspects of sexuality research: locating the nature & practice of sexuality within the accepted norms, finding methods to expand our knowledge of sexuality, & the role of the researcher in translating psycho-sociological theory to the reality of people's lived experiences. The study represents the work of Interventions for Support, Healing & Awareness (IFSHA's) in the field of gender violence, child sexual abuse, sexuality through workshops, counseling & healing & research. It advocates that the researcher develop a language of emotion that fits in with the language of theory. Class & cultural differences have to be taken into account while developing the language of sexuality. Besides, while working with varied target groups, the intervenor has to be able to maintain both neutrality & distance. This calls for a deep understanding of one's own psyche & sexuality. The article suggests that a support system be developed. 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Concept of Sex and Sexual Behaviour among Young Men

Author: Murthy, Nirmala1; Vasan, Akhila1 Foundation Research Health Systems, Bangalore, Karnataka, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61541313?accountid=14925

Abstract: This exploratory study carried out in Bangalore, an urban city in South India & Nagar, a semi-rural town in Western India, looks at the concept of sex & sexual behavior of young men, between the ages of 20 & 24. The article finds many similarities in young men's concept of sex & sexual behavior across locations as well as certain critical differences. Their concepts were dominated by physical sexual acts & excluded emotional content. Both groups sought sexual pleasure without responsibilities -- either of contraception, marriage or of protection against disease. But most information, education & communication (IEC) campaigns stress on aspects that young men consider not pleasurable postponing sex, using condoms, having one sexual partner or practicing non-penetrative sex. Urban respondents' concept seemed somewhat more amenable to safe sex practices because their concept of "real sex" included non-penetrative sexual acts as well as masturbation. But the peri-urban respondents' concept of sex combined multi-partner sex with penetrative sexual acts. The IEC interventions will need to take these differences into account. The article also underscores the importance of using peer groups to reach out to young men &, therefore, the need to understand the nature, composition & dynamics of these peer groups. 2 Tables, 7 Boxes, 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Sexuality and Reproductive Health: A Conceptual Model and Policy Implications

Author: Mahadevan, K; Raju, S Siva; Jayasree, R; Rani, P M Sandhya

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61517676?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study focuses on factors that affect the sexuality of a diverse population. The conceptual model has been formulated based on available literature, interaction with the key players -- behavioral scientists, & peripheral health & family planning workers -- & evaluative studies carried out among sex workers. There is a critical analysis of the direct & indirect relationship of the causal factors with the dependent variables. Several dimensions of sexual behavior have been looked into, especially patterns of premarital & extramarital sex. Independent variables such as physiological & lifestyle variables & their impact on sexual behavior & patterns have been studied. Sexual restraints such as celibacy & chastity & the influence of religion on sexuality have been discussed. The study focuses on familial & marital variables, which exercise restraint on the sexual practices of adolescents & youth. The effect of poverty on prostitution, the influence of mass media on sexuality & the role of modernization, migration & isolation on extramarital sexual practices of married couples have been discussed. Sexual degeneration & rejuvenation have also been discussed. This conceptual model underlines the importance of a holistic study of sexuality, sexual behavior & patterns, so that suitable policies & interventions can be identified to promote permissible & safe sex on the one hand & prevention of HIV/AIDS & sexually transmitted diseases on the other. 4 References. Womanhood and Spirituality: A Journey between Transcendence and Tradition

Author: Nayar, Usha S11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61526020?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article focuses on how women in the past & women in contemporary India have chosen the path of spirituality, & how Indian culture has positioned women vis-a-vis spirituality. It explores female spirituality in a patriarchal paradigm through women like Sita, Meera, Savitri & Kannagi, who faced humiliation & hostility, but who tread the path of single-minded devotion to their principles & thus combined the feminine principle of grace with tenacity, steadfastness of purpose, vision & character. These prototypes inspire & guide the women in India even today & the article illustrates this through contemporary profiles in courage. The article stresses on the fact that in the Hindu pantheon of gods & goddesses, every god has a goddess, & as the form of Ardhanaareeshwara, the fusion of Shiva & Shakti in one body, denotes, male & female principles work together as equal partners in the universe. Other instances reiterate that in ancient India, women occupied a very important position. While analyzing the spirituality of women as a cultural expression, the study underlines the fact that the Hindu version of the Mother image has manifested itself in the vision of Bharat Mata & underlines the fact that spirituality mediates relationships. It heals, provides succor to the emotionally needy, physically abused, & rebuilds fundamental trust in oneself. The modern approach to spirituality, according to this study, defines it as a means of reaching equilibrium or harmony through gender equality. 1 Reference. Adapted from the source document.

Sexual Behaviour and HIV/AIDS Related Implications

Author: Somayajulu, U V11 TNS India, Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61560747?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article is based on the data collected for a study carried out in Andhra Pradesh to understand the sexual behavior of the population sub-groups -- adult males, male students & fishermen & the HIV/AIDS related implications thereof. The study used qualitative techniques such as focus group discussions, & in depth interviews & quantitative structured interviews. The findings of the qualitative study revealed that there was poor awareness of AIDS in rural areas. Most of the respondents were aware of the sexual transmission of AIDS & that the clients of commercial social workers carried high risk of AIDS. On the whole, the target groups covered exhibited high risk sexual behavior. The married respondents reported premarital & extramarital sexual practices & there was little or no practice of safe sex. The major constraints for the use of condoms in these sub-groups were lack of satisfaction & lack of knowledge. The study concludes that there is an urgent need to educate these sub-groups about safe sex practices, consistent use of condoms, preventive care & non-penetrative sex practices. 4 Tables, 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Sexual Behaviour of Adolescent Sex Workers

Author: Krishnakumari, K11 Dept Demography, U Kerala, Thiruvananthapuram, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61517574?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article focuses on adolescent sexual behavior & reasons leading to an early introduction to sexual life. The many types of adolescent sexual behavior, the reasons for adolescents indulging in the sexual act, the use of contraceptives & the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) among them are examined. A baseline survey was conducted in Thiruvananthapuram, Kochi, & Kozhikode in Kerala state, & 825 children were identified to be engaged in the sex trade. The methods used were observation, focus group discussions & interviews with key informants & informal discussions & interviews with experts on adolescent sex workers (ASWs). The study found that a complex interplay of economic, social, cultural, religious, familial, psychological & environmental factors led the children into the sex trade. The children are mainly from a poor economic background. Penury & inharmonious family relations are the main factors that drive children into a life of social depravity. The most exploited ASWs are those who operate in streets & lodges. Most ASWs are at the mercy of caretakers & pimps who abuse the children physically & monetarily. Their awareness of the consequence of pregnancies, abortions, sexual health, STDs, MDS & HIV is very poor. The study recommends that awareness should be created among ASWs regarding their sexual health & among all social strata on issues like gender roles, sexual & domestic violence, communication & negotiation skills. 16 Tables. Adapted from the source document.

Sexual Behaviour of Commercial Sex Workers and Risk in Reproductive Health

Author: Jayasree, R1; Parvathy, K A1 Dept Women's Studies, Sri Padmavathi Mahila U, Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61534598?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article attempts to study the sexual behavior of commercial sex workers & risk in reproductive health including sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) & HIV/AIDS. The data was generated from 200 female sex workers in Tirupati, in Chittoor district of the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. For collection of data, an interview schedule was prepared on the basis of focus group discussions. The profile of the female sex workers included social & demographic variables such as religion, caste, education, age, age at marriage, current marital status, age of entry into the profession, & years in this profession. The respondents were mainly underprivileged women belonging to the lower socioeconomic strata. The reasons for their entry into the profession were mainly poverty, related economic burden, dissolution of marriage, desertion by husband, lack of education, & lack of alternate job opportunities. The study revealed that these women lost a major share of their earnings to brokers/pimps & the police & they faced harassment & sexual exploitation. The article advocates intervention programs that focus on creating awareness about safe sex & condom use, skill training for income-generating activities, & efforts to integrate STD/HIV/AIDS prevention activities with other ongoing activities such as non-formal education, training in economic activities, micro-enterprise, education & care for their children & free legal aid. 6 Tables, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

From Research to Action: Addressing Masculinty and Gender Norms

Author: Verma, Ravi K1; Mahendra, Vaishali S; Pulerwitz, Julie; Barker, Gary T; Van Dam, Johannes; Flessenkaemper, Sabine1 Population Council, Horizons Program, New Delhi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61534535?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study is an intervention research to reduce HIV/AIDS risk behavior among youth by developing & testing a model of behavior change focused on masculinity & the promotion of equitable gender norms among young men in India. The study aims to test the hypothesis that more equitable gender norms will predict less HIV risk. It also aims to develop, test & evaluate the efficacy of a peer- & community-based intervention that addresses masculinity & gender norms among young men & reduces risk behavior. A range of qualitative methods were used to collect data on various aspects of young men's lifestyle, the context of their sexual behavior & associated beliefs & attitudes. Social mapping exercises helped identify key informants. Educational modules based on experiences & tools generated in Brazil by Instituto Promundo were adapted to the Indian situation. Many respondents felt that they were "feeling better" after sharing their personal concerns with the research team members. The study concludes that through the process of owning, sharing & relationship building, young men can be persuaded to change their behavior & acquire gender equitable attitudes. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abstract: This article compared two crisis management models. One of the models -- 'crisis management practice model' is formulated from the practical crisis management experiences of the integrated home care service center during the SARS attack in 2003. It is based on the service delivery in the two most affected areas, the Lower Ngau Tau Kok Estate & the Amoy Garden. The other model is a four-phase 'crisis management conceptual process model' developed by Gonzalez Herrerom & Pratt (1995). The practice model is further consolidated, enriched & refined in view of the Gonzalez Herrerom & Pratt's model to integrate the conceptual & practical aspects. Its applicability can be extended to other crisis caused by outbreak from other infectious diseases. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Tackling Discrimination against Ethnic Minorities: The Case of Post-Colonial Hong Kong

Author: Tang, Kwang-Leung1; Lam, Mong Chow; Ngai, Steven Sek-Yum1 Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61561652?accountid=14925

Abstract: Ethnic & racial minorities living in Asia face widespread racial discrimination. The case of post-colonial Hong Kong is illustrative of racial discrimination encountered by racial groups as well as the effective use of international law in tackling racial discrimination. Wary of business opposition to the introduction of antidiscrimination legislation, the Hong Kong post-colonial government played down the severity of racial discrimination against migrant workers & ethnic minority groups. Social workers, advocates & legal professionals drew upon the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination in their campaigns against racial discrimination. As a result of their activism, & pressure from the United Nations, the post-colonial government is set to introduce a law against racial discrimination in the year 2004. The Convention proves to be an impetus to legislation against racial discrimination. Social workers in Asia have an obligation to advance the rights of ethnic minorities in their daily practice. They have an important role to play in ensuring that their governments comply with international human rights standards. 2 Tables, 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abstract: The rationale for studying clinical environments is based on the assumption that negative environmental factors impinge on clinicians & result in negative client-clinician interaction & outcome. The Causes of Poverty among the Poor Families of Iran

Author: Hafeznia, Mohammad Reza11 Tarbiat Modarres U, Tehran, Iran

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61508479?accountid=14925

Abstract: The present research, which is the first of its kind in Iran, started with the question: 'What things have affected the lives of poor families in particular, & the poverty of Iran in general?' The families who have been studied in this research belong to the low strata of Iranian society, & are protected by the Emdad Imam Khomaini Committee. Information & data have been collected through observation, interviews, questionnaires, & then analyzed by both qualitative & quantitative methods. The results show that the families are poverty stricken due to the influence of individual, social, & environmental factors, which directly or indirectly influence poverty. 8 Tables, 2 Figures, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Education and Ideologies of the Knowledge Economy: Europe and the Politics of Emulation

Author: Peters, Michael A11 Dept Educational Studies, Faculty Education, U Glasgow, Scotland, UK M.Peters@educ.gla.ac.uk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61403420?accountid=14925

Abstract: This is a discussion of a number of interrelated topics that are features of the evolving international Knowledge Economy. Specific topics surveyed include economic policies as performance ideologies, the New Economy as defined by Karel Williams, the Learning Economy as part of the New Economy, the politics of emulation within the context of Britain as an enterprise society, & the ongoing legacy of the Knowledge Economy. Features of the Knowledge Economy as an emerging international system include the mobility of symbolic capital, the economics of abundance, the growth of e-commerce & e-business, knowledge diffusion & innovation, the technological transformation of leading sciences, & the growth of intellectual, human, & social capital. Within this emerging international system, the continued development of technology will require convergent integrated systems, a decline in the concept of territorialism, & the further development of the concept of international intellectual property rights. Figures, References. R. Young

Comparative Analyses of Child and Youth Services in Europe

Author: Seckinger, Mike1; van Santen, Eric; Pluto, Liane1 Deutsches Jugendinstit e.V. Munchen

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61403490?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper contains a comparative evaluation of the reactions of welfare states to the isomorphic pressures emanating from the European Union based on two case studies taken from the Child & Youth Welfare System. In the European Community different concepts of welfare policy exist. In the unification process, every member state has to find answers to the pressure of assimilation invoked by the legislation. The objective of this explorative study is to show that countries can learn from each other in order to improve their own system of social services. References. Adapted from the source document.

Youth Work and Schools in 'Full-Day' Education Systems: International Comparison of Links between Formal and Non-Formal Education

Author: Coelen, Thomas11 Instit Allgemeine & Sozialpadagogik, U Rostock thomas.coelen@uni-rostock.de

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61382285?accountid=14925

Abstract: In this article I will outline the methodological approach of a non-empirical comparative research project which I began in 2003. The project is situated in the context of the research training group "Youth Welfare in Transition" at the universities of Bielefeld & Dortmund, funded by the German Research Council (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft). In that context I have organised an international conference about the modes of cooperation between school & youth work agencies with colleagues from Canada, France, Finland, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Russia, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, the United States, Israel, & Germany. Meeting in Bielefeld from the 9th to the 11th of October 2003, we compared the respective national arrangements of formal & non-formal education (www.uni-bielefeld.de/paedagogik/agn/ag8/Ganztagsbildung. html). This note is based on the scheme of comparison which was given to the contributors in order to help them preparing their presentations. References. Adapted from the source document.

New Security Threats for Humanitarian Aid Workers

Author: Runge, Peter11 VENRO, Bonn p.runge@venro.org

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61403448?accountid=14925

Abstract: Two recent events in Afghanistan & Iraq highlight the current security threats for humanitarian aid workers: Firstly, in July 2004 the humanitarian aid organisation Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) stopped its operations in Afghanistan. This decision followed the targeted killing of five MSF aid workers in Northwestern Afghanistan in June 2004, a brutal act unprecedented in the organisation's history. Afghanistan has become a dangerous place for aid workers: Since March 2003 more than 30 humanitarian aid workers have been killed. Secondly, in September 2004 the so-called "two Simonas," staff members of the Italian non-governmental organization (NGO) "Un ponte per Bagdad" (A Bridge for Baghdad) were abducted in Iraq but, fortunately, released in October 2004. Around 130 foreigners have been seized in Iraq in a wave of abductions that began in April. Most have been released, but around 30 have been killed. Due to the tense security situation in Iraq all the expatriate staff members of Western NGOs have been evacuated in the last months. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=New+Security+Threats+for+Humanitarian+Aid+Workers&amp;author=Runge%2C+Peter&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2004-01-01&amp;spage=233&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

An Insight into the Actual Socio-Economic Situation of Romania

Author: Bela, Szabo11 Babes-Bolyai U, Cluj, Romania eszbe@hotmail.com

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61377641?accountid=14925

Abstract: Approximately half of the population population experience some degree of poverty while 10% live in extreme poverty (according to a report made by the Ministry of Labor, Social Solidarity & Family -- MLSSF). This poverty has grown rapidly over the transition decade. Real wages, already amongst the lowest in Europe (including Central & Eastern Europe) in 1990, have since declined by approximately half. A high proportion of households, mostly those in rural areas, are engaged in informal economic activity such as small-scale farming, & it is estimated that at least one third of household incomes are in kind. High levels of poverty in the country tend to be associated with families of more than three children. The only ethnic group with a markedly distinct level of poverty is the Roma, who collectively experience 3.5 times the average poverty rate. Poverty appears to be up to half as prevalent again in rural areas (where over 45% of the population live) compared to the urban areas, as there is also some regional concentration, often associated with declining of industrial activity. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://GS6DU7GB6H.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=An+Insight+into+the+Actual+Socio-Economic+Situation+of+Romania&amp;author=Bela%2C+Szabo&amp;issn=16138953&amp;title=Social+Work+%26+Society&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2004-01-01&amp;spage=250&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Sexual Harassment of Women at the Workplace: A Socio-Legal Study

Author: Das, Bharat Bhusan1; Padhy, Sunanda1 Dept Law, Berhampur U, Orissa

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61542880?accountid=14925

Abstract: The dimensions of violence against women, especially at the workplace has been concealed for so long that its seriousness had not attracted the attention of the legislators. In spite of growing awareness of the concepts & need for gender justice, there has been, in recent times, an increasing trend of sexual harassment of women at the workplace. In the presence of these inadequacies in the enacted laws for enforcement of basic human rights against sexual harassment in the workplace & as an answer to the growing menace of sexual harassment at the workplace, this paper seek to explore the pervasiveness of the problem & to examine how far the innovative judicial law making progress have contributed in providing protection of women from sexual harassment at the workplace. 11 References. Consanguineous Marriages and Pregnancy Wastage

Author: Sureender, S1; Ramachandran, S; Subbiah, A; Ravishankar, A K1 c/o Ramachandran -- Centre Population Studies, Annamalai U, Tamil Nadu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61433980?accountid=14925

Abstract: In order to investigate the biological disadvantages of marrying within relatives, an effort has been made in this article to examine the relationship between consanguineous marriages & pregnancy wastage. This article has drawn upon NFHS-I & NFHS-2 data. The authors call upon vigomous mass campaigns by state governments to propagate the biological disadvantages of consanguineous marriages. 3 Tables, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

How Do Hong Kong Children React to Maternal I-Messages and Inductive Reasoning?

Author: Cheung, Siu-kau1; Kwok, Sylvia Y C1 Division Social Studies, City U Hong Kong, Kowloon S.K.cheung@cityu.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499103?accountid=14925

Abstract: The study investigated the affective reactions (unhappiness, animosity, & compassion) & behavioral tendencies (antagonistic & conciliatory) of Chinese children to four kinds of maternal communicative behaviors, namely, I-message revealing primary feelings, I-message revealing anger, You-message implying moralizing, & You-message implying criticizing. The sample was composed of 527 Chinese students studying at primary four to form three in Hong Kong. Participants rated their affective reactions & behavioral tendencies to videotaped parent disciplinary messages. Results showed that children are most receptive to mothers' I-messages revealing parental distress, next comes You-messages in the form of inductive reasoning, then I-messages revealing anger whereas they are most antagonistic toward You-messages implying criticizing. Implications for parent education practice are discussed. 2 Tables, 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=How+Do+Hong+Kong+Children+React+to+Maternal+I-Messages+and+Inductive+Reasoning%3F&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2003-07-01&amp;volume=37&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=3&amp;author=Cheung%2C+Siu-kau%3BKwok%2C+Sylvia+Y+C

The Agonising Plight of Orphans of War: A National Survey

Author: Reddy, Suma Narayan11 Ministry Labour & Human Welfare, Asmara, Eritrea

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61537421?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article reports about the important findings of a national survey on disadvantaged orphans in Eritrea, one among the 15 poorest countries of the world. Thousands of children were made orphans owing to the long drawn out war situation this country had been gripped with. The survey is an attempt to unearth the background characteristics of these disadvantaged orphans, the circumstances of parental loss, their living situations, & the various problems encountered by them. The present survey is based on 50,782 disadvantaged orphans where the majority of the orphans were paternal orphans followed by maternal orphans, & a few were complete orphans. They belonged to extremely poor families, & suffered from all kinds of deprivations, including schooling opportunities, medical care, food, & clothing, apart from social & psychological problems of various kinds. A few of them were further affected by disabilities & chronic health problems. Analysis indicated that various factors such as loss of one parent or both, age, availability of adult care & type of care, economic status, schooling opportunity, age at loss of mother, cause of mother's death, & health status seemed to contribute to the vulnerability of these orphans. 3 Tables, 2 Appendixes, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Agonising+Plight+of+Orphans+of+War%3A+A+National+Survey&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2003-07-01&amp;volume=64&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=307&amp;author=Reddy%2C+Suma+Narayan

Community Psychiatry Projects: Some Experiences

Author: Mishra, Arun K1; Mattoo, Surendra K; Babu, Debashish1 Dept Psychiatry, Postgraduate Instit Medical Education & Research, Chandigarh

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61514380?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article is based on the experience gained during 14-15 years of follow-up of patients with psychotic disorders & the experience of organizing a rural de-addiction service. The article highlights the different aspects related to community psychiatry projects under preparatory, intake & follow-up or evaluation phases. It is observed that the achievement of aims & objectives of any community psychiatry project is contingent on full understanding of the community in terms of its needs, & material & non-material resources, & the resources available to the study team. The article also deals, in detail, with both organizational aspects & amount & type of training requirements. The importance of the follow-up or the evaluation phase in the final outcome of any community psychiatry project is highlighted in the background of locating & interviewing strategies used for different segments of the community. Lastly, some practical advice is listed for the beginners. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Bhatti, Ranbir S11 Dept Psychiatry, National Instit Mental Health & Neuro Sciences, Bangalore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61537461?accountid=14925

Abstract: Marriage is an enduring relationship between an adult male & an adult female & is one of the most important stages in the life cycle of a human being. Marriage is like any other living system; therefore, for a good, healthy, & enduring marriage, it has to be nurtured & cared for. This article looks at the marital system, the various aspects that promotes a good marriage, & the factors that affect marital life. The author stresses that marriage counseling or therapy should be based on Indian realities & not on western concepts. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Human Rights Issue in Family Counselling and Advocacy

Author: Kanango, Sukla Deb11 Dept Social Work, Visva Bharati, Sriniketan

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61542937?accountid=14925

Abstract: While the goal of family counseling is to strengthen family units, counselors are often confronted with the issue of violation of human rights whose origin is sometimes the family, & sometimes the external environment. Determination of acts as violation of rights, particularly at the family level, becomes complex because of cultural connotations these have. This article seeks to focus on the various implications the violation of human rights have for counseling families & how advocacy can play a complementary role in this. 8 References. Author: Kashyap, Lina11 Dept Family & Child Welfare, Tat Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61556851?accountid=14925

Abstract: Children are the forgotten victims of a marriage breakdown, in spite of the fact that they too go through extreme trauma. This paper describes parental behavior towards their children during the period of marital tension & during the process of separation &/or divorce. It then highlights the reactions & behavior patterns that children exhibit. Lastly, it discusses the areas of direct intervention with children as well as interventions needed for parents & other social systems for obtaining their cooperation & support in the interest of these children. 4 References. Attitudes toward Partner Abuse and Their Relationship to the Incidence of Partner Abuse among First Generation Korean-Americans

Author: Ahn, Bonnie11 Social Work Program, Southeastern Louisiana U, Hammond

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61563084?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study examined various demographic characteristics, the attitudes toward partner abuse, & the relationship between the attitudes toward partner abuse & the incidence of partner abuse among first-generation Korean Americans. The study employed a correlational explanatory design using a cross-sectional survey technique utilizing a total of 223 Korean immigrant adults currently residing in Baton Rouge, LA, US. A three-part instrument was used for data collection. The use of domestic violence among Korean immigrants was highly prevalent. Korean Americans generally did not approve the use of interpersonal violence against spouses/partners. The relationship between the attitudes toward partner abuse & the incidence of partner abuse as perpetrator was significantly correlated. 3 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Debates and Repositioning of Community Service Orders in Hong Kong

Author: Lo, T Wing11 Dept Applied Social Studies, City U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61455520?accountid=14925

Abstract: Sentencing has various objectives & functions, including reparation, rehabilitation, reintegration, retribution, deterrence, & removal from society, such as incarceration. Community service orders incorporate the first three functions. They assist offenders to make reparation to society for the crimes they have committed, to turn over a new leaf, & to reintegrate into society. In the case of singer Nicholas Tse, the last three functions were demanded by the community. To avoid similar conflicts in the future, to reposition community service orders is inevitable. There is an urgent need to reiterate community service orders as alternatives to imprisonment, & to establish a clear guideline for conversion between service hours & jail days. This approach would minimize conflicts in society, increase sentencing options & community penalties for the court, strike a balance between different penal goals, & strive for a restorative society. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Psychological Well-Being of Newly Arrived and Locally Born Adolescents in Hong Kong: A Comparative Study

Author: Lam, Mong Chow1; Tsoi, Kcon Wah; Chan, Ting Sam1 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong alam@cuhk.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61518814?accountid=14925

Abstract: Reports on a study that explores the psychological health of young new arrivals in Hong Kong from mainland China as compared to students born in Hong Kong. Measures used to assess psychological well-being/psychological symptoms are described, along with two new measures developed specifically for this study: the 19-item Adolescent Self-Positioning Index for measuring adolescents' self-concept, & the Index of Adolescents' Contentment with Hong Kong Living. Data were obtained from a self-reported questionnaire completed by 1,109 Hong Kong-born students aged 12 to 15, & 342 respondents, aged 12-15, who were born in Mainland China but had been residing legally in Hong Kong between one & three years. The findings indicated that the psychological functioning of the new arrivals was generally better than that of locally born youth. These results are inconsistent with the conventional belief that new arrivals have trouble coping with life in Hong Kong & are a source of societal problems. The implications are discussed. 14 References. J. Lindroth

Missing Older Persons with Dementia -- A Hong Kong View

Author: Lai, Claudia K Y1; Chung, Jenny C C; Wong, Thomas K S; Faulkner, Lawrence W; Ng, Louise; Lau, Liam K P1 School Nursing, Faculty Health & Social Sciences, Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61550027?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper reviews missing person incidents that occurred in older persons with dementia reported in local newspapers from 1 January 1999 to 1 May 2002. Ten relevant incidents, two of which happened to the same person, were found in WiseNews, an electronic database of 21 local newspapers. There were four (44%) males & five (56%) females with a mean age of 77 (standard deviation = 5). In six (60%) cases, the missing persons eloped from home & four (40%) outside of home. Nine (90%) of the cases required less than a day to three days to locate the missing person. Six (60%) cases resulted in injuries or death due to falls or traffic accidents. It is not uncommon for dementia patients to get lost. Public awareness & understanding of the phenomenon is very important because the survival of missing persons depends on the implementation of timely & effective search & rescue. This analysis confirms the need for a prospective study to further examine the characteristics of missing older adults & missing incidents, as well as the search strategies adopted by caregivers. 1 Table, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Blighted Spaces and the Politics of Everyday Life

Author: Fairbanks, Robert P, II11 School Social Work, U Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61375041?accountid=14925

Abstract: While a great deal is known about the demographic and historical trends that shape the built environment of American cities, much less is known about the politics of everyday life among residents who continue to live in postindustrial neighborhoods. This study seeks to compensate for the current gaps in academic research by conducting spatially informed ethnography in a North Philadelphia community. Specifically, the study will explore the issue of urban "blight" from a cultural geography perspective, primarily by looking at the ways in which "blighted" spaces shape everyday life, and everyday life in turn shapes and produces the spatial environment. In response to these concerns, my study poses the questions: What would it mean to focus on the ways in which human agency, imagination, and subjectivity are shaped by "blighted" geographical locations? What would it mean to pay ethnographic attention to how subjects in given historical conditions are shaped by "blighted" spaces, as well as how they respond to these spaces in culturally specific ways? By incorporating critical interdisciplinary approaches, this study offers a new way of looking at the various practices of daily life -- including flexible, informal economic activities and post-welfare related "lifestyles" of resistance. Through the lens of spatial ethnography, the study seeks to elucidate the ways in which postindustrial space interacts with culture, poverty and addiction; as well as the ways in which users continue to appropriate postindustrial spaces in culturally meaningful ways under the aegis of the semi-welfare state. References. Adapted from the source document.

Gender -- An Issue for German Welfare Organisation

Author: Lange, Chris

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61380095?accountid=14925

Abstract: During the last months and years the English expression 'gender' has become a well-known word all over Germany, often with the annex 'mainstreaming'. Gender mainstreaming was initiated as a political strategy by the Women's World Conference in Beijing in 1995 and adopted by the European Union in 1997 (COM(96)76 final). It basically means that all actions and initiatives planned have to be tested as to their effects on women and men and should not be taken if they disadvantage either one. But gender is also a category in the discussion about democratic features. Gender democracy means that males and females should be represented equally in the public, political, cultural, social and economic sphere of a society. On this background, this paper traces the gender issue in the field of organizations in the social sector of Germany, in particular the 'welfare organizations'. In this article, 'welfare organizations' is used as a translation of the German word 'Wohlfahrtsverbande'. The reason for this choice is the endeavor to indicate their difference from for instance English 'charitable associations' or French 'associations sociale et sanitaire', because social organizations in the EU-member states differ considerably in regard to their history, function, self-image, financing, political power etc. The terms 'social non-governmental organizations' (NGOs) or 'social nonprofit organizations' (NPOs) are used synonymously. References. Adapted from the source document.

Problem Solving Policing: Views of Citizens and Citizens Expectations in Germany

Author: Weitekamp, Elmar G M; Kerner, Hans-Jurgen; Meier, Ulrike

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61396053?accountid=14925

Abstract: For the last two decades American police experts developed new police philosophies in order to tackle more successful the increasing crime problems. Community Policing tries to improve the cooperation between the population and the police & to increase the trust in the police. A crucial factor is a meaningful cooperation between the police & the citizens. Problem Oriented Policing aims at structural changes in the organisation & the procedures of the police in public. The police have to investigate the hidden problems & conflicts of an individual offence & to create proactive & long term concepts for the social area of conflicts beyond the specific case. It is doubtful whether these philosophies can be implemented in Germany since the legality principle prohibits meaningful, trustworthy relationships between citizens & police officers. However, if one examines the results of surveys on citizens views & expectations towards the police one finds that the majority of the German citizens favour the postulates of community & problem oriented policing. They expect through these measures an improvement of their life situation in the community & the feelings of safety. If one takes these results seriously one has to question if the legality principle is still appropriate. It seems to hamper new, more promising policing styles which seem to improve life of it's citizens & reflect what the citizens want & expect from their police force. Figures, References. Role of Motivation and Cognition on School Performance of High-School Students: A Structural Analysis

Author: Yailagh, Manizheh Sheni11 Dept Education & Psychology, Shahid Chamran U, Ahwaz, Iran

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61451941?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article reports a path analysis examining the causal relationships among goal setting, self-efficacy, learning strategies, & prior performance on final achievement of high school students in Ahwaz, Iran. Questionnaires assessing goal setting (Students' Grade Goals, & Parents' Grade Goals), self-efficacy (Self-Efficacy for Self-Regulated Learning, & Self-Efficacy for Academic Achievement), & learning strategies (Cognitive Strategy Use & Self-Regulation), were administered to 148 randomly selected Iranian high school students. Structural path analysis was employed to examine the relationships among variables. The results show that the paths of self-efficacy with learning strategies & goal setting, the paths of goal setting with prior & final grades, & the path of prior grades with final grades were significant, thus supporting social cognitive theory of motivation. The only non-significant path was between learning strategies & final grades. The probable reasons for this latter finding are discussed in the paper. 2 Tables, 2 Figures, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Role+of+Motivation+and+Cognition+on+School+Performance+of+High-School+Students%3A+A+Structural+Analysis&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2003-01-01&amp;volume=64&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=50&amp;author=Yailagh%2C+Manizheh+Sheni

Role of Family in Detection, Labelling, Motivation, Detoxification and Rehabilitation of Heroin Addicts

Author: Prakash, Braham11 Drug Addiction Center, All India Instit Medical Sciences, New Delhi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61433156?accountid=14925

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to examine the role of family in the detection, labeling, motivation, detoxification, & rehabilitation of heroin addicts. The participants of this study were 100 heroin addicts. Semi-Structured interview Schedule, Diagnostic & Statistical Manual III-R Criteria for Drug dependence, & WHO modified schedule for the assessment of sociodemographic variables were the main tools used in the study. Chi-Square test was used to examine the relationship between independent/dependent variables & response to detoxification & rehabilitation. The results showed that family has significant impact on the success of detoxification & rehabilitation program. The findings of the study strongly recommend the involvement of family in the treatment of heroin addicts. 16 Tables, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Indian Families Adopting Indian Children

Author: Groza, Victor1; Kalyanvala, Roxana; Bharatiya Samaj Seva Kendra Team1 Mandel School Applied Social Sciences, Case Western Reserve U, Cleveland, OH

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61451945?accountid=14925

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to provide research-based information about the experiences of Indian families who adopted Indian children as part of program evaluation of the Bharatiya Samaj Seva Kendra. The project was designed primarily as a program evaluation. Both a mailed survey & face-to-face interviews were used to collect data for this study. This article reports only on the data obtained from the mailed survey. The study reveals that more information is needed to build support & capacity for Indian adoptions. More families need to be recruited to meet the demands for placement of children who cannot reside with their birth families. Community marketing & public relations would strengthen the domestic adoption program. There is a critical need for public education campaigns that present accurate information about adoption, adoptive parents, & adoptees. This must include working with the media to provide this information. 5 Tables, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Empowering Female Sex Workers for AIDS Prevention and Far Beyond: Sonagachi Shows the Way

Author: Nag, Moni11 Dept Anthropology, Columbia U, New York

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61432033?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper describes the process by which the STD/HIV Intervention Programme (popularly known as Sonagachi Project) among female sex workers (FSWs) in a red light area of Kolkata (formerly Calcutta) became a catalyst for the formation of an association of sex workers called Durbar Mahila Samanwaya Committee (DMSC) & how the DMSC, in turn, has become a powerful tool for not only the epidemiological success of the Sonagachi Project, but also a vehicle for the poor & powerless FSWs to gain some control over their own lives & environment. The training & recruitment of a few selected FSWs as Peer Educators of the Project at its beginning was the first important step. The novel experience of working together with the Project physicians & college-graduate women supervisors for the welfare of community FSWs gave the Peer Educators a new sense of pride & self-confidence. They became increasingly convinced that to protect their health & fight against the injustices they suffered from, FSWs had to mobilize themselves & demand their legitimate rights through an association of their own. With the guidance & help from some dedicated Project staff, the Peer Educators took the initiative to form DMSC in 1995. The multifarious activities of the DMSC & of a few other bodies generated by it are described. These activities & their consequences demonstrate that active participation of sex workers in all aspects of a HIV/AIDS intervention project among them as well as their united struggle for the power to protect their health & basic human rights is essential for the projects success & also contributes toward an overall betterment of their life. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

New Agricultural Technology: A Gender Analysis

Author: Sundari, S1; Gowri, V1 Mother Teresa Women's U, Kodaikanal

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61515454?accountid=14925

Abstract: In this study, an attempt is made to assess the impact of the new agricultural technology (NAT) on rural male & female workers in terms of employment, wages, & living conditions in Thiruvaiyaru taluka of Thanjavur district in the state of Tamil Nadu. Based on a sample survey, the study reveals that NAT in paddy cultivation has increased the time spent on different activities & has also generated additional employment for both sexes per season. The NAT has doubled the return on investment on farm, through an increase in the yield per acre. Despite the increase in productivity per acre, cropping pattern is undergoing a change with area under paddy cultivation declining. Money wages have increased, but there is no increase in the real wages of the workers. About 25%-35% of the families bear the brunt of poverty & the incidence of poverty is higher among the landless labor households. To reduce overcrowding of women into agriculture as laborers, women need access to inputs such as education, training, credit, & other agents of growth & change. 11 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Female Labour Force in Punjab: Socioeconomic Profile, Participation Rates and Problems Faced

Author: Sandhu, Pushpinder11 Dept Family Resource Management, Coll Home Science, Panjabi U, Ludhiana

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61530717?accountid=14925

Abstract: All the respondents in this study, female farm laborers, were seasonal workers & did rice transplanting, wheat harvesting, hoeing & sorting out of farm produce, ie, potato picking & vegetable picking on daily wages. They were illiterate & were paid lesser wages than their male counterparts. Most of them were young & belonged to the Rai Sikhs, Baziger, Sansi, & other mixed castes. All the respondents, who had small children, brought them to the work site. Most of them cooked their day's meals before going to the work site. The main problem faced by them was weakness, followed by back pain, early onset of fatigue, & poor diet, which made their 'jobs' difficult to accomplish. Small children, no outside help, inefficient fuel, poor housing, lack of proper water supply, electricity, & lack of required household utensils & other items, were also major constraints. 6 Tables, 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Causes of Marital Breakdown among the Diaspora of Muslims of Indian Origin

Author: Stears, Louw-Haardt1; Khan, Sultan1 Dept Sociology, U Durban-Westville, South Africa

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61548008?accountid=14925

Abstract: The assumption that the institution of marriage is a universal phenomenon suggests that the causes leading to its breakdown are likely to be similar. Despite this similarity, the factors leading to marital breakdown are many, involving a complex interaction of sociological processes leading to disturbed marital relationships. When this happens, the potential for marital breakdown increases. This study suggests that the causes of marital breakdown among a select group of minority South African Indian Muslims in the Durban Metropolitan Area (DMA), is no different than that experienced by married couples elsewhere in the world. The attitudes of 80 respondents toward the causes of marital breakdown are measured using the Likert Scale, & analyzed against the independent variables of age, gender, education, occupation, & income. 1 Table, 49 References. Adapted from the source document.

Rehabilitated Bonded Labourers in Rural Karnataka

Author: Mutharayappa, R11 Instit Economic & Social Change, Bangalore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61540743?accountid=14925

Abstract: The main focus of this study was to examine the nature of bondage of identified & released laborers & whether the rehabilitation had resulted in any increase in their income & improvements in their living conditions. To highlight these dimensions, 387 rehabilitated bonded laborers were interviewed in four districts of Karnataka state. The study finds that most of the ex-bonded laborers had worked with landlords on an annual contract, & all the respondents had received rehabilitation assets from the government. However, nearly 2% of the rehabilitated laborers had relapsed into further bondage because of their poor economic conditions. Though the rehabilitation scheme has improved their living condition, the majority have low incomes & are living below the poverty line. Even today, the major source of income is wage only. Most of them had taken loans either from the banks, cooperative societies, or private sources. The reasons for their indebtedness included expenditures related to marriage, medical treatment, & consumption. 15 Tables, 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Disaster and Mental Health: Psychosocial Interventions

Author: Murthy, R Srinivasa1; Karki, Manju1 National Instit Mental Health & Neuro Sciences, Bangalore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61530548?accountid=14925

Abstract: Worldwide, there is increasing scientific evidence to support the importance of psychosocial interventions on the mental health of disaster victims. The objective of this article is to provide an international perspective on post-disaster mental health & the progress achieved thus far with a special focus on India. The article briefly presents new evidence on the magnitude of mental health following different disasters. It then takes into account an emerging understanding of the biological mechanisms that contribute to mental distress. One such remarkable understanding has been the association between psychosocial factors (life events, life style choices, availability of help in the occurrence) & posttraumatic stress disorder. The main section of the article analyzes different psychosocial interventions that have been used to meet the mental health needs of the population & their effectiveness. The article concludes with the discussion on the relevance of such interventions in the context of India, its implications at different levels, & future recommendations. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499100?accountid=14925

Abstract: The present study discusses the effects of the Marathwada Earthquake on the mental health of widows & married women of the region. Among women, widows are a particularly vulnerable group. Impact of Riots on Children

Author: Dhavale, H S1; Damani, Leena; Kedare, Jahnavi; Jethani, Shanu; Sharma, Sumit1 Dept Psychiatry, B. Y. L. Nair Hospital, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61504139?accountid=14925

Abstract: Community violence has a significant effect on children & adolescents. Early exposure to violence is not without its consequences, which may be wide-ranging from immediate physical loss to emotional & mental trauma. A study was conducted using a specially designed questionnaire that was administered to third & fourth standard students from two municipal schools in a riot-hit area. The results obtained showed high prevalence of distress symptoms among the study group. 2 Boxes, 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Psychosocial Issues of Disasters and the Aftermath: A Second Victimisation

Author: Aubrey, Jane1; Krishnadas, S1 Dept Community Rehabilitation, Oxfam

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61499148?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article presents a summary analysis of the secondary psychosocial stressors & impact in the four-year aftermath of the Marathwada Earthquake Rehabilitation Project. The analysis reflects upon the day-to-day relations & experiences with villagers from the 52 core affected villages from 1993-1997. This paper traces the relationship between the change in psychological perspective, brought from the actual impact of the earthquake, & the ongoing relief & rehabilitation process. It focuses particularly on the impact of the 'rehabilitation package' & identifies eight key stages/milestones of the rehabilitation process & analyzes the specific psychosocial consequences & impact of each stage. Adapted from the source document.

Skimming through the Socioeconomic Losses from an Earthquake: A Case Study from Kachchh

Author: Parikh, Alka11 Unit Rural Studies, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61549506?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article stresses on the prime importance of economic rehabilitation in any rehabilitation process after a disaster. While a food-for-work program should start almost immediately after the relief distributions begin as a method of economic rehabilitation, supporting local economic activities is the best form of rehabilitation. An attempt is made to list some of the economic losses to the families & some social costs to the community. The article also shows how the government tried to come out with policies to help in each of these losses, & observes that the benefits did not always reach the victims. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Towards Rebuilding a Post-Disaster Society: A Case Study of Supercyclone-Affected Coastal Orissa

Author: Pareeda, Pradeep Kumar11 Mody Instit Education & Research, Sikar, Rajasthan

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61548523?accountid=14925

Abstract: The article demonstrates the overwhelming significance of societal conditions & the distribution of damage in the supercyclone-affected coastal Orissa. To understand what happens to a community in disaster, it is necessary to know what happens to families in a disaster situation. Therefore, the article has examined the family conditions that directed the continuity of social life after the catastrophe. Socioeconomic, health, cultural, & psychological factors related to rehabilitation have been given special attention. The study is based on a post-disaster society, which broadly means the rehabilitation & reconstruction process. Rehabilitation does not mean only rebuilding or repairing houses & roads, but giving utmost importance to the region if it is disaster-prone. Thus, it is more than restoring basic infrastructure. The article concludes with a brief on how sociological knowledge should advance in the broad boundaries of disaster research. 5 Tables, 1 Figure, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Problem and Coping Mechanisms of Lambani Female Heads of Family

Author: Kinnal, Anuradha M1; Saroja, K1 Dept Human Development, Rural Home Science Coll, U Agricultural Sciences, Dharwad

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61431927?accountid=14925

Abstract: Lambani female heads, being born in disadvantaged families, face problems in their childhood. These problems were found to be repeated in the lives of their children. Case studies conducted with a life span perspective revealed that unless there was intervention to break this circle of poverty, it not only continued, but it was also likely to increase in the present context of inflation, unemployment, & depletion of natural resources. This paper identifies the focal points at which intervention is needed & specifies the kind of intervention needed, based on the analysis of case studies. 7 Tables, 2 Figures, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Genetic Counselling: Answer to Thalassaemia and Other Genetic Disorders in the Next Millennium

Author: Ghosh, S K; Sinha, Debotosh

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61503846?accountid=14925

Abstract: Over four million people with major congenital disorders, including hundreds of thousands suffering from thalassaemia, are born every year all over the world. The problem is increasing every day & becoming a threat to human existence. It is time to explore ways & means to tackle the problem. Medical treatment is very expensive for thalassaemia & other genetic dysfunctions. Prevention is the ultimate answer & genetic counseling is an answer for the prevention of genetic disorders. This article is an attempt to gloss over the concept of genetic counseling along with an introductory note on thalassaemia. Contemporary relevance of the article in social work, advances in reproductive technology & its relation to genetic counseling, the threat of HIV/AIDS that thalassaemia patients face, whether genetic counseling is to be regulated, & probable genetic services are also some of the concomitant issues briefly highlighted. 1 Figure, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

What Does Demographic Transition Mean to a Population?

Author: Karkal, Malini

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61523375?accountid=14925

Abstract: Demographers swear by demographic transition -- balancing of birth & death rates -- as a solution to all population problems. The state of Kerala was the first one to experience demographic transition. The paper presents the employment, education, marriage, health, & economic situation in Kerala to see if the problems of the Keralites are really solved. The state has low population of people living below the poverty line, but remittances from the family members who have migrated to the Gulf & other parts of India are known to be substantial. 8 Tables, 7 References. Impact of Liberalisation on Women's Health in the Marine Food Export Processing Industry

Author: Rani, S Vanaja11 Dept Sociology, Andhra U, Visakhapatnam, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61486004?accountid=14925

Abstract: Over the last two decades, the employment of women in various nontraditional, export-oriented industries like the marine food export processing industry, has been widespread in the coastal areas of India. It is a lucrative industry where the profit margin is very high. However, the processing workers (who are all women) in these plants work under very unsatisfactory conditions. They stand for more than 12 hours a day & withstand low temperatures without any protective equipment. This paper highlights how employment conditions in this industry have resulted in the poor health of women. 5 Tables, 1 Appendix, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Chinese Counseling Method: Ways to Indigenization

Author: Lee, Wai-Man

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61497689?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper discusses possible ways to develop indigenous counseling theories & techniques that are based on the philosophies & knowledge of Chinese traditional counseling practices. Indigenous theories & techniques should have their own knowledge substance, terminology, & language to describe & understand Chinese behaviors, which are very different from those described in the Western counseling theories. To begin with, this paper will give a brief overview of the rationale for developing indigenous counseling theories & techniques. There is a strong psychosocial component in accord with Chinese philosophies about human & nature in the majority of Chinese classical canons. This psychosocial component has a solid scientific ideology & has voluminous empirical evidence. Based on these materials, this paper suggests that it is possible to develop indigenous counseling approaches that are in accordance with the Chinese worldview & cultural practices. All the new indigenous theories, counseling processes, & specific interventions should reflect the foundation of Chinese thought. They are the fundamental platform on which indigenous counseling approaches are built. 65 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Chinese+Counseling+Method%3A+Ways+to+Indigenization&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2001-07-01&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=35&amp;author=Lee%2C+Wai-Man

Parent Education Programmes in Hong Kong: Are They Effective?

Author: Cheung, Siu-Kau11 Division Social Studies, City U Hong Kong, Kowloon s.k.cheung@cityu.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61537445?accountid=14925

Abstract: The study examined whether participants of parent education programs in Hong Kong experienced gains in parental efficacy, parental empathy, availability of social support, & parenting satisfaction as a result of program attendance. A single-group pre- & postprogram design was adopted. Data from 130 mother participants showed that they had positive gains in the four dimensions. However, mothers aged 40 & above & those with more than one child did not experience higher parenting satisfaction after the program. Results also indicated that among the three instrumental variables, social support was the most crucial determinant of parenting satisfaction. Implications for social work practice were discussed. 4 Tables, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Parent+Education+Programmes+in+Hong+Kong%3A+Are+They+Effective%3F&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2001-07-01&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=85&amp;author=Cheung%2C+Siu-Kau

The Double Whammy Revisited: The Impact of Exposure to Domestic Violence and Being a Victim of Parent to Child Violence

Author: Silverman, Amy1; Gelles, Richard J1 Hennepin County Medical Center, Minneapolis, MN

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61429201?accountid=14925

Abstract: The current study tests the hypothesis that children who both experience & are exposed to domestic violence suffer from a "double whammy" in terms of significant detrimental impacts. The hypothesis is tested by a secondary analysis of data collected for the Second National Family Violence Survey in the US. There was no general support for the "double whammy" hypothesis, though girls, ages 12-17, who were exposed to & experienced violence did experience more behavioral problems. 6 Tables, 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Maternal Employment and Child Abuse

Author: Prasad, B Devi11 Dept Social Work, Andhra U, Visakhapatnam, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482904?accountid=14925

Abstract: The present study, comprising a sample of 133 dual- & 136 single-earner couples, aims at exploring the relationship between mother's employment & violence toward children. The data strongly indicate that nonworking mothers report higher rates of violence. As for working parents, work stress & income are found to be indirectly related to child abuse. Family life education programs & opportunities for learning alternative, nonpunitive ways of managing interpersonal conflict are suggested, among others, to help reduce violence in families. 7 Tables, 1 Appendix, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Journey from Violence to Crime: A Research Study on Domestic Violence

Author: Dave, Anjali1; Solanki, Gopika; Basu, Pekham1 Dept Family & Child Welfare, Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61429218?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper is essentially a summary of an earlier study by the authors (1999) on the Special Cell for Women & Children, a field action project of the Tata Instit of Social Sciences in Mumbai, India. The paper introduces the causation of violence as outlined by the Vienna Summit (UN, 1991). It then enumerates the objectives of the research study, sources of data, issues in data collection, & limitations of the data. Analysis of the Special Cell records permits a profile of the woman approaching the Cell for redressal of their grievances. The noncognizable offenses data is also looked into along with the findings of some other research studies in the area of domestic violence. The language used by women to voice their pain & trauma & how it is interpreted by the police are also discussed. The metaphor of a journey is used, beginning with the violated women approaching the Special Cell to report the violence experienced by her & ending with, ultimately, which voice is recognized & recorded by the police. 3 Tables, 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Elder Abuse: Global Response and Indian Initiatives

Author: Prakash, Indira Jai11 Dept Psychology, Adult & Population Research Centre, Bangalore U, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470020?accountid=14925

Abstract: Described as "granny bashing" in the UK & "parent battering" in the US, elder abuse is yet to be clearly conceptualized in India. The prevalence rate of maltreatment of elders ranges from 4% to 10% of older people surveyed in the West. In India, neglect of the elderly is assumed to be much more prevalent than active abuse. Global response to elder abuse has been in terms of legislative measures, creating public awareness as well as intervention with victims & abusers. In India, recently, some initiatives have been taken to identify this problem, assess its prevalence, & attend to the issue of intervention & prevention. 51 References. Adapted from the source document.

Elder Abuse in the Urban Context

Author: Veedon, Rosamma11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61482948?accountid=14925

Abstract: Elder abuse is a phenomenon that families are finding difficult to handle on their own. This paper is based on analysis of 200+ calls that came to a leading newspaper office in Mumbai, India, over a 2-week period in response to a request by a nongovernmental organization for information about elder abuse. The cases recorded were related to issues connected to one's residence, financial vulnerability, environmental stress, dysfunctional parent-child relationships, misuse of power, cycle of violence, & violation of rights. Efforts required by the individual, the community, & the government to reduce elder abuse are suggested. A training program to develop skills for working in situations of elder abuse is also recommended. 1 Reference. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Wolf, David B11 Florida State U, Tallahassee

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467151?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study examined effects of the maha mantra. The dependent variables included some mental health indicators, namely, verbal aggressiveness, spirituality, life satisfaction, stress, depression, well-being, sattva, rajas, & tamas. Five subjects were measured during a one-week baseline & a four-week intervention-chanting phase. Results were in the direction predicted by Vedic theory. These findings suggest potential for the use of the maha mantra in social work practice in areas such as stress reduction & treatment for depression. 1 Table, 32 References. Understanding Youth Sexuality: A Study of College Students in Mumbai City

Author: Abraham, Leena11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61525307?accountid=14925

Abstract: Students (N = 625 boys & 341 girls, lower-income, ages 16-22) at four Mumbai colleges were surveyed on their construction of sexuality; attitudes toward premarital sexuality; contexts influencing sexual activity; & sexual behaviors surrounding unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted diseases, & human immune deficiency virus. Qualitative data were gathered via observation, focus groups, & interviews to identify general views & trends. Analysis of the qualitative & quantitative data showed that boys were much more sexually knowledgeable, sexually active, & sexually liberal than girls, & had more access to sexual knowledge. In comparison to educators' views that sex education would increase promiscuity, the relationship between knowledge & behavior was not significant. Many myths & misconceptions about sex were found in both sexes, showing that the sex education programs have failed to reach this population. Recommendations for sex education programs are addressed. M. Pflum
