What Support by Kin to Widows?

Author: Aruna, C1; Reddy, T Chandramohan1 c/o Reddy -- Dept Sociology, Bharathia U, Coimbatore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61463072?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper portrays the type of support received by widows in rebuilding their lives through interpersonal relationships & is viewed through the emerging network perspective. It examines the inflow of support form different sources, both kin as well as non-kin. The results show that the network is small, kin-centered, physically proximate & homogeneous in gender & caste. While members of primary kin & friends of the same gender are active in extending emotional support, parents & siblings are the usual supporters in financial domain. Proximate & frequently met ties, irrespective of sectors, dominate services & informational domain. 7 Tables, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Problems of Female Agricultural Labourers in Male and Female Headed Families

Author: Meti, Rajeshwari D1; Krishnaswamy, Saroja; Bhat, A.R.S.1 Dept Human Development, Rural Home Science Coll

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61463276?accountid=14925

Abstract: The present study aims at examining the effect of female headedness on the problems faced by the families of female agricultural laborers, who constituted the poorest among the poor sections in rural areas. The results revealed no significant difference in health problems as all respondents reported to be suffering from ill health. Even though all respondents were found to face insufficiency of food, the female heads were found to face less number of such problems. This was because their family size was small, their children were sent to wage work instead of school & there were few adult dependents in the family. These results imply that in female-headed households, many children were working for wages & deprived of education. Thus, continuing the vicious circle of poverty, arising out of illiteracy to the next generation, female heads were found to be facing significantly more problems than the respondents from the male-headed families, in child care, wage work & during off season/drought. Suggestions are given to reduce these problems of female-headed households. 8 Tables, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Problems+of+Female+Agricultural+Labourers+in+Male+and+Female+Headed+Families&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2001-01-01&amp;volume=62&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=29&amp;author=Meti%2C+Rajeshwari+D%3BKrishnaswamy%2C+Saroja%3BBhat%2C+A.R.S.

Indian Women's Experience of Household Labour: Oppression or Personal Fulfillment

Author: Verma, Suman1; Larson, Reed W1 Dept Child Development, Government Home Science Coll, Chandigarh, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61467006?accountid=14925

Abstract: This article examines the time spent by urban middle-class women in household work with accompanying subjective states. Participants carried beeper watches for one week & reported their time spent in different activities with their subjective states, when signaled at random times. The findings reveal that women spend much more time doing household labor than their husbands, but they experience choice over these activities & do not experience them as aversive. Women often report feeling hurried, but do not feel less in control. Their emotional states neither suggest a high rate of distress, nor a high feeling of self-fulfillment while doing family work. 3 Tables, 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Domestic and Commercial Solid Waste Management

Author: Sundari, S1; Saradha, K K1 Dept Economics, Mother Teresa Women's U, Kodaikanal

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61415819?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study examines the nature, quantity, & method of disposal of domestic & commercial solid waste in the Gobichettipalayam block of Erode district in Tamil Nadu. Based on a sample survey, the study reveals that, in urban areas, there is a large-scale generation of domestic solid waste, as compared to the rural areas. The quantum of solid waste released is directly related to the level of household income, family size, & level of education. On account of poor disposal methods, health problems are more severe in urban, than in rural areas. With regard to commercial waste, it is inferred that industries release large quantities of solid waste, in comparison to other types of activities. The present modes of disposal by the hospitals, hotels, & markets are not safe & satisfactory. The disposal activities of Gobi Municipality lags far behind the total quantity of wastes generated, leaving about 2,322 tons of garbage unattended to every year. Therefore, effective & efficient solid waste management is of paramount importance for the maintenance of health, environmental protection, & natural resource management. 3 Tables, 3 Figures, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Gender Violence, Trauma, and Its Impact on Women's Mental Health

Author: Purewal, Jasjit1; Ganesh, Indira1 Interventions for Support, Healing, & Awareness, New Delhi, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61504287?accountid=14925

Abstract: Psychological trauma arising from gender violence is a significant life situation in Indian women's lives. This dimension of trauma has rarely been studied through mental health research, & remains within the ambit of law reform & enforcement, & prevention. A statistical correlation between trauma & mental illness has not been achieved yet, but a close relationship is extrapolated from significantly high rates of violence & mental illness in specific cases, as the recent study by Interventions For Support Healing & Awareness (1994) has shown. The perceptions & practice of mainstream mental health professionals about gender violence fails to recognize the psychological trauma women are exposed to. Posttraumatic Stress Disorder is a useful diagnosis to be used in the measurement, assessment, & management of trauma from gender violence. It is rarely used in cases of sexual & physical violence. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Women in Disasters and Mental Health

Author: Lohokare, Madhura1; Davar, Bhargavi V1 Jawaharlal Nehru U, New Delhi, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61457995?accountid=14925

Abstract: A "disaster" is a sociological, cultural phenomenon offering much to be studied about the interpersonal as well as group negotiations happening in community life, when the "normal" social equations do not function. Understanding what happens within communities at this time is important in planning interventions, as every individual/social interest group does not always make the same response to disasters. "Disaster management" teams, who operate with a clinical model & diagnostic operators (such as posttraumatic stress disaster) will be enabled further if they address the cultural mindsets & behavioral variety that determines human mental responses to disasters. If this variety is not appreciated, disaster management will end up being reductionist & homogenizing. Against this background of what is "community" & how communities function organically during disasters, we look at gender relations during disaster times. We address the question of the specific ways in which women have dealt with disaster situations. We look at instances where there has been an extreme elevation or extreme depression of women's space. We address the issue of whether women are victims, survivors or perpetrators in the disaster situation. We emphasize that how women are located within the social matrix will determine how they will be affected by the situation. We also emphasize that from the women's point of view, a whole range of experiences (such as violence, poverty, & homelessness) are "beyond the realm of human experience" but are yet to be fully recognized by mental health professionals as "disasters.". 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Analysing Forms of Vulnerability in a Disaster

Author: Parasuraman, S1; Acharya, Niru1 World Commission on Dams, Cape Town, South Africa

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458278?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper attempts to highlight the plurality of vulnerability in an affected community. It aims to suggest that the needs of each affected group differ & should accordingly be addressed. The paper is divided into three sections. The first section briefly reflects on the intertwining of disasters with vulnerability & entitlement systems. The second section draws upon a case study of the earthquake in the Osmanabad & Latur districts of Maharashtra to understand the social processes underway in the aftermath & their impact on different vulnerable groups' entitlement systems, & illustrate from available data, differential vulnerability faced by different groups. The last section generates indicators of vulnerability in a disaster situation. 2 Tables, 1 Appendix, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Culture and the Mental Health Consequences of Trauma

Author: Patel, Vikram11 Instit Psychiatry, London & MacArthur Population Fellow, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61496559?accountid=14925

Abstract: The symptoms of mental disorders are universal as they are experienced by people in all cultures & societies, though the manner in which they are conceptualized & categorized can vary considerably. The cultural influences on mental disorders are especially relevant if research findings are to be implemented in health interventions. If, for example, depression is not viewed as a psychiatric problem, how & where should interventions for depression be delivered? The article reviews the debates on the cross-cultural validity of psychiatric categories & considers its implications for the expression, concepts, & diagnoses of the mental health consequences of trauma such as depression & Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder. The article presents an agenda for research, which aims to generate culturally sensitive findings on the mental health consequences of trauma. 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Disaster and Mental Health: Responses of Mental Health Professionals

Author: Murthy, R Srinivasa11 Dept Mental Health & Substance Dependence, World Health Organisation, Geneva, Switzerland

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458018?accountid=14925

Abstract: Mental health professionals have become a part of the teams of professionals working with disaster-affected populations all over the world. There is strong evidence, based on meta-analysis, to show that disasters increase the prevalence rate of psychopathology by approximately 17%-20% on an average. The involvement of mental health professionals in disasters, in India, has been only in the last 20 years. These professionals have attempted to raise awareness of the impact of disasters on mental health of the affected populations among the general public & policymakers. They also provide direct care to the affected populations; training of primary care doctors, health workers, & volunteers; support to the initiatives of voluntary organizations; & research. Mental health professionals in India face the challenge of building services with limited available community resources. The roles of professionals are different in the different phases of the disaster. Functions include working with the media, evaluation of ongoing programs, & reporting on the findings & advocacy with administrators, voluntary organizations, & funding agencies. These efforts not only can result in services for a large number of the population who would normally not have sought help, but also increase the awareness of the importance of mental health among individuals, communities, & planners. 57 References. Adapted from the source document.

Assessment of Marital Communication and Conflict Resolution: Psychometric Properties of Two Scales

Author: Cheung, Siu-Kau11 Division Social Studies, City U Hong Kong, Kowloon s.k.cheung@cityu.edu.hk

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61484673?accountid=14925

Abstract: Preliminary psychometric data are presented for two Chinese self-report scales that assess marital communication & conflict resolution. These scales were based on English versions but adapted to fit the local cultural context. Results showed that the 11-item Marital Communication Scale & the 8-item Chinese Ineffective Arguing Scale produced scores that were internally consistent. Their correlations with the Kansas Marital Satisfaction Scale were high & significant. There was moderate evidence to support the claim that the scales distinguished between respondents with & without marital problems. 4 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Poverty in Yau-Tsim-Mong District: Concentration of and Solutions to Poverty in an Old Urban District

Author: Wong, Hung

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61484014?accountid=14925

Abstract: A secondary analysis of data from the 1996 Population By-Census is used to explore & explain the geographical concentration of poverty in the old urban area in Hong Kong, especially in the Yau Tsim Mong District. It suggests that the poverty problem in Hong Kong is concentrated in small geographical localities in old urban areas. The characteristic of these small localities is the high ratio of households sharing quarters with other households. More elderly, unmarried male adult & new arrival residents can be found in these poor communities. Moreover, more residents are employed as service workers & construction workers. The study reports that the concentration of poverty is a result of the interaction between the supply & demand of the low-end rental market of private housing & the development & characteristics of community economics. It recommends using community development as a strategy to alleviate poverty in these localities, to prevent ghettoization of old urban areas. 9 Tables, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Poverty+in+Yau-Tsim-Mong+District%3A+Concentration+of+and+Solutions+to+Poverty+in+an+Old+Urban+District&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2000-07-01&amp;volume=34&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=27&amp;author=Wong%2C+Hung

A Study on Differences of High School Students' Idol Worship: Hong Kong and Mainland China

Author: Yu, Xiao Dong; Wong, Sing Wing; Cheung, Chau Kiu

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61533533?accountid=14925

Abstract: The study examined how youths in Hong Kong & mainland People's Republic of China view idols in life; 763 high school students in Hong Kong, Nanjing, Changsha, & Nantong (Tibetan students) participated in the study. They were first required to nominate three most admired people in their lives & rate them based on the degrees to which these people could become their idols & models. Then, they completed a 25-item questionnaire that examined differences in manners, motives, & perceived influence of idol worship. Hong Kong students mostly nominated recreational celebrities in the entertainment & sports industries while mainland Chinese students mostly nominated ideological celebrities in politics & academics. The most admired people nominated by mainland Chinese youths were a lot more diverse than those nominated by the Hong Kong youths. Hong Kong students were more interested in romantic & sexual characteristics, while mainland Chinese students were more interested in personality & ideological characteristics of those whom they admire. The different idol worship cultures in Hong Kong & mainland China may be attributed to a strong commercialization of adolescent idol worship culture in Hong Kong & a strong ideological identification of adolescent idol worship culture in mainland China. 4 Tables, 1 Appendix, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=A+Study+on+Differences+of+High+School+Students%27+Idol+Worship%3A+Hong+Kong+and+Mainland+China&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=2000-07-01&amp;volume=34&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=57&amp;author=Yu%2C+Xiao+Dong%3BWong%2C+Sing+Wing%3BCheung%2C+Chau+Kiu

Prevalence, Organization and Members' Characteristics of Cancer Self-Help Organizations in China

Author: Mok, Bong Ho; Cheung, See Fai; Cheung, Hung

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61484092?accountid=14925

Abstract: Based on a national survey, this paper reports the prevalence of & group/member characteristics of cancer self-help organizations in the People's Republic of China. The findings show these organizations to be categorized as one of two types: one that is totally independent, organized, & managed by members; & the other initiated & led by professionals. Family as Partners in Care: Perspectives from AMEND

Author: Srinivasan, Nirmala

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61663891?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses Indian families who are caregivers of family members affected by mental illness, eg, schizophrenia & other psychiatric disorders. The analysis draws on the experience of the Assoc for Mentally Disabled (AMEND) in Bangalore, a self-help group comprising about 55 families. The practical aspects involved in the caregiving role of Indian families are discussed, suggesting that AMEND offers a unique model to family support groups across the world. The discussion on barriers & gateways to the partnership role of family provides an insight into the cultural dynamics of care in a country like India. 5 References. Mental Disorders in India: An Analysis of Epidemiological Studies

Author: Ganguli, H C11 Dept Psychology, U Delhi, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61661498?accountid=14925

Abstract: Analyzes 15 epidemiological studies on psychiatric morbidity in India & presents prevalence rates for all mental disorders & five specific disorders for all-India & six regions. The national prevalence rates for "all mental disorders" arrived at are: 70.5 (rural), 73 (urban), & 73 (rural & urban) per 1,000 population. Prevalence of schizophrenia, which seems to be the only disorder whose prevalence is consistent across cultures & over time, is 2.5%. Among the Indian states, Uttar Pradesh has the lowest total morbidity & West Bengal has the highest. Urban morbidity in India is 3.5% higher than the rural rate, but these differences are not consistent for different disease categories. Also, unexpected rural-urban differences may be found due to factors such as social networking among city dwellers on the basis of caste, language, & village of origin linkage. In Hindi-speaking north India, mental morbidity among factory workers is 2.5 times that of nonindustrial urban inhabitants & 5 times the rural morbidity. Four large high-risk groups are identified: housewives, the unemployed, the elderly, & rank-&-file factory workers. Suggestions for improving epidemiological studies in India are offered, & attention is drawn to the need for testing socially useful hypotheses. 6 Tables, 48 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Mental+Disorders+in+India%3A+An+Analysis+of+Epidemiological+Studies&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=2000-07-01&amp;volume=61&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=394&amp;author=Ganguli%2C+H+C

Family and the Emergence of Deviant Behavior among Children and Adolescents

Author: Dassi, Archana1; Khan, M Z1 Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61669387?accountid=14925

Abstract: Focuses on a shanty colony in the metropolis of Delhi, India to explore the dynamics of social deviance & social tolerance, using interview data from randomly sampled children & adolescents (N = 100) & their parents (N = 100). Their socioeconomic background is typical of slum dwellers: low education, unsettled occupation, & low income. Interestingly enough, parents' reaction to juvenile antisocial & predelinquent behavior is strong, but it is indifferent insofar as delinquent behavior is concerned. Apparently social milieu & lifestyle in slum neighborhoods is relatively more tolerant of delinquent behavior. It is concluded that parents need to be sensitized on these issues. 2 Tables, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Timing of Marriage and Fertility in Kerala: A Cohort Analysis

Author: Sivakumar, M N11 Dept Population Studies, Bharathiar U, Coimbatore, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61654534?accountid=14925

Abstract: The marriage & fertility histories of 941 women of reproductive age from the Alapuzha district of Kerala are drawn on to examine whether the timing of marriage & fertility have changed over time among ever-married Indian women with respect to their background characteristics, namely, religion, education, place of residence, & working status. The findings show that there is a rising trend in the age at marriage of women, but a declining trend in fertility. Both Hindu & Christian women have higher age at marriage & lower fertility than do Muslim women over the birth cohorts. There is a positive relationship between age at marriage & educational attainment, but a negative relationship between fertility level & educational attainment. Working & rural women have slightly higher age at marriage & lower fertility than do their nonworking & urban counterparts in all birth cohorts, though the difference is only marginal. 3 Tables, 1 Figure, 16 References. Perceptions and Interactions of Vulnerable Groups with the Government Health Services

Author: Babu, B V1; Chhotray, G P; Hazra, R K; Satyanarayana, K1 Epidemiology & Informatics Division, Regional Medical Research Centre, Bhubaneshwar, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61640669?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview & focus group data from 749 respondents (Rs) in Khurda district, Orissa, India, are drawn on to examine the perceptions & interactions of various segments of the community regarding services provided by government health centers. It was found that the visits of health workers to the villages were infrequent, & their services were not satisfactory for many of the Rs. Scheduled Caste & Scheduled Tribe Rs reported discrimination for services at the household level. The majority were not satisfied with the services & reported many drawbacks at health centers. The need for reorientation of the health care delivery system to make it more responsive to the felt needs of the community is discussed. 1 Table, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Predictors of Attitudes to Persons with AIDS among Young Adults in India

Author: Melkote, Srinivas R1; Goswami, Divakar1 Dept Telecommunications, Bowling Green State U, OH

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61623364?accountid=14925

Abstract: At the turn of the 21st century, India was estimated to have about 5 million HIV (human immunodeficiency virus)-infected cases, more than anywhere else in the world. The AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) pandemic presents a challenge for educators, mass media communicators, & social workers. The absence of pharmacological, immunological, & medical interventions puts the spotlight on social & behavioral intervention strategies such as health communication campaigns, though their success is posited to be dependent on the attitudes of the general population toward HIV/AIDS-infected persons. Here, questionnaire data are drawn on to identify predictors of attitudes toward persons with AIDS among young adults (N = 203 students at the U of Hyderabad). Multiple regression analysis reveals that higher scores on knowledge of AIDS transmission through external contact, more positive attitude toward AIDS & safe sex, & higher parental income had a direct (positive) influence on persons with AIDS. Implications for media-based intervention strategies are discussed. 3 Tables, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.soatt

Selection of Favorite Idols and Models among Chinese High School Students: A Comparative Study in Hong Kong and Changsha

Author: Yue, Xiao Dong; Yan, Suet Lai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61446272?accountid=14925

Abstract: This study asked 258 high school students in Hong Kong & Changsha, People's Republic of China, to nominate three most admired people in their lives & rate them on the degrees to which they could become their idols & models. Hong Kong students mostly nominated celebrities in the entertainment & sports industries, while Changsha students mostly nominated celebrities in politics. Hong Kong students were more inclined than Changsha students to nominate family members, friends, & teachers to be their most admired people. A clear distinction was also noted between idols & models. Based on these results, the authors argue that "tri-star idol worship" constitutes the mainstream of idol worship for young people & that a distinction can be made between remote intimacy & immediate intimacy in understanding adolescent idol worship. 3 Tables, 1 Figure, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Description of the Career Path of a "Street Kid" in Hong Kong and Its Implications for Labor Laws, the Education System and Social Service Provision

Author: Newbery, Peter11 Youth Outreach, Shatin, New Territories, Hong Kong newbery@asiaonline.net

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61495970?accountid=14925

Abstract: A review of extant research on marginal & delinquent youths in Hong Kong is used to describe a typical career path for marginal youths. They tend to pass through five stages, from casually running away at age 10 to serving a second prison term at age 18. Age 14 is an important turning point at which young people make crucial decisions that either take them out of this path or fix them more firmly in it. The fact that 14 is a critical age has implications for labor laws, the educational system, & the provision of social services. It is suggested that these findings make it possible to identify the target group & prescribe interventions. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Raising the Age of Criminal Responsibility: Protection or Harm?

Author: Lo, Tit Wing

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61483982?accountid=14925

Abstract: In Hong Kong, the age of criminal responsibility is age 7, one of the lowest in the world. Recently, the Law Reform Commission recommended raising the age to 10; the Committee on Children's Rights even suggested raising it to 14. If the age of criminal responsibility is to be raised, juvenile offenders would no longer be cautioned by the police or prosecuted in the juvenile court, although care or a protection order can be granted to them. This article outlines the major factors affecting juvenile crimes & the current methods in handling juvenile offenders. It also identifies several crucial factors for consideration, in particular, the negative effect of using care or protection orders when no substantial improvement in the juvenile justice system has been made, if the age of criminal responsibility is to be raised. Several recommendations to improve the juvenile justice system are highlighted. 1 Table, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abstract: Examines the front page coverage of women's issues in regional (Karnataka) & national newspapers in India in late 1995, quantifying the data in terms of amount of space, kinds of issues, & number of items. Impact of Women's Supplementary Income on Family's Nutritional Status

Author: Khader, Vijaya11 Post Graduate & Research Center, Coll Home Science, Rajendrangar, Hyderabad, India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61652311?accountid=14925

Abstract: Empirical data collected on 120 families from four villages of Rajendranagar Mandal, Ranga Reddy district, Andhra Pradesh, India, are examined to explore the impact of women's supplementary income on family food & nutrient intake & nutritional status. Results show that expenditure on all food items except cereals & millets was significantly higher in the experimental group (women having supplementary income) than the control group, indicating the input of women's supplementary income. No significant between-group difference was observed in nutritional awareness. Children of the experimental groups were found to be in better nutritional status than children of the control group. 8 Tables, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Some Correlates of Sexual Anxiety

Author: Kumar, Promod

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61670725?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the relationship of gender difference & marital duration with sexual anxiety via scale data from 200 married people, ages 25-45, in Gujarat, India. A 2 x 2 factorial design with two levels of gender difference (male/female) & two levels of marital duration (+/- 10 years) is used. Analysis shows that only the variable of marital duration is associated significantly with sexual anxiety. 2 Tables, 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Limited Democracy and Welfare Ideologies: Hong Kong People's Attitudes towards Financial Assistance

Author: Chan, Chak Kwan11 School Administration & Applied Sciences Macau Polytechnic Instit

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61642542?accountid=14925

Abstract: Analyzes the relationship between democratization & Hong Kong people's welfare attitudes, based on a 1996 survey of 787 households. An "incoherent residual welfare concept" was found: on the one hand, respondents suggested higher rates of assistance for welfare recipients; but on the other hand, many strongly supported the government's residual welfare ideology. This pattern, it is argued, might be caused by limited democracy, a strong administrative-led government, & the failure of political parties to challenge the fundamental values of social welfare in a capitalist society. 5 Tables, 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Stressors and Well-Being of Divorced Women in Hong Kong

Author: Cheung, Siu-Kau11 Division Social Studies City U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61671488?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the prevalence of divorce-related stressors & their impact on the well-being of a cross-sectional sample of 237 separated women in Hong Kong. Interview responses reveal that most had difficulty engaging in divorce litigation, anticipated housing problems, & experienced declines in income. Regression analysis shows that litigation & housing problems are the strongest predictors among the various stressors of mental health problems. 4 Tables, 39 References. Reflection and the Gap between Practice, Education and Research in Nursing

Author: Stark, Sheila1; Stronach, Ian; Cooke, Peggy1 Dept Health Care Studies, Manchester Metropolitan U, Elizabeth Gaskell Site, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61675063?accountid=14925

Abstract: Turbulence naturally results where there are tensions & disjunctions between educational theory & research, on the one hand, & practical application & outcomes, on the other. Explored here is how these tensions, commonly referred to as theory/practice gaps, manifest themselves in nursing practice, education, & research. To smooth the turbulence, reflection is commonly suggested as a solution. It is argued, however, that reflection may only provide, at best, a consolation in times of rapid & disturbing change & cannot spirit away the gap. If the politics of the nursing context are not acknowledged, ultimately, frustration & cynicism among professionals may result, as they find they cannot achieve the ideals that reflective practice promises to bring. 50 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Reflection+and+the+Gap+between+Practice%2C+Education+and+Research+in+Nursing&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Social+Work+and+Practice&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=1999-01-01&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=6&amp;author=Stark%2C+Sheila%3BStronach%2C+Ian%3BCooke%2C+Peggy

Developing a Culturally Sensitive Approach to Promoting Heart Disease Prevention among UK Asians: An Action Research Approach Utilising Reflective Practice

Author: Verma, Chaman11 Fife SIP, Kirkcaldy Community Resource Centre, UK

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61648702?accountid=14925

Abstract: Presents a case study of how a health promotion specialist used the action research model, grounded in reflective practice, to tackle deaths from coronary heart disease among Asian communities in the UK. He was keen to use the national "Look after Yourself" (LAY) program, but felt that this initiative lacked cultural sensitivity to the needs of the Asian community. He therefore used reflective practice within the action research model, his experience as a health promotion specialist, & current theories & models of health promotion to adapt the national program by developing quality standards or guiding principles. The quality of the revised LAY intervention program continued to improve & better meet the health needs of Asians, as the action research cycle was continued. The modified program benefited 102 Asian men & women by reducing the risk of their developing heart disease. It is argued that practitioners from other disciplines could use a similar approach when there is some uncertainty about meeting the needs of clients. 1 Figure, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Developing+a+Culturally+Sensitive+Approach+to+Promoting+Heart+Disease+Prevention+among+UK+Asians%3A+An+Action+Research+Approach+Utilising+Reflective+Practice&amp;title=Journal+of+Practice+Teaching+in+Social+Work+and+Practice&amp;issn=14606690&amp;date=1999-01-01&amp;volume=2&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=37&amp;author=Verma%2C+Chaman

The Family's Influence on Religious Orientation of Women in Malaysia

Author: Ali, Mubarak11 U Sains Malaysia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61442128?accountid=14925

Abstract: Uses scale data to analyze the family's influence on the religious orientation of 276 Malay, 225 Chinese, & 249 Indian women in Malaysia. Results revealed three family-related variables -- expressiveness, conflict, & moral-religious emphasis -- as having major influences on religious orientation. Chinese respondents indicated extrinsic religious orientations, while Malays & Indians revealed intrinsic religious orientations. Implications of these observations for social work are discussed. 3 Tables, 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Longitudinal Case Study on the Deviation Process of Youth At Risk

Author: Wong, S W

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61446265?accountid=14925

Abstract: To understand the factors that lead to the onset & continuation of delinquency, a longitudinal case study, with data collected at five points of time, was launched. Nineteen outreach clients, who have exhibited some sorts of deviant behavior, were selected as research targets. The results reveal the interactive effects of social bonds, peer influence, negative labeling, & delinquent behavior. The study also identifies four different delinquent typologies based on the client's motivation & path to deviation. Based on the analysis, the investigator suggests possible solutions for helping youths at risk. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Help-Seeking Patterns of Chinese Parents in Hong Kong

Author: Shek, Daniel T L11 Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin New Territories

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448798?accountid=14925

Abstract: Help-seeking attitudes, knowledge, & behavior of 751 Chinese parents, ages 30-60, were examined via interviews conducted at the public housing estates in Hong Kong. Roughly 20% of the parents negatively viewed help-seeking, & 56.6% of them seldom sought help when needed. Most of them had weak understanding of family services, & they rarely participated in family-life education programs. Interrelationships among help-seeking attitudes, knowledge, & behavior were not strong. 2 Tables, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Some Findings about How AIDS Patients in Hong Kong React to Their Illness

Author: Tam, Jane11 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61528615?accountid=14925

Abstract: A total of 50 AIDS patients (including 10 expatriates) were interviewed during the period from the summer of 1993 to the end of 1996. However, interview data on the expatriates were excluded in order to focus the study on the Hong Kong context. Among the 40 local Hong Kong Chinese interviewed, 5 were female & 35 male. Their age ranged from early teens to mid-sixties, with most (85%) of them coming from the 21-40 age group. The causes of infection varied: six of them became infected due to homosexual contact, 21 due to heterosexual relationship (including the 3 women who were infected by their husbands), 5 via blood transfusion due to hemophilia/operation, & 8 were unknown. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Abstract: Discusses the impact of changes over the last 10 years within social work organizations & social work education in GB on practice learning & teaching. Colonial Labour Conditions in the Plantation Industry: The Case of Criminal Tribes on the Tea Estates of Annamalai Hills

Author: Ramachandran, C1; Maya, R K1 Dept Humanities & Social Sciences Indian Instit Technology, Chennai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61515927?accountid=14925

Abstract: Analyzes the historical causes & repercussions of the Sept 1916 strike by the indigenous tea plantation workers in the Annamalai Hills of colonial India, elucidating the broader political & economic forces that shaped the spontaneous insurrection. Focus is on how the imposition of laws such as the Criminal Tribes Act of 1911 enabled the colonial state & plantation owners to recruit & control cheap labor. The development of the tea industry in the area during the turn of the century is examined to underline the changing economic situation, the growing need for tea labor, & the impacts of WWI. The Criminal Tribes Act allowed the state to designate entire ethnic groups as criminal & subject to several exploitative labor controls. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Status of Women in Capitalist Societies

Author: Yeung, Agnes; Yu, Kam-Wai

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61484027?accountid=14925

Abstract: In 1995, the Division of Social Studies in the City U of Hong Kong interviewed 235 women in managerial positions with the aim of exploring their status & roles in the family & workplace. The findings are reported here. The main argument is that women from different social classes have different experiences in developing their careers & looking after their families. It is possible for some women to achieve a high status at work &, at the same time, enjoy a greater share of power at home in a capitalist society. However, this should not be taken as an indication that the majority of women in Hong Kong could enhance their social status solely through participation in the labor market. There are some structural factors in the capitalist system that require further exploration. 11 Tables, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Status+of+Women+in+Capitalist+Societies&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1997-07-01&amp;volume=31&amp;issue=1-2&amp;spage=49&amp;author=Yeung%2C+Agnes%3BYu%2C+Kam-Wai

Combating Violence against Women: Hindsight from a Decade of News Reports on Family Violence in Hong Kong

Author: Chung, Chan Yuk11 Dept Applied Social Studies, Hong Kong Polytechnic U

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61484595?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper is based on a research project, "A Documentation of Newspaper Reports on Family Violence in Hong Kong in the Past Decade," carried out between 1992 & 1994. Based on a content analysis of news coverage of domestic violence in a local Chinese newspaper between 1 Jan 1981 & 31 Dec 1990, the author identified a number of findings in this study. First, it was found that 80% (N = 91) of the victims of spousal abuse were women. Second, news coverage on violence against women in conjugal relationships were skewed with reports of violence of a physical nature (94%). Third, the reports represented only the most serious cases &, therefore, only the tip of the iceberg insofar as violence against women is concerned. This is because (1) a large number of these cases involved the use of deadly weapons such as choppers & knives; (2) all cases required police intervention; & (3) 93% of nonfatal cases required immediate medical attention. Lastly, the present study found that the discourse tended to view violence against women as a private, rather than public, issue. On the basis of these findings, the paper discusses the implications for social work practice. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Uncovering the Etiological Assumptions of the Response to Juvenile Delinquency in Hong Kong

Author: Wong, Dennis S.-W.11 Dept Applied Social Studies, City U Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61511216?accountid=14925

Abstract: This paper highlights the profiles of juvenile crime & the responses to juvenile delinquency in Hong Kong in the last few decades. With the aid of criminological literature & policy documents, the author uncovers the underlying etiological assumptions of delinquency. The assumptions are biased in favor of the functionalist perspective. Until the publication of a recent study on the social causes of delinquency, interactionist theories seemed to have no part in explaining crime in Hong Kong. The author argues that under the dominance of the positive noninterventionist political culture in Hong Kong, academics are prone to be conservative. This paper suggests that future research should focus on testing interactional effects among the social variables derived from the social control, strain, labeling, & differential association theories. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Revival of the Devadasi System

Author: Sahoo, B B11 Indian Statistical Instit, New Delhi

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61458949?accountid=14925

Abstract: Condemns the devadasi system, which recruits young girls for lifelong service in a temple, & its recent revival in southern India. Events at the Jagannath Temple at Puri, where its administration has relaxed the rules governing devadasi, are recounted. The history of the devadasi system is recalled, & changes in the recruitment & rewarding of the women who served are discussed. It is argued that this ancient practice that once provided spiritual satisfaction, respect, & a decent income has turned into a system of sexual slavery, where women are mistreated, exploited, & forced into prostitution to survive. This is linked to broader issues of gender inequality & disempowerment of women in Indian society & discriminatory practices such as dowries & purdah. The devadasi system should be declared a violation of women's human rights & eradicated through socioeconomic changes among the poor, uneducated, & untouchables; an identification & rehabilitation program is advocated. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Human Ecological Stress and Demographic Decline: A Case of Negritos of Andamans

Author: Kailash11 Unit Urban Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Mumbai 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61533840?accountid=14925

Abstract: Links the threatened survival of the Indian Negritos of the Andaman Islands to British colonial policies. A history of British contact & the harmful effects of policies aimed at controlling & "civilizing" Negritos is presented. Policies revolved around separating the Negritos from their natural environment & imposing Western customs, foods, & religion on a people traditionally closely tied to a jungle ecosystem that supported them. The resulting demographic decline is analyzed, & population data are presented. Changes brought on after Indian independence, eg, immigration, growth of disease from heavy deforestation, & fertility & mortality effects of depopulation, are discussed. Welfare & rehabilitation efforts, beginning with the Colonization Plan of 1950, are found to be inadequate. By bringing disease, taking land, & forcing civilization, the British deprived the Negritos of their identity & livelihood, leaving a legacy that could eliminate them completely. 9 Tables, 1 Figure, 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Human+Ecological+Stress+and+Demographic+Decline%3A+A+Case+of+Negritos+of+Andamans&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1997-07-01&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=3&amp;spage=382&amp;author=Kailash

Achievement Motivation Level of Primary School Children: Anxiety and Academic Achievement

Author: Mishra, K N11 Regional Coll Education, Bhubaneshwar

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61448153?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores the effect of achievement motivation on anxiety & academic achievement for 183 primary school children in classes III-V in India, drawing on scale data. Children, grouped by high & low achievement motivation on the basis of median split on achievement motivation score, were matched on motivational levels. Findings showed that children with high n-ach performed better academically & possessed a significantly low level of test anxiety. However, they failed to differ in general anxiety. A disordinal interaction was observed between education & achievement motivation level on test anxiety. Further, academic achievement of class III children was negatively correlated with general test anxiety. Low achievement motivation children of class V showed significant & positive correlation between academic achievement & test anxiety. 4 Tables, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Structure and Marriage Patterns among Tribals in Karnataka

Author: Mutharayappa, R11 Population Research Centre, Bangalore India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61486013?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes the social structure & marriage patterns among the Jenu Kurubas & Kadu Kurubas of Karnataka, India, drawing on structured interviews with 1,133 women. It is found that, while Kadu Kurubas structure themselves according to divisions & clans, the Jenu Kurubas prefer to speak of gods and groups. Further, among the Kadu Kurubas, members of the community called patri-sibs help to regulate marital relations, while Jenu Kuruba young people are allowed to marry anyone except immediate blood relations. In both tribes, elders exercise very little control over brides & grooms in the marriage ceremony, as marriages are sometimes arranged by parents & at other times initated by elopement. Both consanguineous & nonconsanguineous marriages are found among both tribes. Although these two tribes live in similar ecological regions, it is found that they differ in cultural behavior. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Structure+and+Marriage+Patterns+among+Tribals+in+Karnataka&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1996-10-01&amp;volume=57&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=522&amp;author=Mutharayappa%2C+R

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Structure+and+Marriage+Patterns+among+Tribals+in+Karnataka&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1996-10-01&amp;volume=57&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=522&amp;author=Mutharayappa%2C+R

Emergence of Slums: A Case Study of Thane Urban Agglomeration

Author: Nangia, Parveen1; Gupta, Kamla; Tiwari, N C1 Dept Migration & Urban Studies International Instit Population Sciences, Govandi Station Rd Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61587830?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes the prevalence of urban slums in Thane, India, & the tolerance policy of the government, drawing on a 1991-1993 survey of 176 slums. Two types of slums are depicted: (1) those that consist of settlements where living conditions are very bad because of a variety of conditions, eg, the old age of buildings, materials used to construct the buildings, & lack of basic amenities; & (2) those that function as squatter settlements in which people live in poorly made temporary huts. Proximity to main roads & workplaces & the availability of water are found to be important locational indicators. Squatters prefer to squat on government land, where eviction is less common, & many of these newer slums have been located in the forest. A typical slum is a labyrinth of haphazardly strewn, electrified, single-story huts complete with small stores & schools. The development level of a slum is generally predicted by its duration of existence, the ownership of land on which it is located, & the place of origin of the first settlers. An environmental improvement scheme is slated to provide water, plumbing, & electrical amenities. Recommendations for improving conditions are listed. 2 Tables, 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Are Educated Unemployed Youth in India Externally Oriented?

Author: Singh, Lal Bahadur1; Singh, Arun Kumar; Singh, Arvind Kumar1 Dept Psychology T M Bhagalpur U, 812007 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61488048?accountid=14925

Abstract: Investigates the degree of internal & external orientation at macro- & microlevels in 400 educated youths in India, ages 27-32, equally divided into professional unemployed, nonprofessional unemployed, professional employed, & nonprofessional employed, drawing on scale data. Statistical comparison revealed that both professional groups & the nonprofessionally educated unemployed youth were relatively less internally oriented & more externally directed than the nonprofessional employed group. Findings indicated that all groups had a tendency to score higher on measures of external control. Implications for analyzing the impact of occupational status on psychological well-being are briefly noted. 3 Tables, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Unemployment as a Stressor: Role of Socio-Psychological Factors

Author: Chakrapani, C11 C. D. Deshmukh IMPART Council Social Development, Hyderabad India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61490501?accountid=14925

Abstract: Several approaches to stress are discussed, & the transactional approach is used to explain the stressor character of unemployment among 312 educated unemployed youths who answered questionnaires comprising scales in Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh, India. Sociopsychological factors affecting the stressor character of unemployment are discussed. The social support systems are seen as potential stress moderators. Family support & religion emerged as the two most important resources in altering the stressor character of unemployment. 3 Tables, 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Mental Hospital and Colonialism in India

Author: Mondal, Parthasarathi11 Centre Social Medicine & Community Health Jawaharlal Nehru U, New Delhi 110067 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61490525?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues that the development of mental-health-oriented psychiatry in India is closely associated with British social control in colonial India. The spread of mental hospitals is demonstrated to be commensurate with the spread of colonialism in that country, with the establishment of the first such facility in Calcutta in 1787. Another period of growth occurred in the mid-19th century as the British sought to extend their control through eastern India. As with any product of an alien society, the mental hospital introduced a set of disciplinarian, medical, & psychiatric processes. In this way, their proliferation & function was closely associated with that of British prison facilities throughout India. In postcolonial India, these processes continue but they are more complex & insidious. It is argued that, in postcolonial India, the Western-influenced development of community psychiatry continues the practice of controlling the masses left in turmoil by the exploitative policies of the ruling class. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+Mental+Hospital+and+Colonialism+in+India&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1996-10-01&amp;volume=57&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=591&amp;author=Mondal%2C+Parthasarathi

Role Conflicts and Tensions of Women Police in Criminal Justice Administration

Author: Krishnamurthi, Latha11 Dept Humanities Priyadarshini Coll Engineering & Architecture, Nagpur India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61505241?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview data from 105 Indian women police officers selected proportionally by regional area & job category are used to investigate problems they face in the criminal justice administration regarding tensions involved in performing a diverse set of roles connected to both traditional & nontraditional society. Ss were found to experience the least amount of role conflict when performing traditional female roles; however, they experienced much higher levels of conflict & stress in their job roles, attributed to the duties allotted to them rather than to relationships to & attitudes of their male counterparts. Most prominent areas of stress included time management, energy, & resources. The time factor is found to correlate with the traditional roles; it is a common resource to both traditional & job-related roles. 5 Tables, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Child Sexual Abuse: Need for Law Reforms

Author: Bajpai, Asha11 Unit Women's Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61602655?accountid=14925

Abstract: Statistical data, 1990-1994, indicate that ordinary criminal laws against child sexual abuse in India are inadequate to protect children, requiring special legislation. Secondary survey data from 348 girls reveal that sexual abuse takes many forms, eg, molestation/sexual overtures & rape. Moreover, over 40,000 children are forced into the flesh trade catering to international tourists; a 1991 case study illustrates. International legal trends are reviewed, eg, chemical castration of sex offenders in CA. At present, no such comprehensive laws or policies exist in India, with several different statutes dealing with such crimes as rape, "unnatural" sexual practices, molestation, exploitation, & indecent representation. Further, the common forms of child sexual abuses do not even fall under the legal definition of rape. A change in Indian attitudes, which presently place a premium on virginity & therefore tend to overlook the plight of sexually abused children, & vigorous advocacy of legal reform on the part of the media & nongovernmental organizations are called for. 2 Tables, 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Look at the Illness Trajectory of AIDS Patients in Hong Kong

Author: Tam, Jane S C11 Dept Applied Social Studies Hong Kong Polytechnic U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61542249?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview & in-depth case study data gathered 1993/94 from 50 acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) patients in Hong Kong are used to examine their adjustment to the illness. The concept of trajectory is used to delineate four illness phases: human immunodeficiency virus infection onset, appearance of AIDS-related complexes, full-blown situation, & dying. In each phase, findings are discussed in terms of socioeconomic, psychological, & existential disruptions. It is concluded that AIDS patients write their own unique illness trajectories. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Wong, Donna Kam-pun11 Dept Social Work U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61473552?accountid=14925

Abstract: Argues that the well-being of housewives is closely tied to the meaning & satisfaction they derive from their social role, drawing on 1990 questionnaire data from 250 housewives in Tuen Mun, Hong Kong. A Study of the Attitudes of Secondary School Students toward Marriage in Hong Kong

Author: Yeung, Caroline S T1; Kwong, Wai-man1 Dept Applied Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61518479?accountid=14925

Abstract: Investigates secondary school students' attitudes toward marriage in Hong Kong, drawing on 1994 self-administered questionnaire data from 952 secondary school students. Findings revealed emerging trends of divorce, extramarital affairs, early dating, & premarital sex. Further, students perceived a multifaceted change occurring in the belief-value system, including declining notions of marriage as a life-long commitment & increased preferences for nonmarried cohabitation. Despite positive conceptions of parental marriages & beliefs in their own future marriages, students showed preference for later marriages with less emphasis on procreation. Though overall gender differences were evident, females proved more traditional toward social standing, yet more progressive in attitudes on egalitarian family practices & equal sexual roles. D. Bajo

Metropolitan Crime: Delhi and Houston

Author: Sindwani, K L1; Chowdhry, D Paul1 Dept Sociology Southern Texas U, Houston 77004

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61485095?accountid=14925

Abstract: Compares the 1991 rates of homicide, rape, robbery, burglary & larceny/theft in Houston, TX, & Delhi, India, based on published government reports. Perceptions of crime & its related aspects of 100 randomly selected residents of each city are also compared, drawing on questionnaire data. Four high officials in the criminal justice system of both cities were interviewed, & their perception of crime & its related aspects are discussed, compared with those of adult citizens, judges, & police officers. 7 Tables, 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Support and Suicide Attempts

Author: K.S., Latha1; D'Souza, Philomena; Bhat, Shripathy M1 Dept Psychiatry Kasturba Hospital, Manipal Indonesia

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61489542?accountid=14925

Abstract: Longitudinal semistructured interview data are drawn on to investigate stressful life events, social support patterns, & suicide attempt characteristics of 73 suicide attempters treated 1988-1991 in the emergency ward & at a psychiatric service of a general hospital in India. Responses were compared to those of 58 depressives at the same hospital & 60 members of the general population matched for age & sex. Specific features of the quantity & quality of social relationships leading to help & support are examined. The crucial differences between suicide attempters, depressives, & the general population are in the number of friends with whom the Ss had regular contact or fulfilled other support functions. Implications for suicide prevention planning strategies are discussed. 3 Tables, 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Child Abuse: A Systems Analysis

Author: Kewalramani, G S11 Dept Sociology U Rajasthan, Jaipur 302004 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61513976?accountid=14925

Abstract: Based on a survey of 167 child abuse cases in Rajasthan, India, the concept, magnitude, & types of child abuse & victims' problems are examined. In assessing the etiological factors in physical, sexual, & emotional abuse of children, examined is a model that emphasizes the interrelationship of four factors: family environment, structural stresses, parent characteristics, & subcultural learning. Two important factors in the causative analysis are described: (1) socialization practices & child development patterns that explain child abuse in terms of the degree to which a parent uses negative, inappropriate control strategies; & (2) stresses that give rise to maladaptive behavior. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Conversion of Upper Castes into Lower Castes: A Process of Asprashyeekaran (Encompassing Untouchability)

Author: Lal, Shyam11 Dept Sociology U Rajasthan, Jaipur 302004 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61487689?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses the nature, underlying motivations, & implications of Asprashyeekaran (AK): the downward caste mobility of Indian groups & individuals. AK is defined as a process whereby high- or low-caste individuals or tribes accept the membership of an untouchable caste (Bhangi, Chamar, Bhalahi, Mahar, Bairwa) & thereby lower their social & ritual position. Previous caste identity is lost over 1-2 generations & the customs, beliefs, & ways of life of the untouchable caste are adopted. Four models of this process are considered: sociocultural, religion-ritual, historicopolitical, & economic. Although AK may be forced on people due to violation of caste social norms, irregular conduct, punishment for crimes, or illicit relations with a lower-caste woman, it has been deliberately sought in some instances. As a result of strict association of castes with types of employment & economic upheaval in recent decades, certain high-caste members have been exposed to poverty & have sought membership in lower castes to secure reservation benefits &/or government services. 1 Table, 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Conversion+of+Upper+Castes+into+Lower+Castes%3A+A+Process+of+Asprashyeekaran+%28Encompassing+Untouchability%29&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1996-04-01&amp;volume=57&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=163&amp;author=Lal%2C+Shyam

Enforcement of Mahr by Muslim Women: A Case for Reconsideration

Author: Wani, M Afzal11 Faculty Law U Kashmir, Hazratbal Srinagar 190006 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61488388?accountid=14925

Abstract: The concept of mahr, a Muslim law requiring a husband to grant a gift of property to his wife at marriage, is discussed in a review of Islamic literature & legal decisions. Although mahr is an accepted & vital symbol of female property & authority rights, it is argued that this law has been neglected & misused in recent decades. The courts have advocated three potential schemes for the payment of mahr: at the time of marriage, at the time of a specified event or duration, or gradual payment of deferred portions. Although Muslim scholars continue to debate this point, the courts have also limited women's rights, as outlined in the Koran, to seek divorce &/or refuse the company of their partner due to failed or tardy payment of mahr. Drawing on the Koran & other Muslim literature, it is argued that the courts have violated the Islamic spirit of mahr. A more functional & clearly defined institution of mahr is needed to advance the rights & status of women in Islamic nations; strategies for doing so are outlined. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Enforcement+of+Mahr+by+Muslim+Women%3A+A+Case+for+Reconsideration&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1996-04-01&amp;volume=57&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=295&amp;author=Wani%2C+M+Afzal

Working Status and Health: A Study of Middle-Class Calcutta Women

Author: Mukhopadhyay, Susmita11 Indian Statistical Instit, Calcutta 700035

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61490116?accountid=14925

Abstract: The relationship between working status & measures of mental & physical health was examined in a survey of approximately 200 middle-class working & nonworking mothers (WMs & NWMs) from Calcutta, India. Recent research & theory have suggested that the dual roles of worker & mother may cause identity conflict & mental & physical problems, but the present findings do not support this claim &, instead, evidence an overall similarity between WMs & NWMs. Hired help performed the majority of domestic duties for both groups. WMs did experience a statistically significantly greater frequency of nonchronic illnesses than NWMs. In terms of mental health, WMs evidenced greater mental well-being & higher scores of subjective family cohesion. It is concluded that the dual obligations of work & family life are either nonstressful for WMs, or they successfully cope with conflicting demands. 8 Tables, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Examine the Occupational Therapy Stations in Guangzhou with Reference to the Shared Care Approach

Author: Yu, Sam Wai-kam1; Chau, Ruby Chui-man1 Division Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61444403?accountid=14925

Abstract: Explores occupational therapy stations in Guangzhou, People's Republic of China, highlighting the shared care approach & drawing on interviews with trainers & discussions with officials in Dong Shan District. It is argued that occupational therapy stations share common points with the shared care approach in reinforcing the family as the main care provider & emphasizing community intersectoral cooperation in helping people with learning difficulties. However, they fail to reduce family caring costs & responsibilities. This is because existing relationships between participants in the caregiving process are too hierarchical to support a client-centered & user-friendly service. 9 References. Relationship between Achievement Motivation and Level of Aspiration as a Function of Social Class Variables

Author: Nayak, Bidyut Prava11 Regional Coll Education, Bhubaneshwar Orissa India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61538267?accountid=14925

Abstract: The relationship between achievement motivation & level of aspiration of tribal vs nontribal children (N = 200 each group) in Koraput, India, was examined using the Oriya adaptation of n-Ach Scale & the level of aspiration test. Results revealed a negligible relationship between achievement motivation & level of aspiration in the case of nontribal children; but in the case of tribal children, need achievement for failure was negatively related to the attainment discrepancy scores. 1 Table, 14 References. The Emerging Rural Youth: A Study of Their Changing Values towards Marriage

Author: Uplaonkar, Ambarao T11 Sharanabasaveshwar Coll Arts, Gulbarga India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61524969?accountid=14925

Abstract: Assesses the effects of modernization & urbanization in changing the attitudes of Indian youth toward marriage, which had traditionally been arranged by parents at a young age. A sample of 1,500 rural youth from 7 villages in Gulbarga District, Karnataka, were interviewed over 3 months, revealing that the attitude of male, but not female, youth toward the ideal age at marriage & arranged marriage had changed considerably. It is concluded that modernizing forces in India have not adequately reached female youth, & that there is a need for greater involvement of young women in democratic processes. 4 Tables, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

From Penal Settlement to Capital Town: Human Ecological Aspect of the Rise and Growth of Port Blair

Author: Kailash11 Unit Urban Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61438080?accountid=14925

Abstract: Examines the effects of unabated population pressure from the Indian mainland on the human ecology & environment of Port Blair, the capital of the Andaman islands. At the time that Port Blair was established as a penal settlement, the region was covered by lush forests. It has now become a multicultural center of urban trade & transport, whose growth is marginalizing the native island inhabitants & threatening their remaining land. The developmental pursuits of the islands are far behind those of other parts of India, & urban facilities are deteriorating due to the heavy population pressure. It is recommended that: controls be placed on continued population growth, island administration be decentralized, & more emphasis be placed on developmental activities that rely on local resources. 2 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Patient Satisfaction in Public Health System -- A Case Study

Author: Sharma, R D1; Chahal, Hardeep1 Dept Commerce U Jammu, 180004 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61590304?accountid=14925

Abstract: The degree of patient satisfaction with the Indian public health system is measured using Likert scale data from 25% of the outpatients & inpatients served by the governmental hospital 1990/91. Variables included doctors, nurses, medical assistants, management, sanitation, cleanliness, & other supportive medical facilities; the extent to which sociodemographic factors influence patient satisfaction was assessed. Results reveal general dissatisfaction with the health care system. Females are more satisfied than males, & those with lower educational status & lower income are more satisfied with health care services. 6 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Study of Familial and Non-Familial Influences in Aggression among Adolescents

Author: Talwar, Prashant11 KMC Hospital, Mangalore India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61533535?accountid=14925

Abstract: Draws on previous research to study factors in the family & peer group that influence adolescent aggression. Interviews were conducted with 106 adolescents of Bengere Island, India, regarding their levels of latent aggression, peer relations, & family functioning, while their mothers were questioned on the functioning of their marriages. Multiple regression analysis revealed significant inverse correlations between family functioning & latent aggression & between peer group influence & aggression. It is concluded that the poorer the influences of family & peer group, the higher the level of adolescent aggression, & that family influences are stronger than peer influences. 6 Tables, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Panchayati Raj: Challenges to Be Met

Author: Galliara, Meena11 Tata Instit Social Sciences, Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61543841?accountid=14925

Abstract: Analyzes the issues & challenges confronting the panchayat institution of India, which is a constitutionally safeguarded instrument of decentralized democratic development. Lack of regulatory powers & adequate representation has rendered many of these panchayats nonfunctional, ineffective, & subject to centralized state control. In response, the Indian government passed an amendment that further empowered the panchayats such that they would become an effective & strong people's organization. Since the panchayats pose a challenge to the established order, however, the states have followed the amendment in letter but not in spirit. It is concluded that, for the panchayats to succeed, a commitment to decentralization must be formed among government officials, & a multidisciplinary approach must be taken. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Panchayati+Raj%3A+Challenges+to+Be+Met&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1995-10-01&amp;volume=56&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=493&amp;author=Galliara%2C+Meena

The Impact of Schizophrenia on Hong Kong Chinese Families

Author: Chan, Kai-fong11 Dept Social Work Hong Kong Baptist U, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61431912?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is well-documented in the Western literature that families living with & caring for a relative with schizophrenia experience a considerable financial, social, & emotional burden. Reported here are survey data from 100 Chinese primary carers of schizophrenic family members in Hong Kong, exploring: (1) the patients' behavior associated with the illness & their effects on the primary carers; (2) difficulties encountered by the carers resulting from caregiving, including financial strain, restriction of social activities, impairment of health or well-being, influence on job, conflicts with family members, not taking good care of other family members, & disturbance of domestic routines; & (3) emotional & psychological impacts. 3 Tables, 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Post-Divorce Family Environment as a Protective Factor against Depression among Children of Single-Parent Families

Author: Cheung, Siu-kau11 Division Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61431026?accountid=14925

Abstract: Previous research shows that depression is a central phenomenological experience of children of divorce, & the problem is mainly attributed to parental conflict. Examined here is the significance of family cohesion as a protective factor against depression, drawing on scale data from 143 children of single-parent families in Hong Kong whose parents divorced or separated within the past 2 years. As predicted, the Ss had elevated depressive symptoms. Both family cohesion & family conflict were associated with depressive symptoms, but the former was a significantly stronger predictor. Depression was not associated with change in family economic condition. Findings highlight the importance of promoting family cohesion in addition to the prevention of family conflict in helping children cope with divorce. 4 Tables, 52 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Men Speak Out over Their Extramarital Activities in China

Author: Young, Katherine P H1; Kwan, Roger W H1 Dept Social Work & Social Administration U Hong Kong, Hong Kong

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61427150?accountid=14925

Abstract: In-depth interview data from 11 Hong Kong men who engaged in extramarital activities while working in China are drawn on to describe their experiences & viewpoints. These men considered that if they just provided financially, cared for & about their wives & family, extramarital activities, while away from home, would not harm their marriage. It is suggested that the lifestyle & business culture of working in China tend to create norms & circumstances that contribute to the increasing prevalance of such extramarital involvement. Risks to marital stability associated with this lifestyle are discussed. 2 Tables, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Empowerment Networking Groups for Women Whose Spouses Are Having Extramarital Affairs

Author: Kwok, Paulina C Y11 Hong Kong Caritas Family Service, Tuen Mun South

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61591378?accountid=14925

Abstract: The conventional social work approach toward extramarital affairs among men in Hong Kong tends to marginalize the problem into individual weakness rather than empowerment. Inspired by feminist thinking, the problem is redefined here into one of gender inequality. The first empowerment networking group for women whose spouses are having affairs was established in Dec 1993 in a family service center. Through the collective sharing of similar experiences & causes of their emotional problems, participants became their own representatives to speak about their difficulties & concern. Their unheard voices are now attended by both political & public sectors. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

Multiple Case Study -- Women of Infertility in Hong Kong: Implications for Social Work Intervention

Author: Ko, Grace Po-chee11 Dept Applied Social Studies City U Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61481920?accountid=14925

Abstract: Attempts to understand the stresses & coping mechanisms of infertile women in Hong Kong with reference to the Chinese culture. Interviews (N = 7) show that high levels of stress exist in terms of treatment, attitudes of medical & nursing staff, lack of money & time, & sexual relations difficulties. Dependency on advanced medical technology create major challenges; loneliness & isolation from social circles cause psychological strain. The behavioral, cognitive, & affective coping mechanisms used by these women are reported. Recommendations at both macro- & microlevels are discussed. 2 Figures, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Sexual Behaviour and AIDS in India: State-of-the-Art

Author: Nag, Moni11 Columbia U, New York NY 10027

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61577877?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes an urgent need for increased awareness among the people of India regarding aspects of sexual behavior that are particularly risky with regard to contracting AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome). Topics such as premarital & extramarital sex, female & male sex workers, homosexuality, & hiras (eunuchs) are discussed. High risk sexual behavior involving the above aspects are not as uncommon in India as generally assumed, according to extant empirical evidence. 2 Tables, 91 References.
