Appropriate Methodologies for Studying Sexual Behaviour in India

Author: Basu, D P

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61381490?accountid=14925

Abstract: Describes research conducted to develop appropriate methodologies for studying sexual lifestyles & habits of urban Indians. Findings from 8 focus-group interviews of middle-class men & women in Bombay & Calcutta, supplemented by subsequent field research & testing, demonstrate the need for large-scale quantitative studies to map sexual behavior. It is concluded that, given an in-depth understanding of sociocultural issues unique to the Indian context, it is possible to undertake such an exercise with reasonable levels of acceptability & validity. 17 Tables, 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61410219?accountid=14925

Cultural Contexts of Sexual Behaviours and Identities and Their Impact upon HIV Prevention Models: An Overview of South Asian Men Who Have Sex with Men

Author: Khan, Shivananda

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61609575?accountid=14925

Abstract: The sexual behaviors & identities of 1,200 men of South Asian descent who engage in homosexual behavior were examined through discussions, interviews, letters, & phone calls. Ss were predominantly ages 22-35, & the vast majority were married & not identified as gay. Few of the Ss informed their wives of their encounters, & many saw sex with their wife not as a pleasure, but as a duty. Encounters with men were a sexual release & did not usually lead to emotional relationships. Fifteen % of the Ss described their first sexual encounter with a man as rape or sexual abuse. Masturbation was the most common first sex act & the first encounter was usually initiated by the partner, to whom the S was often related. Findings are viewed in relation to HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) prevention, & are compared to previous research in Western populations. 2 Tables. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Cultural+Contexts+of+Sexual+Behaviours+and+Identities+and+Their+Impact+upon+HIV+Prevention+Models%3A+An+Overview+of+South+Asian+Men+Who+Have+Sex+with+Men&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1994-10-01&amp;volume=55&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=633&amp;author=Khan%2C+Shivananda

Meeting the Needs of the Ageing Population in Hong Kong: Burden or Challenge?

Author: Kwan, Alex Yui-huen1; Davis, Leonard F1 Dept Applied Social Studies City Polytechnic Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61624607?accountid=14925

Abstract: Growth in the proportion of elderly in Hong Kong's population has implications for demands on public services, given that the elderly are more likely to require medical, financial, & personal support. Focus here is on how these needs are met. An emphasis on the community care approach -- support given to frail, disabled, or dependent people living in their own homes -- has effects on housing & residential provision, women in the labor force, & the quality of life of the elderly. The system of family care is not likely to remain feasible since there will be fewer family members to care for the elderly. Long-term care should offer wide-ranging support services for the elderly & their families in different areas & should be integrated with housing, nutrition, & health services. Without a commitment to community care policies, a bleak future is predicted. 10 Tables, 22 References. A. Cole

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Meeting+the+Needs+of+the+Ageing+Population+in+Hong+Kong%3A+Burden+or+Challenge%3F&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1994-07-01&amp;volume=28&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=66&amp;author=Kwan%2C+Alex+Yui-huen%3BDavis%2C+Leonard+F

Unemployed Educated Young Men in India: Their Problems of Adjustment

Author: Singh, Lal Bahadur11 Dept Psychology Tilkamanjhi Bhagalpur U, Bihar India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61583213?accountid=14925

Abstract: Statistical data were used to compare 150 educated employed young men with 150 unemployed educated young men in India. Findings indicate that the educated job seeker, as compared to the employed person, had significantly more adjustment problems on every front (home, health, social, & emotional) as well as in their totality. There was a strong interrelationship among different adjustment patterns. 2 Tables, 59 References. Adapted from the source document.

Women in Chemical Environment: Reproductive Hazards and Management

Author: Nag, Anjali11 Indian Council Medicine Research National Instit Occupational Health, Ahmedabad 380016 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61637294?accountid=14925

Abstract: The reproductive hazards faced by women in the chemical industries & regulatory approaches to hazard management are discussed. Infertility, subfertility, miscarriage, & birth defects can be caused by the toxic effects of single compounds or reactions between compounds. The women at greatest risk are young, less-educated, unskilled, part-time, & disabled workers, & those with multiple exposures. Measures to minimize exposure include enforced compliance with existing standards, biological & environmental monitoring, computerization of inventory, information access, proper use of health & safety personnel, medical surveillance, preemployment health screening, employee education & counseling, management initiative to handle chemicals correctly, supportive maternal leave & return policies, engineering & work practice controls, &, as a last resort, protective gear. 3 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Organisational Conflict, Role Conflict and Correlates: An Empirical Study

Author: Kumar, E Sendil1; Pandey, S1 c/o Pandey -- Dept Personnel Management & Industrial Relations Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61629522?accountid=14925

Abstract: Bivariate & multiple regression analyses of survey data obtained from 100 midlevel executives in 4 medium-sized Indian organizations reveal statistically significant negative correlations between conflict & age, tenure, job involvement, work involvement, & role efficacy. Four role conflict & 3 organizational conflict variables were used. Role efficacy explained 22% of role conflict perception variance. Role efficacy combined with job involvement accounted for 47% of organizational conflict variance. 3 Tables, 67 References. Adapted from the source document.

Theoretical Controversies in Organisational Behaviour

Author: Pandey, S11 Dept Personnel Management & Industrial Relations Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61387712?accountid=14925

Abstract: The debates over methodologies in organization research & the question of whether universal or culture- & nation-specific management theories should be developed are summarized. There is no evidence that any theory of how to manage is the best theory, but there is still a strong desire to seek one. Often this means the importation of Japanese or US models into countries where they may not be ideally applicable. Methodological debates (eg, idiographic vs nomothetic) & paradigm competition (eg, radical structuralism vs functionalism vs interpretivism vs radical humanism) have also muddied the field of organization theory. 44 References. E. Blackwell

Challenges in Developing Indigenous Theories of Organisation and Management: An Indian Perspective

Author: Gupta, Rajen K11 Indian Instit Management, Lucknow 226013

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61382709?accountid=14925

Abstract: The development of culture- & nation-specific theories of organizational behavior are advocated for India. Theoretical challenges include forming concepts in the context of Indian cultures & languages, understanding the complexity of Indian society, & developing comparisons with other contexts. Methodological challenges are performing grounded research, using holistic case studies, incorporating historical methods & culturally sensitive depth psychology, studying natural experiments of organizational change, & conducting action research & international research. In The Importance of the Historical Context, Udai Pareek (Indian Instit of Health Management Research, Jaipur) applauds Gupta & emphasizes the need to study India's identity formation & inherited collective unconscious. In Indigenisation of OB Research in India: A Subjective View, Jai B. P. Sinha (ANS Instit of Social Studies, Patna, India) agrees that a specifically Indian organization research (but one that integrates relevant ideas & methods from other cultures) should be developed by the collective efforts of Indian academia. In Prospects for Phenomenological Organizational Behavior, Nirmala Srinivasan argues that Gupta idealizes Indianization & downplays serious academic conflicts & rivalries that will not be easily overcome. Controversies over phenomenology & applications of grounded theories for solving behavioral problems are discussed in the context of Gupta's call. 20 References. E. Blackwell

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Challenges+in+Developing+Indigenous+Theories+of+Organisation+and+Management%3A+An+Indian+Perspective&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1994-04-01&amp;volume=55&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=220&amp;author=Gupta%2C+Rajen+K

The Future of Trade Unions

Author: Mathur, Ajeet11 Dept Personnel Management & Industrial Relations Indian Instit Management, Calcutta 700027

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374240?accountid=14925

Abstract: As evidenced by declining membership, political clout, & tactical strength, trade unions are weakening, both internationally & in India. Here, this decline is considered in the context of union history in GB, the US, Australia, the former USSR, Scandinavia, & the People's Republic of China. Due to its pursuit of a mixed economy, India developed several forms of union. This fragmentation, coupled with a shrinking base, makes collective mobilization unlikely. The future of unions in India depends on broadened objectives that seek the well-being of all working people. The democratization of unions & coalitions or mergers of unions with overlapping concerns are also advocated. Adapted from the source document.

Higher Education Teachers' Perception and Feelings about Their Community and Institutions: A Study of the Culture of Educational Institutions

Author: Kalra, Satish Kumar1; Raina, Rashmi; Gupta, Rajen K1 Indian Instit Management, Lucknow 226013

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61374542?accountid=14925

Abstract: The perceptions & attitudes of teachers (N = 176) are explored using a projective methodology in order to learn more about the culture of India's colleges & universities. In general, the teachers hold negative perceptions of their community & organizational systems. Many hold negative attitudes about other teachers & about colleges & universities as a whole, which indicates a poor work culture with potentially serious consequences for teacher performance. Improved training (including role training), the consideration of personality in teacher selection & employment, & better leadership are required to improve the culture of higher education in India. 2 Tables, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Jha, Saroj S

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61610316?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses lifestyle-related problems of youth, ie, drug use, problem drinking, tobacco use, early experimentation with sex, & injuries & violence. Problem behaviors cluster together in the same individual & are also likely to be triggered by peer pressure & unrewarding environments at work, study, or the home. 1 Chart. Patients in Indian Hospitals: Environmental Stresses and Affective Reactions

Author: Agrawal, Manju1; Dalal, Ajit K1 Dept Psychology Lucknow U, 226007 Uttar Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61619751?accountid=14925

Abstract: Indian hospitals are characterized by urban bias, overcrowding, depersonalization, routine treatment procedures, & inadequate communication between medical staff & patients. Here, interview data are used to examine patients' (N = 122) affective reactions to this stressful hospital environment. Findings reveal that the characteristic responses of both male & female patients were depression, rationalization, & sense of helplessness. Male patients showed less anger & anxiety than females, but were higer on disengagement & rationalization. 1 Table, 1 Appendix, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Tilak, Damodar

Land Reforms in Dadra and Nagar Haveli: When a Saranjam Refused to Surrender!

Author: Bhatia, R C; Bhatia, Alka

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61626021?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses the historical context of land reform in Dadra & Nagar Haveli, India, where reform occurred only twenty-seven years after independence. The dispute over territorial sovereignty between Portugal & the British is traced, 1947-1961, when Dadra & Nagar Haveli finally merged with the Indian Union. These difficulties led to the delay in implementing land reform in the region. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Logical Synthesis of Rational-Emotive Therapy and Cognitive Therapy in the Treatment of Emotional Disturbance

Author: Cheung, Siu-kau11 Division Humanities & Social Sciences City Polytechnic Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61626473?accountid=14925

Abstract: In cognitive behavioral therapy, it is proposed that the client's cognitive distortions & disturbances can be represented by syllogistic reasoning. A model of the cognitive deduction process is presented, which comprises both practical & theoretical syllogistic deductions. In this light, rational-emotive therapy & cognitive therapy can be seen to be complementary in their treatment of emotional disorders. Caveats of the individual approach are discussed, & the logical system comprising practical & theoretical syllogisms is introduced. Implications for clinical practice are considered. 1 Figure, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Determinants of the Transition to Marriage among Young Chinese Women in Hong Kong

Author: Luis, B P K1; Chan, Kwok-leung; Choy, Yee-hung1 Dept Applied Social Studies Hong Kong Polytechnic, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61620282?accountid=14925

Abstract: A questionnaire survey was conducted among 692 young adults ages 18-27 in 1986 to explore the social contexts & life events pertaining to the transition to marriage among young Chinese women in Hong Kong. Findings reveal that parental control & social attributes of the family were largely irrelevant. Surprisingly, the gender composition of younger siblings affected the transition in a very gender-specific way, pointing to a subtle psychosexual process between siblings. The sharp increase in marriage following the exit from school indicates that the normative restriction of marriage to those who have finished their education is still adhered to. Christian faith had no bearing on the transition to marriage. Two sexual life events -- romantic love & premarital sex -- were found to be relevant, indicating that a traditional normative connotation is still attached to these acts. 1 Table, 1 Appendix, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Determinants+of+the+Transition+to+Marriage+among+Young+Chinese+Women+in+Hong+Kong&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=34&amp;author=Luis%2C+B+P+K%3BChan%2C+Kwok-leung%3BChoy%2C+Yee-hung

The 'Astronaut Family'

Author: Hui, Y F

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61620228?accountid=14925

Abstract: Focused interviews with 12 Hong Kong "astronaut" fathers ages 40+ (ie, men whose families have emigrated to other countries, but who return to work in Hong Kong for long periods) investigate the impact of separation. Findings reveal that these men feel pressure to earn a lot of money quickly, because it is the reason they are away from their families & because they will face uncertain futures in their new countries after China assumes Hong Kong in 1997. The men socialize less & with fewer people than before the separation, & say that holidays are difficult. They stand by their decision, but do not recommend it for younger men, citing age & length of marriage as important factors in holding their families together. The mothers & children experience some of the problems of single-parent homes, the stresses of being new immigrants, & emotional loss. Family structure, which in Hong Kong usually means a dominant father & homemaker wife, is disrupted. Male decision-making authority is diminished, & mistrust & marital discord sometimes occur. Social service recommendations are made. 2 Tables, 13 References. E. Blackwell

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=The+%27Astronaut+Family%27&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=59&amp;author=Hui%2C+Y+F

Mind Your Language: Terminology in the Field of Mental Retardation

Author: Tse, W L John1; Davis, Leonard1 Faculty Humanities & Social Sciences City Polytechnic Hong Kong, Kowloon

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61584590?accountid=14925

Abstract: Outdated terminology used to describe the mentally retarded in Hong Kong & elsewhere is identified in glossary form. Terminology should accurately describe the intellectual & adaptive functioning characteristics of the condition, & recognize problems while being positive or neutral, not offensive. Inappropriate or inaccurate terms include: abbreviations such as MR for mental retardation (except in academic journals), mental deficiency, mongolism, learning difficulty, mental age, special, intellectual disability, vegetative, unfortunate, & victim. Sometimes a word is accurate, but a phrase is not, eg, confined to a wheelchair, Down's syndrome people. It is hoped that Hong Kong social workers will communicate proper terminology & positive attitudes toward people with mental retardation to the media & the public. 15 References. E. Blackwell

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Mind+Your+Language%3A+Terminology+in+the+Field+of+Mental+Retardation&amp;title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=02192462&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=69&amp;author=Tse%2C+W+L+John%3BDavis%2C+Leonard

Patients' Rights: A Perspective

Author: Jesani, Amar1; Nadkarni, Vimla1 Centre Enquiry Health & Allied Themes, 310 Prabhu Darshan Amboli Bombay 400058 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61620135?accountid=14925

Abstract: An introduction to a special journal issue (see related abstracts in SOPODA 16:2) focusing on patient rights. Though the World Health Organization's goal of "Health for All by 2000" was endorsed by numerous countries, health strategies have become separated from lofty universal health sentiments. Health care strategies now emphasize health status targets (eg, sterilization or infant mortality rates) to the extent that primary health care has become little more than selective health care. Previous emphasis on the right to health has shifted to the right to health care; in the transformation, consideration of the needs of people has disappeared. People's needs can be brought back into focus through an emphasis on patients' rights at two levels: (1) basic comprehensive health care for all without regard for capacity to pay, & (2) provision of humane, quality care. 11 References. D. Generoli

Consumer Protection Act and Medical Profession

Author: Bal, Arun

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61620063?accountid=14925

Abstract: India's 1986 Consumer Protection Act has generated much controversy within the medical profession. Doctors claim that the doctor-patient relationship differs from the buyer-seller relationship. In a discussion of such problem issues as negligence, the objections of the medical profession are refuted. Possible regulatory actions that can be taken by the medical profession are described. 2 Appendixes. Adapted from the source document.

Internal Migration of Scientific/Technical and Social Sciences Personnel in India: An Analysis of DHTP Survey 1981

Author: Singh, D P11 Dept Research Methodology Tata Instit Social Sciences, Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61363643?accountid=14925

Abstract: Data from a 1981 survey by the Council of Scientific & Industrial Research in India are drawn on to explore the interstate migration of degree holders & technical personnel (DHTP), differentiating by (1) scientific, technical, & social sciences personnel; (2) sex; & (3) distance moved. Variations in in- & outmigration of DHTP are explained in terms of unemployment level, average income level, & urbanization. Results indicate that: (A) scientific/technical personnel are more migratory than social sciences personnel, & (B) unemployment & expected income level are important factors significantly affecting the in- & outmigration rates of DHTP. 9 Tables, 4 Figures, 2 Appendixes, 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Family Planning and Reproductive Health

Author: Karkal, Malini

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61594309?accountid=14925

Abstract: Discusses population control polices in India, noting their effect on reproductive health & the right of women to control their fertility. It is argued that population control policies, framed to further the interest of First World countries & function in the patriarchal social situation, oppress women while denying them choices to promotes their health. Whether antinatalist or pronatalist, the population polices tend to treat women's bodies as instruments of male-dominated populationist ends. 1 Table, 11 References. ____________________________________________________________

Does Enough Work Make Women Free? Part-Time and Full-Time Work Strategies for Women in the United States and Germany

Author: Olsen, Frances11 U California, Los Angeles 90024

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61364278?accountid=14925

Abstract: A critical comparison of the effects of work outside the home on the status of women in the newly reunified Germany vs the US. The exploitation of US women, who work full-time while retaining primary responsibility for child care & homemaking, is contrasted to that of women in (the former) West Germany, many of whom work part-time. Some pitfalls awaiting women of former East Germany (& other parts of the world), regardless of whether they adopt the US or West German pattern for dealing with the double burden of work inside & outside the home, are identified. It is maintained that the privacy of the family is a political myth that disempowers women. Some public policy reforms that alter the sexual division of labor so as to ameliorate the oppression of women are suggested. 5 References. Adapted from the source document.

Urbanisation in the Third World Countries

Author: Parmar, Y A11 Dept Sociology South Gujarat U, Surat 395007 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61342096?accountid=14925

Abstract: Draws on statistical data from several sources to document the accelerating growth of urbanization in the Third World since 1950, the continuous increase of population in urban areas, the growth of large cities, & the consequent problems confronting the inhabitants -- eg, slums & poverty. Within their limited resources, Third World countries will have to evolve such a policy that at least a minimum of health & shelter services are made available to the poorest sectors. A comparative picture of the situation in the different countries of the Third World is attempted. 1 Table, 44 References. Adapted from the source document.

Influence of Socio-Economic Factors on the Employed Hindu Woman's Attitude towards Dowry

Author: Nadagouda, Sharada G1; K., Saroja; Rao, Aruna1 U Agricultural Sciences, Dharwad 560065 Karnataka India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61363382?accountid=14925

Abstract: Scale data obtained from 100 married employed Hindu women ages 20-40 in Dharwad city, India, are used to investigate their attitudes toward dowry with respect to educational, occupational, & income levels. The majority (41%) of respondents expressed a favorable attitude toward dowry, with 26% expressing a medium & 33% an unfavorable attitude. Contrary to expectations, increases in levels of education, occupation, & income of these women have failed to create a negative attitude toward the practice of dowry. 4 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Family Environment and Interpersonal Behaviour: A Comparative Study of Dual Career and Single Career Families

Author: Rani, Veena1; Khandelwal, Preetam1 Dept Psychology U Delhi, 110007 Haryana India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61593574?accountid=14925

Abstract: An effort is made to delineate family members' perception of family environment & the nature of interpersonal need structure in 20 dual- & 20 single-career families in Delhi, India. Scale data from the father, mother, son, & daughter in each family indicate that compared to single-career families, dual-career families place significantly more emphasis on cultural & recreational pursuits, independence, & organization; express significantly higher control; & want less control in interpersonal relationships. Females score significantly lower on expressed control & higher on wanted control than do males. Implications of the findings with respect to the socialization of Indian children are discussed. 3 Tables, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Family+Environment+and+Interpersonal+Behaviour%3A+A+Comparative+Study+of+Dual+Career+and+Single+Career+Families&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1992-04-01&amp;volume=53&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=232&amp;author=Rani%2C+Veena%3BKhandelwal%2C+Preetam

De-Sanskritisation and High Caste Converts into "Bhangis"

Author: Shyamlal11 Dept Sociology U Jaipur, Rajasthan India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61314016?accountid=14925

Abstract: Though sanskritization, ie, the changeover from lower to higher castes, has received much attention in India, its reverse, desanskritization, has not. Analyzed here is the downward mobility of a population in Rajasthan, where individuals of upper castes or tribes broke away their affiliation with the parent group & culturally incorporated themselves, formally or legally, into the lower castes, acquiring a new low-caste identity. The desanskritization of upper castes into this Bhangi caste ("Bhangiisation") is detailed, drawing on data obtained during field observations & case examples of conversion to describe the processes involved, the reasons for conversion, religious background, employment, etc. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Humour as Social Critique

Author: Dhond, M V

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61332597?accountid=14925

Abstract: Based on the assumption that mainstream humor perpetuates traditional divisions within society between communities, religions, & genders, & contributes to a bitter division between "us" & "them," examined here are alternative forms of humor in India that, while producing laughter, eliminate social divisions. Four forms of alternative humor that target criticism at the larger society rather than at individuals are reviewed: (1) the Bhana, a single-actor Sanskrit play; (2) the theater of Kutiyattam, presented in Sanskrit & Prakit; (3) the popular folk theater of Maharashtra; & (4) modern cartoons in daily newspapers. I. Shagrir

Scheduled Castes and Social Justice: A Karnataka Case in Point

Author: Uplaonkar, Ambarao11 Sharanabasaveshwar Coll Arts, Gulbarga 585 103 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61340988?accountid=14925

Abstract: In India, the centenary of Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar's birth was recently celebrated as the year of social justice, with many seminars & conferences held to highlight the problems of the scheduled castes. Among Harijan youth, however, it is increasingly argued that there has been no significant change in the socioeconomic status of the former untouchables since independence, as most of the reservation benefits are being taken away by backward & forward castes. Here, this situation is attributed to the imprecise & ambiguous use of the phrase "scheduled caste" in the Indian constitution. An official redefinition of the phrase is called for that will enable the former untouchable castes to reap the maximum benefits of the reservations. 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Community Based Study of the Sociological Aspects of Night Blindness in the Desert Region of Rajasthan

Author: Ganguly, K K1; Yadav, Sheshpal; Mahapatra, A; Dam, P K; Krishnamachari, K. A. V. R.1 Regional Medical Research Centre, Jodhpur India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61333761?accountid=14925

Abstract: An analysis of sociological factors contributing to the functional effects of night blindness (NB) in the Thar desert of western Rajasthan, India. The scarcity of leafy vegetables (a source of Vitamin A) in the region increases the incidence of NB. Here, analysis of questionnaire data from 60 children & 24 adults reveals that strong familial & societal bonds help overcome the detrimental effect of NB. While children suffering from NB get sympathy from the society, adult women do not, & adult men seem to ignore the affliction. Ignorance & laxity compound the situation, often with dire consequences for the larger society. A concerted effort to overcome the problem is described that focused on the administration of Vitamin A supplements, & education about NB. 5 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=A+Community+Based+Study+of+the+Sociological+Aspects+of+Night+Blindness+in+the+Desert+Region+of+Rajasthan&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1992-01-01&amp;volume=53&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=45&amp;author=Ganguly%2C+K+K%3BYadav%2C+Sheshpal%3BMahapatra%2C+A%3BDam%2C+P+K%3BKrishnamachari%2C+K.+A.+V.+R.

The Jain Movement and Socio-Religious Tranformation of the "Bhangis" of Jodhpur, Rajasthan

Author: Shyamlal11 Dept Sociology U Rajasthan, Jaipur India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61333451?accountid=14925

Abstract: Data obtained via interviews with key informants (N not provided) & published documentary sources are drawn on to describe the activities of the Bharatiya Sanskar Nirman Samiti (BSNS), a Jain organization established in India in 1973 to initiate a socioreligious reform movement among the exuntouchable castes. Focus is on activities in the Western part of the state of Rajasthan since 1984, when the BSNS began its work in Jodhpur City. A detail account of the efforts of the BSNS workers among the Bhangis are described, focusing on its efforts toward conversion & struggle against social vices; the special role of Acharya Sri Tulsi, founder of the Anuurat movement, in the struggle is documented. 10 References. Trends and Correlates of Widowhood in India

Author: Sinha, R K11 International Instit Population Sciences, Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61315078?accountid=14925

Abstract: Data from the decennial Indian census, 1901-1981, reveal that widowhood has declined gradually due to improvement in the general mortality situation & the rise in female age at marriage. Additionally, the mean age at first widowhood has also increased. However, general improvement in the widowhood situation is only valid if %s are considered: in terms of absolute numbers, it has deteriorated. 7 Tables, 13 References. Operation Flood -- A Few Constraints

Author: Thirunavakkarasu, M1; Prabaharan, R; Ramasamy, C1 Dept Animal Husbandry Economics Madras Veterinary Coll, 600 007 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61315660?accountid=14925

Abstract: Structured interview data from 90 members of 5 milk producers' cooperative socieities in Tamil Nadu, India, are drawn on to identify the major constraints faced by the beneficiaries of Operation Flood (OF), a highly controversial dairy development program. Women Employees: An Emerging Issue of HRM in Organisations

Author: Sastry, N11 Dept Humanities & Social Sciences Indian Instit Technology, Bombay 400076

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61297297?accountid=14925

Abstract: The influx of women into the Indian workplace has precipitated clashes between the female (F) behavior encouraged by F socialization & the male (M) corporate culture. In F socialization, Fs are encouraged to work inside the home, or choose F-type occupations; even those holding executive or management positions do so in F-type specializations. Fs generally do not view their jobs as full-time, long-term careers, & have lower self-concepts about their management ability. Fs have less opportunity to enter M-dominated community networks & political systems, & attempts to integrate themselves into the mentoring system may be viewed as sexually motivated. Organizations may reinforce these attitudes by selection, recruitment, & promotion practices. The situation in the workplace could be improved with androgynous sex-role orientation during socialization, the buildup of social & professional networks supportive of women, protection of women's rights in the organization, solutions for child care, & the understanding that overwork at the family's expense is detrimental for both genders. 139 References. M. Pflum

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Women+Employees%3A+An+Emerging+Issue+of+HRM+in+Organisations&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-10-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=493&amp;author=Sastry%2C+N

HRD through Training in the Changing Perspective

Author: D'Souza, R11 Xavier Instit Management, Bhubaneswar India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61293683?accountid=14925

Abstract: An Indian industrial organizations design new human resources development (HRD) programs coincident with the rapid development of technology & the globalization of the ecoonomy, on-the-job training will need to consider the actual educational & skill levels of the workers, many of whom have traditional, or even below-standard, educations. Next, the organization's HRD objectives, learning experiences, performance criteria, & effectiveness standards need to be identified. Training programs, however, cannot solve all quality-of-work-life issues. Special programs must be developed to deal with changes in work attitudes & values, & to develop organizational commitment. Self-managed team structures will play an increasingly important role, while the leader's function will consist of monitoring & facilitating the team in its own self-regulation, & in advancing & developing talented subordinates (mentoring). 28 References. Hierarchy and Modern Organisation: A Paradox Leading to Human Wastage

Author: Chattopadhyay, Gouranga P; Malhotra, Ashok

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61297346?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is contended that the hierarchical structure of many modern organizations is a breeding ground for incompetence, & leads to a waste of human resources. Examination of the concepts of hierarchy & modern organization reveals that the two cannot coexist without producing enormous problems for personnel. Insights derived from the science of psychodynamics are utilized to understand reasons for the survival of hierarchy in modern organizations, & possible means for jettisoning hierarchy are explored. 4 Figures, 19 References. Personal-Personality, Job and Organisational Correlates of Work Identification

Author: Dolke, A M11 Indian Instit Banking, Bombay 400093

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61293741?accountid=14925

Abstract: The relationship between employee work identification (WI) & various personal-personality, job, & organizational variables is examined using data collected from 567 male technical & clerical personnel working in 6 composite textile mills in Ahmedabad, India, using a 29-item Likert-type scale. Results indicate that WI is significantly related to personal variables of age & tenure, personality variables of locus of control & satisfaction of higher-order needs, & certain dimensions of work value. WI is also related to job variables of challenge & autonomy. The organizational variables related to WI are participation in departmental decision making, supervisory support, perceived chances of rising in the organizational hierarchy, & fulfillment of higher-order needs. 4 Tables, 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Managerial Value Profile Task and Interaction Facilitation: An Empirical Assessment

Author: Sayeed, O B11 National Instit Training Industrial Engineering, Bombay 400087 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61301092?accountid=14925

Abstract: The construct identity of value profile & the linkage between value profile & esteem for coworkers were investigated with data from 98 banking branch managers in India who completed the Bales-Couch Value Profile Scales ([VPS] a personality measure) & the Least Preferred Coworker Scales (LPCS); 18 of the managers also completed personal orientation inventories. Factor analysis of the VPS data yielded respect for authority, value-determined restraint, egalitarianism, & individualism factors, all relatively independent. ANOVAS between the LPCS, age, & education, & the 4 value dimensions of the VPS yielded a significant main effect for age on respect for authority; age & education individually explained more variation in the 4 dependent variables than did esteem for coworkers, contrary to the hypothesis. Regardless of the lack of statistically significant differences between categories of esteem for coworkers, the moderating influence of esteem for coworkers showing interaction & task facilitation was confirmed with respect to acceptance of authority & egalitarianism. The differences between the Indian & similar US study findings are discussed. 5 Tables, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Marital disharmony following head injury

Author: Sabhesan, S; Rajasakthivel, M; Natarajan, M

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/42389511?accountid=14925

Abstract: In a prospective follow up of head injured patients, 105 couples were seen at three monthly intervals for a period of 18 months. Marital disturbances were found in 45 couples and seven of them ended in divorce or separation. The disturbances were not related to the age or sex of the patient. Indices of head injury such as biomechanics of injury, duration of coma, length of post traumatic amnesia, persistent neurological disabilities, and neuropsychological impairments were not predictive of marital discord. Behavior changes, particularly irritability and amotivation were most disturbing. Sexual dysfunctions were common among the disturbed couples. Divorce was frequently related to physical violence between the spouses who belonged to nuclear families and had no dependent children. Though joint families were able to provide financial support and protection against divorce, they were not emotionally supportive of the spouses. The need for identifying the marital difficulties early and resolving the conflicts through a multi-disciplinary approach is emphasized. [Author Abstract]

School Performance of Disadvantaged Children: The Educational Resourcefulness Model

Author: Dalal, Ajit K11 Dept Psychology U Allahabad, 211002 Uttar Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61631546?accountid=14925

Abstract: The literature shows that lower-caste & scheduled tribe children in India perform poorly on scholastic tasks & have a high rate of school dropout. An educational resourcefulness model is proposed to improve the school performance of socioeconomically disadvantaged children. According to this model, self-esteem, sense of personal control, & ability to plan are recognized as cognitive attributes essential to benefit maximally from the given opportunities to learn. The model utilizes an intervention program to indicate educational resourcefulness through teaching games for children in the first year of schooling. The efficacy of such an intervention program in a supportive school environment is discussed. 1 Figure, 51 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61321562?accountid=14925

Abstract: In an investigation of the origin of helplessness, 225 children were classified into mastery-oriented & helpless categories, & by urban & rural background, based on questionnaires. Managing Voluntary Organisations with Limited Finances and Unskilled Personnel

Author: Narayana, E A11 Dept Political Science & Public Administration Nagarjuna U, 522510 Andhra Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61307032?accountid=14925

Abstract: Income data for a sample of 33 organizations engaged in rural development in Andhra Pradesh are used to examine two major problems experienced by voluntary organizations in India: finance resources & the quality of personnel. The findings indicate that the most important source of funding is from abroad, with roughly 90% of the agencies having access to foreign funds; next in importance are grants from the federal & state governments. The staffing patterns of the organizations reflect the essential Weberian bureaucratic characteristics of hierarchy of authority & division of labor. An overwhelming majority of the personnel did not have technical & professional education & training in their respective organizations. Recommendations include: the mobilization of local resources & funds to replace dependence on external agencies or the government, adherence to the norms stipulated by the funding agencies to assure accountability; improved technical & professional competence of the employees; & the implementation of a system of staff development. Changes in the organizational structure to enhance job satisfaction are also suggested. 2 Tables, 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Subjective Construction of Morality: The Indian Experience

Author: Jain, Uday11 Dept Psychology Barkatullah Vishwavidyalaya, Bhopal 462026 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61300319?accountid=14925

Abstract: The subjective construction of morality in the prevailing social atmosphere is examined, arguing that attribution of responsibility is involved in moral judgment, & responsibility is understood in distinct ways; further, attribution is also influenced by the social perspective. Data supporting the social aspect of moral judgment are presented, obtained in a study in which 64 Indian college teachers responded to a modified version of L. Kohlberg's Heinz dilemma (eg, see "Moral Stages and Moralization: The Cognitive Developmental Approach" in Lickona [Ed], Moral Development and Behavior: Theory, Research and Social Issues, New York: Holt Reinhart, 1976) & scale measuring perceptions of social atmosphere. Traditional Indian (Hindu) thought on morality is also discussed, along with implications for moral development. 2 Tables, 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Life events and family consequences among head injured patients

Author: Sabhesan, S; Ramasamy, P; Athiappan, S; Natarajan, M

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/42390487?accountid=14925

Abstract: In a long term prospective follow up of head injured patients and their families, patients admitted in the Trauma Ward between September 1984 and June 1985 were seen three years after the injury. 115 patients, in whom details of life events during the previous 18 months could be studied, were included in the present study. The life changes were classified as those related to head injury disturbances and those occurring independently. Interactional pattern in the family, psychological morbidity in significant family members and burden experienced by family members were studied in relation to life events. Unlike independent events, those related to head injury sequelae were more frequent and accounted for a significant proportion of family disturbances. The nature of the life events indicated that the stress-event-stress cycle was attributable to the behavioural and economic consequences of head injury. [Author Abstract]

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Life+events+and+family+consequences+among+head+injured+patients&amp;title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-04-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=161&amp;author=Sabhesan%2C+S%3BRamasamy%2C+P%3BAthiappan%2C+S%3BNatarajan%2C+M

Socio-Cultural Influences on Moral Behaviour

Author: Misra, Girishwar11 Barkatullah U, Bhopal India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61293324?accountid=14925

Abstract: The influence of sociocultural factors on the development of moral behavior in Indian children was examined in 4 studies (total N = 488) via questionnaire & scale data. Results show that while moral realism, retribution, & efficiency of severe punishment increased with age, immanent justice was considerably high in almost all age groups. In an additional experimental study on children drawn from this sample, it was noted that level of moral reasoning did not have a significant effect on generosity. However, experimentally created empathy did, not only on generosity, but also on behavior. It is concluded that the pattern of moral behavior has cultural variations &, in view of global changes in the world order, a constitutive orientation toward the conceptualization of individual & morality is warranted. In this context, the Indian conceptualization of man-society as symbiotically related & the idea of Dharma have important implications. 6 Tables, 70 References. Modified AA

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Socio-Cultural+Influences+on+Moral+Behaviour&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-04-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=179&amp;author=Misra%2C+Girishwar

Income and Dowry: Some Revealing Connections

Author: Saroja, K1; Chandrika, S M1 Rural Home Science Coll U Agricultural Sciences, Karnataka India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61292379?accountid=14925

Abstract: The myth that better education & employment of women will eradicate the gender-stratifying practice of dowry in India is explored. Statistical analyses of interview & other data obtained from 150 married women reveal that, in certain circumstances, contrary to the myth, social practices for determining the amount of dowry depend on calculations of the family's socioeconomic status & the bride's & groom's educational & occupational levels. Analyses of the various factors reveal the complex ways that market forces help establish informal bidding processes through which a groom price is settled, & though which the community is given a method of groom allocation among bidders that is based on economic status. 4 Tables, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Vocational Choice Patterns of Urban Adolescents: A Case Study

Author: Akhilesh, K B11 Dept Management Studies Indian Instit Science, Bangalore

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61295273?accountid=14925

Abstract: Patterns of occupational preference were identified via responses of 240 middle-class, urban high school students in Bangalore City, India, to the Kuppuswamy socioeconomic status (SES) scale & an occupational preference scale, attempting to provide data for vocational guidance counselors. Indicating that students prefer specialization, computer engineer consistently ranked at the top of list, along with aircraft pilot, sportsman, electronics engineer, & singer. SES, gender, & age (to a lesser extent) influenced career selection. Additional research is needed on choices made by rural youth. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Pastor, R

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61163618?accountid=14925

Abstract: FOR CENTRAL AMERICANS, GEORGE BUSH'S PRAGMATIC STYLE WAS A WELCOME DEPARTURE FROM THE IDEOLOGICAL INTENSITY OF HIS PREDECESSOR. THIS ARTICLE DESCRIBES THE BACKGROUNND OF U.S. FOREIGN POLICY IN 1989 WHEN BUSH TOOK OFICE--THE GEOPOLITICAL SETTING, THE PHILOSOPHY AND ORIENTATION OF THE ADMINISTRATION'S KEY PLAYERS, AND THE STATE OF THE REGION'S PROBLEMS. POLITICIZED DEMOCRACY: COMPETITION, INSTITUTIONS, AND CIVIC FATIGUE IN BRAZIL

Author: Power, T

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61052528?accountid=14925

Abstract: BRAZIL BEGAN THE 1990S THE SAME WAY IT BEGAN THE 1980S: IN CRISIS. THIS ARTICLE DRAWS ON RECENT POLITICAL EVENTS IN BRAZIL, INCLUDING THE ADVENT OF THE COLLOR GOVERNMENT AND THE ELECTIONS OF 1990S, IN ORDER TO CONSTRUCT AN ARGUMENT ABOUT THE INSTITUTIONALIZATION OF DEMOCRACY. THE ARGUMENT IS BASED ON THE PREMISE THAT, BETWEEN THE COLLAPSE OF AN AUTHORITARIAN REGIME AND THE CONSOLIDATION OF POLITICAL DEMOCRACY, THERE EXISTS A LIMITED TIMEFRAME--A WINDOW OF VULNERABILTIY, IN WHICH DEMOCRACTIC ACTORS MUST WORK QUICKLY AND CAREFULLY TO ESTABLISH THOSE INSTITUTIONS, AS WELL AS FORMAL RULES AND PRACTICES, NEEDED TO FORM THE NEW DEMOCRACY.

PERU'S BLACK MARKET IN FOREIGN EXCHANGE

Author: Grosse, R

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/60967957?accountid=14925

Abstract: THE FOREIGN EXCHANGE MARKET IN PERU EXPERIENCED THE SAME KINDS OF VOLATILITY AND SHOCKS AS THE REST OF THE NATIONAL ECONOMY DURING THE 1980S. BECAUSE OF VARIOUS GOVERNMENT IMPOSED LIMITATIONS ON ACCESS TO FOREIGN EXCHANGE, A SIGNIFICANT BLACK MARKET IN FOREIGN CURRENCIES WAS BORN, WHICH HAS GROWN, OVER THE DECADES, TO MAKE UP A VERY SIGNIFICANT PART OF TOTAL FOREIGN EXCHANGE DEALINGS IN PERU. THE REASONS FOR BLACK MARKETS IN FOREIGN EXCHANGE, PREVIOUS ANALYSES OF FOREIGN EXCHANGE BLACK MARKETS AND THE CHARACTERISTICS FOR FOREIGN EXHANGE BLACK MARKETS ARE EXPLORED IN THIS ARTICLE.

Invisibility of the Girl Child in India

Author: Karkal, Malini

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61294393?accountid=14925

Abstract: Statistics for the metropolitan area of Bombay, India, provide evidence of negative male:female (F) ratios among children: Fs have higher child mortality & less access to food, health, education, & recreation, & are induced early into domestic work, marriage, & motherhood. The perpetuation of a cycle of more burden & less care for Fs starts at birth & continues unabashedly during the prime years of growing up, leading to an oppressed womanhood. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Sex-Detection Tests and Female Foeticide: Discrimination before Birth

Author: Lingam, Lakshmi11 Women's Studies Unit Tata Instit Social Sciences, 400088 Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61622409?accountid=14925

Abstract: It is contended that sex-determination testing (amniocentesis) in India often leads to abortion of female fetuses (feticide). Societal & government interventions against the practice are examined, & the inadequacy of accurate statistical data is lamented. Maharashtra state legislation's regulation of the use of prenatal diagnostic techniques since 1988 is discussed. It is concluded that the selective abortion of female fetuses perpetuates the negative social worth of women. 23 References. H. L. Stidger

Girl Child: A Lifetime of Deprivation and Discrimination

Author: Ghosh, Shanti11 World Health Organization, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61653155?accountid=14925

Abstract: A variety of statistics are presented that demonstrate discrimination against female (F) children in India, among them: (1) a declining F:male child population ratio, dropping from 972:1,000 in 1901 to 935:1,000 in 1981; (2) poorer nutritional status among F children seen at Safdarjang Hospital in New Delhi, 1986; (3) higher levels of F malnutrition in West Bengal & Punjab during the 1980s; & (4) higher infancy & childhood morbidity & mortality rates for Fs throughout India, 1970-1982. For Fs who achieve puberty, earlier motherhood among immature brides (ages 12-14 in many states) endangers both the young mothers & their babies. Further, their higher illiteracy rates make it almost impossible for Fs to overcome the discrimination against them & improve their overall life chances. 6 Tables, 6 References. J. W. Stanton

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Girl+Child%3A+A+Lifetime+of+Deprivation+and+Discrimination&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-01-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=21&amp;author=Ghosh%2C+Shanti

The Female Child in a Family Setting

Author: Anandalakshmi, S11 Lady Irwin Coll, New Delhi India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61317566?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview & other data gathered from 50 traditional craftsmen's & farmers' families in India are used to explore the female (F) child's role in the family. Socialization practices begin early in a child's life, & the F child is already at a disadvantage due to the tradition of overindulging the male at the cost of the F. The data also show a discernible relationship between the nature of the parental occupation, the ecocultural milieu, & the specific aspects of the child's socialization. Adapted from the source document.

Labour of the Indian Girl Child: Multi-Curse, Multi-Abuse and Multi-Neglect

Author: Nayar, Usha S11 Unit Child & Youth Research Tata Instit Social Sciences, Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61315221?accountid=14925

Abstract: The working conditions of female (F) children in India are explored via census & other data. Highlighted are the lower status & value of F child labor vis-a-vis that of their male counterparts, at home & outside. In addition to occupational hazards, F children are also vulnerable to sexual abuse both at the place of employment & at home. Since poverty is the main reason for child labor, Fs from poor backgrounds, who have other traditional social disadvantages, risk severe exploitation. Suggestions are made to alleviate the the F child plight resulting from the double curse of being F & a laborer. 2 Tables, 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Labour+of+the+Indian+Girl+Child%3A+Multi-Curse%2C+Multi-Abuse+and+Multi-Neglect&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1991-01-01&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=1&amp;spage=37&amp;author=Nayar%2C+Usha+S

Author: Subramaniam, Aparna

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61315281?accountid=14925

Abstract: Interview data obtained from 60 Indian females (Fs) ages 5-15 are drawn on to examine their work patterns, at home & outside, in relation to age, birth order, family type, & size, occupational status of other family members, & educational status of siblings. Girl Child in Red Light Areas

Author: Patkar, Priti

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61287519?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Indian social system has traditionally considered prostitution as a necessary social evil, but the society's failure to provide any kind of care for prostitutes' children has resulted in a growing number of female children who are driven to destitution & ploughed back into the profession. Field experience is drawn on to describe the miserable plight of such girls in the red light area of Kamathipura, Bombay. The need to initiate social work intervention is emphasized. Prostitution and the Girl Child

Author: Pawar, M S11 Dept Criminology & Correctional Administration Tata Instit Social Sciences, 400088 Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61294434?accountid=14925

Abstract: India has sought to abolish the traffic in persons for the purpose of prostitution, not to abolish prostitution itself, though the Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act (ITPA), 1956, & several state acts. Despite these efforts, sexual exploitation or abuse of females, including children, has continued to grow at an alarming rate. Official statistics & figures provided by the media are examined & compared, revealing that ITPA enforcement leaves much to be desired. Recent amendments to the ITPA have had little impact on the growing phenomenon of sexual exploitation. 4 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Personnel Management Function and Education in a Changing Environment

Author: Misra, Santrupt11 Dept Personnel Management & Industrial Relations Tata Instit Social Sciences, POB 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61624624?accountid=14925

Abstract: The changing environment for business & industrial organizations is discussed, addressing the globalization of business, rising domestic & international competition, decreasing time lag between a technical discovery & commercial use, & concern for more investment in human resources. Personnel management in India will encounter a new generation of workers with higher pre-employment education acquired from nontraditional sources; these employees will be more individualistic, questioning, & have a greater frame of reference, & may need to be integrated with union & organizational values. Implications for personnel management education include moving management education toward a mode that emphasizes skills more than functions. 20 References. V. Wagener

Trade Unionism: Problems for the Nineties

Author: Tulpule, Bagaram

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61636940?accountid=14925

Abstract: A successful aspect of the trade union movement in India has been its ability to protect & promote members' interests in the workplace; however, fragmentation of ideology, & more recently, problems of personality, caste, & region, have occurred. National leadership is unlikely to begin to attend to socioeconomic & basic class interests of workers because local leaders continue to focus on immediate demands & personal benefits. A plea is made for reversing the process, unifying the trade union movement, & making trade unions representative of workers in the broadest sense of the term. V. Wagener

National Housing Policy: A Critique

Author: Reddy, I U B11 Unit Urban Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, PO Box 8313 Deonar Bombay 400088 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61607289?accountid=14925

Abstract: The objectives, strategies, & land & finance conditions of India's first National Housing Policy, finalized Dec 1987, are summarized. Positive aspects of the policy include creation of institutional facilities for housing finance & loans with subsidy schemes; promotion of access to shelter for disadvantaged groups such as the poor, certain castes, bonded laborers, widows, & victims of natural calamities; & enabling urban slum dwellers & squatters to get title & learn how to maintain property. Lacunae are that the policy does not specify details & places the government as a facilitator instead of an active participant in providing housing. 8 References. V. Wagener

Perception of Organizational Commitment: Preliminary Findings and Scale Construction

Author: Sayeed, Omer Bin11 National Instit Training Industrial Engineering, Vihar Lake Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61519294?accountid=14925

Abstract: Open-ended questionnaire data obtained from 82 managers of various organizations in India were used to develop a scale measuring organizational commitment under unstructured & structured conditions, which was then administered to a second group of 204 managers. Results indicate that the longer an individual has been with an organization that has good fringe benefits, cordial management-subordinate relationships, & positive organizational policies, the greater is the level of commitment & period of attachment to the organization. The scale is found to have highly satisfactory item total correlations & alpha reliabilities; it is appended. 7 Tables, 1 Appendix, 8 References. Modified AA

Goal-Risk Behaviour of the Delinquents and Non-Delinquents: A Comparative Study

Author: Thilagaraj, R11 Dept Criminology U Madras, 600005 Tamil Nadu India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61236262?accountid=14925

Abstract: A comparative investigation of the psychological association between goal-oriented behavior & degree of risk for delinquents vs nondelinquents, viewing risk as perceived on the basis of previous success or failure experience. A variation of J. Rotter's "level of aspiration board" was used to measure goal-risk behavior among 180 delinquent & nondelinquent students ages 13-17 in Chengalput, India. Results revealed that both groups displayed similar risk behavior in a goal situation involving risk. In the well-adjusted Ss, while motivation to achieve high goals prevailed despite risk factors, a favorable or unfavorable experience affected subsequent risk behavior; the delinquents did not demonstrate a similar learning process, repeating risk tasks associated with failure experiences. 6 Tables, 1 Figure, 15 References. S. Millett

What the Poor Think about Their Poverty -- A Socio-Psychological Study

Author: Sharma, A K11 Dept Humanities & Social Sciences Indian Instit Technology, IIT PO Kanpur 208016 Uttar Pradesh

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61259797?accountid=14925

Abstract: Focusing on subjective & cognitive aspects of poverty, the goals of the impoverished, motivation to improve their condition, & development of locus of control are examined, based on both quantitative & qualitative fieldwork data, among poor & nonpoor residents (N = 506 & 79, respectively) of developed & developing villages in rural India. Lack of productive work for a largely landless population is the main cause of poverty in rural areas, creating food, clothing, & housing inadequacies. Nonpoor show little concern for the poor & their dissatisfaction with leadership to improve societal conditions. It is contended that while the rural poor are complacent regarding social change, they demonstrate an internal locus of control despite their dependency, & a unique & somewhat hopeful perception of their economic condition given government aid. 6 Tables, 10 References. S. Millett

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=What+the+Poor+Think+about+Their+Poverty+--+A+Socio-Psychological+Study&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1989-04-01&amp;volume=50&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=171&amp;author=Sharma%2C+A+K

http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=What+the+Poor+Think+about+Their+Poverty+--+A+Socio-Psychological+Study&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1989-04-01&amp;volume=50&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=171&amp;author=Sharma%2C+A+K

Ethnicity, Power and Discontent: The Problem of Identity Reconstruction in a Pluralist Society

Author: Mohan, Brij11 Louisiana State U, Baton Rouge 70803

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61262684?accountid=14925

Abstract: Research on the increasing immigration of Asians from the Indian subcontinent to the US is reviewed, focusing on patterns of ethnic relationships among the immigrants, obstacles to their success & adaptation, & identity crisis & other implications of their alienated status. Ethnic differentiation & inequalities promote stereotypes & prejudices that create obstacles to survival & success & negatively affect the development of an Indo-American identity. Despite barriers, Asian Indians generally comprise a productive, achievement-oriented community, with different internal classes based on religion, caste, economic status, language, & regional background. However, their own color & class consciousness in a racist (US) society create distrust & discontent. A cloutless minority in a culture of capitalism, they enjoy little influence in policy making & resource allocation. Despite the culturally inspired tolerance of the Indian character, evidence of increasing divorce, suicide, & homicide rates reveals stress at both the individual & family level, similar to that mirrored in US society generally. It is argued that identity reconstruction is a pragmatic ethnic process of adaptation & survival. 1 Table, 40 References. S. Millett

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Ethnicity%2C+Power+and+Discontent%3A+The+Problem+of+Identity+Reconstruction+in+a+Pluralist+Society&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1989-04-01&amp;volume=50&amp;issue=2&amp;spage=199&amp;author=Mohan%2C+Brij

Occupational Mobility in an Industrial-Urban Setting

Author: Dahiwale, S M11 Dept Sociology Shivaji U, Kolhapur 416004 Maharashtra India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61264400?accountid=14925

Abstract: The occupational mobility of self-employed Indians of scheduled castes in the industrial secular city of Kolhapur is analyzed, based on interviews with 200 respondents (Rs) in modern occupations & 30 in caste-based traditional occupations, eliciting data on sources of mobility, type of modern occupations adopted, & the effects on mobility of caste, religion, education, age, gender, & family background. The findings indicate that the subjective, motivational determinants of mobility for these Rs included encouragement by social networks, economic hardships, ideological impact, & educational qualifications. Objective factors included a government policy of protective discrimination toward depressed groups & the historical influences of city founder Shahu Chhatrapati & of Christian missionaries. 4 Tables, 3 References. Psychotherapy with Addicts

Author: Surati, Munira

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61573608?accountid=14925

Abstract: Data obtained in a questionnaire survey of 75 psychiatrists in 8 cities of India are used to examine psychotherapeutic approaches used in the treatment of drug addicts. The majority of respondents (Rs) supported an eclectic approach, combining behavioral therapy, reality therapy, & vocational counseling. Only 9 Rs utilized the psychoanalytic approach, while 21 used family therapy primarily. The specific ways that several therapies, eg, behavior therapy & group therapy, can be used to address the issue of drug addiction are described. Because of the length of time needed for treatment, psychoanalytic therapy requires a high level of motivation, which is difficult to achieve among drug addicts; behavior therapy is viewed as the brightest hope for treating addicts. 2 Tables, 16 References. Modified HA

Children of Single Parents in a Slum Community

Author: Bharat, Shalini11 Unit Family Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61572539?accountid=14925

Abstract: Children (N = 36) of single-parent families who live in a slum of a Bombay, India, suburb are compared with a sample of children (N = 31) from intact families, focusing on incidence of socioemotional, economic, & educational problems. Analysis of interview data indicates that children in single-parent families felt a sense of loss regarding the absent parent & often were more affected by the socioeconomic problems of their social class than were children of intact parents; eg, single parenthood may be somewhat associated with early child employment. Contrary to the findings in Western studies, however, the prevalence of juvenile delinquency, drug addiction, & other bad habits was found to be low. 1 Table, 14 References. Modified HA

Are the Poor Less Intelligent? Or Much Ado about Nothing

Author: Singh, Anup Kumar

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61037962?accountid=14925

Abstract: Various studies in India & other nations from the early 1950s to the present have shown that the verbal intelligence of students of lower socioeconomic status is correspondingly low. It is suggested that these low IQ scores do not necessarily imply an innate inferiority; rather, poorer groups are at a disadvantage when taking IQ tests. All children exhibit equal intelligence skills in their respective environments: testing lower class children by middle class norms produces low scores. Even if intelligence is genetic, there are chances for great improvement. 37 References. Modified HA

Urbanisation and Its Effect

Author: Tripathy, S K11 Consultancy Organisation OUAT, Bhubaneswar 751003 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/60995495?accountid=14925

Abstract: An examination of the effect of urbanization on the income & consumption patterns of tribal farmers in the Baripada Block of Mayurbhanj district of Orissa State, India. A survey methodology was utilized to: (1) determine the level of disposable income of small & marginal farmers & rural villages; (2) define the consumption pattern of categories of tribal farmers of specific village types; & (3) estimate the consumption function of categories of small farmers of urban & rural villages. Ss (N not specified) were defined as urban or rural by their geographic position, & as marginal or small by farm size. Findings show that marginal & small farmers of urban villages had a higher level of total disposable income as compared to farmers from rural villages. The level of total disposable income was higher in small farms as compared to marginal farms. The tribal farmers of higher income groups spent a higher % of the total disposable income on nonfood items as compared to lower income groups. The propensity for marginal consumption was higher in lower income groups. 8 Tables, 7 References. Modified HA

Links: http://up7af9tu5s.search.serialssolutions.com/?&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:&amp;atitle=Urbanisation+and+Its+Effect&amp;title=The+Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;issn=00195634&amp;date=1988-10-01&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=4&amp;spage=387&amp;author=Tripathy%2C+S+K

Urban Basic Services Scheme: A Strategy for Improving the Living Conditions of the Urban Poor -- An Evaluation

Author: Kumar, N Ashok1; Gnaneshwar, V1 Regional Centre Ur & Environmental Studies Osmania U, Hyderabad 500007 Andhra Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61554331?accountid=14925

Abstract: The Ur Basic Services (UBS) program was established to improve the living conditions of the Ur poor in India by inculcating community spirit & providing primary education, health, & vocational training services. Designed as a comprehensive & integrated scheme to avoid the sectoral approach that had been the downfall of previous schemes, UBS was launched by the Indian government in the seventh plan period, 1981-1983, with the involvement of UNICEF, the central government, the state & local governments, & voluntary community agencies. The program did not achieve the anticipated results in the first part of the period, for complex & multiple reasons. Suggested remedial measures include more participation by voluntary agencies & more clarity of needs, goals, & roles. Modified HA

Child Labour in India: Extent and Associated Factors

Author: Kanbargi, Ramesh11 Population Research Centre Instit Social & Economic Change, Bangalore 560072 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61578205?accountid=14925

Abstract: Child labor is blamed both for the persistent high fertility in the Third World & for the poor progress made in primary schooling. The extent of child labor & its correlates in India are examined by looking at available scattered data & some empirical investigations. Children suffer exploitation in the Ur LF & remain tied to traditional occupations in Ru areas. The occupations in which children are most often exploited are in the match & carpet-weaving industries & in chilli, cotton, & groundnut cultivation. Girls work longer hours than boys in all age groups. The adverse effect of early LF participation on schooling is clear from the studies reviewed. Modified HA

Female Population, Literacy and Employment -- Some Observations

Author: Rani, T Jyothi1; Rajaiah, B1 Kakatiya U, Vidyaranyapuri Warangal 500009 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61529396?accountid=14925

Abstract: Despite advancement in various aspects of social life, the F in India is viewed from birth as an economic liability. This has resulted in the widening gap between M & F population from 1901 to 1981. It is argued that the use of amniocentesis as a sex determination test & subsequent abortion of F fetuses will exacerbate the problem of the sex ratio. Data pertaining to literacy reveal the continuing educational gap between Ms & Fs. Low work participation by Fs in organized employment, coupled with employment primarily in poorly paid work, is responsible for the low SES of women. 6 Tables, 4 References. Modified HA

Knowledge of and Attitude towards the Legislation on Age at Marriage and Their Influence on Ideal Age at Marriage

Author: Audinarayana, N11 International Instit Population Sciences, Bombay India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61554256?accountid=14925

Abstract: Familiarity with & attitude toward the 1978 legislation raising the legal age of marriage to 18 for girls & 21 for boys were tested in a survey of residents of Ru India (N = 240 caste Hindus & 120 Harijans). Though knowledge of the legislation was not widespread, when informed, most Rs were in favor of the new minimum ages, as were those who already knew of the law. Caste Hindu Rs were more knowledgeable & more favorably inclined than the Harijans, who cling to the tradition of early age at marriage, especially for girls. 5 Tables, 7 References. Modified HA

Aged Females: The Most Deprived among the Deprived

Author: Sahayam, M Deva11 RUHSA Dept Christian Medical Coll & Hospital, North Arcot District Tamil Nadu India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61578138?accountid=14925

Abstract: Aged (55+) men's & women's numbers (sex ratio), economic participation, living arrangements, & SS were examined among a stratified random sample of 214 Indian households (total N = 1,002). The relatively low age minimum was chosen to take premature aging due to inadequate nutrition into account. Contrary to expectations, the number of aged Ms exceeded that of Fs in the sample. Aged Ms participated more in economic activities. Widowed Fs more often than Ms were left to fend for themselves in single-person households, demonstrating the differential treatment by adult children. 8 Tables, 4 References. Modified HA

Dowry-Related Violence towards Women -- Some Issues

Author: Prasad, B Devi1; Vijayalakshmi, B1 Dept Social Work Andhra U, Waltar 530003 Andhra Pradesh India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/60987262?accountid=14925

Abstract: In contemporary Indian society, persistent demands for dowry can lead to violent conduct by the in-laws toward the bride. A review of the literature shows that the victims of such dowry-related violence are usually young, of dependent status, & lack education. Gathering evidence about dowry-related crimes is difficult &, very frequently, the dying victim may herself save the guilty. Amendments to the Dowry Prohibition Act & the preventive legislation brought about by the central government, have not yet proven effective. Voluntary action is needed to prevent violence against women & to make the anti-dowry movement strong. 20 References. Modified HA

Bombay's Weaker Sections -- A Survey of Their Levels of Living

Author: Acharya, Sarthi11 Dept Ru Studies Tata Instit Social Sciences, Deonar Bombay 400088 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61563921?accountid=14925

Abstract: Data collected during a 1978 survey of 2,000 households (composed of slum settlement & pavement dwellers) are used to examine the nature of poverty in greater Bombay, India, with focus on migration, employment, housing, access to amenities, & the SE parameters of poverty. Results show that the majority of migrants in Bombay have come from other districts of Maharashtra rather than from other states, as commonly believed. Income levels in a caste-based distribution of the sample are described, along with factors responsible for entitlement to housing. Differences in access to amenities are identified as well as a "resource-sharing" phenomenon, whereby the hardships arising out of economic pressures are countered through sharing. 24 Tables, 1 Illustration, 17 References. Modified HA

Preparing for the 1991 Census of India

Author: Mahatme, Anand

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/60978638?accountid=14925

Abstract: In 1961 India transformed its census taking from a descriptive exercise to collecting population information for developmental planning purposes & began using modern methods. However, the methods introduced in 1961 should be evaluated carefully before they are used in 1991. The delay in getting the data to users in the 1981 census is noted, & some suggestions are made for enhancing the comparability of 1961-1981 data. Improvements are suggested in the areas of enumeration & administration, & it is argued that data users should be more involved in census planning. 1 Reference. A. Waters
