A Study of Dowry among Working and Non-Working Women

Author: Sandhu, M K11 Dept Sociology Panjab U, Chandigarh 160014 Union Territory India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/60969357?accountid=14925

Abstract: The practice of giving a dowry among middle class Indian families of working & nonworking women & its consequences are explored using data from interviews with 150 women working in selected government departments & 150 nonworking wives of men employed in the same departments. Results show that dowry was given in a majority of the women's marriages, regardless of work status, indicating that economic independence of women does not constitute a solution to the problem. Dowry was perceived to be a problem for the middle & lower middle classes, who are not well off financially & who seek to enhance their social status by marrying daughters into a higher stratum. Although respondents were disinclined to accept that dowry might have caused problems to their parents, they perceived it as a problem for society in general. 11 Tables, 12 References. Modified HA

Promiscuity and Family Pathology

Author: Ramasamy, P; Sabhesan, S; Jeyasingh, P; Bennett, Belinda

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61554600?accountid=14925

Abstract: To test the hypothesis that promiscuity is deeply ingrained in the personality of the individual & is a product of early life experiences, 30 promiscuous Ms aged 18-22 & a matched control group of 30 nonpromiscuous Ms were compared in terms of their family interactions. Data collected via in-home observations, interviews, & a family interaction scale indicate that the interactions within different subsystems are defective in the families of promiscuous Ms. The results are discussed in light of developmental theories. 2 Tables, 9 References. Vocational Restitution after Head Injury

Author: Sabhesan, S1; Arumugham, R; Ramasamy, P; Andal, G; Natarajan, M1 Government Rajaji Hospital, Madurai India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470159?accountid=14925

Abstract: Follow-up interview data are used to examine the occupational rehabilitation & resettlement of 75 head-injured M agriculturists admitted to the trauma ward of the Dept of Neurosurgery, Government Rajaji Hospital, Madurai, India. Though neurological deficits interfered with work restoration for only 2 patients, psychological sequelae, particularly cognitive/behavioral disturbances & disturbed interpersonal relations, were prevalent. Intrinsic factors -- eg, age, severity of damage, early neurological deficits, & alcohol abuse -- & extrinsic factors -- eg, financial status & family attitudes -- were found to significantly influence the work restoration. 3 Tables, 18 References. Dynamics of Atrocities on Scheduled Castes in Rural India

Author: Mohanty, Rabindra K11 Rajdhani Coll, Bhubaneshwar Orissa India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61602192?accountid=14925

Abstract: The nature & dynamics of atrocities committed against members of scheduled castes in Ru areas in India are examined, based on news reports, books, official reports, & previously published studies. Perceived Likelihood of Rape as an Operational Measure of Rape Victim's Causal Responsibility

Author: Kanekar, Suresh1; Shirgavi, Kamal1 Dept Applied Psychology U Bombay, Vidyanagari 400098 India

http://search.proquest.com.proxy.lib.wayne.edu/docview/61470333?accountid=14925

Abstract: Perceived likelihood of rape is examined as an operational measure of the causal responsibility attributed to a rape victim based on judgments of written case accounts of a rape incident by 240 U of Bombay (India) undergraduate students. The accounts varied in the physical attractiveness of the victim & the psychological & physical injuries inflicted. The dependent measures included the length of the recommended imprisonment for the rapist & the perceived likelihood of rape. Longer imprisonment was recommended for the rapist when the victim was physically hurt & emotionally disturbed; greater likelihood was perceived when the victim was attractive. These findings are discussed in the context of a proposed theoretical distinction between causal & moral responsibility. 1 Table, 16 References. Modified HA
